nodes.note: {{c1::Levothyroxine}} is a recombinant form of T4 that serves as a thyroxine replacement. It has agonist action at thyroid hormone receptors
{{c1::Aplasia cutis}} is a possible teratogenic complication of methimazole if given in the first trimester
{{c1::Agranulocytosis}} and {{c1::Aplastic}} Anemia are rare hematological complications of propylthiouracil and methimazole use

On which days following fertilization is the morula formed?

{{c1::3-4}}

On which days following fertilization does implantation occur?

{{c1::6-10}}

During which week of gestation does the primitive streak appear?

{{c1::3}}

What is the embryonic origin of the spinal cord?

{{c1::Neural tube (neuroectoderm)}}

What is the embryonic origin of the Alveoli, epithelium of trachea / bronchi?

{{c1::Endoderm}}

Which antacid is associated with hyporeflexia, hypotension and cardiac arrest if overused?

{{c1::Magnesium hydroxide}}

The {{c1::nucleus tractus solitarius}}, also known as the vomiting center (located in the medulla) receives main inputs from:
1. {{c2::GI tract}}
2. {{c2::Vestibular system}}
3. {{c2::Area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone)}}
The nucleus tractus solitarius projects neurons to other medullary nuclei to coordinate the {{c1::vomiting}} response
The vestibular system is responsible for {{c1::vertigo}} and motion sickness (vestibular nausea)
The {{c1::area postrema}} (chemoreceptor trigger zone) is located adjacent to the nucleus tractus solitarius in the {{c2::4th}} ventricle
The area postrema (chemoreceptor trigger zone) responds to {{c1::emetogenic}} substances (e.g. chemotherapeutic agents)
{{c2::Ondansetron}} antagonizes the {{c1::5-HT3}} receptor on vagal afferents in the GI tract
Ondansetron is used to treat {{c1::chemotherapy}} or {{c1::post-operative}} induced nausea and vomiting
Ondansetron may cause {{c1::constipation}} at the gut and {{c1::headache/dizziness}} at the head as possible side effects
Ondansetron may cause {{c1::serotonin syndrome}}, which presents with symptoms including rigidity, tremor, hyperthermia, and confusion
Diphenhydramine and meclizine (1st generation H1 receptor blockers) may cause significant {{c1::sedation}} and have significant anti-{{c2::muscarinic}} properties
The vestibular system contains {{c1::M1}} muscarinic receptors
{{c1::Scopolamine}} is a(n) {{c2::muscarinic (M1)}} antagonist that treats vestibular nausea (motion sickness)
Motion sickness (vestibular nausea) is treated with {{c1::1st generation anti-histamines (diphenhydramine, meclizine)}} and {{c1::scopolamine}}
{{c1::Metoclopramide}} antagonizes {{c2::D2}} receptors in the area postrema (treats chemotherapy induced vomiting)
Metoclopramide (D2 antagonist) is contraindicated in patients with {{c1::small bowel obstruction}}
Side effects of metoclopramide include extrapyramidal effects such as dystonia, akathisia, and {{c1::parkinsonian}} features as a result of central D2 blockade
Metoclopramide may cause elevated {{c1::prolactin}} levels, which can cause galactorrhea, impotence, gynecomastia, and menstrual disorders

Which anti-emetic(s) should be used to treat a patient with nausea/vomiting due to motion sickness?

{{c1::1. H1 receptor blockers, such as diphenhydramine and meclizine
2. M1 receptor blockers, such as scopolamine
}}
Histamine, from ECL cells, activates {{c1::H2}} receptors (coupled to {{c1::Gs}}) on the basolateral membrane of parietal cells
Vagal stimulation is a potent direct activator of parietal cells (H+ secretion) via binding of the neurotransmitter {{c1::ACh}} to {{c2::M3}} receptors

What drug class do cimetidine, ranitidine, famotidine, and nizatidine belong to?

{{c1::H2 receptor antagonists}}

By what mechanisms can H+ secretion still occur in a patient on H2 receptor blockers?

{{c1::Direct stimulation of parietal cells by vagal stimulation and gastrin stimulation}}
The H2 receptor antagonist {{c2::cimetidine}} is a potent {{c3::inhibitor}} of {{c1::cytochrome P-450}} and therefore has multiple drug interactions
The H2 receptor antagonist {{c2::cimetidine}} has many anti-{{c1::androgenic}} effects (e.g. gynecomastia, impotence, elevated prolactin levels)
Both cimetidine and ranitidine decrease renal excretion of {{c1::creatinine}}
{{c1::Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs)}} are effective at reducing both nocturnal and meal-stimulated secretion of acid and thus suppress H+ secretion to a greater extent than H2 receptor blockers

What is the first line treatment for a patient with Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome?

{{c1::Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs)}}
One adverse effect of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) is increased risk for {{c1::Clostridioides difficile}} infection (2-3x increased risk)
In addition to increased risk for C. difficile infection, patients on proton pump inhibitors are also at increased risk for {{c1::pneumonia}}
Proton pump inhibitors decrease the absorption of {{c1::divalent cations (Ca2+, Mg2+, and Fe2+)}}, which require an acidic environment
Reduced calcium absorption as a result of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) increases risk of worsening {{c1::osteoporosis (e.g. increased osteoporotic hip fractures)}}
Decreased magnesium absorption as a result of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) may cause {{c1::hypomagnesemia}}
When proton pump inhibitors are unable to control gastric acid secretion, {{c1::octreotide}} (a long acting somatostatin analog) may be of use in treating gastrinomas
{{c1::Osmotic}} laxatives are non-absorbable substances that draw water into the intestinal lumen, causing distention and peristalsis
Magnesium hydroxide and magnesium citrate are both examples of {{c1::osmotic}} laxatives
Polyethylene glycol (PEG) is a non-absorbable sugar that acts as a(n) {{c1::osmotic}} laxative
Lactulose is a non-absorbable sugar that acts as a(n) {{c1::osmotic}} laxative
In addition to its use as an osmotic laxative, {{c2::lactulose}} may be used in the treatment of {{c1::hepatic encephalopathy}}
Docusate is used medically as a(n) {{c1::stool softener}}
{{c1::Loperamide}} is a(n) {{c2::μ-opioid}} agonist that does not cross the BBB, therefore there is no analgesia and low potential for addiction

What GI side effect may be caused by opioid agonists?

{{c1::Constipation}}
VIPoma and carcinoid tumor both cause {{c1::secretory}} diarrhea
{{c1::Octreotide (a somatostatin analog)}} may be used to treat the secretory diarrhea caused by VIPoma and carcinoid syndrome
{{c1::Interferons}} are immunomodulatory {{c2::cytokines}} that are released from virus infected host cells
Interferon {{c2::alpha}} may be used in the treatment of hepatitis {{c1::B}} and {{c1::C}} infections
Interferon {{c1::β}} may be used to treat {{c2::multiple sclerosis}}
Ribavirin is a(n) {{c1::guanosine nucleoside}} analog
Ribavirin must be {{c1::phosphorylated three times::specific}} by intracellular enzymes to reach its activated nucleotide form
A major side effect of ribavirin is that it may cause {{c1::dose-dependent hemolytic anemia (10-20% of patients)}}
Ribavirin is contraindicated in {{c1::pregnant women}} due to its {{c1::teratogenic}} effects

In addition to hepatitis C, what other virus is ribavirin classically used to treat?

{{c1::respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)}}
{{c1::Sofosbuvir}} is a nucleotide analog that inhibits the HCV {{c3::NS5B}} {{c2::RNA-dependent RNA polymerase}}
Misoprostol is a synthetic analog of {{c1::PGE1}}
Misoprostol promotes increased production and secretion of a gastric {{c1::mucous}} barrier and decreased {{c1::acid}} production
{{c1::Misoprostol}} is a PGE1 analog that may be used to prevent NSAID-induced {{c2::peptic ulcers}}
Misoprostol promotes {{c1::uterine}} contraction and therefore may be used for induction of {{c1::labor (ripens cervix)}}
All steroid hormones are derivatives of {{c1::cholesterol}}

In the first step of the adenylyl cyclase and phospholipase C mechanism of signaling, binding of hormone to its receptor causes release of {{c1::GDP}} from its α subunit (αs, αi, or aq) and replacement by {{c1::GTP}}
In the adenylyl cyclase mechanism of cellular signaling, the {{c2::αs-GTP}} complex activates adenylyl cyclase, which then catalyzes the conversion of {{c1::ATP}} to {{c1::cAMP}}

In the adenylyl cyclase mechanism of cellular signaling, the second messenger {{c1::cAMP}} activates {{c2::protein kinase A}}, which then phosphorylates specific proteins to produce physiologic actions
After its use as a second messenger in the adenylyl cyclase signaling pathway, cAMP is degraded to {{c1::5-AMP}} by {{c2::phosphodiesterase}}
In the phospholipase C mechanism of cellular signaling, the {{c3::αq-GTP}} complex activates phospholipase C, which then catalyzes the liberation of {{c1::DAG}} and {{c1::IP3}} from {{c2::PIP2}}
In the phospholipase C mechanism of cellular signaling, the {{c2::IP3}} generated from PIP2 causes release of {{c1::Ca2+}} from intracellular stores in the endoplasmic or sarcoplasmic reticulum

In the phospholipase C mechanism of cellular signaling, {{c1::Ca2+}} and {{c1::diacylglycerol (DAG)}} activate {{c2::protein kinase C}}, which phosphorylates specific proteins to produce physiologic actions

What hormone acts through a receptor guanylyl cyclase?

{{c1::Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)}}
Binding of atrial natriuretic peptide to its receptor guanylyl cyclase causes conversion of {{c1::GTP}} to {{c1::cGMP}}
Newly synthesized cGMP (from guanylyl cyclase activity) activates {{c1::protein kinase G}}, which phosphorylates specific proteins responsible for physiologic actions

What hormone/chemical acts through a cytosolic guanylyl cyclase?

{{c1::Nitric Oxide}}
{{c1::NO synthase}} cleaves the amino acid {{c2::arginine}} into citrulline and nitric oxide
Once nitric oxide diffuses into muscle cells, it activates soluble (cytosolic) guanylyl cyclase, which converts {{c1::GTP}} to {{c1::cGMP}}

What is the difference between the binding sites of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and nitric oxide (NO) to guanylyl cyclase receptors?

{{c1::- ANP binds to a receptor guanylyl cyclase

- NO binds to a cytoplasmic guanylyl cyclase}}
{{c1::Receptor tyrosine kinases}} have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity within the receptor molecule
{{c1::Receptor-associated tyrosine kinases}} do not have intrinsic kinase activity, but rather associate non-covalently with proteins that do (e.g. JAK)
Receptor-associated tyrosine kinases are non-covalently associated with a tyrosine kinase, such as {{c1::JAK}}
Targets of JAK (tyrosine kinase associated-receptor pathway) include {{c1::STATs}}, which cause transcription of new mRNAs and new protein synthesis

What type of receptor do growth hormones use for their signaling pathways?

{{c1::Receptor associated tyrosine kinases}}

How do the receptors bound by steroid and thyroid hormones differ from the receptors bound by peptide hormones?

{{c1::Peptide hormones bind extracellular receptors}}
Once a steroid hormone has bound its receptor in the cytoplasm or nucleus, the hormone-receptor complex then {{c1::dimerizes}}
The pituitary gland, which also is called the {{c1::hypophysis}}, consists of an anterior and posterior lobe
The hypothalamus is connected to the pituitary gland by a thin stalk called the {{c1::infundibulum}}
The posterior lobe of the pituitary gland is derived from {{c1::neural}} tissue
The connections between the hypothalamus and the {{c1::posterior}} pituitary are neural only
The {{c2::posterior}} pituitary is a collection of nerve axons whose cell bodies are located in {{c1::hypothalamic nuclei}}
Hypothalamic-Pituitary Relationships Summary Picture: No answer {{c1:::)}}
The {{c1::anterior}} lobe of the pituitary gland is primarily composed of {{c2::endocrine}} cells
The hypothalamus and anterior pituitary are linked directly by the {{c1::hypothalamic-hypophysial portal}} system
Blood from the hypothalamus that contains high concentrations of hypothalamic hormones is delivered directly to the {{c1::anterior pituitary}}
Hypothalamic hormones stimulate or inhibit the release of {{c1::anterior pituitary}} hormones

How does the blood supply of the anterior pituitary differ from that of most other organs?

{{c1::Most of its blood supply is venous blood from the hypothalamus}}
The connections between the hypothalamus and {{c1::anterior}} pituitary are both neural and endocrine

Six major hormones are secreted by the anterior lobe of the pituitary:
{{c1::
1. FSH
2. LH
3. ACTH
4. TSH
5. Prolactin
6. Growth hormone
}}
The {{c1::α}} subunits of the anterior pituitary hormones TSH, FSH, hCG and LH are identical
The {{c1::β}} subunits of the anterior pituitary hormones TSH, FSH, and LH are different and are responsible for the unique biologic activity of each hormone

The placental hormone {{c1::human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)}} is structurally related to the TSH, FSH, and LH family
- It contains an identical alpha chain and unique beta chain
The {{c1::ACTH}} family of hormones is derived from a single precursor, {{c2::pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC)}}
Alpha-MSH and beta-MSH are produced in the {{c1::intermediate}} lobe of the pituitary gland, which is rudimentary in adult humans
{{c2::Melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH)}} is found in POMC and its fragments, thus, increased levels of POMC and ACTH may lead to {{c1::skin/mucosal pigmentation}} (e.g. Addison disease)
{{c1::Growth hormone}} is the single most important hormone for normal growth to adult size
Growth hormone is a single-chain polypeptide that is homologous with {{c1::prolactin}} and human placental lactogen
{{c2::Growth hormone}} is synthesized in the {{c1::somatotrophs::cell type}} of the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland
Growth hormone is released in a(n) {{c1::pulsatile}} pattern, with bursts of secretion occurring approximately every 2 hours
The largest secretory burst of growth hormone occurs within 1 hour of {{c1::falling asleep}}
At {{c1::puberty}}, there is an enormous secretory burst of growth hormone induced by estrogen (females) or testosterone (males)

What is the effect of hypoglycemia and starvation on growth hormone secretion?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the effect of sleep on growth hormone secretion?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the effect of obesity, pregnancy, and hyperglycemia on growth hormone secretion?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What is the effect of exercise and stress on growth hormone secretion?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the effect of somatostatin on growth hormone secretion?

{{c1::Decreased}}
The synthesis of growth hormone is stimulated by {{c1::growth-hormone releasing hormone (GHRH)}}, its hypothalamic-releasing hormone
The synthesis of growth hormone is inhibited by {{c1::somatostatin}}, its release-inhibiting hormone

Through which secondary messenger(s) does GHRH initiate its action on somatotrophs?

{{c1::Both cAMP (primarily) and IP3/Ca2+}}

How does GHRH affect its own secretion from the hypothalamus?

{{c1::Decreases (ultrashort-loop negative feedback)}}
{{c1::Somatomedins (IGFs)}} are produced, predominantly by the liver, when growth hormones act on target tissue

How do somatomedins affect the secretion of growth hormone from the anterior pituitary?

{{c1::Decrease, through both direct and indirect mechanisms}}

How does growth hormone affect its own secretion from the anterior pituitary?

{{c1::Decreased, indirectly}}
Growth hormone inhibits its own secretion by stimulating the secretion of {{c1::somatostatin}} from the hypothalamus
In the liver, growth hormone generates the production of somatomedins, or {{c1::insulin-like growth factors (IGF)}}, which serve as the intermediaries of several physiologic actions
The insulin-like growth factor (IGF) receptor has {{c1::tyrosine kinase}} activity, similar to the insulin receptor
One direct action of growth hormone is {{c1::decreased}} glucose uptake into cells, producing a(n) {{c1::increase}} in glucose blood concentration

What direct action does growth hormone have on lipolysis?

{{c1::Increased}}

How does growth hormone affect protein synthesis and lean body mass?

{{c1::Increased}}

What direct action does growth hormone have on production of insulin-like growth factor (IGF)?

{{c1::Increased}}
Growth hormone/IGF-1 alters cartilage metabolism to increase {{c1::linear}} growth

Failure to grow, short stature, mild obesity, and delayed puberty is associated with what hormone deficiency?

{{c1::Growth hormone deficiency}}
Growth hormone excess is most often due to a(n) {{c1::growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma}}
{{c2::Before}} puberty, excessive levels of growth hormone cause {{c1::gigantism (increased linear growth)}}
{{c1::After}} puberty, excessive levels of growth hormone cause increased periosteal bone growth, increased organ size, glucose intolerance, and coarsening of facial features
Conditions with excess growth hormone may be treated with {{c1::somatostatin}} analogues such as {{c1::octreotide}}, which inhibit growth hormone secretion
The most important of the somatomedins is {{c1::somatomedin C}}, also known as {{c1::IGF-1}}

What is the embryonic origin of the anterior pituitary?

{{c1::Oral ectoderm, specifically from Rathkes pouch::very specific}}

What is the source of prolactin and growth hormone secretion?

{{c1::Anterior pituitary}}
Prolactin is the major hormone responsible for {{c1::milk production (lactogenesis)}} and also participates (with estrogen) in {{c1::breast development}}
Prolactin is structurally homologous to {{c1::growth hormone}}
Prolactin is synthesized by {{c1::lactotrophs}}, which represent approximately 15% of the tissue in the anterior pituitary
Prolactin secretion is {{c2::tonically inhibited}} by {{c1::dopamine}}
Prolactin secretion is stimulated via {{c1::thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH)}} from the hypothalamus

What effect does prolactin have on its own secretion?

{{c1::Decreased}}
{{c1::Breast-feeding}} and {{c1::pregnancy}} are the most important stimuli for prolactin secretion

What is the effect of bromocriptine (a dopamine agonist) on prolactin secretion?

{{c1::Decreased}}
{{c1::Prolactin}} stimulates milk production in the breast by inducing synthesis of milk components including casein and lactose
{{c1::Prolactin}} stimulates breast development in a supportive role with estrogen

What effect does prolactin have on ovulation and spermatogenesis?

{{c1::Decreased / Inhibition}}
Prolactin {{c2::inhibits}} ovulation and spermatogenesis by decreasing synthesis and release of {{c1::GnRH}}
Prolactin deficiency occurs with destruction of the {{c2::anterior pituitary}} and results in the failure to {{c1::lactate}} (females)
Destruction of the hypothalamus or interruption of the hypothalamic-hypophysial tract result in prolactin excess by causing loss of {{c1::tonic inhibition by dopamine}}
The major symptoms of prolactin excess are {{c1::galactorrhea}} and {{c2::infertility}}

Is libido increased or decreased in patients with excess prolactin?

{{c1::Decreased}}

How can prolactin excess be treated?

{{c1::Dopamine agonists (e.g. bromocriptine)}}

What two hormones are secreted by the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland?

{{c1::ADH and oxytocin}}
Both ADH and oxytocin are neuropeptides, synthesized in hypothalamic neurons and secreted from nerve terminals in the {{c1::posterior pituitary}}
{{c2::Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)}} and {{c1::oxytocin}} are homologous nonapeptides (9 AA)
En route to the posterior pituitary, ADH and oxytocin are packaged in secretory granules with their respective {{c1::neurophysins}}
{{c2::Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)}} is packaged with neurophysin {{c1::II}} and glycoprotein
{{c2::Oxytocin}} is packaged with neurophysin {{c1::I}}
The cell bodies of {{c1::ADH}}-secreting neurons originate primarily in the {{c2::supraoptic}} nuclei of the hypothalamus
The cell bodies of {{c1::oxytocin}}-secreting neurons (from the posterior pituitary) originate primarily in the {{c2::paraventricular}} nuclei of the hypothalamus
The most important physiologic stimulus for increasing antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion is {{c1::increased plasma osmolarity}}

What receptors sense an increase in plasma osmolarity, providing stimuli to increase ADH secretion?

{{c1::Osmoreceptors in the anterior hypothalamus::What and where?}}
Hypovolemia or volume {{c1::contraction}} is another potent stimulus for ADH secretion

What receptors sense a decrease in plasma volume, providing stimuli to increase ADH secretion?

{{c1::Baroreceptors}}

What is the effect on ADH secretion if a patient has low volume AND low osmolarity?

{{c1::Volume trumps osmolarity and ADH is secreted}}

What is the effect on ADH secretion if a patient has high volume AND high osmolarity?

{{c1::Volume trumps osmolarity and ADH is not secreted (or less is secreted as osmolarity increases)}}

What effect do pain, nausea, hypoglycemia, and opiates have on ADH secretion?

{{c1::Increased}}

What effect does alcohol, atrial natriuretic peptide, and α-adrenergic agonists have on ADH secretion?

{{c1::Decreased}}
The major action of ADH (vasopressin) is to increase {{c1::water permeability (and thus reabsorption)}} of the principal cells in the {{c2::late distal convoluted tubule}} and {{c2::collecting duct}}
The receptors for ADH on the principal cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct are {{c1::V2}} receptors

Through which secondary messenger(s) does the ADH-bound V2 receptor propagate its signal?

{{c1::cAMP}}

How does ADH increase H2O permeability of the principal cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct?

Increased {{c1::aquaporin 2 (AQP2)}} channels via increased {{c1::cAMP}}
In addition to its actions on serum osmolarity, ADH (vasopressin) may also cause {{c1::contraction of vascular smooth muscle (regulate blood pressure)}}
The receptor for ADH on vascular smooth muscle is a(n) {{c1::V1}} receptor

Through which secondary messenger(s) does the ADH-bound V1 receptor propagate its signal?

{{c1::IP3/Ca2+}}

What is the end result of ADH binding to V1 receptors on vascular smooth muscle?

{{c1::Contraction of vascular smooth muscle}}

Which receptor does antidiuretic hormone (vasopressin) bind to regulate serum osmolarity?

{{c1::V2 receptors}}

Which receptor does antidiuretic hormone bind to regulate blood pressure?

{{c1::V1 receptors}}
{{c2::Central}} diabetes insipidus is caused by failure of the posterior pituitary to secrete {{c1::ADH}}

Which ADH disorder is characterized by low levels of circulating ADH and thus large volumes of dilute urine?

{{c1::central diabetes insipidus (nephrogenic has high ADH levels)}}
Central diabetes insipidus is treated with a(n) {{c1::ADH}} analogue, such as {{c2::dDAVP (desmopressin)}}
In {{c1::nephrogenic diabetes insipidus}}, the principal cells of the collecting duct are unresponsive to {{c2::ADH}} due to a defect in the V2 receptor, Gs protein, or adenylyl cyclase

Which type of diabetes insipidus is characterized by an inability of the posterior pituitary to secrete ADH?

{{c1::Central diabetes insipidus}}

Which type of diabetes insipidus is characterized by a lack of response to the ADH secreted by the posterior pituitary?

{{c1::Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus}}

Which type of diabetes insipidus is characterized by elevated levels of ADH?

{{c1::Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus}}
Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is treated with {{c1::thiazide}} diuretics
In syndrome of {{c1::inappropriate ADH (SIADH)}}, excess ADH is secreted from an autonomous site

Which ADH disorder is characterized by high levels of circulating ADH and thus inappropriately concentrated urine?

{{c1::Syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH)}}
Syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH) may be treated with {{c1::water::first line treatment}} restriction, with {{c3::conivaptan/tolvaptan}}, or with a tetracycline such as {{c2::demeclocycline}}

What endocrine pathology is treated with demeclocycline?

{{c1::SIADH}}
{{c2::Oxytocin}} causes {{c1::ejection of milk}} from the breast when stimulated by suckling

What is the major stimulus for oxytocin secretion?

{{c1::Suckling of the breast}}

What conditioned responses may stimulate oxytocin secretion?

{{c1::Sight, sound, or smell of an infant}}
Oxytocin is secreted in response to {{c1::dilation of the cervix}} during labor or orgasm
Oxytocin causes contraction of {{c1::myoepithelial cells}} in the breast, forcing milk stored in the mammary alveoli into the ducts for ejection
Oxytocin causes powerful rhythmic contractions of {{c1::uterine smooth}} muscle
{{c1::Oxytocin}} is a hormone that may be used to induce {{c2::labor}} and reduce {{c3::postpartum bleeding}}
{{c1::Cretinism}} is a condition of severely stunted physical and mental growth due to untreated congenital deficiency of {{c2::thyroid}} hormones

Which thyroid hormone (T3 or T4) is more active?

{{c1::T3}}

What is the main thyroid hormone (T3 or T4) that is secreted?

{{c1::T4}}
Thyroid hormones are synthesized by the {{c1::follicular epithelial}} cells of the thyroid gland
In the first step of thyroid hormone synthesis, {{c1::thyroglobulin}} is synthesized from {{c2::tyrosine}} in the thyroid follicular cells
The glycoprotein thyroglobulin (TG) contains large quantities of the amino acid {{c1::tyrosine}}
Thyroglobulin synthesis (as part of thyroid hormone synthesis) occurs in the {{c1::RER}} and {{c1::Golgi apparatus}} of the thyroid follicular cells

How does iodine enter the follicular epithelial cell (as part of thyroid hormone synthesis)?

{{c1::Through Na+-I- cotransport, A.K.A the iodine pump}}
If there are low levels of iodine (I-), the activity of the Na+-I- cotransport {{c1::increases}}, and vice versa
Thiocyanate and perchlorate are competitive inhibitors of the {{c1::Na+-I- cotransport}} pump, thus interfering with the synthesis of thyroid hormones
Once I- has been pumped into the cell for thyroid hormone synthesis, it is {{c1::oxidized}} to I2 by the enzyme {{c2::thyroid peroxidase}} in the follicular cell membrane
Thyroid peroxidase and deiodinase may be inhibited by {{c1::propylthiouracil (PTU)}}, which is used therapeutically for the treatment of {{c2::hyperthyroidism}}
{{c1::5-Deiodinase}} is inhibited by glucocorticoids, β-blockers, and PTU
{{c1::Thyroperoxidase}} is inhibited by Methimazole and PTU
At the junction of the follicular cells and the follicular lumen, {{c1::tyrosine}} residues of thyroglobulin react with I2 to form {{c2::monoiodotyrosine (MIT)}} and {{c2::diiodotyrosine (DIT)}}
The {{c1::organification}} of I2 into thyroglobulin is mediated by the enzyme {{c2::thyroid peroxidase}}
High levels of {{c1::I-}} inhibit {{c2::organification}} of I2, and therefore inhibit synthesis of thyroid hormones ({{c3::Wolff-Chaikoff}} effect)
After organification of I2, coupling between {{c2::two molecules of DIT}} may combine to form {{c1::thyroxine (T4)}}
After organification of I2, coupling between {{c1::a molecule of MIT and a molecule of DIT}} may combine to form {{c2::triiodothyronine (T3)}}
After iodinated thyroglobulin is synthesized, it is stored in the follicular lumen as {{c1::colloid}} until the thyroid gland is stimulated to secrete thyroid hormones

Why is much more T4 produced compared to T3?

{{c1::The coupling reaction for T4 is much faster}}

What three steps does thyroid peroxidase catalyze during the synthesis of thyroid hormones?

{{c1::
1. Oxidation (I- to I2)
2. Organification (of I2 into MIT and DIT)
3. Coupling (of MIT and DIT into T3 and T4)
}}
When the thyroid gland is stimulated, iodinated thyroglobulin is {{c1::endocytosed}} into the follicular epithelial cells
After iodinated thyroglobulin is endocytosed into the follicular epithelial cells, {{c1::lysosomal proteases}} hydrolyze peptide bonds, releasing T4, T3, MIT, and DIT
After release from iodinated thyroglobulin, T4 and T3 enter the {{c1::systemic circulation}}
After release from iodinated thyroglobulin, MIT and DIT are {{c1::deiodinated}} by the enzyme {{c2::thyroid deiodinase}}, reproducing {{c3::I-}} and {{c3::tyrosine}}
The {{c1::tyrosine}} and {{c1::I-}} that is generated by deiodination of MIT and DIT is recycled and used for further thyroid hormone synthesis

A patient with thyroid deiodinase deficiency would mimic which mineral deficiency?

{{c1::Iodine deficiency, due to inability recycle iodine}}
In the circulation, most of the T3 and T4 is bound to {{c1::thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)}}
Once in target tissues, the enzyme {{c1::5-deiodinase}} converts {{c3::T4}} to {{c3::T3}} by removing one atom of I2; a certain portion is also converted to {{c2::reverse T3 (rT3)}} which is inactive

Which thyroid hormone (T4 or T3) binds to nuclear receptor with greater affinity?

{{c1::T3}}
Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) is secreted by the {{c1::paraventricular}} nuclei of the hypothalamus
{{c3::Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH)}} acts on thyrotrophs of the anterior pituitary to stimulate the secretion of {{c2::thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)}}

How does free T3 cause decreased secretion of thyroid stimulating hormone?

{{c1::Down-regulating the TRH receptors on the thyrotrophs of the anterior pituitary}}

Through which secondary messenger(s) does TSH exert its actions on the thyroid gland?

{{c1::cAMP}}
One role of TSH on the thyroid gland is to increase both {{c1::synthesis}} and {{c1::secretion}} of thyroid hormones by the follicular cells
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) has a trophic effect on the thyroid gland, thus, chronic elevation of TSH causes {{c2::hypertrophy/hyperplasia}} of the thyroid gland
In addition to TSH, the TSH receptor on thyroid glands may be activated by {{c1::Thyrotropin receptor antibodies (TRAb)}} (Graves disease)

What effect does increased TBG levels have on thyroid hormone secretion?

{{c1::Increases secretion}}

What effect does excessive I- intake have on thyroid hormone secretion?

{{c1::Decreases secretion (Wolff-Chaikoff effect)}}

What effect does I- deficiency have on thyroid hormone secretion?

{{c1::Decreases secretion}}
Once T3 is produced inside its target cell, it enters the {{c1::nucleus}} and binds to a(n) {{c1::nuclear}} receptor
After T3 binds its nuclear receptor, the T3-receptor complex binds to a thyroid-regulatory element on DNA, where it stimulates {{c1::DNA transcription}}
One major effect of thyroid hormone is increased {{c1::O2 consumption}} with a resultant increase in {{c2::BMR}} and {{c2::body temperature}}, due to increased {{c3::Na/K+-ATPase}} activity
Thyroid hormones increase oxygen consumption in all tissues EXCEPT the {{c1::brain}}, {{c1::gonads}}, and {{c1::spleen}}

How do thyroid hormones cause an increase in oxygen consumption?

{{c1::Via increased synthesis and activity of the Na+-K+-ATPase pump}}
Thyroid hormone increases the processes of {{c1::glycogenolysis}}, {{c1::gluconeogenesis}}, {{c2::proteolysis}}, and {{c2::lipolysis}}, all of which may provide sources of ATP
Thyroid hormone increases {{c1::glucose}} absorption from the GI tract to meet the metabolic demands of increased O2 consumption
While thyroid hormone increases both protein synthesis and degradation, the overall effect of thyroid hormone is {{c1::catabolic}}

What is the effect of thyroid hormone on the cardiovascular and respiratory systems?

{{c1::Increased activity}}
Thyroid hormones increase cardiac output by inducing synthesis (upregulation) of {{c1::β1-adrenergic}} receptors in the heart
The increase in {{c2::cardiac output}} due to thyroid hormone is the result of a combination of increased heart rate and increased stroke volume (contractility)
One potential complication of excess thyroid hormone is high output {{c1::heart failure}}
Thyroid hormone works synergistically with growth hormone and somatomedins to promote {{c1::bone formation}}
Thyroid hormones stimulate bone {{c1::maturation}} as a result of ossification and fusion of the growth plates
In the {{c2::perinatal}} period, thyroid hormone is essential for {{c1::CNS maturation}}
Hypothyroidism in the perinatal period causes irreversible {{c1::mental retardation (cretinism)}}

Which thyroid disorder causes hyperexcitability, hyperreflexia, and irritability in adulthood?

{{c1::Hyperthyroidism}}
A useful adjunct therapy for hyperthyroidism is a(n) {{c1::β-adrenergic}} blocking agent, such as {{c2::propranolol}}
Actions of Thyroid Hormone Summary: No answer {{c1:::)}}
The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is {{c1::Graves disease}}

In what cases may the levels of TSH be increased during hyperthyroidism?

{{c1::When the disorder is in the hypothalamus or anterior pituitary (i.e. excessive TRH or TSH secretion)}}
Hyperthyroidism may be treated surgically via {{c1::thyroidectomy}} or with the drug {{c1::propylthiouracil (PTU)}}, which inhibits both thyroid peroxidase and deiodinase

In which disorder (hyper- or hypothyroidism) may a patient present with a goiter?

{{c1::Both!}}
The most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine replete countries is {{c1::autoimmune or Hashimoto thyroiditis}}

What are the levels of TSH in hypothyroidism due to thyroiditis or I- deficiency? Why?

{{c1::Increased due to negative feedback from decreased level of free T3}}

In what cases may the levels of TSH be decreased during hypothyroidism?

{{c1::When the disorder is in the hypothalamus or anterior pituitary (i.e. insufficient TRH or TSH secretion)}}
Hypothyroidism may be treated with {{c1::thyroid hormone replacement therapy (e.g. levothyroxine, triiodothyronine)}}
Hyperthyroidism vs Hypothyroidism Summary Table: no answer {{c1:::)}}
The adrenal medulla is in the {{c1::inner}} zone of the adrenal gland and composes approximately 20% of the glandular tissue
The adrenal medulla is of {{c1::neural crest}} origin
The adrenal medulla is responsible for the secretion of the catecholamines {{c1::norepinephrine}} and {{c1::epinephrine}}
The adrenal cortex is in the {{c1::outer}} zone of the adrenal gland and composes approximately 80% of the glandular tissue

The adrenal cortex has three layers:
1. Zona {{c1::reticularis}} (the innermost zone)
2. Zona {{c1::fasciculata}} (middle, widest zone)
3. Zona {{c1::glomerulosa}} (outermost zone)
The zona {{c2::glomerulosa}} secretes {{c1::mineralocorticoids}}, such as {{c1::aldosterone}}
The zona {{c1::fasciculata}} secretes {{c2::glucocorticoids}}, such as {{c2::cortisol}}
The zona {{c2::reticularis}} secretes {{c1::androgens}}, such as dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and androstenedione

What is the rate-limiting enzyme in the biosynthesis of adrenocortical hormones?

{{c1::Cholesterol desmolase}}
The major glucocorticoid produced in humans is {{c1::cortisol (hydrocortisone)}}
The major mineralocorticoid produced in humans is {{c1::aldosterone}}
The first step in all pathways of adrenocortical hormone synthesis is the conversion of {{c1::cholesterol}} to {{c1::pregnenolone}} by the enzyme {{c2::cholesterol desmolase}}
Pregnenolone may be converted to {{c1::progesterone}} via the enzyme {{c2::3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase}}
Progesterone may be converted to {{c1::11-deoxycorticosterone (DOC)}} via the enzyme {{c2::21β-hydroxylase}}
11-deoxycorticosterone (DOC) may be converted to {{c1::corticosterone}} via the enzyme {{c2::11β-hydroxylase}}
Corticosterone may be converted to {{c1::aldosterone}} via the enzyme {{c2::aldosterone synthase}}
Pregnenolone may be converted to {{c1::17-hydroxypregnenolone}} via the enzyme {{c2::17α-hydroxylase}}
Progesterone may be converted to {{c1::17-hydroxyprogesterone}} via the enzyme {{c2::17α-hydroxylase}}
17-hydroxypregnenolone may be converted to {{c1::17-hydroxyprogesterone}} via the enzyme {{c2::3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase}}
17-hydroxyprogesterone may be converted to {{c1::11-deoxycortisol}} via the enzyme {{c2::21β-hydroxylase}}
11-deoxycortisol may be converted to {{c1::cortisol}} via the enzyme {{c2::11β-hydroxylase}}
17-hydroxypregnenolone may be converted to {{c1::dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA)}} via the enzyme {{c2::17,20-lyase}}
17-hydroxyprogesterone may be converted to {{c1::androstenedione}} via the enzyme {{c2::17,20-lyase}}
Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) may be converted to {{c1::androstenedione}} via the enzyme {{c2::3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase}}
Adrenal {{c1::androgens}}, such as DHEA and androstenedione, have a(n) {{c2::ketone}} group at C-17 and are excreted as {{c3::17-ketosteroids}} in the {{c4::urine}}
{{c1::Ketoconazole}} is a drug that inhibits glucocorticoid biosynthesis via inhibition of the enzyme {{c2::cholesterol desmolase}}
Glucocorticoid (cortisol) secretion is {{c1::pulsatile}} and {{c1::diurnal}} (daily) in nature, oscillating with a circadian rhythm
Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) is secreted by cells of the {{c1::paraventricular}} nuclei of the hypothalamus

Through which secondary messenger(s) does CRH exert its actions on the anterior pituitary?

{{c1::cAMP}}
Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) binds to corticotrophs on the anterior pituitary, directing them to synthesize {{c2::POMC}} and secrete {{c2::ACTH}}
ACTH increases steroid hormone synthesis via stimulation of the enzyme {{c1::cholesterol desmolase}}, thus increasing the conversion of cholesterol to pregnenolone
Chronically elevated levels of ACTH cause {{c1::hypertrophy/hyperplasia}} of the adrenal cortex

Through which secondary messenger(s) does ACTH exert its actions on the adrenal cortex?

{{c1::cAMP}}
Chronic excess levels of cortisol (glucocorticoid) result in decreased levels of {{c1::CRH}} and {{c1::ACTH}} via negative feedback
{{c2::Dexamethasone}} is a synthetic {{c1::glucocorticoid}} that mimics the actions of cortisol, including suppression of ACTH
The {{c1::dexamethasone}} suppression test is useful in patients with {{c2::hypercortisolism}}

What is the result of the dexamethasone suppression test in a normal patient?

{{c1::Low-dose dexamethasone inhibits ACTH secretion and consequently cortisol secretion}}

What is the result of a dexamethasone suppression test if the cause of hypercortisolism is an ACTH-secreting tumor of the anterior pituitary?

{{c1::LOW dose of dexamethasone does not suppress cortisol secretion, but HIGH dose does}}

What is the result of a dexamethasone suppression test if the cause of hypercortisolism is an adrenal cortical tumor?

{{c1::Neither low nor high dose dexamethasone suppresses cortisol secretion}}
{{c1::Aldosterone}} secretion (from the zona glomerulosa) is under tonic, but not exclusive, control by ACTH
The primary regulation of aldosterone secretion occurs through changes in {{c1::ECF volume}} (via the {{c2::renin-angiotensin II-aldosterone}} system) and changes in serum {{c1::potassium}} levels
Decreases in {{c2::ECF volume}} (e.g. hemorrhage or decreased Na+) cause a decrease in renal perfusion pressure, which in turn increases secretion of the enzyme {{c1::renin}}
{{c1::Renin}} is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of {{c2::angiotensinogen}} to {{c2::angiotensin I}} in the plasma
{{c2::Angiotensin I}} is converted to {{c2::angiotensin II}} by the enzyme {{c1::angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)}}
{{c1::Angiotensin II}} acts on the zona glomerulosa to stimulate aldosterone synthesis via increased activity of the enzyme {{c2::aldosterone synthase}}
{{c1::Aldosterone}} is a hormone that increases renal Na+ reabsorption, thereby restoring ECF volume and blood volume to normal

To what receptor does angiotensin II bind?

{{c1::AT1 receptor}}

Through which secondary messenger(s) does the angiotensin II-bound AT1 receptor propagate its signal?

{{c1::IP3/Ca2+}}

How does hyperkalemia influence aldosterone secretion?

{{c1::Increased aldosterone secretion}}
Glucocorticoids increase {{c1::protein catabolism (proteolysis)}} in muscle and decrease protein synthesis, thereby providing more amino acids to the liver for gluconeogenesis
Glucocorticoids {{c1::decrease}} glucose utilization by tissues and {{c1::decrease}} insulin sensitivity of adipose tissue

Do glucocorticoids increase or decrease insulin resistance?

{{c1::Increase (by decreasing insulin sensitivity of adipose tissue)}}
Glucocorticoids increase peripheral {{c1::lipolysis}}, which provides more glycerol to the liver for gluconeogenesis
Glucocorticoids are a potent stimulator for {{c1::gluconeogenesis}}, thus they are essential for survival during {{c2::fasting}}
In hypocortisolism, there is decreased {{c1::gluconeogenesis}} and thus hypoglycemia, and vice versa
Glucocorticoids may have anti-inflammatory effects by inducing the synthesis of {{c1::lipocortin}}, an inhibitor of {{c2::phospholipase A2}}
Glucocorticoids may have anti-inflammatory effects by inhibiting the production of {{c1::interleukin-2 (IL-2)}} and thus inhibiting the proliferation of {{c2::T lymphocytes}}
Glucocorticoids may have anti-inflammatory effects via the inhibition of the release of {{c1::histamine}} and {{c1::serotonin}} from mast cells and platelets

What is the effect of glucocorticoids on blood neutrophil levels?

{{c1::Increased (neutrophilia) due to decreased WBC adhesion}}

Do glucocorticoids cause an increase or decrease in eosinophils?

{{c1::Decrease}}

How do glucocorticoids suppress the immune response?

{{c1::By inhibiting production of IL-2 and subsequent T-cell proliferation}}
Cortisol (glucocorticoids) up-regulates {{c1::α1}} receptors on arterioles, increasing their sensitivity to {{c2::catecholamines (i.e. norepinephrine and epinephrine)}}

What is the effect of hypocortisolism on blood pressure?

{{c1::Decreased (hypotension)}}
Glucocorticoids decrease {{c2::bone formation}} by decreasing {{c1::osteoblast}} activity
Cortisol travels in the blood bound to {{c1::corticosteroid-binding globulin (CBG)}}

Mineralocorticoids (aldosterone) cause increased renal {{c1::Na+}}
reabsorption via action on the {{c2::principal}} cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct

Mineralocorticoids (aldosterone) cause increased renal {{c1::K+}}
secretion via action on the {{c2::principal}} cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct
Mineralocorticoids (aldosterone) cause increased renal {{c1::H+}} secretion via action on the {{c2::α-intercalated}} cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct
{{c2::Addison}} disease is most commonly caused by {{c1::autoimmune destruction}} of all three zones of the adrenal cortex, which causes acute adrenal crisis
One clinical feature of Addison disease is {{c1::hyperkalemia::K+ levels}}

What classes of steroid hormones are decreased in secondary adrenocortical insufficiency?

{{c1::Glucocorticoids +/- androgens}}

What is the level of ACTH in secondary adrenocortical insufficiency? Why?

{{c1::Decreased; the disease is a result of decreased ACTH secretion}}

How do blood sugar levels change in secondary adrenocortical deficiency?

{{c1::Decreased (hypoglycemia)}}

Does secondary adrenocortical insufficiency present with hyperpigmentation? Why?

{{c1::No, ACTH levels are low therefore there is no increased melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH)}}

{{c1::Cushing}} syndrome is the result of chronic excess glucocorticoids by:

1. Adrenal gland hyperplasia
2. {{c2::Pharmacologic doses of glucocorticoids}} (most common)
3. ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease)
4. Ectopic ACTH production (e.g. small cell lung carcinoma)
Cushing {{c1::disease}} is the result of chronic excess glucocorticoids caused by {{c2::hypersecretion of ACTH from a pituitary adenoma}}

What classes of steroid hormones are increased in Cushing syndrome/disease?

{{c1::Glucocorticoids (cortisol) +/- androgens}}

What is the level of ACTH in Cushing disease? Why?

{{c1::Increased because the disease is caused by an ACTH-secreting tumor}}

What would the result of a dexamethasone suppression test be in a patient with Cushing disease?

{{c1::Cortisol response WOULD BE suppressed by high dose dexamethasone}}

What is a possible treatment for Cushing syndrome?

{{c1::Ketoconazole}} or {{c1::metyrapone}}, which block steroid hormone biosynthesis

What is the treatment for Cushing disease?

{{c1::Removal of the ACTH-secreting tumor}}
Conn syndrome presents with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis due to {{c1::increased}} aldosterone levels
Treatment of Conn syndrome consists of administration of a(n) {{c1::aldosterone}} antagonist, such as {{c2::spironolactone}}, followed by removal of the aldosterone-secreting tumor

What classes of steroid hormones are decreased in 21β-hydroxylase deficiency?

{{c1::Glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids::2}}
{{c1::21β-hydroxylase}} deficiency is the most common cause of congenital adrenal hyperplasia

What is the level of ACTH in 21β-hydroxylase deficiency? Why?

{{c1::Increased, due to decreased feedback inhibition from cortisol}}

What clinical features are seen in 21β-hydroxylase deficiency that are a result of increased androgen levels in females?

{{c1::Masculinization (clitoral enlargement, early appearance of pubic/axillary hair)}}

What classes of steroid hormones are decreased in 17α-hydroxylase deficiency?

{{c1::Glucocorticoids and androgens::2}}

What clinical features are seen in 17α-hydroxylase deficiency that are a result of decreased androgen levels in females?

{{c1::Lack of sexual development; e.g. lack pubic and axillary hair}}

What is the level of aldosterone in 17α-hydroxylase deficiency?

{{c1::Decreased!}}

Which adrenal cortex deficiency results in shunting towards the aldosterone synthesis pathway?

{{c1::17α-hydroxylase deficiency}}

Which adrenal cortex deficiency results in shunting towards the androgen synthesis pathway?

{{c1::21β-hydroxylase deficiency}}
The endocrine cells of the pancreas are arranged in clusters called the {{c1::islets of Langerhans}}, which compose 1% to 2% of the pancreatic mass
The {{c2::alpha}} cells of the islets of Langerhans compose 20% of the islet and secrete {{c1::glucagon}}
The {{c2::β}} cells of the islets of Langerhans compose 65% of the islet and secrete {{c1::insulin}}
The {{c2::delta}} cells of the islets of Langerhans compose 10% of the islet and secrete {{c1::somatostatin}}
The remaining cells (non-alpha, beta, delta) of the islets of Langerhans secrete {{c1::pancreatic polypeptide}} or other peptides
{{c1::Gap junctions}} in the islets of Langerhan link β-cells to each other, α-cells to each other, and β-cells to α-cells, allowing for rapid communication
The portal blood supply of the islets of Langerhans allow blood from the {{c1::beta}} cells to bathe the {{c1::alpha}} and {{c1::delta}} cells, further promoting rapid communication
The {{c2::central core}} of the islet of Langerhans contains mostly {{c1::beta}} cells
The {{c2::outer rim}} of the islet of Langerhans contains mostly {{c1::alpha}} cells

What is location of the delta cells in the islet of Langerhans?

{{c1::Interspersed between alpha and beta cells}}
Insulin is a peptide hormone consisting of two straight chains, a(n) {{c1::A}} chain (21 AA) and a(n) {{c1::B}} chain (30 AA), connected by two {{c2::disulfide bridges}}
mRNA directs ribosomal synthesis of {{c1::preproinsulin}}, which contains a signal peptide, the A and B chains of insulin, and a connecting peptide (insulin synthesis)
The {{c1::signal peptide}} of preproinsulin is cleaved while the peptide chains are being assembled, yielding {{c2::proinsulin}}
Proinsulin is packaged in secretory granules in the {{c1::Golgi apparatus}}
While being packed into secretory granules, proteases cleave the {{c1::connecting peptide}} of proinsulin, yielding {{c1::insulin}}
Insulin is packaged in secretory granules of the Golgi apparatus with {{c1::C peptide}}
When the β cell is stimulated, exocytosis of insulin and C peptide are released in {{c1::equimolar}} quantities

What peptide is packaged with insulin and may be used to monitor β cell function in patients receiving exogenous insulin?

{{c1::C peptide (connecting peptide)}}

What may cause increased levels of both insulin and C-peptide?

{{c1::Insulinoma, sulfonylurea drugs::2}}
{{c1::Glucose}} is the major regulator of insulin release
Transport of glucose from blood into the pancreatic β-cell occurs via a(n) {{c1::GLUT2}} transporter
Once inside the pancreatic β-cell, glucose is {{c1::phosphorylated}} by the enzyme {{c2::glucokinase}}
In the pancreatic β cell, metabolism of glucose generates {{c1::ATP}}, which may cause closure of select K+ channels with consequent membrane depolarization
Increased ATP:ADP ratio in the pancreatic β cell (as a result of glucose metabolism) causes ATP-sensitive {{c1::K+}} channels to {{c2::close}}, causing membrane {{c2::depolarization}}
Depolarization of the pancreatic β cell causes voltage-sensitive {{c1::Ca2+}} channels to {{c2::open}}, causing a(n) {{c2::increase}} in intracellular {{c1::Ca2+}}
Increased intracellular Ca2+ in the pancreatic β-cell causes {{c1::exocytosis}} of insulin-containing granules

What class of drugs acts by closing K+ channels in pancreatic β cells, causing increased insulin secretion?

{{c1::Sulfonylurea drugs (e.g. tolbutamide, glyburide)}}

Why is oral glucose a more powerful stimulant of insulin secretion than IV glucose?

{{c1::Oral glucose stimulates secretion of GIP and GLP-1}}

How do sulfonylurea drugs (e.g. tolbutamide, glyburde) cause an increased insulin secretion?

{{c1::By closing the ATP-dependent K+ channels, causing depolarization and subsequent insulin release}}

What effect does somatostatin have on insulin secretion?

{{c1::Decreased}}
The insulin receptor is a tetramer consisting of two {{c1::α}} subunits and two {{c1::β}} subunits
The {{c1::alpha}} subunits of the insulin receptor are connected by a disulfide bond and lie in the extracellular domain
The {{c1::β}} subunits of the insulin receptor are connected to the alpha subunit by a disulfide bond and span the cell membrane
The β subunits of the insulin receptor have {{c1::intrinsic tyrosine kinase}} activity
When insulin binds to its receptor, {{c1::tyrosine kinase}} is activated and autophosphorylates the β-subunits

What are the three locations that insulin acts on?

{{c1::Liver, muscle, and adipose tissue}}
Insulin increases glucose transport to {{c1::muscle}} and {{c1::adipose}} tissue by directing the insertion of the {{c2::GLUT4}} transporter into the cell membranes
Insulin decreases blood glucose concentration by promoting synthesis and storage of {{c1::glycogen}} in the {{c2::muscle}} and {{c2::liver}}, while simultaneously inhibiting {{c1::glycogenolysis}}
Insulin decreases blood glucose concentration by decreasing {{c1::gluconeogenesis}} via increased production of fructose-2,6-bisphosphate
In adipose tissue, insulin stimulates {{c1::fat deposition (increased triglyceride synthesis)}} and inhibits {{c1::lipolysis}}
Insulin stimulates amino acid uptake into cells and {{c1::increases}} protein synthesis in muscles
Insulin results in {{c1::increased}} K+ uptake into cells

What is the effect of insulin on blood K+ and amino acid concentration?

{{c1::Decreased (due to increased uptake into cells)}}

What is the effect of insulin on Na+ retention in the kidneys?

{{c1::Increased retention}}

Does glucose cross the placenta? What about insulin?

{{c1::Glucose does; insulin does not}}

What is the cause of metabolic acidosis in a patient with diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::Increased production of ketoacids}}

What is the blood concentration of K+ in a patient with diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::Increased (hyperkalemia) due to decreased K+ uptake into cells}}
{{c1::Glucagon}}, an endocrine hormone, is a member of a family of peptides that includes the GI hormones secretin and GIP
Glucagon acts on the {{c1::liver}} (primarily) and {{c1::adipose}} tissue
The major factor that stimulates glucagon secretion is {{c1::hypoglycemia}}

What is the effect of insulin on glucagon secretion?

{{c1::Decreased}}

Through which secondary messenger(s) does glucagon exert its actions on liver and adipose tissue?

{{c1::cAMP}}
Glucagon increases blood glucose concentration by increasing {{c1::glycogenolysis}}, while simultaneously inhibiting {{c1::glycogen}} formation from glucose
Glucagon increases blood glucose concentration by increasing {{c1::gluconeogenesis}} via decreased production of fructose-2,6-bisphosphate
Glucagon causes {{c1::decreased}} fatty acid synthesis and {{c1::increased}} lipolysis, which shunts substrates towards gluconeogenesis

What is the effect of somatostatin on insulin and glucagon secretion?

{{c1::Decreased}}

Hyperreflexia, spontaneous twitching, muscle cramping, tingling, and numbness are signs of which calcium imbalance?

{{c1::Hypocalcemia}}
The {{c3::Chvostek}} sign is {{c2::twitching of the facial muscles}} elicited by tapping on the facial nerve; it is an indicator of {{c1::hypocalcemia}}
The {{c3::Trousseau}} sign is {{c1::carpopedal spasm}} upon inflation of a blood pressure cuff; it is an indicator of {{c2::hypocalcemia}}

Why does hypocalcemia cause symptoms such as tingling/numbness and twitching/cramping?

{{c1::Decreased extracellular Ca2+ decreases the threshold potential (makes it more negative)}}

Constipation, polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy, and hyporeflexia are signs of which calcium imbalance?

{{c1::Hypercalcemia}}

What is the effect of acidemia on free ionized Ca2+ concentration?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the effect of alkalemia on free ionized Ca2+ concentration?

{{c1::Decreased}}

Which three hormones are involved in Ca2+ homeostasis?

{{c1::Parathyroid hormone, calcitonin, and vitamin D (1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol)}}
Parathyroid hormone is synthesized and secreted by the {{c1::chief}} cells of the parathyroid glands
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion is regulated by plasma {{c1::Ca2+}} concentration
When plasma Ca2+ concentrations {{c1::decrease}}, parathyroid hormone secretion is {{c2::increased}} (and vice versa)
Secretion of PTH is controlled by extracellular (serum) Ca2+ binding to {{c1::Ca2+-sensing}} receptors in the parathyroid cell membrane
Chronic hypocalcemia causes secondary {{c1::hyperparathyroidism}}, which is characterized by increased synthesis and storage of PTH and hyperplasia of the parathyroid glands
{{c2::Mild decreases}} in serum Mg2+ concentration cause {{c1::increased}} PTH secretion
{{c2::Severe decreases}} in serum Mg2+ concentration cause {{c1::decreased}} PTH secretion

What is the effect of increased serum PO43- on PTH secretion?

{{c1::Increased}}
The actions of PTH are coordinated to produce an increase in serum {{c1::Ca2+}} and a decrease in serum {{c1::phosphate (PO43-)}}

Through what secondary messenger(s) does PTH exert its actions on bone and kidney tissue?

{{c1::cAMP}}
In bone, PTH receptors are located on {{c1::osteoblasts}}, but not on {{c1::osteoclasts}}
Initially and transiently, PTH causes an increase in bone {{c1::formation}} by a direct action on {{c1::osteoblasts}}
In bone, the long-term effect of PTH is bone {{c1::resorption}} via indirect action on {{c1::osteoclasts}}
The action of PTH on osteoclasts is indirect and mediated by cytokines released from {{c1::osteoblasts}}
The overall effect of PTH on bone is to promote bone {{c1::resorption}}, which delivers both {{c2::Ca2+}} and {{c2::phosphate}} to extracellular fluid
PTH acts on the kidney to inhibit renal {{c1::phosphate}} reabsorption in the {{c2::proximal convoluted tubule}}, which therefore increases phosphate excretion
The cAMP generated as a result of the action of PTH on the proximal tubule is excreted in the {{c1::urine (urinary cAMP)}}
PTH acts on the kidney to increase renal {{c1::calcium}} reabsorption in the {{c2::distal convoluted tubule}}
PTH stimulates the renal enzyme {{c1::1α-hydroxylase}}, which converts 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to the active form, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (vitamin D)

How does PTH increase intestinal Ca2+ absorption?

{{c1::Indirectly, by stimulating production of 1,25-(OH)2D3 in the kidney}}
PTH Actions Summary Picture: no answer {{c1:::)}}
Primary hyperparathyroidism is most commonly caused by a(n) {{c1::parathyroid adenoma (which secretes excess PTH)}}
{{c1::Primary hyperparathyroidism}} is characterized by hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and increased circulating levels of PTH
Patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have {{c1::increased}} Ca2+ excretion due to the high filtered load of calcium on the kidney

What is a possible complication of increased Ca2+ in the urine (e.g. due to primary hyperparathyroidism)?

{{c1::Calcium-oxalate kidney stones}}
Patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have {{c1::increased}} urinary excretion of phosphate, calcium, and cAMP

Which parathyroid disorder is characterized by "stones, bones, groans, and psychiatric undertones"?

{{c1::Primary hyperparathyroidism}}

What is the treatment for a patient with primary hyperparathyroidism?

{{c1::Parathyroidectomy}}
In secondary hyperparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated secondary to {{c1::hypocalcemia (or hyperphosphatemia)}}
Hypoparathyroidism is most commonly a result of {{c1::thyroid surgery}}, or less commonly may be {{c3::autoimmune}} or {{c2::congenital}}
Hypoparathyroidism is characterized by decreased serum {{c1::calcium (hypocalcemia)}} and increased serum {{c1::phosphate (hyperphosphatemia)}}
Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a, or Albright hereditary osteodystrophy, is due to a defective {{c1::Gs}} protein in the kidney and bone, which causes end-organ resistance to {{c2::PTH}}
{{c1::Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a}} is characterized by hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia that is not correctable by administration of exogenous PTH

What is the difference in PTH levels in hypoparathyroidism versus
pseudohypoparathyroidism?

{{c1::PTH levels are elevated in pseudohypoparathyroidism due to stimulation by hypocalcemia}}
Some {{c1::malignant tumors}} secrete {{c2::PTH-related peptide (PTH-rp)}}, which is structurally homologous with the PTH secreted by the parathyroid glands
{{c2::Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH)}} is caused by inactivating mutations of the {{c1::Ca2+-sensing receptors}} that regulate PTH secretion

What is the inheritance of familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH)?

{{c1::Autosomal dominant}}

What is the effect of chronic renal failure on serum phosphate levels?

{{c1::Increased}}
In chronic renal failure, increased serum phosphate complexes Ca2+ and leads to decreased {{c1::free, ionized Ca2+}}
In chronic renal failure, decreased production of the active form of vitamin {{c1::D, (1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol)}} by the kidney contributes to decreased ionized Ca2+
The decreased ionized Ca2+ in chronic renal failure causes {{c1::secondary hyperparathyroidism}}, which is characterized by increased levels of PTH
In {{c2::CKD}}, the combination of elevated PTH and decreased 1,25-(OH)2D3 produces {{c1::renal osteodystrophy}}, in which there is increased bone resorption and osteomalacia
{{c2::Calcitonin}} is secreted by the {{c1::parafollicular cells (C cells)}} of the thyroid gland
The major function of calcitonin is to inhibit bone {{c1::resorption}}, thus decreasing the plasma Ca2+ concentration
Cholecalciferol is converted to {{c1::25-hydroxycholecalciferol (25-OH-cholecalciferol)}} in the {{c2::liver}}; this compound is chemically {{c3::inactive}}
The activity of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase is increased with {{c1::increased}} PTH levels
The activity of the renal enzyme 1α-hydroxylase is increased with {{c1::decreased}} serum phosphate concentration
In addition to calcium, 1,25-(OH)2 D3 also increases the intestinal absorption of {{c1::phosphate (PO43-)}}
Similar to its action on the intestines, 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol increases the {{c1::renal}} reabsorption of Ca2+ and phosphate
In bone, 1,25-(OH)2 D3 acts syngergistically with PTH to stimulate {{c1::osteoclast}} activity and bone {{c1::resorption}}
In children, vitamin D deficiency causes {{c1::rickets}}
In adults, vitamin D deficiency causes {{c1::osteomalacia}}
Vitamin D resistance most commonly occurs due to {{c1::chronic renal failure}}
Pituitary {{c1::adenoma}} is a benign tumor of the anterior pituitary cells
Nonfunctional pituitary adenomas present with symptoms due to {{c1::mass effect}}
Pituitary adenoma may present with {{c1::bitemporal hemianopsia}} due to compression of the {{c2::optic chiasm}}
Pituitary adenoma may present with {{c1::hypopituitarism}} due to compression of normal pituitary tissue
A non-specific symptom of pituitary adenoma is {{c1::headache}} (due to mass effect)

What is the most common type of functional pituitary adenoma?

{{c1::Prolactinoma}}
In females, prolactinoma presents as {{c1::galactorrhea}} and {{c2::amenorrhea}}
{{c1::Hypopituitarism}} is the insufficient production of hormones by the anterior pituitary gland
One possible cause of hypopituitarism in adults is {{c1::pituitary adenoma}} (due to mass effect)
Hypopituitarism may be caused by {{c1::Sheehan}} syndrome, which is a(n) {{c2::pregnancy}}-related {{c3::infarction}} of the pituitary gland
Pregnancy-related infarction of the pituitary gland (Sheehan syndrome) often occurs following {{c1::postpartum bleeding}}
Symptoms of Sheehan syndrome include poor {{c1::lactation}}, loss of {{c1::pubic hair}}, and fatigue
{{c1::Central}} diabetes insipidus is characterized by polyuria and polydipsia with an inability to {{c3::concentrate}} urine due to {{c2::lack of ADH}}
{{c1::Nephrogenic}} diabetes insipidus is characterized by polyuria and polydipsia with an inability to {{c3::concentrate}} urine due to {{c2::lack of response to ADH}}
Etiologies of {{c1::central}} diabetes insipidus include pituitary tumor, autoimmune, trauma, surgery, and ischemic encephalopathy
{{c2::Nephrogenic}} diabetes insipidus is often caused by {{c1::ADH receptor}} mutations
{{c1::Nephrogenic}} diabetes insipidus may be caused by drugs such as {{c2::lithium}} and {{c3::demeclocycline}}
Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by urine specific gravity < {{c1::1.006}}
Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by {{c1::low}} urine osmolality
Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by serum osmolality {{c1::>}} 290 mOsm/kg
Both central and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are characterized by blood hyperosmotic volume {{c1::contraction}}
Central diabetes insipidus is characterized by {{c1::low}} levels of ADH
Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is characterized by {{c1::normal}} or {{c1::elevated}} levels of ADH
Treatment for central diabetes insipidus includes hydration and {{c1::desmopressin}}, which is an ADH analog
Treatment for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus includes hydration and {{c1::HCTZ}}, which is a thiazide diuretic
Diagnosis of diabetes insipidus is aided by the {{c1::water deprivation}} test
In diabetes insipidus, the water deprivation test fails to {{c1::increase}} urine osmolality
One possible cause of SIADH is {{c1::small cell}} lung carcinoma, which provides a source of ectopic ADH

Disease of which organ system is most commonly associated with SIADH?

{{c1::Pulmonary}}

SIADH may be caused by drugs, such as (Cant Concentrate Serum Sodium)

- C{{c1::arbamazepine}}
- C{{c2::yclophosphamide}}
- S{{c3::SRI}}
SIADH is characterized by increased {{c1::retention}} of free water
SIADH is characterized by {{c1::urine}} osmolality > {{c1::serum}} osmolality
SIADH is characterized by {{c1::euvolemic::volume}} {{c1::hyponatremia::Na+ level}} with continued urinary Na+ excretion
The very low serum Na+ concentration in SIADH can lead to {{c2::cerebral}} {{c1::edema}} and seizures
In SIADH, serum Na+ levels must be corrected slowly to prevent {{c1::osmotic demyelination}} syndrome
Treatment of SIADH includes water restriction and {{c1::demeclocycline}}, which is a tetracycline
A(n) {{c2::thyroglossal duct}} cyst presents as a(n) {{c1::anterior, midline::location}} {{c3::neck}} mass that moves with swallowing or protrusion of the tongue

The thyroid develops at the base of the tongue (primitive pharynx) and then travels along the {{c1::thyroglossal}} duct to the anterior neck

Bonus: forms from which arch?
The {{c1::foramen cecum}} (of the tongue) is the normal remnant of the thyroglossal duct
A partially involuted thyroglossal duct may present as a(n) {{c1::pyramidal}} lobe on the thyroid

What is the most common site for ectopic thyroid tissue?

{{c1::The tongue}}

How does hyperthyroidism cause an increased basal metabolic rate?

{{c1::Via increased synthesis of Na+-K+ ATPase pumps}}

Which thyroid imbalance presents with decreased heat production (cold intolerance) and decreased sweating?

{{c1::Hypothyroidism}}

Which thyroid imbalance presents with increased heat production (heat intolerance) and increased sweating?

{{c1::Hyperthyroidism}}

Which thyroid imbalance presents with weight loss and increased appetite?

{{c1::Hyperthyroidism}}

Which thyroid imbalance presents with weight gain and decreased appetite?

{{c1::Hypothyroidism}}

Which thyroid imbalance presents with hyperdefecation / diarrhea?

{{c1::Hyperthyroidism}}

Which thyroid imbalance presents with constipation?

{{c1::Hypothyroidism}}

Which thyroid imbalance presents with decreased reflexes?

{{c1::Hypothyroidism}}

Which thyroid imbalance presents with tachycardia, palpitations, and arrhythmias?

{{c1::Hyperthyroidism}}

Which thyroid imbalance presents with bradycardia and dyspnea on exertion?

{{c1::Hypothyroidism}}

Which thyroid imbalance presents with proximal muscle weakness and increased creatine kinase?

{{c1::Hypothyroidism}}

Does hyperthyroidism present with hypo- or hyper-cholesterolemia? Why?

{{c1::Hypocholesterolemia; due to increased LDL receptor expression}}

Does hypothyroidism present with hypo- or hyper-cholesterolemia? Why?

{{c1::Hypercholesterolemia; due to decreased LDL receptor expression}}

Does hyperthyroidism present with hypo- or hyper-glycemia? Why?

{{c1::Hyperglycemia; due to increased gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis}}
Graves disease is associated with {{c1::pretibial}} {{c2::myxedema}} which occurs due to activation of dermal {{c3::fibroblasts}}
Graves disease is associated with {{c1::exophthalmos}} which occurs due to activation of retro-orbital {{c2::fibroblasts}}
{{c1::Thyroid storm (Thyrotoxicosis)}} is a serious complication that occurs when hyperthyroidism is untreated and worsened in the setting of acute stress (e.g. infection, trauma, surgery)

What are the "4 Ps" used to treat thyroid storm?

1. {{c1::Propranolol}} (a β-blocker)
2. {{c1::Propylthiouracil}}
3. {{c2::Prednisolone}} (a corticosteroid)
4. {{c2::Potassium iodide}} (Lugol iodine)
Toxic multinodular goiter is most often due to {{c1::TSH receptor}} mutations (60% of cases)
The {{c1::Jod-Basedow}} phenomenon describes {{c3::thyrotoxicosis (hyperthyroidism)}} in a patient with iodine deficiency who is made iodine replete
{{c1::Hypothyroidism}} in neonates and infants is known as cretinism
A pot-bellied, pale, puffy-faced child with protruding umbilicus, protuberant tongue, and poor brain development is characteristic of {{c1::cretinism}}
One cause of cretinism is {{c1::dyshormonogenetic goiter}}, which is due to a congenital defect in thyroid hormone production
The most common cause of cretinism in the U.S. is {{c1::thyroid dysgenesis}}
{{c2::Myxedema}} is the accumulation of {{c1::glycosaminoglycans}} in the skin and soft tissue; it is most often associated with {{c3::hypothyroidism}}
In hypothyroidism patients, myxedema commonly affects the {{c1::larynx}} (causing deep voice) and {{c1::tongue}} (causing enlargement)

Which thyroid imbalance is associated with dry, cool skin and coarse, brittle hair?

{{c1::Hypothyroidism}}

Which thyroid imbalance is associated with warm, moist skin and fine hair?

{{c1::Hyperthyroidism}}
Hashimoto thyroiditis is associated with HLA-{{c1::DR3}} and HLA-{{c1::DR5}}

What is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in regions where iodine levels are adequate?

{{c1::Hashimoto thyroiditis}}
Initially, Hashimoto thyroiditis presents as {{c1::hyperthyroidism}} due to thyrotoxicosis during follicular rupture

Which two antibodies are associated with Hashimoto thyroiditis?

{{c1::Anti-thyroglobulin}} and {{c2::anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-microsomal)}}
Histologically, Hashimoto thyroiditis is associated with chronic inflammation with well-developed {{c1::germinal centers}}
Histologically, Hashimoto thyroiditis may have {{c1::Hurthle}} cells, which are eosinophilic metaplastic cells that line the follicles
Patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis have an increased risk for {{c1::B-cell (marginal zone) lymphoma}}; presents as an enlarging thyroid late in disease course

Does Hashimoto thyroiditis present with a tender or nontender thyroid?

{{c1::Nontender}}
Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain) is a self-limited disease often following {{c1::viral infection}}

Does subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain) present with a tender or nontender thyroid?

{{c1::**Very tender**}}
Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain) may initially present with {{c1::hyperthyroidism}}, which typically is followed by a brief {{c1::hypothyroid}} state

What histological findings are associated with Subacute thyroiditis (de Quervain)?

{{c1::Granulomatous inflammation}}
Riedel thyroiditis is characterized by replacement of thyroid by {{c1::fibrous}} tissue with inflammatory infiltrate
In Riedel thyroiditis, fibrosis may extend to {{c1::local structures (e.g. airway)}}, thus mimicking {{c2::anaplastic carcinoma}}
Riedel thyroiditis presents as a "{{c1::hard as wood}}", {{c2::nontender::tender or non-tender}} goiter
Riedel thyroiditis is considered a manifestation of {{c1::IgG4}}-related systemic disease, which includes autoimmune pancreatitis, retroperitoneal fibrosis, and noninfectious aortitis
Thyroid nodules are more likely to be {{c1::benign::benign or malignant}} than {{c1::malignant::benign or malignant}}
Thyroid nodules may be studied using {{c1::131I}} radioactive uptake studies
If a thyroid nodule has increased uptake of 131I, it is considered a(n) {{c1::hot}} nodule; seen in Graves disease or nodular goiter
If a thyroid nodule has decreased uptake of 131I, it is considered a(n) {{c1::cold}} nodule

What is a cold nodule on 131I radioactive uptake studies indicative of?

{{c1::Adenoma or carcinoma; warrants further biopsy}}

How is a biopsy performed for a thyroid nodule?

{{c1::Fine needle aspiration (FNA)}}
Thyroid {{c1::adenoma}} is a benign solitary growth of the thyroid
Most thyroid adenomas are nonfunctional ("cold"), but may rarely cause {{c1::hyperthyroidism}} via autonomous thyroid hormone production ("hot" or "toxic")
The most common type of thyroid adenoma is {{c1::follicular}} adenoma

What is the main distinguishing feature between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma of the thyroid?

{{c1::Follicular adenoma has a lack of capsular and vascular invasion}}
Thyroid follicular adenoma is a benign tumor of follicles surrounded by a(n) {{c1::fibrous capsule}}

What is the most common type of thyroid carcinoma?

{{c1::Papillary Carcinoma (80%)}}
Exposure to {{c1::ionizing radiation}} in childhood is a major risk factor for thyroid {{c2::papillary}} carcinoma
Thyroid {{c1::papillary}} carcinoma may be lined by cells with clear, {{c2::Orphan Annie eye}} nuclei
In addition to Orphan Annie eye nuclei, thyroid papillary carcinoma may have cells with intranuclear {{c1::grooves}} and inclusions
Thyroid {{c2::papillary}} carcinoma may have {{c1::psammoma}} bodies on biopsy, which are characterized by concentric layers of calcification

What is the prognosis of thyroid papillary carcinoma?

{{c1::Excellent}}
Thyroid follicular carcinoma is characterized by a malignant proliferation of follicles surrounded by a(n) {{c1::fibrous capsule}} with {{c1::invasion through the capsule}}

Can fine needle aspiration distinguish between thyroid follicular adenoma versus carcinoma?

{{c1::No; the fibrous capsule cannot be visualized with FNA}}

What is the most common route of metastasis for a thyroid follicular carcinoma?

{{c1::Hematogenous}}
Thyroid {{c1::medullary}} carcinoma is a malignant proliferation of {{c2::parafollicular "C"}} cells
Thyroid medullary carcinomas secrete {{c1::calcitonin}}
High levels of calcitonin produced by a thyroid medullary carcinoma may lead to {{c1::hypocalcemia}}
In thyroid medullary carcinoma, calcitonin often deposits within the tumor as {{c1::amyloid}}, which may be visualized with a(n) {{c2::congo red}} stain
Detection of a RET oncogene mutation warrants prophylactic {{c1::thyroidectomy}}

What two multiple endocrine neoplasias are associated with thyroid medullary carcinoma?

{{c1::MEN 2A and 2B}}
Thyroid {{c1::anaplastic}} carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant tumor of thyroid
Thyroid {{c1::anaplastic}} carcinoma often invades local structures leading to dysphagia or respiratory compromise

What is the prognosis of thyroid anaplastic carcinoma?

{{c1::Poor}}

What type of thyroid carcinoma is illustrated in this histology slide?

{{c1::Anaplastic carcinoma}}

What is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism?

{{c1::Parathyroid adenoma (>80%)}}

What is the serum calcium level in primary hyperparathyroidism?

{{c1::Increased (due to increased PTH)}}
As a result of hypercalcemia, patients with primary hyperparathyroidism are at increased risk for {{c1::calcium oxalate kidney}} stones
{{c1::Nephrocalcinosis}} is the deposition of calcium in the tubules of the kidney due to primary hyperparathyroidism
Primary hyperparathyroidism may lead to CNS disturbances, such as {{c1::depression}} and seizures

Is a patient with hyperparathyroidism more likely to present with constipation or diarrhea?

{{c1::Constipation}}

What is the serum level of calcium in primary hyperparathyroidism?

{{c1::Increased (hypercalcemia)}}

What is the serum level of phosphate in primary hyperparathyroidism?

{{c1::Decreased (hypophosphatemia)}}

What is the serum level of calcium in secondary hyperparathyroidism?

{{c1::Decreased (hypocalcemia)}}

What is the most common cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?

{{c1::Chronic renal failure}}

How does renal insufficiency cause secondary hyperparathyroidism? (sorry)

{{c1::
1. Renal insufficiency causes decreased phosphate excretion and thus increased serum phosphate levels
2. Increased serum phosphate may bind free, ionized calcium, thus decreasing serum calcium levels
3. Decreased free calcium stimulates PTH release from the parathyroid glands
}}

Chronic {{c1::renal}} disease can cause a secondary hyperparathyroidism syndrome known as {{c1::Renal Osteodystrophy}}, which is characterized by bone lesions due to increased bone resorption (from elevated PTH)
{{c1::Tertiary}} hyperparathyroidism is refractory (autonomous) hyperparathyroidism resulting from chronic renal disease
Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a or Albright hereditary osteodystrophy is characterized by shortened stature and shortened {{c1::4th}} and {{c1::5th}} digits

What is the inheritance of pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1a (Albright hereditary osteodystrophy)?

{{c1::Autosomal dominant}}

Which endocrine disorder presents with the physical features of Albright hereditary dystrophy but without the end-organ PTH resistance?

{{c1::Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism}}
Type {{c1::1}} diabetes mellitus is characterized by insulin deficiency
Type {{c1::2}} diabetes mellitus is characterized by insulin resistance
Type 1 diabetes mellitus is due to {{c1::autoimmune destruction}} of pancreatic {{c2::β}} cells by {{c3::anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase}} antibodies

What type of hypersensitivity is type 1 DM?

{{c1::type IV HSR}}

What age group is most commonly affected by type 1 DM?

{{c1::< 30 years old}}

What age group is most commonly affected by type 2 DM?

{{c1::> 40 years old}}

Is type 1 DM characterized by a strong or weak genetic predisposition (compared to type 2)?

{{c1::Relatively weak (50% concordance in identical twins)}}

Is type 2 DM characterized by a strong or weak genetic predisposition (compared to type 1)?

{{c1::Relatively strong (90% concordance in twin studies)}}
Histology of type 1 diabetes mellitus demonstrates islets with {{c1::leukocytic infiltrate (inflammation)}}
Histology of type 2 diabetes mellitus demonstrates islets with {{c1::amyloid deposits}}

What is the level of insulin in a patient with type 2 diabetes (elevated, decreased, normal)?

{{c1::Variable; increased early in disease, but may be decreased later in disease due to β cell exhaustion}}
Type 1 diabetes is associated with HLA-{{c1::DR3}} and HLA-{{c1::DR4}}

Why does type 1 diabetes mellitus present with weight loss and decreased muscle mass?

{{c1::increased lipolysis and proteolysis due to unopposed glucagon from lack of insulin}}

Why do patients with diabetes mellitus present with polyuria and polydipsia?

{{c1::Excess glucose is filtered into the urine and pulls water with it}}

What is the most common type of diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::Type 2}}

How does insulin resistance manifest in obese patients, causing type 2 DM?

{{c1::Obesity causes downregulation of insulin receptors}}
The diagnosis for diabetes mellitus may be made using {{c1::HbA1c}} which reflects average blood glucose over 3 prior months

What is the diagnostic cutoff for HbA1c for a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::≥6.5%}}

What is the diagnostic cutoff for fasting plasma glucose for a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::≥126 mg/dL}}

What is the diagnostic cutoff for the 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test for a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::≥ 200 mg/dL}}

What is the range for normal blood glucose levels (mg/dL)?

{{c1::70-120 mg/dL}}
One of the most feared complications of type 1 diabetes is {{c1::diabetic ketoacidosis}}
Diabetic ketoacidosis often arises with {{c1::stress}} (e.g. infection)
In type 1 diabetics, increased {{c2::lipolysis}} leads to an increase in free fatty acids which are converted to {{c1::ketone bodies}} in the liver

What are the two major ketone bodies produced in a type 1 diabetic patient?

{{c1::β-hydroxybutyrate and acetoacetate}}
Diabetic ketoacidosis is associated with a(n) {{c1::fruity}} breath odor due to exhaled {{c2::acetone}}
Diabetic ketoacidosis is associated with {{c1::Kussmaul}} respirations, which is rapid/deep breathing to compensate for metabolic {{c2::acidosis}}

What is the serum potassium level in a type 1 diabetic patient?

{{c1::Increased::increased or decreased}}

What is the intracellular potassium level in a type 1 diabetic patient?

{{c1::Decreased::increased or decreased}}

What type of acidosis will a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis experience?

{{c1::high anion gap metabolic acidosis}}

Will a diabetic ketoacidosis patient present with hyper- or hypo-glycemia?

{{c1::Hyperglycemia (usually >300 mg/dL)}}

What fungal infection is a feared complication in a diabetic ketoacidosis patient?

{{c1::Mucormycosis (usually caused by Rhizopus infection)}}

What is the treatment for diabetic ketoacidosis?

IV {{c1::fluids}}, {{c1::insulin}}, and {{c1::K+ (to replete intracellular stores)}}
One of the most feared complications of type 2 diabetes is {{c1::hyperosmolar hyperglycemia non-ketotic syndrome}}

What demographic is most commonly associated with hyperosmolar hyperglycemia non-ketotic syndrome?

{{c1::Elderly type 2 diabetics, especially with limited ability to drink}}
Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic non-ketotic syndrome often presents with glucose levels > {{c1::600}} mg/dL and increased serum osmolarity (> 320 mOsm/kg)

Does hyperosmolar hyperglycemia non-ketotic syndrome present with ketoacidosis? Why?

{{c1::No, ketone production is inhibited by presence of insulin}}

What is the treatment for hyperosmolar hyperglycemic non-ketotic syndrome?

{{c1::Intense IV fluids and insulin therapy}}
One chronic complication of diabetes mellitus is {{c1::non-enzymatic glycosylation}} of vascular basement membranes
{{c2::Non-enzymatic glycosylation}} of medium and large-sized vessels leads to {{c1::atherosclerosis}} in diabetic patients

What is the leading cause of death in a patient with diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::Heart attack (MI)}}
