Non-enzymatic glycosylation of medium and large-sized vessels may cause {{c1::peripheral vascular occlusive disease}}, which is the leading cause of nontraumatic amputation in diabetic patients
Non-enzymatic glycosylation of small vessels may cause nodular {{c1::glomerulosclerosis}} with Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules; may cause chronic renal failure
Non-enzymatic glycosylation of small vessels can cause hyaline {{c1::arteriolosclerosis}} of the kidney, which may lead to chronic renal failure
Non-enzymatic glycosylation of hemoglobin leads to {{c1::HbA1c}}
In diabetes patients, {{c1::osmotic}} damage may occur when glucose in tissue is converted to {{c2::sorbitol}} by the enzyme {{c3::aldose reductase}}
In diabetes patients, {{c1::peripheral neuropathy}} and {{c1::autonomic}} neuropathy occurs as a result of osmotic damage to {{c2::Schwann}} cells
In diabetes patients, {{c2::blindness}} occurs as a result of osmotic damage to {{c1::pericytes::cell type}} of retinal blood vessels, weakening the vessel wall and causing aneurysm formation
In diabetes patients, {{c1::cataracts}} occur as a result of osmotic damage to the {{c2::lens::structure}}
Glucose is converted to {{c1::sorbitol}} by the enzyme {{c2::aldose reductase}}
A(n) {{c1::glucagonoma}} is a tumor of pancreatic alpha cells

Which hormone-secreting tumor is associated with dermatitis (necrolytic migratory erythema), diabetes, DVT, declining weight, and depression?

{{c1::Glucagonoma}}

What is the treatment for a glucagonoma?

{{c1::Octreotide (somatostatin analog) or surgery}}
A(n) {{c1::insulinoma}} is a tumor of pancreatic β cells

The Whipples triad help confirm symptomatic {{c2::hypoglycemia}}

- low blood {{c1::glucose}}
- {{c1::symptoms}} of hypoglycemia
- resolution of symptoms after normalization of {{c1::glucose}} levels
Symptomatic patients with insulinoma have {{c1::low::high/low}} blood glucose and {{c1::high::high/low}} C-peptide levels
About 10% of cases of insulinoma are associated with {{c1::MEN 1}} syndrome
The {{c1::secretin stimulation}} test may be used to aid in the diagnosis of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
If a patient has Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, gastrin levels will remain {{c1::elevated}} after administration of secretin (secretin stimulation test)
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is caused by a(n) {{c1::gastrinoma}} of the pancreas or duodenum
Carcinoid tumors often secrete {{c1::serotonin (5-HT)}}, which is dumped into the portal vein and processed by the liver via {{c2::monoamine oxidase (MAO)}}
Elevated levels of {{c1::5-HIAA}}, a metabolite of serotonin, in the urine is indicative of a(n) {{c2::carcinoid}} tumor

What is the most common malignancy in the small intestine?

{{c1::Carcinoid tumor (neuroendocrine cells)}}
Carcinoid syndrome may occur if the carcinoid tumor metastasizes to the {{c1::liver}}
Carcinoid syndrome is characterized by bronchospasm (asthmatic wheezing), recurrent diarrhea, and {{c1::flushing of the skin}}
Carcinoid syndrome may cause carcinoid heart disease, which is characterized by {{c1::right}}-sided valvular fibrosis leading to {{c1::tricuspid}} regurgitation and pulmonary valve stenosis

Why are left-sided valvular lesions not seen in a patient with carcinoid heart disease?

{{c1::blood passes through the lung, which contains MAO, thus converting 5-HT to 5-HIAA before reaching the left heart}}
{{c1::VIPoma}} is a non-α, non-β, non-δ islet cell pancreatic tumor that secretes VIP (also known as WDHA syndrome)
The symptoms of VIPoma are {{c1::Watery Diarrhea}}, {{c1::Hypokalemia}}, and {{c1::Achlorhydria}}
Cushing syndrome simply refers to an increase in serum {{c1::cortisol}}
Cushing disease refers specifically to a(n) {{c1::ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma}}

What is the most common cause of Cushing syndrome?

{{c1::Exogenous glucocorticoids}}

What is the most common endogenous cause of Cushing syndrome?

{{c1::Cushing disease (i.e. an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma)}}
One clinical feature of Cushing syndrome is muscle weakness with {{c1::thin}} extremities
Clinical features of {{c2::Cushing syndrome}} include moon facies, buffalo hump, and truncal obesity due to increased {{c1::fat storage}}, secondary to excess {{c1::insulin}}
One clinical feature of Cushing syndrome is {{c2::abdominal striae}} which is a result of impaired {{c1::collagen}} synthesis, allowing blood vessels to rupture easily

One clinical feature of Cushing syndrome is {{c1::hypertension}}, which is a result of an upregulation of {{c2::alpha1-adrenergic}} receptors, causing increased sensitivity of blood vessels to catecholamines
One clinical feature of Cushing syndrome is {{c1::immune suppression}}, which is a result of inhibition of phospholipase A2, IL-2, and histamine
One positive screening test for Cushing syndrome is an increased free {{c1::cortisol}} on 24-hour urinalysis
One positive screening test for Cushing syndrome is an increased midnight {{c1::salivary}} cortisol
One positive screening test for Cushing syndrome is no {{c1::cortisol suppression}} with overnight low-dose dexamethasone test (1mg)

What is the state of the adrenal glands in Cushing syndrome due to exogenous corticosteroids?

{{c1::Atrophy of both adrenal glands::hyperplasia, atrophy; one, both}}

What is the state of the adrenal glands in Cushing syndrome due to a paraneoplastic (ectopic) ACTH secretion?

{{c1::Hyperplasia of both adrenal glands::hyperplasia, atrophy; one, both}}

What is the most common tumor that produces ectopic ACTH?

{{c1::Small cell lung carcinoma}}

What is the differential diagnosis in a Cushing syndrome patient with suppressed ACTH?

{{c1::
1. Exogenous glucocorticoids
2. Adrenal adenoma (or carcinoma, hyperplasia)
::2}}

What is the differential diagnosis in a Cushing syndrome patient with elevated ACTH?

{{c1::1. Cushing disease (ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma)
2. Ectopic ACTH secretion
::2}}

If a patient with ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome has adequate cortisol suppression following a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test (8mg), the most likely cause of their syndrome is {{c1::Cushing disease}}

If a patient with ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome has no cortisol suppression following a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test (8mg), the most likely cause of their syndrome is {{c1::ectopic ACTH secretion}}
Hyperaldosteronism presents as {{c2::hypertension::blood pressure}} with {{c1::hypernatremia::Na+}}, {{c3::hypokalemia::K+}}, and {{c4::metabolic alkalosis::H+}}
Aldosterone increases {{c1::Na+}} and H2O reabsorption at the distal tubules and collecting duct
The most common cause of primary hyperaldosteronism is {{c1::bilateral adrenal hyperplasia}}
{{c1::Primary}} hyperaldosteronism is characterized by high aldosterone and {{c2::low}} renin
{{c1::Secondary}} hyperaldosteronism is characterized by high aldosterone and {{c2::high}} renin
Secondary hyperaldosteronism is due to activation of {{c1::renin-angiotensin}} system
Congenital adrenal {{c1::hyperplasia}} occurs due to loss of one of the four enzymes needed for cortisol synthesis
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a result of decreased levels of {{c1::cortisol}}, causing increased {{c1::ACTH}} secretion via negative feedback
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia affects the adrenal glands on {{c1::both::one or both}} side(s) of the body
Decreased cortisol production in congenital adrenal hyperplasia may cause life-threatening {{c1::hypotension}} due to decreased {{c1::alpha1-adrenergic}} receptors

Which steroid synthesis enzyme deficiency results in salt wasting and hyponatremia due to lack of aldosterone?

{{c1::21β-hydroxylase deficiency}}
21β-hydroxylase deficiency presents with {{c1::hyperkalemia::K+}} and {{c2::hypotension::blood pressure}}
11β-hydroxylase deficiency presents with {{c1::hypokalemia::K+}} and {{c2::hypertension::blood pressure}}

What clinical features are seen in 11β-hydroxylase deficiency that are a result of increased androgen levels:

{{c1::virilization}} (in women)
17α-hydroxylase deficiency presents with {{c1::hypokalemia::K+}} and {{c2::hypertension::blood pressure}}
{{c1::Adrenal insufficiency}} is the inability of the adrenal glands to generate enough glucocorticoids +/- mineralocorticoids
{{c2::Primary}} adrenal insufficiency presents with {{c1::low}} cortisol and {{c1::high}} ACTH
One cause of acute primary adrenal insufficiency is {{c1::Waterhouse-Friderichsen}} syndrome
Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is the bilateral {{c1::hemorrhagic}} necrosis of the {{c2::adrenal glands}}, causing the gland to look like a "sack of blood"
Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome classically follows after DIC in young children with {{c1::N. meningitidis}} infection
Chronic primary adrenal insufficiency, also known as {{c1::Addison}} disease, is due to adrenal atrophy or destruction by disease
The most common cause of Addison disease in the West is {{c1::autoimmune destruction}}
The most common cause of Addison disease in the developing world is {{c1::tuberculosis}}
A common cause of Addison disease is metastatic carcinoma, especially from the {{c1::lungs}}
Clinical features of Addison disease include hyponatremia, hypovolemia, and hyperkalemia, due to lack of {{c1::mineralocorticoids}}
One clinical feature of Addison disease is {{c1::hyperpigmentation}}, due to increased levels of {{c2::MSH}} secondary to elevated ACTH

Does secondary adrenal insufficiency present with skin/mucosal hyperpigmentation?

{{c1::No, because ACTH levels are decreased}}

Does secondary adrenal insufficiency present with hyperkalemia?

{{c1::No, because aldosterone synthesis is preserved}}
{{c2::Tertiary}} adrenal insufficiency is seen in patients with chronic exogenous {{c1::steroid}} use, precipitated by {{c1::abrupt withdrawal}}
{{c2::Pheochromocytoma}} is the most common tumor of the {{c1::adrenal medulla}} in adults
The adrenal medulla is composed of {{c1::chromaffin}} cells, which are derived from {{c2::neural crest}}
The adrenal medulla is responsible for the secretion of the catecholamines {{c1::norepinephrine}} and {{c1::epinephrine}}
A pheochromocytoma is a tumor of {{c1::chromaffin}} cells
Patients with pheochromocytoma experience their symptoms {{c1::episodically}}, rather than continuously

The five episodic hyperadrenergic symptoms of a(n) {{c3::pheochromocytoma}} are:
1. {{c1::Pressure (increased BP)}}
2. {{c1::Pain (headache)}}
3. {{c2::Perspiration}}
4. {{c2::Palpitations (tachycardia)}}
5. Pallor
{{c2::Pheochromocytoma}} is diagnosed by increased serum and urine levels of catecholamines, or their breakdown products {{c1::metanephrines}} and {{c1::vanillylmandelic acid (VMA)}}
Treatment for a pheochromocytoma is {{c1::surgical excision}}
Prior to removal of a pheochromocytoma, irreversible {{c1::α-antagonists}}, such as {{c2::phenoxybenzamine}} are administered, followed by {{c1::β-blockers}}

What is the embryonic origin of thyroid tissue?

{{c1::Endoderm}}

What is the embryonic origin of parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid?

{{c1::Endoderm}}

What is the embryonic origin of the adrenal cortex?

{{c1::Mesoderm}}

What is the embryonic origin of the adrenal medulla?

{{c1::Neural crest}}

Which anterior pituitary hormones are basophilic on histological preparation?

{{c1::FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH}}

Which anterior pituitary hormones are acidophilic on histological preparation?

{{c1::GH, Prolactin}}
Insulin increases expression of the GLUT4 transporter on adipose and muscle tissue via the {{c1::PI3 kinase}} signaling pathway

Which insulin-independent transporter is found in the brain, placenta, cornea, and RBCs?

{{c1::GLUT1}}

Which bidirectional insulin-independent transporter is found in the β-islet cells, liver, kidney, and small intestine?

{{c1::GLUT2}}

What is the effect of chest wall trauma on prolactin secretion?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the effect of renal failure on prolactin levels?

{{c1::Increased (due to reduced prolactin elimination)}}

What is the effect of leptin on appetite?

{{c1::Decreased}}

Which steroid hormone enzyme deficiency (21- or 11β-hydroxylase) presents with decreased renin activity?

{{c1::11β-hydroxylase}}
Overall, the effect of cortisol is {{c1::catabolic::anabolic, catabolic}}
After PTH binds to {{c1::osteoblasts}}, RANK-L is secreted which binds to RANK on {{c1::osteoclasts}}, increasing bone resorption

Which two endocrine hormones act to increase bone growth?

{{c1::Growth hormone & Thyroid hormone}}
Overall, the effects of thyroid hormones are {{c1::catabolic::anabolic, catabolic}}

The main functions of thyroid hormone can be remembered with the "7 Bs"?

1. {{c1::Brain maturation}}
2. {{c2::Bone growth}}
3. {{c3::β1-adrenergic effects}}
4. {{c4::Basal metabolic rate (increased)}}
5. {{c5::Blood sugar}}
6. {{c6::Break down lipids}}
7. {{c1::Stimulates surfactant synthesis in Babies}}

Which hormones use cAMP as their secondary messenger?

{{c1::(FLAT ChAMPs CHuGG)
FSH
LH
ACTH
TSH

CRH
hCG
ADH (V2)
MSH
PTH

Calcitonin
Histamine (H2-receptor)
Glucagon
GHRH
}}

Which hormones use cGMP as their secondary messenger?

{{c1::ANP, BNP, NO::3}}

Which hormones use IP3 as their secondary messenger?

{{c1::GnRH, Oxytocin, ADH (V1), TRH, Histamine (H1), Angiotensin II, Gastrin}}
In women, decreased levels of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) causes {{c1::hirsutism}} due to {{c1::increased}} free testosterone
In men, increased levels of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) causes {{c1::gynecomastia}} due to {{c1::decreased}} free testosterone

What are the two main areas that experience hyperpigmentation due to Addison disease?

{{c1::Skin and mucous membranes}}

What is the most common tumor of the adrenal medulla in children?

{{c1::Neuroblastoma}}
Neuroblastoma originates from {{c2::neural crest}} cells and can occur anywhere along the {{c1::sympathetic chain}}
The most common presentation for a(n) {{c1::neuroblastoma}} is abdominal distention with a firm, {{c2::irregular}} mass that {{c2::can}} cross the midline
Neuroblastoma may present with {{c1::opsoclonus-myoclonus}} syndrome, sometimes referred to as "dancing eyes, dancing feet"

Which oncogene is associated with Neuroblastoma?

{{c1::N-myc overexpression}}
Neuroblastoma is characterized by increased levels of {{c1::homovanillic acid (HVA)}} and {{c1::vanillylmandelic acid (VMA)}} in the urine (catecholamine metabolites)
{{c1::Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia}} presents with mild hypercalcemia and hypocalciuria with normal or increased PTH levels
One complication of {{c2::hyperparathyroidism}} is {{c1::osteitis fibrosa cystica}}, which is characterized by bone pain and cystic bone spaces filled with brown fibrous tissue

What is the inheritance of all multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes?

{{c1::Autosomal dominant}}

Which three organs are involved in MEN1?

{{c1::Pituitary, pancreas, and parathyroids}}
MEN {{c2::1}} is associated with pituitary tumors that secrete {{c1::prolactin}} or {{c1::GH}}
MEN {{c2::1}} is associated with pancreatic endocrine tumors, such as {{c1::Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (gastrinoma)}}, {{c3::insulinomas}}, VIPomas, and glucagonomas (rare)
MEN {{c1::1}} is associated with parathyroid adenomas
MEN 1 is associated with mutation of the {{c1::MEN1}} gene (menin), which is a tumor suppressor gene found on chromosome {{c2::11}}

Which three organs or diseases are involved in MEN 2A?

{{c1::Parathyroid, thyroid (medullary carcinoma) and pheochromocytomas}}
MEN {{c1::2A}} is associated with parathyroid hyperplasia
MEN {{c2::2A}} and {{c2::2B}} are associated with {{c1::medullary thyroid carcinoma::thyroid}}
MEN {{c2::2A}} and {{c2::2B}} are associated with {{c1::pheochromocytoma::adrenal medulla}}

Which three organs or diseases are involved in MEN 2B?

{{c1::Thyroid (medullary carcinoma), pheochromocytomas, and mucosal neuromas}}
MEN 2B is associated with mucosal {{c1::neuromas}} (oral/intestinal ganglioneuromatosis)
MEN {{c3::2B}} is associated with {{c1::marfanoid}} habitus and mutations in the {{c2::RET}} gene
MEN 2A is associated with mutations in the {{c1::RET}} gene, which codes for receptor tyrosine kinase in cells of neural crest origin

Activation of which adrenergic receptor increases production of insulin?

{{c1::β2}}

What is the effect of insulin on Na+-K+-ATPase activity?

{{c1::Increased (thus causing increased K+ uptake into cells)}}
When insulin acts on liver tissue, it causes {{c1::increased}} glycogenesis and {{c1::decreased}} glycogenolysis
When insulin acts on muscle tissue, it causes {{c1::increased}} glycogen storage and {{c2::increased}} protein synthesis
When insulin acts on adipose tissue, it causes {{c1::increased}} triglyceride storage and {{c1::decreased}} lipolysis
Insulin Glulisine, Aspart, and Lispro are characterized by {{c1::rapid}} action and duration
Glulisine, aspart, and lispro (rapid acting insulin) are useful for controlling the {{c1::postprandial}} glucose spike
Regular insulin is characterized by {{c1::short}} action and duration
{{c2::Regular}} insulin is the only insulin that can be administered {{c1::IV}}
IV {{c2::regular}} insulin is useful in management of {{c1::diabetic ketoacidosis}} (T1DM complication)
IV regular insulin is useful in the management of {{c1::hyperkalemia}} (K+ levels)
Neutral Protamine Hagedorn (NPH) is characterized by {{c1::intermediate}} action and duration
Insulin Detemir and Glargine are characterized by {{c1::long}} action and duration
The most common complication of insulin therapy is {{c1::hypoglycemia}}; may also experience lipodystrophy and hypersensitivity reaction (rare)

Which type(s) of diabetes may be treated with insulin therapy?

{{c1::T1DM, T2DM, and GDM (exogenous therefore doesnt require β cell activity)}}
Sulfonylureas are {{c1::sulfa}} drugs and thus may cause adverse reactions in allergic patients
{{c1::Sulfonylureas}} (and {{c1::meglitinides}}) bind the ATP-dependent {{c2::K+}} channels on pancreatic β cells, causing release of endogenous insulin

What drug class do tolbutamide and chlorpropamide belong to?

{{c1::1st generation sulfonylureas}}

What drug class do glyburide, glimepiride, and glipizide belong to?

{{c1::2nd generation sulfonylureas}}
{{c1::Glipizide}} has the shortest duration of action of the 2nd generation sulfonylureas and thus least risk of hypoglycemia
{{c1::Meglitinides}} are short-acting diabetic medications that act similarly to sulfonylureas (same MOA)
Meglitinides are not {{c1::sulfa drugs}} and thus may be used to treat a T2DM patients with an allergy to {{c1::sulfonylureas}}
Sulfonylureas and meglitinides have significant risk of causing {{c1::hypoglycemia}} as a possible side effect
Sulfonylureas and meglitinides may cause weight {{c1::gain}} as a side effect
{{c2::1st}} generation sulfonylureas (e.g. chlorpropamide, tolbutamide) may cause a(n) {{c1::disulfiram-like}} reaction as a possible side effect when you ingest alcohol while taking these drugs

What type(s) of diabetes may be treated with sulfonylureas and meglitinides?

{{c1::T2DM only; dependent on some functional β cells}}
Patients on sulfonylureas are at increased risk of hypoglycemia if they have {{c1::renal}} failure
Exenatide and liraglutide are both examples of {{c1::GLP-1 agonists}}
GLP-1 analogs cause increased {{c1::insulin}} release and satiety
GLP-1 analogs cause decreased {{c1::glucagon}} release and gastric emptying
{{c1::Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4)}} inhibitors act via preventing the breakdown of {{c2::GLP-1}}
Linagliptin, saxagliptin, and sitagliptin are all examples of {{c1::DPP-4 inhibitors}}
DPP-4 inhibitors increase levels of endogenously secreted {{c1::GLP-1}}
GLP-1 agonists and DPP-4 inhibitors cause decreased {{c1::glucagon}} secretion
GLP-1 agonists and DPP-4 inhibitors cause increased satiety via decreased {{c1::gastric emptying}}
DPP-4 inhibitors can increase risk of {{c1::upper respiratory}} tract infection
GLP-1 agonists can cause {{c1::pancreatitis}} as a possible side effect, as well as nausea and vomiting

Do GLP-1 agonists and/or DPP-4 inhibitors cause hypoglycemia as a possible side effect?

{{c1::No}}

What type(s) of diabetes may be treated with GLP-1 agonists and DPP-4 inhibitors?

{{c1::T2DM only; dependent on some functional β cells}}

The effects of cortisol may be remembered with the mnemonic "A BIG FIB":

A: {{c1::increased Appetite}}
B: {{c2::Blood pressure (increased, via alpha1)}}
I: {{c3::Insulin resistance (increased)}}
G: {{c4::Gluconeogenesis (increased)}}
F: {{c5::Fibroblast activity (decreased)}}
I: {{c6::Inflammatory/Immune response (decreased)}}
B: {{c7::Bone formation (decreased)}}
{{c1::Metformin}}, a(n) {{c2::biguanide}}, is the first line oral agent for the management of type {{c3::2}} diabetes
Metformin modulates enzyme function to decrease hepatic {{c1::gluconeogenesis}}
One mechanism by which metformin decreases gluconeogenesis is via {{c2::inhibition}} of the mitochondrial enzyme {{c1::glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (mGPDH)}}
One mechanism by which metformin decreases gluconeogenesis is via {{c2::activation}} of the enzyme {{c1::AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK)}}
Metformin causes increased insulin {{c1::sensitivity}}, therefore enhancing glucose uptake in peripheral tissues
The most serious side effect of metformin is {{c1::lactic acidosis}}
Patients with {{c1::renal insufficiency}} have increased risk for metformin-induced lactic acidosis due to metformin accumulation
The most common side effect of metformin is {{c1::GI upset (e.g. nausea, vomiting, anorexia, diarrhea)}}
Metformin may cause modest weight {{c1::reduction}}
Pioglitazone and rosiglitazone are examples of glitazones, also known as {{c1::thiazolidinediones}}
Thiazolidinediones cause increased insulin {{c1::sensitivity}}, therefore enhancing glucose uptake in peripheral tissues
{{c2::Thiazolidinediones (glitazones)}} are ligands of {{c1::PPAR-γ}}, an intranuclear receptor that regulates gene transcription
PPAR-gamma, which is activated by thiazolidinediones, upregulates {{c1::adiponectin}}, which causes increased insulin sensitivity and fatty acid oxidation

What is the effect of thiazolidinediones on the differentiation and number of adipocytes?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the effect of thiazolidinediones on triglyceride storage and fatty acid oxidation?

{{c1::Increased}}

Which GLUT receptor is upregulated in peripheral tissue by thiazolidinediones?

{{c1::GLUT4}}

Do thiazolidinediones act quickly to reduce blood glucose levels? Why?

{{c1::No, because it acts at the level of gene transcription (slow)}}
Thiazolidinediones (glitazones) can cause weight {{c1::gain}} and increased {{c2::Liver}} Function Tests
Thiazolidinediones can cause fluid retention and thus {{c1::peripheral edema}} as a possible side effect in the extremities
Thiazolidinedione-induced fluid retention can exacerbate {{c1::heart failure}}
Thiazolidinediones can increase the risk of atypical extremity {{c1::fractures}}

What class of diabetic drugs is associated with increased risk of fracture as a possible side effect?

{{c1::Thiazolidinediones (glitazones)}}

What class of diabetic drugs is associated with increased risk of heart failure as a possible side effect?

{{c1::Thiazolidinediones}}
{{c2::Pramlintide}} is an analog of {{c1::amylin (islet amyloid polypeptide, IAPP)}}
Amylin analogues (e.g. pramlintide) cause {{c1::decreased}} gastric emptying
Amylin analogues (e.g. pramlintide) decrease {{c1::glucagon}} secretion

Which type(s) of diabetes may be treated with pramlintide (amylin analogs)?

{{c1::T1DM and T2DM}}
Pramlintide (amylin analog) is used to control the {{c1::postprandial}} glucose spike
Pramlintide may cause {{c1::hypoglycemia}} as a side effect, especially in the setting of mistimed prandial insulin
A common side effect of pramlintide, an amylin analog, is {{c1::GI upset (e.g. nausea, vomiting, anorexia)}}

How is an amylin analog, such as pramlintide, administered?

{{c1::Subcutaneous injection (usually prior to a meal)}}
Acarbose and miglitol are examples of {{c1::alpha-glucosidase}} inhibitors
Acarbose and miglitol inhibit alpha-glucosidase enzymes which decreases the conversion of {{c1::disaccharides}} into absorbable {{c1::monosaccharides}}
Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors (e.g. acarbose, miglitol) reduce the activity of alpha-glucosidases on the {{c1::intestinal brush border}}, thus delaying carbohydrate hydrolysis and absorption
Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors (e.g. acarbose, miglitol) are used to control the {{c1::postprandial}} glucose spike
Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors (e.g. acarbose, miglitol) are infrequently prescribed due to their ability to cause {{c1::diarrhea}}, {{c1::flatulence}}, and abdominal pain as side effects
Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin are all examples of {{c1::SGLT2}} inhibitors
SGLT2 inhibitors, such as canagliflozin, cause increased excretion of urinary {{c1::glucose (glucosuria)}}

At which site do SGLT2 inhibitors block reabsorption of glucose?

{{c1::Proximal tubule of the nephron}}
One adverse effect of SGLT2 inhibitors is increased risk of {{c1::urinary}} tract infection
SGLT2 inhibitors may cause increased risk of vaginal {{c1::candidiasis (yeast infection)}}
SGLT2 inhibitors may cause dehydration, and consequently {{c1::orthostatic hypotension}} due to osmotic diuresis
SGLT2 inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with {{c1::renal}} insufficiency
The germ cells of the male gonads produce {{c1::spermatogonia}}
The {{c2::theca}} cells of the female gonads synthesize the hormone progesterone
The theca cells and granulosa cells, together, synthesize {{c1::estradiol (estrogen)}}

Which two hormones (from the testes) are decisive in determining differences between male and female gonads?

{{c1::Anti-müllerian hormone and testosterone (both synthesized in testes)}}
Gonadal males have testes that synthesize and secrete {{c1::anti-müllerian hormone}} and {{c1::testosterone}}, which are required for development of the male phenotype
{{c3::Testosterone}} stimulates the growth and differentiation of the {{c1::wolffian}} ducts, which develop into the male {{c2::internal}} genital tract
{{c3::Anti-müllerian hormone (müllerian inhibitory factor)}} causes atrophy of the {{c1::müllerian}} ducts, which would have developed into the female {{c2::internal}} genital tract
Without {{c1::testosterone}} (gonadal females), the wolffian ducts do not differentiate into male internal genitalia
Without {{c1::anti-müllerian hormone}} (gonadal females), the müllerian ducts are not suppressed and therefore develop into the female internal genitalia
In puberty and throughout the reproductive years, FSH levels are {{c1::less}} than LH levels
The primary event that initiates puberty is the onset of {{c2::pulsatile}} secretion of {{c1::GnRH}} from the hypothalamus
The pulsatile pattern of GnRH after puberty drives a parallel pulsatile secretion of both {{c1::FSH}} and {{c1::LH}} by the anterior pituitary
The onset of menstrual cycles in females is referred to as {{c1::menarche}}
{{c1::Germ}} cells (spermatogonia) maintain the germ pool and produce primary spermatocytes
{{c2::Sertoli}} cells secrete {{c1::androgen-binding protein}} which serves to maintain local levels of testosterone
{{c1::Tight junctions}} between adjacent {{c3::Sertoli}} cells form the {{c2::blood-testis}} barrier, which isolate gametes from autoimmune attack

What is the effect of increased temperature on sperm production?

{{c1::Decreased}}
The first stage of spermatogenesis is {{c1::DNA replication (interphase)}} of {{c2::spermatogonia}} to generate the {{c2::primary spermatocyte}}
After the primary spermatocyte has been formed, it undergoes {{c1::meiosis I}} to become a(n) {{c2::secondary spermatocyte}}
After the secondary spermatocyte has been formed, it undergoes {{c1::meiosis II}} to become a(n) {{c2::spermatid}}
After spermatids have been formed from secondary spermatocytes, they undergo {{c1::spermiogenesis}} to form {{c2::spermatozoa}}

What changes occur during the process of spermiogenesis?

- Loss of {{c1::cytoplasmic contents}}
- Gain of a(n) {{c1::acrosomal}} cap
- Development of {{c1::flagella}}

After which stage of spermatogenesis does the diploid sperm become haploid?

{{c1::Meiosis I (primary spermatocyte to secondary spermatocyte)}}
One full cycle of spermatogenesis takes {{c1::64}} days

What is the pathway of sperm during ejaculation?

{{c1::Seminiferous tubules
Epididymis
Vas deferens
Ejaculatory ducts (receives vas deferens and seminal vesicle)
(Nothing)
Urethra
Penis
}}
The primary location for the maturation and storage of sperm is the {{c1::epididymis}}
{{c1::LH}} increases testosterone synthesis by stimulating the enzyme {{c2::cholesterol desmolase}}
Androstenedione may be converted to {{c1::testosterone}} via the enzyme {{c2::17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase}}
Ninety-eight percent of circulating testosterone is bound to plasma proteins, such as {{c1::sex steroid-binding globulin (SSBG)}} and albumin
Hypothalamic control of spermatogenesis and testosterone secretion are regulated via the hormone {{c1::GnRH}}
GnRH is primarily secreted by the Hypothalamic {{c1::Preoptic}} nuclei
Pulsatile secretion of GnRH stimulates the anterior pituitary to secrete {{c1::FSH}} and {{c1::LH}}
Anterior pituitary control of spermatogenesis and testosterone secretion are regulated via the hormones {{c1::FSH}} and {{c1::LH}}
Testosterone acts via an intratesticular {{c1::paracrine}} mechanism to reinforce the spermatogenic effects of FSH in Sertoli cells

What is the effect of testosterone on GnRH secretion?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What is the effect of testosterone on LH secretion?

{{c1::Decreased}}
The Sertoli cells release a substance called {{c1::inhibin B::specific}} which causes decreased secretion of {{c2::FSH}} (negative feedback)

Which hormone directly inhibits the secretion of LH in males?

{{c1::Testosterone}}

Which androgen is responsible for the differentiation of the internal male genitalia (epididymis, vas deferens, seminal vesicles)?

{{c1::Testosterone}}

Which androgen is responsible for the growth spurt, including growth of the penis, seminal vesicles, sperm, and muscle?

{{c1::Testosterone}}

Which androgen is responsible for deepening of the voice?

{{c1::Testosterone}}

Which androgen is responsible for closing of epiphyseal plates (cessation of pubertal growth)?

{{c1::Testosterone}}

Which androgen is responsible for libido?

{{c1::Testosterone}}
In {{c2::5α-reductase}} deficiency, a person is genotypically XY but has underdeveloped (ambiguous) male {{c1::external}} genitalia with normal {{c1::internal}} genitalia
In males, androgens are converted to estrogen primarily in {{c1::adipose}} tissue and the {{c1::testis}}
In males, exogenous {{c1::testosterone}} causes decreased {{c2::intratesticular}} testosterone, leading to decreased testicular size and azoospermia

Which androgen is the most potent?

{{c1::DHT > testosterone > androstenedione}}
The functional unit of the ovaries is the single {{c1::ovarian follicle}}, which comprises one germ cell surrounded by endocrine cells
In the developing ovaries, primordial germ cells produce {{c1::oogonia}} by {{c2::mitotic}} divisions until gestational weeks {{c3::20}} to {{c3::24}}
{{c1::DNA replication (interphase)}} of oogonia generates the {{c2::primary oocytes}} (arrested in prophase 1)

Which phase of the cell cycle are primary oocytes arrested in until ovulation?

{{c1::Prophase I (of meiosis I)}}
Beginning at ovulation, primary oocytes begin to complete {{c1::meiosis I}} (diploid) to form {{c2::secondary oocytes}} (haploid)

Which phase of the cell cycle are secondary oocytes arrested in until fertilization?

{{c1::Metaphase II (of meiosis II)}}
After fertilization, the secondary oocyte completes {{c1::meiosis II}} to form a(n) {{c2::ovum}}
Primary oocytes are arrested in prophase I of meiosis I for years until {{c1::ovulation}}
Secondary oocytes are arrested in metaphase II of meiosis II until {{c1::fertilization}}
In the ovaries, {{c1::theca}} cells synthesize pregnenolone from cholesterol via the enzyme {{c2::cholesterol desmolase}}
In addition to progesterone, theca cells also synthesize {{c1::androstenedione}} which diffuses to nearby granulosa cells
In the {{c2::granulosa}} cells of the ovary, androstenedione is converted to testosterone via the enzyme 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase
In the {{c1::granulosa}} cells of the ovary, testosterone is converted to {{c2::17β-estradiol}} via the enzyme {{c3::aromatase}}
Hypothalamic control of oogenesis and progesterone/estradiol secretion are regulated via the hormone {{c1::GnRH}}
Ovarian granulosa cells may produce {{c1::inhibin}}, which inhibits FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary

What is the effect of estrogen on LH, estrogen, and progesterone receptors?

{{c1::Up-regulation::up- or down-regulation}}

What is the effect of estrogen on prolactin secretion?

{{c1::Increased}}

What form of estrogen is produced in the ovary?

{{c1::17β-estradiol}}

What form of estrogen is produced in the placenta?

{{c1::Estriol}}

What form of estrogen is produced in the adipose tissue?

{{c1::Estrone}}

Rank the forms of estrogen from most to least potent?

{{c1::17β-estradiol > estrone > estriol}}

Where are estrogen receptors expressed (cell membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus)?

{{c1::Cytoplasm; translocate to nucleus when bound by estrogen}}

What is the effect of estrogen on sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) levels?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the effect of estrogen on levels of HDL?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the effect of estrogen on levels of LDL?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What is the effect of progesterone on estrogen receptors?

{{c1::Downregulation::up- or down-regulation}}
Elevated levels of {{c1::progesterone}} in a non-pregnant patient is an indication that {{c2::ovulation}} has occurred
Variation in menstrual cycle length is attributed to the variability in duration of the {{c1::follicular}} phase
By convention, day 0 of the menstrual cycle marks the {{c1::onset of menses}}
During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, estradiol {{c1::inhibits}} FSH and LH secretion
During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, progesterone levels are {{c1::low}}
In the middle of the menstrual cycle {{c1::ovulation}} occurs, which occurs {{c2::14}} days prior to menses
Estradiol levels {{c1::decrease}} just after ovulation, but {{c1::increase}} again during the luteal phase
During the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle, basal body temperature {{c1::increases}} due to the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamic temperature set-point
If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses and estradiol and progesterone levels {{c1::decrease}} abruptly
Abnormal uterine bleeding is characterized as either {{c1::heavy menstrual}} bleeding (AUB/{{c1::HMB}}) or {{c2::intermenstrual}} bleeding (AUB/{{c2::IMB}})

Abnormal uterine bleeding is further subcategorized by PALM-COEIN; with Structural causes including:

- P{{c1::olyp}}
- A{{c2::denomyosis}}
- L{{c3::eiomyoma}}
- M{{c4::alignancy / hyperplasia}}

Abnormal uterine bleeding is further subcategorized by PALM-COEIN; with Non-structural causes including:

- C{{c1::oagulopathy}}
- O{{c2::vulatory dysfunction}}
- E{{c3::ndometrial}}
- I{{c4::atrogenic}}
- Not yet classified
In cases of heavy menstrual bleeding, Abnormal uterine bleeding can be treated with {{c1::hormone}} therapy or NSAIDS / {{c2::tranexamic acid}}
In cases of menstrual bleeding due to ovulatory dysfunction, abnormal uterine bleeding can be treated with {{c1::hormone}} therapy
Fertilization must occur within {{c1::one}} day(s) of ovulation
Fertilization most commonly occurs in the upper end of the fallopian tube called the {{c1::ampulla}}
Implantation within the wall of the uterus occurs {{c1::six}} day(s) after ovulation
Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is detectable in blood {{c1::1}} week(s) after conception and on home test in urine {{c1::2}} weeks after conception
{{c1::Gestational}} age of a fetus is calculated from date of last menstrual period
{{c1::Embryonic}} age of a fetus is calculated from date of conception (gestational age minus 2 weeks)
The function of hCG is to maintain the {{c1::corpus luteum}} by acting like LH for the first {{c2::8-10}} weeks of pregnancy
During the second and third trimesters, progesterone is produced by the {{c1::placenta}}, using cholesterol from the mother
{{c1::Human placental lactogen (HPL)}} is a hormone produced throughout pregnancy and has actions similar to those of growth hormone and prolactin

Why does lactation not occur during pregnancy, even though prolactin levels are increasing?

{{c1::Progesterone and estrogen downregulate prolactin receptors on the breast}}
As long as lactation continues, {{c1::ovulation}} is suppressed, due to inhibitory effects of prolactin on GnRH, FSH, and LH
In the development of a female, the {{c1::mesonephric (wolffian)}} duct degenerates and the {{c1::paramesonephric (müllerian)}} duct develops
In the male, the {{c1::SRY}} gene on the Y chromosome produces {{c2::testis-determining factor}}, which is necessary for testes development
Anti-müllerian hormone, from the Sertoli cells, is also referred to as {{c1::müllerian inhibitory factor}}
If there is a lack of Sertoli cells or MIF during development of a genotypically XY fetus, there is {{c1::both male and female}} internal genitalia and {{c1::male}} external genitalia
The indifferent gonad (testis, ovary) begins development next to the fetal kidney, known as the {{c1::mesonephros}}

Which embryologic structure develops into the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper portion of the vagina (internal female genitalia)?

{{c1::Paramesonephric (müllerian) duct}}
{{c2::Müllerian}} agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome, presents as primary {{c1::amenorrhea}} in females with fully developed secondary sexual characteristics

Which embryologic structure develops into the seminal vesicles, epididymis, ejaculatory duct, and ductus deferens (male internal genitalia, except prostate)?

{{c1::Mesonephric (wolffian) duct}}
{{c1::Septate}} uterus is a common anomaly of the uterus due to incomplete resorption of the septum

What is the treatment for septate uterus?

{{c1::Septoplasty}}

What is the effect of septate uterus on fertility?

{{c1::Decreased}}
{{c1::Bicornuate}} uterus is an anomaly of the uterus due to {{c2::incomplete}} lateral fusion of Müllerian ducts
Uterus {{c1::didelphys}} is an anomaly of the uterus due to {{c2::complete failure of}} lateral fusion of the müllerian ducts, leading to double uterus, vagina, and cervix

Is pregnancy possible in a patient with uterus didelphys?

{{c1::Yes}}
The male {{c1::glans penis}} is homologous to the female {{c2::glans clitoris}}, which both arise from the {{c3::genital tubercle}}
The male {{c1::corpus cavernosum and spongiosum}} are homologous to the female {{c2::vestibular bulbs}}, which both arise from the {{c3::genital tubercle}}
The male {{c1::bulbourethral glands (of Cowper)}} are homologous to the female {{c2::greater vestibular glands (of Bartholin)}}, which both arise from the {{c3::urogenital sinus}}
The male {{c1::prostate gland}} is homologous to the female {{c2::urethral and paraurethral glands (of Skene)}}, which both arise from the {{c3::urogenital sinus}}
The male {{c1::ventral shaft of penis (penile urethra)}} is homologous to the female {{c2::labia minora}}, which both arise from the {{c3::urogenital folds}}
The male {{c1::scrotum}} is homologous to the female {{c2::labia majora}}, which both arise from the {{c3::labioscrotal swelling}}
{{c1::Hypospadias}} is the abnormal opening of the penile urethra on the {{c2::ventral}} surface of the penis due to failure of urethral folds to fuse
{{c1::Epispadias}} is the abnormal opening of the penile urethra on the {{c2::dorsal}} surface of the penis due to faulty positioning of the genital tubercle

Which congenital penile abnormality (hypospadias or epispadias) is more common?

{{c1::Hypospadias}}
The congenital penile abnormality {{c1::epispadias}} is associated with {{c2::exstrophy of the bladder}}
The congenital penile abnormality {{c1::hypospadias}} is associated with {{c2::inguinal}} hernia and {{c2::cryptorchidism}}

What is the male remnant of the processus vaginalis?

{{c1::Tunica vaginalis}}

What is the female remnant of the processus vaginalis?

{{c1::None (obliterated)}}

What is the male remnant of the gubernaculum?

{{c1::Scrotal ligament (anchors testes within scrotum)}}

What is the female remnant of the gubernaculum?

{{c1::Ovarian ligament + round ligament of uterus::2}}
{{c1::Mittelschmerz}} is transient mid-cycle ovulatory pain that may mimic appendicitis
The {{c1::Apgar score}} is an assessment of newborn vital signs following labor via a 10-point scale evaluated at 1 minute and 5 minutes

What appearance is associated with the following scores using the Apgar score?

0: {{c1::pale or blue}}
1: {{c1::extremities blue}}
2: {{c1::pink}}

What pulse is associated with the following scores using the Apgar score?

0: {{c1::no pulse}}
1: {{c1::pulse <100 bpm}}
2: {{c1::pulse >=100 bpm}}

What grimace is associated with the following scores using the Apgar score?

0: {{c1::no response to stimulation}}
1: {{c1::grimaces or weak cry}}
2: {{c1::cries and pulls away}}

What activity is associated with each of the following scores using the Apgar score?

0: {{c1::no movement}}
1: {{c1::arms, legs flexed}}
2: {{c1::active movement}}

What respiration is associated with the following scores using the Apgar score?

0: {{c1::no breathing}}
1: {{c1::slow, irregular}}
2: {{c1::strong cry}}
If a neonates Apgar score remains low at late time points, there is increased risk the child will develop long-term {{c1::neurologic}} damage
Low birth weight is defined as less than {{c1::2500}} grams (5.5 pounds)
Breastfeeding reduces maternal risk of {{c1::breast}} and {{c1::ovarian}} cancer
Very elevated levels of {{c1::FSH}} is specific for menopause
Menopause is associated with {{c1::increased}} levels of FSH, LH, and GnRH with {{c1::decreased}} levels of estrogen
Menopause before age 40 suggests {{c1::primary ovarian}} insufficiency

The symptoms/complications of menopause may be remembered with the mnemonic "HAVOCS":

H: {{c1::Hot flashes}}, {{c1::Hirsutism}}
AV: {{c2::Atrophy of the Vagina}}
O: {{c3::Osteoporosis}}
C: {{c4::Coronary artery disease}}
S: {{c5::Sleep disturbances}}
The source of {{c1::estrogen}} after menopause becomes peripheral conversion of androgens
Menopause is due to decreased {{c1::estrogen}} production due to age-linked decline in the number of ovarian follicles
{{c1::Estrogen/progesterone}} replacement therapy may be used to minimize the symptoms of menopause
{{c1::Menopause}} is usually preceded by 4-5 years of abnormal menstrual cycles
Menopause is diagnosed by amenorrhea for at least {{c1::12}} months
The {{c1::Tanner}} stages of sexual development are assigned independently to genitalia, pubic hair, and breast
In Tanner stage {{c1::I}}, a person is pre-pubertal (childhood) with no pubic hair and a flat chest
In Tanner stage {{c1::II}}, pubic hair appears (pubarche), breast buds form (thelarche), and testicular enlargement occurs
In Tanner stage {{c1::III}}, the pubic hair coarsens, the penis size increases, and the breast enlarges
In Tanner stage {{c1::IV}}, the penis width and glans increases and the breast enlarges with raised areola
In Tanner stage {{c1::V}} (adulthood) the penis and testis enlarge to adult size and the areola flattens
Condyloma {{c1::acuminata}} is caused by HPV types {{c2::6}} and {{c2::11}}

What are the three areas that HPV most commonly affects in female genital tract?

{{c1::Vulva}}, {{c1::vaginal canal}}, and {{c1::cervix}}
Condyloma {{c1::latum}} is caused by secondary {{c2::syphilis}}
Histologically, HPV-associated condylomas are characterized by {{c1::koilocytes}}
{{c2::Paget}} disease (of the vulva and nipple) is characterized by {{c1::malignant epithelial}} cells in the epidermis
The following image shows large cells in the epidermis with a clear halo, which are characteristic of {{c1::Paget}} disease

What embryological structure is the lower (distal) 2/3rd of the vaginal canal derived from?

{{c1::Urogenital sinus}}
The normal fetal epithelium of the upper 1/3rd of the vaginal canal is {{c1::columnar}} epithelium
Vaginal {{c1::adenosis}} is the focal persistence of {{c2::columnar}} epithelium in the upper 1/3rd of the vagina
Increased incidence of vaginal {{c1::adenosis}} is classically seen in females who were exposed to {{c2::diethylstilbestrol (DES)}} in utero

What type of cancer does vaginal adenosis increase risk for?

{{c1::Clear cell adenocarcinoma}}
{{c1::Clear cell adenocarcinoma}}, a rare complication of diethylstilbestrol, is the malignant proliferation of glands in the vagina with clear cytoplasm
Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, also known as sarcoma botryoides, is a rare malignant mesenchymal proliferation of immature {{c1::skeletal muscle}}
{{c2::Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma}}, also known as {{c3::sarcoma botryoides}}, presents with bleeding and a(n) {{c1::grape}}-like mass protruding from the vagina or penis of a child

What demographic is most commonly associated with embryonal rhabdomysosarcoma (sarcoma botryoides)?

{{c1::Girls < 4 years old}}
The malignant cell of embryonal rhabdomysosarcoma is a(n) {{c1::rhabdomyoblast}}
Rhabdomyoblasts are spindle-shaped cells that sometimes exhibit cytoplasmic {{c1::cross-striations}}
Rhabdomyoblasts are characterized by positive IHC staining for {{c1::desmin}} and {{c1::myogenin}}
Vaginal carcinoma arises from the {{c1::stratified squamous}} epithelium lining the vaginal mucosa

Vaginal carcinoma is usually related to which infectious disease?

{{c1::HPV (high-risk strains)}}

What is the precursor lesion of a vaginal squamous cell carcinoma?

{{c1::Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VAIN)}}
Vaginal squamous cell carcinoma is usually secondary to {{c1::cervical}} SCC
Vaginal carcinoma from the lower 2/3rd of the vagina travels first to the {{c1::inguinal}} nodes
Vaginal carcinoma from the upper 1/3rd of the vagina travels first to the {{c1::iliac}} nodes
The {{c1::transformation zone}} is the squamocolumnar junction between the ectocervix and the endocervix
HPV is a sexually transmitted DNA virus that infects the lower genital tract, especially the cervix at the {{c1::transformation zone}}
Persistent HPV infection leads to risk for cervical dysplasia, also known as {{c1::cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)}}
High-risk HPV strains produce {{c2::E6}} protein, which increases destruction of {{c1::p53}}
High-risk HPV strains produce {{c1::E7}} protein, which increases destruction of {{c2::Rb}}
{{c1::Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)}} is characterized by koilocytic change, nuclear atypia, and increased mitotic activity of cervical epithelium (dysplasia)

What is the extent of epithelial involvement by immature dysplastic cells in cervical carcinoma in situ?

{{c1::the entire thickness of the epithelium}}

What is the percent chance of reversal back to normal cervical epithelium in carcinoma in situ?

{{c1::Not possible}}
Cervical carcinoma may present with abnormal vaginal {{c1::bleeding (often postcoital)}} or cervical discharge

What is the #1 risk factor for cervical carcinoma?

{{c1::Multiple sexual partners}}

Besides for multiple sexual partners, the other major risk factors for cervical carcinoma are:

- deficiency of the {{c1::immune}} system
- infection by high-risk {{c2::HPV}}
- {{c3::tobacco}} use
- {{c4::early}} onset of sexual activity
- lack of {{c5::barrier contraception}}
Cervical carcinoma is an invasive carcinoma that arises from the cervical epithelium and invades through the {{c1::basement membrane}}

What demographic is most commonly associated with cervical carcinoma?

{{c1::Middle-aged women (average age is 40-50 years)::age}}

Which subtype of cervical carcinoma (adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma) is associated with HPV?

{{c1::Both :)}}
The most common type of cervical carcinoma is {{c1::squamous cell carcinoma}} (80%)
The second most common subtype of cervical carcinoma is {{c1::adenocarcinoma}} (15%)
Advanced cervical carcinoma tumors often invade through the anterior uterine wall into the bladder, blocking the {{c1::ureters}}
{{c2::Hydronephrosis}} with {{c1::post-renal failure}} is a common cause of death in advanced {{c3::cervical}} carcinoma in females
Screening for cervical carcinoma is performed via {{c1::pap smears}}
Pap smear screening begins at age {{c1::21}} and are performed every {{c1::three}} year(s)
A pap smear is performed by scraping cells at the {{c1::transformation zone}} of the cervix
High-grade dysplasia on pap smear is characterized by {{c1::dark::color}} nuclei with a(n) {{c1::high}} nuclear:cytoplasmic ratio
An abnormal pap smear is followed by confirmatory {{c1::colposcopy}} (visualization of cervix with a magnifying glass) and {{c1::biopsy}}
One limitation of pap smears is {{c1::inadequate sampling}} of transformation zone resulting in false negative screening
One limitation of pap smears is limited efficacy in screening for {{c1::adenocarcinoma}}

What is the embryonic origin of the posterior pituitary?

{{c1::Neuroectoderm}}

What is the most common cause of hematochezia in adults?

{{c1::Diverticulosis}}
Growth of endometrium is {{c1::estrogen}} driven (proliferative phase)
Preparation of endometrium for implantation is {{c1::progesterone}} driven (secretory phase)
Shedding of the endometrium occurs with loss of {{c1::progesterone}} support (menstrual phase)
{{c1::Asherman}} syndrome is secondary {{c2::amenorrhea}} due to loss and scarring of the {{c3::basalis}} layer of the endometrium
Asherman syndrome is often the result of overaggressive {{c1::dilation and curettage (D&C)}}
Anovulatory cycle is a menstrual cycle that lacks {{c1::ovulation}}
Anovulatory cycle results in an estrogen-driven proliferative phase, but no {{c1::progesterone}}-driven {{c1::secretory}} phase
Anovulatory cycles lead to the break down and shedding of proliferative glands resulting in abnormal {{c1::uterine bleeding}}

When are anovulatory cycles more likely to occur?

{{c1::during menarche and menopause}}
{{c1::Acute endometritis}} is due to a bacterial infection of the endometrium
Acute endometritis is associated with retained products of {{c1::conception}} or foreign bodies
Acute endometritis presents as fever, abnormal {{c1::uterine bleeding}}, and {{c1::pelvic}} pain
{{c1::Chronic endometritis}} is due to chronic inflammation of endometrium
Chronic endometritis is characterized by {{c1::lymphocytes}} and {{c1::plasma cells}} in the endometrium
The histology image below has lymphocytes and plasma cells in the endometrium, which is indicative of {{c1::chronic endometritis}}
Common causes of chronic endometritis include retained products of conception, chronic {{c1::pelvic inflammatory disease}} (e.g. from long-standing chlamydia), IUD, and TB
Chronic endometritis presents with abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, and {{c1::infertility}}
{{c1::Endometrial polyp}} is a well-circumscribed, hyperplastic protrusion of endometrial tissue
Endometrial polyps may be asymptomatic or may present with painless abnormal {{c1::uterine bleeding}}
Endometrial polyps and endometrial hyperplasia can arise as a side effect of the chemotherapeutic drug {{c1::tamoxifen}}
{{c1::Endometriosis}} is the abnormal placement of endometrial {{c2::glands}} and {{c2::stroma}} outside the endometrial lining/cavity
Endometriosis often presents with {{c1::dysmenorrhea}} and cyclic {{c3::pelvic}} pain; it may also cause {{c2::infertility}}

What is the most supported theory for the etiology of endometriosis?

{{c1::Retrograde menstruation}}
One theory behind the etiology of endometriosis is {{c1::metaplastic}} transformation of multipotent cells
One theory behind the etiology of endometriosis is transportation of endometrial tissue via the {{c1::lymphatic}} system

What is the most common site that endometriosis spreads to?

{{c1::Ovary}}

What is the appearance of an ovarian endometrioma?

{{c1::Chocolate cyst (blood-filled)}}
When endometriosis spreads to soft tissue, it appears as "{{c1::gun-powder}} lesions"
Endometriosis spread to the Pouch of Douglas (posterior cul-de-sac) can present with {{c1::dyschezia (pain with defecation)}} and {{c2::painful}} intercourse
Endometriosis spread to the bladder wall presents with {{c1::dysuria}}
Endometriosis spread to the bowel serosa presents with {{c1::abdominal}} pain and adhesions
Endometriosis spread to the fallopian tube mucosa presents with increased risk of {{c1::ectopic tubal}} pregnancy and {{c1::infertility}}
The presence of endometrial tissue (endometriosis) in the uterine myometrium is known as {{c1::adenomyosis}}
Continuous (not pulsatile) {{c1::GnRH}} agonists may be used to treat adenomyosis (endometriosis in the myometrium)
There is an increased risk of {{c1::carcinoma}} at the site of endometriosis, especially in the ovary
{{c1::Endometrial hyperplasia}} is the hyperplasia of endometrial glands relative to the stroma
Endometrial hyperplasia is usually caused by unopposed {{c1::estrogen}}
Endometrial hyperplasia typically presents as {{c1::postmenopausal::pre- or post-menopausal}} uterine bleeding
Endometrial hyperplasia is classified histologically based on {{c1::architectural growth pattern}} (simple or complex) and the presence or absence of {{c1::cellular atypia}}
The most important predictor for endometrial hyperplasia progression to carcinoma is {{c1::cellular atypia}}

Which architectural growth pattern of endometrial hyperplasia has higher risk of progression to carcinoma?

{{c1::Complex::simple or complex}}
Endometrial hyperplasia has increased risk for progression to endometrial {{c1::carcinoma}}

What is the most common invasive (malignant) carcinoma of the female genital tract?

{{c1::Endometrial carcinoma}}
In the {{c1::hyperplasia}} pathway (75%) of endometrial carcinoma, the carcinoma arises from {{c2::endometrial hyperplasia}}
In the {{c1::sporadic}} pathway (25%) of endometrial carcinoma, the carcinoma arises in an atrophic endometrium with no precursor lesion
{{c1::Endometrial carcinoma}} is a malignant proliferation of endometrial glands
Endometrial carcinoma often presents as {{c1::post}}-menopausal bleeding
Endometrial carcinoma arises via two distinct pathways: {{c1::hyperplasia}} and {{c1::sporadic}}
Endometrial carcinoma from the {{c2::hyperplasia}} pathway has a(n) {{c1::endometrioid}} histology
Endometrial carcinoma from the {{c2::sporadic}} pathway has a(n) {{c1::serous, papillary}} histology
The average age of presentation of endometrial carcinoma from the hyperplasia pathway is {{c1::60}} years old
The average age of presentation for endometrial carcinoma from the sporadic pathway is {{c1::70}} years old

What mutation is common in endometrial carcinoma from the sporadic pathway?

{{c1::p53 mutations}}

What is a possible histological finding of serous, papillary endometrial carcinoma (sporadic pathway)?

{{c1::Psammoma bodies (concentric spherules with dystrophic calcification)}}
Risk factors of endometrial carcinoma from the hyperplasia pathway are related to {{c1::estrogen}} exposure

Which autosomal dominant syndrome is associated with increased risk for colon, ovarian, and endometrial carcinoma?

{{c1::Lynch syndrome (HNPCC)}}

What is the most common tumor in females?

{{c1::Leiomyoma (fibroid)}}

What demographic has increased incidence of leiomyoma (fibroid)?

{{c1::African Americans (peak occurrence 20-40 years old)}}
{{c1::Leiomyoma (uterine fibroid)}} is a benign neoplastic proliferation of smooth muscle arising from myometrium
Leiomyoma (fibroid) is related to {{c1::estrogen}} exposure
Leiomyomas (fibroids) increase with {{c1::pregnancy}} (increased estrogen) and decrease with {{c1::menopause}} (decreased estrogen)
Gross examination of {{c1::leiomyoma (fibroid)}} shows multiple, well-defined, white, whorled masses that may distort the uterus and impinge on pelvic structures
The histology image shows a whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles with well-dermarcated borders, which is characteristic of {{c1::leiomyoma (fibroid)}}

What is the most common symptom of leiomyoma (fibroids)?

{{c1::Nothing (asymptomatic)>Heavy menstrual bleeding (when symptomatic)}}
Severe bleeding from leiomyoma (fibroid) may lead to {{c1::iron deficiency anemia}}
{{c1::Leiomyosarcoma}} is a malignant proliferation of smooth muscle arising from the myometrium

What is the precursor lesion for leiomyosarcoma?

{{c1::None -- arises de novo; leiomyosarcomas do not arise from leiomyomas***}}
Gross exam of {{c1::leiomyosarcoma}} often shows a uterus with a single lesion with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage
An ovarian follicle consists of an oocyte surrounded by {{c1::granulosa}} and {{c1::theca}} cells
Hemorrhage into a corpus luteum can result in a(n) {{c1::hemorrhagic corpus luteal cyst}}, especially during early pregnancy
Degeneration of ovarian follicles may result in follicular {{c1::cysts}}
{{c1::Polycystic ovarian syndrome (Stein-Leventhal syndrome)::fancy name}} is multiple follicular cysts in the ovary and anovulation due to hormone imbalance
Polycystic ovarian syndrome is characterized by {{c1::high::high/low}} LH and {{c1::low::high/low}} FSH
Polycystic ovarian syndrome often has a LH:FSH ratio {{c1::>2}}
In polycystic ovarian syndrome, increased {{c1::LH}} production causes excess {{c2::androgen}} production (from theca cells), resulting in {{c3::hirsutism}}
In polycystic ovarian syndrome, excess androgen (from theca cells) is converted to {{c1::estrone}} in {{c2::adipose}} tissue, which inhibits {{c3::FSH}} secretion from anterior pituitary

What demographic is most commonly affected by polycystic ovarian syndrome (Stein-Leventhal syndrome)?

{{c1::Obese, young women}}

Polycystic ovarian syndrome is a condition characterized by at least 2/3 of the following criteria:

- clinical signs of {{c1::hyperandrogenism}}
- {{c3::irregular periods (typically oligomenorrhea)::menstrual finding}}
- {{c2::polycystic ovaries}} on ultrasound
Polycystic ovarian syndrome is associated with {{c1::insulin resistance}}, which may cause {{c1::type II diabetes mellitus}} 10-15 years later
Patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome have increased risk of {{c1::endometrial}} carcinoma, secondary to unopposed effects of estrogen
{{c1::Polycystic ovarian syndrome}} presents with enlarged, bilateral cystic ovaries
{{c1::Follicular}} cyst is the most common ovarian mass in young women
A(n) {{c1::follicular}} cyst is a distention of an unruptured graafian follicle

Ovarian tumors may arise from three different cell types:

1. {{c1::surface epithelium}}
2. {{c1::germ cells}} (e.g. oocyte)
3. {{c1::sex cord stromal tissue}} (e.g. granulosa & theca cells)
{{c1::Surface epithelial}} tumor is the most common class of ovarian tumor (70%)
Surface epithelial tumors of the ovary are derived from the {{c1::coelomic}} epithelium that lines the ovary (embryologically)
The two most common subtypes of ovarian surface epithelial tumors are {{c1::serous}} and {{c1::mucinous}}; both usually cystic
Ovarian {{c1::cystadenoma}} is a benign tumor composed of a single cyst with a simple, flat lining of epithelial cells
Ovarian cystadenomas (surface epithelial tumors) most commonly arise in women aged {{c1::30-40}} years old

What is the most common benign ovarian tumor?

{{c1::Serous cystadenoma}}
{{c1::Serous}} cystadenoma is a benign tumor lined with fallopian tube-like epithelium; often bilateral
Ovarian {{c1::mucinous}} cystadenoma is a large, multiloculated benign tumor lined by mucus-secreting epithelium
Ovarian {{c1::cystadenocarcinoma}} is a malignant tumor composed of complex cysts with a shaggy lining of epithelium and invasion into the connective tissue
Ovarian adenocarcinomas (surface epithelial tumor) most commonly arise in women aged {{c1::60-70}} years old
{{c1::Borderline}} tumors have features in between benign and malignant
Borderline tumors have {{c1::better}} prognosis than clearly malignant tumors, but still carry {{c1::metastatic}} potential
{{c1::BRCA1}} mutation carriers have increased risk for {{c2::serous}} adenocarcinoma of the {{c3::ovary}} and {{c3::fallopian tube}}

What is the most common malignant ovarian neoplasm?

{{c1::Serous cystadenocarcinoma}}

{{c1::Mucinous}} cystadenocarcinoma may present with {{c2::pseudomyxoma peritonei}}, which is an intraperitoneal accumulation of {{c1::mucinous}} material, usually from a GI, ovarian, appendiceal tumor
One type of a rare ovarian surface epithelial tumor is a(n) {{c1::endometrioid}} tumor, which is composed of endometrial-like glands and is usually malignant
{{c1::15}}% of ovarian endometrioid tumors are associated with an independent endometrial carcinoma
One type of a rare ovarian surface epithelial tumor is a(n) {{c1::Brenner}} tumor, which is composed of bladder-like epithelium ({{c2::urothelium}})
Brenner tumors are solid, encapsulated tumors with a yellow-tan appearance; they have "{{c1::Coffee bean}}" nuclei on H&E stain
Ovarian surface epithelial tumors typically present {{c1::late}} and therefore have {{c1::poor}} prognosis
Ovarian surface epithelial tumors typically present with vague {{c1::abdominal}} symptoms (e.g. pain, fullness) and signs of {{c1::compression}} (e.g. urinary frequency)

What serum tumor marker is useful for monitoring treatment response and recurrence of ovarian neoplasms?

{{c1::CA-125}}
{{c1::Germ cell}} tumors are the second most common class of ovarian tumor (15%)

What demographic is most commonly affected by ovarian germ cell tumors?

{{c1::Women of reproductive age (15-30 years old)::age}}
{{c1::Cystic teratoma}} is a cystic tumor composed of fetal tissue derived from two or three embryologic layers (e.g. hair, teeth, bone, skin, gut, thyroid, etc)

What is the most common germ cell tumor in females?

{{c1::Cystic teratoma}}

What is the malignant potential of a mature cystic teratoma in females?

{{c1::Benign}}

What is the malignant potential of an immature cystic teratoma?

{{c1::Malignancy possible}}

What type of fetal tissue is most commonly seen in an immature teratoma?

{{c1::Neuroectoderm}}
In addition to immature tissue, cystic teratomas may become malignant via {{c1::somatic}} malignancy

What is the most common somatic malignancy stemming from a cystic teratoma?

{{c1::Squamous cell carcinoma of skin}}
{{c1::Struma ovarii}} is a cystic teratoma composed primarily of {{c2::thyroid}} tissue and thus may cause {{c2::hyperthyroidism}}

What is the most common malignant germ cell tumor in females?

{{c1::Dysgerminoma}}
A(n) {{c2::dysgerminoma}} is an ovarian germ cell tumor composed of large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei; described as "{{c1::fried egg}}" cells
Dysgerminoma is equivalent to its male testicular counterpart, termed a(n) {{c1::seminoma}}
Dysgerminoma has a(n) {{c1::good}} prognosis

What serum markers may be elevated in dysgerminoma?

{{c1::LDH and hCG::2}}

What demographic is most commonly associated with dysgerminoma?

{{c1::Adolescent females}}

What is the most common germ cell tumor in children (esp. male infants)?

{{c1::Endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumor}}
{{c1::Endodermal sinus (yolk sac)}} tumor is a malignant tumor that mimics the yolk sac

What serum marker is characteristically elevated in endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumor?

{{c1::Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)}}

Endodermal sinus tumors are characterized by what histological finding (50%)?

{{c1::Schiller-Duval bodies (glomeruloid-like structures)}}
{{c1::Choriocarcinoma}} is a malignant germ cell tumor composed of mononuclear {{c2::cytotrophoblasts}} and multinuclear {{c2::syncytiotrophoblasts}}, but with absent {{c3::villi}}
Choriocarcinoma is a small, hemorrhagic tumor with early, diffuse {{c1::hematogenous}} spread, especially to the {{c1::lungs}}

What serum marker is characteristically elevated in choriocarcinoma?

{{c1::hCG (produced by syncytiotrophoblasts)}}

Choriocarcinoma is associated with which type of ovarian cyst?

{{c1::Theca-lutein cyst}}
{{c1::Embryonal}} carcinoma is a malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary or testis composed of large primitive cells

What is the most common malignant ovarian sex cord stromal tumor?

{{c1::Granulosa cell tumor}}
{{c1::Granulosa}} cell tumor is an ovarian sex cord stromal tumor that often produces {{c2::estrogen}} and {{c2::inhibin}}
Granulosa cell tumor predominantly affects women in their {{c1::50s::age}}

Histologically, {{c2::granulosa}} cell tumors are characterized by {{c1::Call-Exner}} bodies, which are {{c2::granulosa}} cells arranged in follicle / rosette-like collections around eosinophilic fluid, resembling primordial follicles
{{c1::Thecoma}} is a sex cord stromal tumor that, similarly to granulosa cell tumors, may produce estrogen
Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor is a rare ovarian sex cord-stromal cell tumor that may produce androgens, thus causing {{c1::hirsutism/virilization}} in women
{{c1::Fibromas}} are benign sex cord stromal tumors of fibroblasts (bundles of spindle-shaped cells)
{{c1::Meigs}} syndrome is a triad of {{c2::ovarian fibroma}}, {{c2::ascites}}, and {{c2::hydrothorax (pleural effusion)}}
{{c1::Fibroma}} is an ovarian sex cord stromal tumor that may present with a "pulling" sensation in the groin
Primary mucinous tumors of the ovary (e.g. surface epithelial tumor) are usually {{c1::unilateral::unilateral/bilateral}}, where as Krukenberg tumors are usually {{c1::bilateral}}
{{c1::Pseudomyxoma peritonei}} is massive amounts of mucus in the peritoneum

Which ovarian neoplasm is characterized histologically by Schiller-Duval bodies (glomeruloid-like structures)?

{{c1::Endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumor}}

What is the most common site for an ectopic pregnancy? (specific)

{{c1::Ampulla of the fallopian tube}}
Ectopic pregnancy is often clinically mistaken for {{c1::appendicitis}}
{{c1::Ectopic pregnancy}} is the implantation of a fertilized ovum at a site other than uterine wall
The key risk factor for ectopic pregnancy is {{c1::tubal scarring}}
The classic presentation of ectopic pregnancy is {{c1::lower quadrant abdominal}} pain weeks after a missed period (amenorrhea)
Ectopic pregnancy may present with a(n) {{c2::lower}} than expected rise in the hormone {{c1::hCG}} based on dates
Major complications of ectopic pregnancy are {{c1::hematosalpinx (bleeding into the fallopian tube)}} and/or {{c1::rupture}}
Spontaneous abortion is the miscarriage of a fetus before {{c1::20}} weeks gestation
Spontaneous abortion is common and occurs in up to {{c1::1/4}} of recognizable pregnancies
{{c1::Spontaneous abortion}} presents as vaginal bleeding, cramp-like pain, and passage of fetal tissues
Spontaneous abortion is most often due to {{c1::chromosomal}} anomalies, especially {{c1::trisomy 16}}
Spontaneous abortion is more common in patients in a(n) {{c1::hypercoagulable}} state, such as those with antiphospholipid syndrome

What is most commonly the effect of teratogens during the first two weeks of gestation?

{{c1::Spontaneous abortion}}

What is most commonly the effect of teratogens during the weeks 3-8 of gestation?

{{c1::Organ malformation}}

What is most commonly the effect of teratogens after week 8 of gestation?

{{c1::Organ hypoplasia}}
Placenta {{c1::previa}} is attachment of the placenta to the lower uterine segment over (or < 2 cm from) the {{c2::internal cervical os}}
Placenta previa presents with painless {{c1::third}} trimester {{c2::bleeding}}
Risk factors for placenta previa include {{c1::multiparity}} and prior {{c1::C-section}}
Placental {{c1::abruption}} is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall (decidua) prior to delivery of fetus
Placental abruption may cause fetal distress and thus a(n) {{c1::still birth}}
Placental abruption typically presents with abrupt, {{c3::painful}} {{c2::third}} trimester {{c1::bleeding}}
Placenta {{c1::accreta}} is the abnormal attachment of the placenta to the myometrium, without penetrating it
Placenta {{c1::increta}} is the abnormal penetration of the placenta into the myometrium
Placenta {{c1::percreta}} is the abnormal penetration of the placenta through the myometrium and into the uterine serosa
Placenta accreta (or increta/percreta) presents with no separation of the placenta after delivery and {{c1::heavy post-partum bleeding}}
Placenta accreta often requires {{c1::hysterectomy}} after delivery due to attachment of the placenta to the uterus
{{c1::Gestational hypertension}} is a blood pressure >140/90 mmHg after the 20th week of gestation with no proteinuria, pre-existing hypertension, nor end-organ damage
{{c1::Preeclampsia}} is pregnancy-induced {{c2::hypertension}} with {{c3::proteinuria}} or {{c3::end-organ dysfunction}} after 20th week of gestation
Preeclampsia typically presents {{c1::after}} the 20th week of gestation
Preeclampsia is caused by abnormal placental {{c1::spiral}} arteries, causing endothelial dysfunction, vasoconstriction, and ischemia
There is an increased incidence of preeclampsia in patients with pre-existing {{c1::hypertension}}, diabetes, chronic renal disease, and autoimmune disorders
{{c1::Eclampsia}} is defined as preeclampsia with {{c2::seizures}}
{{c2::HELLP}} syndrome is a manifestation of severe {{c1::preeclampsia}} that presents with {{c3::hemolysis}}, {{c3::elevated liver enzymes}}, and {{c3::low platelets}}

What finding on blood smear is characteristic of HELLP syndrome?

{{c1::Schistocytes (due to thrombotic microangiopathy)}}
HELLP syndrome can lead to hepatic subcapsular {{c1::hematomas}}, which may rupture leading to severe hypotension
Eclampsia and HELLP syndrome both warrant immediate {{c1::delivery of the baby}}
{{c1::Sudden Infant Death Syndrome}} is the death of a healthy infant (1 month to 1 year old) without obvious cause
Risk factors of sudden infant death syndrome include sleeping on the {{c1::stomach}}, exposure to {{c1::cigarette smoke}}, and prematurity
{{c2::Hydatidiform mole}} is an abnormal conception characterized by swollen and edematous chorionic {{c1::villi}} with proliferation of {{c1::trophoblasts only}}
Hydatidiform mole presents with uterine {{c1::enlargement}} more than expected for the date of gestation
Hydatidiform mole presents with {{c1::higher}} levels of hCG than expected for the date of gestation
In areas with no prenatal care, a hydatidiform mole presents in the 2nd trimester with {{c1::passage of grape-like masses (large, edematous villi) through the vaginal canal}}
In areas with prenatal care, hydatidiform mole is diagnosed by routine {{c1::ultrasound}} early in the first trimester
A hydatidiform mole may be detected via the absence of fetal {{c1::heart}} sounds
Hydatidiform mole presents with a {{c1::snow-storm}} appearance on ultrasound
A(n) {{c1::complete}} hydatidiform mole is characterized by {{c2::46}} chromosomes
A(n) {{c1::partial}} hydatidiform mole is characterized by {{c2::69}} chromosomes
A(n) {{c1::partial}} hydatidiform mole most commonly consists of {{c2::2}} sperm with {{c2::1}} egg
A(n) {{c1::complete}} hydatidiform mole most commonly consists of {{c2::1}} sperm that {{c2::duplicates}} within a(n) {{c2::enucleated}} egg (85%, karyotype 46, XX)
A(n) {{c1::partial}} hydatidiform mole contains fetal tissue
A(n) {{c1::complete}} hydatidiform mole does not contain fetal tissue
A(n) {{c1::complete}} hydatidiform mole is more commonly associated with increased uterine size
A(n) {{c1::complete}} hydatidiform mole is associated with {{c2::very}} increased levels of hCG
A(n) {{c1::partial}} hydatidiform mole is associated with {{c2::mildly}} increased levels of hCG
A(n) {{c1::complete}} hydatidiform mole is associated with increased risk of choriocarcinoma
A(n) {{c1::partial}} hydatidiform mole is associated with very little increased risk of choriocarcinoma
In a(n) {{c1::partial}} hydatidiform mole, only some villi are hydropic, and there is only partial trophoblastic proliferation around the vili
In a(n) {{c1::complete}} hydatidiform mole, most villi are hydropic and there is circumferential trophoblastic proliferation around the villi

What is the treatment for a hydatidiform mole?

{{c1::Dilatation and curettage}}
After a hydatidiform mole, patients should monitor {{c1::hCG}} levels to ensure adequate mole removal and to screen for development of {{c2::choriocarcinoma}}
Early hypertension during pregnancy (before 20 weeks) is associated with a(n) {{c1::hydatidiform mole}}

What type of ovarian cyst is associated with a hydatidiform mole?

{{c1::Theca-lutein cysts}}
Choriocarcinoma in females may arise as a complication of {{c1::gestation}} or as a spontaneous {{c2::germ cell tumor}}
Choriocarcinoma that arises as a(n) {{c1::spontaneous germ cell tumor}} has a(n) {{c2::poor}} response to chemotherapy
Choriocarcinoma that arises from {{c1::gestation}} has a(n) {{c2::very good}} response to chemotherapy

What chemotherapeutic drug is used in the treatment of a hydatidiform mole if hCG levels remain elevated after D&C?

{{c1::Methotrexate}}
Hypospadias is due to failure of {{c1::urethral folds}} to close
Epispadias is due to abnormal positioning of the {{c1::genital tubercle}} in men
Penile squamous cell carcinoma is associated with a lack of {{c1::circumcision (foreskin can act as a nidus)}}
One precursor lesion of {{c1::penile SCC}} is {{c3::Bowen disease}}, which is the in situ carcinoma of the penile {{c2::shaft}} or scrotum that presents as {{c2::leukoplakia}}
One precursor lesion of {{c1::penile SCC}} is {{c3::Erythroplasia of Queyrat}}, which is the in situ carcinoma of the {{c2::glans}} of the penis that presents as {{c2::erythroplakia}}
One precursor lesion of {{c1::penile SCC}} is {{c3::Bowenoid papulosis}}, which is an in situ carcinoma of the penis that presents as {{c2::reddish papules}}
{{c1::Peyronie}} disease is the abnormal {{c2::curvature}} of the penis due to fibrous plaque within the tunica albuginea
Peyronie disease is associated with {{c1::erectile}} dysfunction
{{c1::Ischemic priapism}} is a painful sustained {{c2::erection}} lasting >{{c3::4}} hours

What blood disorder is associated with ischemic priapism?

{{c1::Sickle cell anemia (sickled RBCs get trapped in vascular channels)}}
{{c1::Cryptorchidism}} is the failure of the testicle to descend into the scrotal sac

What is the most common congenital male reproductive abnormality?

{{c1::Cryptorchidism}}

What is the effect of cryptorchidism on fertility? Why?

{{c1::Decreased; spermatogenesis is impaired due to increased temperature of testis}}

Cryptorchidism increases risk for which class of testicular tumor?

{{c1::Germ cells tumors, especially seminoma}}

What is the effect of cryptorchidism on inhibin B levels?

{{c1::Decreased (due to decreased Sertoli cell activity)}}

What is the effect of cryptorchidism on FSH levels?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the effect of bilateral cryptorchidism on testosterone levels?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What is a possible viral cause of orchitis in teenage males?

{{c1::Mumps virus}}
{{c1::Testicular torsion}} occurs due to twisting of the spermatic cord over thin-walled veins of the scrotum
Testicular torsion causes {{c1::hemorrhagic}} infarction of the testicle
{{c2::Testicular torsion}} commonly presents in 12-18 year olds with sudden testicular pain, {{c3::high-riding}} testis, and absent {{c1::cremasteric reflex}}
{{c1::Varicocele}} is caused by dilated veins in the pampiniform plexus due to increased venous pressure

What is the most common cause of scrotal enlargement in adult males?

{{c1::Varicocele}}
{{c2::Varicocele}} presents as scrotal swelling with a palpable "{{c1::bag of worms}}" while standing
Varicocele most commonly occurs on the {{c1::left}} side of the body
Varicocele is associated with left-sided {{c1::renal cell}} carcinoma

What is the effect of varicocele on fertility?

{{c1::Decreased}}

Does a varicocele transilluminate?

{{c1::No}}

What imaging technique may be used to diagnose a varicocele?

{{c1::Ultrasound with Doppler}}
{{c2::Hydrocele}} is due to accumulation of fluid within the {{c1::tunica vaginalis}} surrounding the testis
Congenital hydrocele ("communicating hydrocele") occurs due to incomplete obliteration of the {{c1::processus vaginalis}} (infants)

Does a hydrocele transilluminate?

{{c1::Yes}}
A(n) {{c1::spermatocele}} is a scrotal cyst due to a dilated epididymal duct or rete testis
Testicular tumors may arise from either {{c1::germ cells}} or {{c1::sex-cord stroma}}
Testicular tumors present as a firm, painless testicular mass that {{c1::cannot}} be transilluminated

Are testicular tumors biopsied? Why or why not?

{{c1::No; increased risk of seeding the scrotum}}

What is the most common class of testicular tumor (>95%)?

{{c1::Germ cell tumors}}

What is the most common testicular tumor?

{{c1::Seminoma}}

What age group is associated with testicular germ cell tumors?

{{c1::Men 15-40 years of age}}
Risk factors for testicular germ cell tumor include {{c1::cryptorchidism}} and {{c1::Klinefelter syndrome}}
Testicular germ cell tumors that are {{c2::seminomas}} (55%) are {{c1::very}} responsive to radiotherapy, metastasize {{c1::late}}, and have {{c1::excellent}} prognosis
{{c1::Seminoma}} is a malignant testicular tumor comprised of large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei, sometimes described as a "fried egg" appearance
{{c1::Seminoma}} is a testicular germ cell tumor that forms a homogenous mass with no hemorrhage or necrosis
In rare cases, seminomas may have elevated levels of the hormone {{c1::hCG}}
Seminomas are associated with increased levels of placental {{c1::ALP}}
{{c1::Embryonal carcinoma}} is a testicular germ cell tumor that forms a hemorrhagic mass with necrosis

What is the most common testicular tumor in children (< 3 years old)?

{{c1::Yolk sac (endodermal sinus) tumor}}

Which testicular neoplasm is characterized histologically by Schiller-Duval bodies (glomeruloid-like structures)?

{{c1::Endodermal sinus (yolk sac) tumor}}
Elevated levels of hCG (e.g. choriocarcinoma) may cause {{c1::gynecomastia}} (males) or {{c3::hyperthyroidism}} due to homology between hCG and {{c2::TSH}}, {{c2::FSH}}, and {{c2::LH}}
Testicular germ cell tumors often present as a(n) {{c1::mixed}} germ cell tumor; prognosis is based on the {{c1::worst}} component
Testicular sex cord-stromal tumors are composed of Sertoli cells and/or Leydig cells and are usually {{c1::benign::benign or malignant}}
{{c1::Leydig cell}} tumors are testicular sex cord stromal tumors that produce {{c3::estrogens}} or {{c3::androgens}}, causing {{c2::gynecomastia}} (men) or {{c2::precocious puberty}} (boys)
{{c2::Leydig cell}} tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor associated with characteristic {{c1::Reinke crystals}} (eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion) on histology
{{c1::Sertoli cell}} tumor is a testicular sex cord stromal tumor comprised of tubules, usually clinically silent

What is the most common cause of testicular cancer in older men (>60)?

{{c1::Lymphoma}}

What type of lymphoma is usually the cause of testicular cancer in older men?

{{c1::diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (aggressive)}}
The {{c1::posterior}} aspect of prostate is palpable by digital rectal exam (DRE)
Common infectious causes of acute prostatitis in young adults include {{c1::Chlamydia trachomatis (D-K)}} and {{c1::Neisseria gonorrhoeae}}
Common infectious causes of acute prostatitis in older adults include {{c1::E. coli}} and {{c1::Pseudomonas}}
Acute prostatitis often presents with {{c1::dysuria}} and fever/chills
A patient with acute prostatitis may have a tender, {{c1::boggy}} prostate on DRE
Prostatic secretions of a patient with {{c2::acute}} prostatitis often contain WBCs with culture showing {{c1::bacteria}}
