Prostatic secretions of a patient with {{c2::chronic}} prostatitis often contain WBCs with culture showing {{c1::no bacteria}}
Chronic prostatitis presents as dysuria with pelvic or {{c1::low back}} pain
{{c1::Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)}} is the age-related hyperplasia of prostatic stroma and glands

Does benign prostatic hyperplasia increase risk of cancer?

{{c1::No}}
Benign prostatic hyperplasia most commonly occurs in the {{c1::periurethral zone (middle/lateral lobes)}} of the prostate
Benign prostatic hyperplasia may present with problems starting and stopping {{c1::urination}}
Benign prostatic hyperplasia may present with impaired {{c1::bladder}} emptying
One possible complication of benign prostatic hyperplasia is {{c1::hydronephrosis}}, due to backup of fluid into the kidney
Benign prostatic hyperplasia may be treated with a(n) {{c1::selective α1A,D}} antagonist such as tamsulosin
{{c1::Prostate adenocarcinoma}} is the malignant proliferation of prostatic glands

Which form of cancer is the 2nd most common cause of cancer death in men?

{{c1::Prostate cancer}}

What ethnicity is associated with increased risk for prostate adenocarcinoma?

{{c1::African Americans > Caucasians > Asians}}
Prostatic adenocarcinoma most commonly occurs in the {{c1::posterior periphery}} of the prostate
Screening for prostatic adenocarcinoma begins at 50 with {{c1::digital rectal exam}} and {{c1::PSA}}
PSA > {{c1::10}} ng/dl is worrisome at any age and may be indicative of prostatic adenocarcinoma

A decreased % of which form of PSA is suggestive of prostatic adenocarcinoma?

{{c1::Free-PSA (cancer makes bound-PSA)}}
A(n) {{c1::prostatic biopsy}} is required to confirm the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma (cannot use PSA levels alone)
Prostatic adenocarcinoma may be graded using the {{c1::Gleason}} grading system
A higher score using the Gleason grading system (for prostatic adenocarcinoma) is associated with a(n) {{c1::worse}} prognosis

Which serum marker may be elevated due to metastasis of prostatic adenocarcinoma to bone?

{{c1::Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)}}
Prostatic adenocarcinoma often has {{c1::osteoblastic::type}} metastases, which is indicated by {{c2::lower back}} pain
If prostatic adenocarcinoma has not metastasized (i.e. local disease), it may be treated with {{c1::prostatectomy}}
Prostatic adenocarcinoma may be treated with {{c1::GnRH}} analogs (e.g. leuprolide) and/or {{c1::androgen}} receptor inhibitors (e.g. flutamide)
Breast tissue is a modified {{c1::sweat gland}} that is embryologically derived from skin
Breast tissue can develop anywhere along the {{c1::milk line}}, which runs from the axilla to the vulva (e.g. supernumerary nipples)
The {{c1::terminal duct-lobular unit (TDLU)}} is the functional unit of the breast; lobules make milk that drains via ducts to nipple
The lobules and ducts of breast tissue are lined by {{c1::two::#}} layers of epithelium
The inner cell layer of breast tissue is the {{c1::luminal (epithelial)}} cell layer
The luminal (epithelial) cell layer of breast tissue is responsible for {{c1::milk production}} in the lobules
The outer cell layer of breast is the {{c1::myoepithelial}} cell layer
The myoepithelial cell layer of breast tissue is responsible for {{c1::propelling milk}} towards the nipple
During pregnancy, breast lobules undergo {{c1::hyperplasia}}
After menopause, breast tissue undergoes {{c1::atrophy}}
Lobules and small ducts of breast tissue are present in highest density in the {{c1::upper outer}} quadrant
{{c1::Galactorrhea}} refers to milk production outside of lactation

Is galactorrhea a symptom of breast cancer?

{{c1::No!}}
{{c1::Acute (lactational) mastitis}} is due to a bacterial infection of breast, usually {{c2::Staphylococcus aureus}}
Acute (lactational) mastitis is associated with {{c1::breast feeding}}
Acute (lactational) mastitis presents as a warm, erythematous breast with {{c1::purulent}} nipple discharge
Treatment for acute (lactational) mastitis is {{c1::continued drainage (e.g. feeding)}} plus {{c1::antibiotics (e.g. dicloxacillin)}}
{{c1::Periductal}} mastitis is inflammation of subareolar ducts
Periductal mastitis is usually seen in {{c1::smokers}}
Periductal mastitis occurs due to a relative vitamin {{c1::A}} deficiency, which results in {{c2::squamous}} metaplasia of lactiferous ducts
Periductal mastitis presents as a subareolar mass with {{c1::nipple retraction}} due to pull from myofibroblasts during healing
Mammary duct {{c1::ectasia}} is inflammation with {{c2::dilation}} of the subareolar duct
{{c2::Mammary duct ectasia}} presents with a periareolar {{c1::green-brown}} nipple discharge (inflammatory debris)
Mammary duct ectasia is associated with chronic inflammation with {{c1::plasma}} cells seen on biopsy
Mammary duct ectasia classically arises in {{c1::multiparous}} (parity), {{c1::post}}-menopausal women
Fat necrosis of breast tissue is usually related to {{c1::trauma}}, but a history of such is not always reported
Fat necrosis of breast tissue presents as a painless {{c1::mass}} on physical exam
Fat necrosis of breast tissue presents as a(n) {{c1::calcified oil cyst::specific}} on mammography
Biopsy of breast tissue with fat necrosis shows necrotic fat with associated calcifications and {{c1::giant}} cells
{{c1::Fibrocystic changes}} are the most common changes in {{c2::pre}}-menopausal breast
Fibrocystic change presents as a {{c1::lumpy}} breast that may be painful
Fibrocystic change of the breast presents as cysts with a(n) {{c1::blue-domed}} appearance on gross exam
Fibrocystic changes of the breast generally are {{c1::benign::benign or malignant}}
Some fibrocystic-related changes carry increased risk for invasive carcinoma, which applies to {{c1::both}} breast(s)

What is the relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma with fibrosis and cysts (fibrocystic changes)?

{{c1::No increased risk}}

What is the relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma with apocrine metaplasia (fibrocystic changes)?

{{c1::No increased risk**}}
{{c1::Sclerosing adenosis}} is an increase in acini (ducts) and stromal fibrosis of breast tissue, which may be seen as {{c2::calcifications}} on mammogram

What is the relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma with sclerosing adenosis (fibrocystic changes)?

{{c1::1.5-2x increased risk}}
Epithelial/ductal {{c1::hyperplasia}} is an increased number of cells in the terminal ductal or lobular epithelium of the breast

What is the relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma with epithelial hyperplasia (fibrocystic changes)?

{{c1::1.5-2x increased risk}}

What is the relative risk of developing invasive breast carcinoma with atypical epithelial hyperplasia (fibrocystic changes)?

{{c1::5x increased risk}}
{{c1::Intraductal papilloma}} is a small papillary proliferation within {{c2::lactiferous}} ducts, typically beneath the areola of the breast

Which type(s) of cells line the fibrovascular projections of an intraductal papilloma of the breast?

{{c1::Both epithelial (luminal) and myoepithelial cells}}
Intraductal papilloma of the breast typically presents as a(n) {{c1::bloody}} nipple discharge in a(n) {{c1::pre}}-menopausal woman

What is the most common cause of nipple discharge (serous or bloody)?

{{c1::Intraductal papilloma (often bloody)}}

Which type(s) of cells line the fibrovascular projections of a papillary carcinoma of the breast?

{{c1::Only epithelial cells; no myoepithelial cells}}
Papillary carcinoma of the breast typically presents as a(n) {{c1::bloody}} nipple discharge in a(n) {{c1::post}}-menopausal woman
{{c1::Fibroadenoma}} is a benign small, well-defined mobile breast mass composed of fibrous tissue and glands

What is the most common benign neoplasm of breast?

{{c1::Fibroadenoma}}
Fibroadenoma is most common in women {{c1::under}} 35 years old
Size and tenderness of a fibroadenoma of the breast increases with exposure to {{c1::estrogen}}

Does fibroadenoma increase risk of breast cancer?

{{c1::No (benign)}}
{{c1::Phyllodes}} tumor is a fibroadenoma-like tumor with overgrowth of the fibrous component, causing {{c2::leaf-like}} projections
Phyllodes tumor is most commonly seen in {{c2::post}}-menopausal women

Can Phyllodes tumor increase risk of breast cancer?

{{c1::Yes, some may be malignant}}
Malignant breast tumors most commonly occur in {{c1::post}}-menopausal women

What is the most common location for an invasive breast tumor?

{{c1::Upper-outer quadrant of the breast}}
Risk factors for developing breast cancer are generally associated with increased {{c1::estrogen}} exposure
Increased risk of developing breast cancer is associated with a(n) {{c1::older::younger/older}} age at first live birth

What is the effect of obesity on risk of developing breast cancer? Why?

{{c1::Increased, due to increased estrone production from adipose tissue}}
Increased risk for breast carcinoma is associated with {{c1::early}} menarche and {{c1::late}} menopause
{{c1::Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)}} is the malignant proliferation of cells in the ducts of the breast with {{c2::no invasion}} of the basement membrane
Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is detected as {{c1::microcalcifications}} on mammography
Mammographic calcifications can be associated with benign conditions such as {{c1::sclerosing adenosis}} (fibrocystic change) and {{c1::fat necrosis}}

{{c1::Comedocarcinoma}} is a subtype of DCIS (breast) that is characterized by high-grade cells with {{c2::dystrophic calcification}} in the center of ducts immediately surrounded by central {{c2::necrosis}}
{{c1::Pagets}} disease is ductal carcinoma in situ that extends up the ducts to the skin of the nipple
Pagets disease (of the nipple) presents as nipple {{c1::ulceration}} and {{c1::erythema}}
Pagets disease of the nipple is almost always associated with an underlying {{c1::carcinoma (e.g. DCIS)}}
The following image shows malignant epithelial cells in the epidermis of the nipple, which is representative of {{c1::Pagets disease}}

What is the most common type of breast cancer?

{{c1::Invasive ductal carcinoma (~75% of all breast cancers)}}
Invasive ductal carcinoma presents on physical exam with a firm, fibrous "{{c1::rock-hard}}" mass with sharp margins
Invasive ductal carcinoma classically forms {{c1::duct}}-like structures
Invasive ductal carcinoma presents as mass detected by {{c1::physical exam}} (> 2cm) or {{c1::mammography}} (> 1cm)
Invasive ductal carcinoma may present, grossly, with classic "{{c1::stellate}}" infiltration
Advanced invasive ductal carcinoma tumors may result in {{c2::dimpling}} of skin or {{c1::retraction}} of the nipple
One subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast) is {{c1::tubular}} carcinoma, which produces tubules in a desmoplastic stroma
Tubular carcinoma can be differentiated from normal breast tissue by lack of {{c1::myoepithelial}} cells and presence of {{c1::desmoplastic}} stroma

What is the prognosis of the tubular carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast)?

{{c1::Good}}
The following image represents the {{c1::tubular}} carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma:
One subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast is {{c1::mucinous}} carcinoma, which is characterized by malignant cells floating in pools of mucus

What is the prognosis of the mucinous carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast)?

{{c1::Good}}

What demographic is most commonly associated with the mucinous carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast)?

{{c1::Elderly women (average 70)}}
The following image represents the {{c1::mucinous}} carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma:

What is the prognosis of the medullary carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast)?

{{c1::Good}}
One subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast) is {{c1::medullary}} carcinoma, which is characterized by large, high-grade malignant cells growing in sheets with {{c2::lymphocytic}} infiltrate
There is an increased incidence of medullary carcinoma of the breast (a subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma) in patients with {{c1::BRCA1}} mutations
One subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast) is {{c1::inflammatory}} carcinoma, which is characterized by an erythematous and swollen breast that does not resolve with {{c2::antibiotics}}
{{c1::Inflammatory}} carcinoma, a subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma, is characterized by cancer within dermal {{c2::lymphatics}}

What is the prognosis of the inflammatory carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast)?

{{c1::Poor (50% survival at 5 years)}}

What other clinical pathology is inflammatory carcinoma of the breast often mistaken with?

{{c1::Acute mastitis}}

The following image represents the {{c1::inflammatory}} carcinoma subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma (breast):

hint: the circled area is lymphatics
The gross appearance of inflammatory breast cancer is often described as resembling a(n) {{c1::orange peel (Peau dorange)}} (due to invasion of lymphatic spaces)
{{c1::Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS)}} is the malignant proliferation of cells in the lobules of the breast with {{c2::no invasion}} of the basement membrane
Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is often discovered {{c1::incidentally}}; does not produce mass or calcification
{{c2::Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS)}} is a non-invasive breast cancer characterized by dyscohesive cells due to lack of {{c1::E-cadherin}} protein
Lobular carcinoma in situ is treated with {{c1::anti-estrogenic drugs (e.g. tamoxifen)}} to reduce risk of subsequent carcinoma

Which type of invasive breast carcinoma is characterized as often being bilateral with multiple lesions in the same location?

{{c1::Invasive lobular carcinoma}}
Invasive lobular carcinoma grows in a(n) {{c1::single-file}} pattern due to lack of E-cadherin
The following image represents {{c1::invasive lobular}} carcinoma (breast):

What is the most important factor in determining prognosis of breast cancer?

{{c1::Metastasis}}

What is the most useful factor in determining prognosis of breast cancer?

{{c1::Spread to axillary lymph nodes}}

How is axillary lymph node involvement assessed when looking for spread of breast cancer?

{{c1::Sentinel node biopsy}}

Presence or absence of which three receptors or genes are most important in predicting response to treatment of breast cancer?

{{c1::estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR) and Her2/neu amplification}}
Breast cancer that is ER+ and PR+ is most likely to respond to anti-{{c1::estrogenic}} agents such as {{c1::tamoxifen}}
Breast cancer that has Her2/neu amplification is associated with good response to {{c1::trastuzumab (herceptin)}}
Breast Cancer Assessment: The following is an immunohistochemical stain for the {{c1::estrogen}} receptor, which is located in {{c2::nuclei}}
Breast Cancer Assessment: The following is an immunohistochemical stain for the {{c1::HER-2 (c-erbB2)}} receptor, which is located on the {{c2::cell membrane}}
Triple-Negative breast cancer is negative for ER, PR, and HER2/neu and has a(n) {{c1::poor}} prognosis

What demographic is most commonly associated with triple negative breast cancer?

{{c1::African American women}}

What are the two single most important gene mutations associated with hereditary breast cancer?

{{c1::BRCA1 and BRCA2}}

Females with BRCA1 mutations have increased risk for which types of cancer?

{{c1::Breast, ovarian, and fallopian tube::3}}
BRCA2 mutation is associated with breast carcinoma in {{c1::males}}

If a women undergoes prophylactic mastectomy, can she still develop breast cancer?

{{c1::Yes, there is a small chance due to small amounts of remaining breast tissue}}
Male breast cancer most commonly presents as a(n) {{c1::subareolar}} mass in older males

What type of breast cancer is most common in males?

{{c1::invasive ductal carcinoma}}
Male breast cancer is associated with {{c1::BRCA2}} mutation and {{c1::Klinefelter}} syndrome
{{c1::Dizygotic (“fraternal”)}} twins arise from 2 eggs that are separately fertilized by 2 different sperm
Dizygotic (“fraternal”) twins will have {{c1::2 separate}} amniotic sacs and {{c1::2 separate}} placentas (chorions)
{{c1::Monozygotic (“identical”)}} twins arise from 1 fertilized egg (1 egg + 1 sperm) that splits in early pregnancy
If the developing embryo splits in the 2-cell stage (0-4 days), the twins will be {{c1::di::mono/di}}-chorionic and {{c1::di::mono/di}}-amniotic
If the developing embryo splits in the morula stage (4-8 days), the twins will be {{c1::mono::mono/di}}-chorionic and {{c1::di::mono/di}}-amniotic
If the developing embryo splits in the blastocyst stage (8-12 days), the twins will be {{c1::mono::mono/di}}-chorionic and {{c1::mono::mono/di}}-amniotic
If the developing embryo splits after the embryonic disc is formed (>13 days), the twins will be {{c1::conjoined}}
The umbilical {{c1::vein}} supplies oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus
The umbilical {{c1::arteries}} return deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta
During the 3rd week of development, the yolk sac forms the {{c1::allantois}}, which extends into the urogenital sinus
The allantois becomes the {{c1::urachus}}, which is a duct between the {{c2::fetal bladder}} and the {{c2::umbilicus}}
The {{c1::vitelline}} duct is a duct that connects the embryonic yolk sac to the midgut lumen
During the {{c1::7th}} week of development, the obliteration of the vitelline duct (omphalo-mesenteric duct) occurs
If the vitelline duct COMPLETELY fails to close, a vitelline {{c1::fistula (persistent vitelline duct)}} develops, which is characterized by {{c2::meconium}} discharge from the umbilicus

Which two pathologies are associated with increased temperature of the testis?

{{c1::Varicocele and cryptorchidism}}
{{c1::Polyhydramnios}} is the presence of too much amniotic fluid and may be associated with fetal malformations (e.g. esophageal or duodenal atresia due to inability to swallow)
{{c1::Oligohydramnios}} is too little amniotic fluid, and may be associated with bilateral renal agenesis or posterior urethral valves (males)

What is the most common gynecologic cancer worldwide?

{{c1::Cervical (due to lack of screening or HPV vaccination)}}

What is the most common gynecologic cancer in the U.S.?

{{c1::Endometrial}}

Which gynecologic cancer (endometrial, cervical, ovarian) has the worst prognosis?

{{c1::Ovarian}}

What is the most common mechanism of chromosomal aneuploidy?

{{c1::Meiotic nondisjunction}}
{{c2::Klinefelter}} syndrome is most commonly characterized by a(n) {{c1::47}},{{c1::XXY}} karyotype

Which sex chromosome disorder is associated with gynecomastia, female hair distribution, tall/long extremities and eunuchoid body shape in a male?

{{c1::Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY)}}

What is the level of testosterone in a patient with Klinefelter syndrome?

{{c1::Decreased (seminiferous tubule dysgenesis, abnormal Leydig cell function)}}

What is the level of estrogen in a patient with Klinefelter syndrome?

{{c1::Increased}}
Klinefelter syndrome is associated with testicular {{c1::atrophy::size}}

Which sex chromosome disorder is associated with short stature, shield chest, and webbed neck in a female?

{{c1::Turner syndrome}}

What is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea?

{{c1::Turners syndrome}}

What is the level of estrogen in a patient with Turner syndrome?

{{c1::Decreased (due to ovarian dysgenesis)}}
Turner syndrome is associated with preductal {{c2::coarctation of the aorta}}, which may present as a femoral pulse {{c1::less}} than brachial pulse
Ovotesticular disorder of sex development, also known as true {{c1::hermaphroditism}}, is the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue
Placental {{c1::aromatase}} deficiency is the inability to synthesize estrogens from androgens
Placental aromatase deficiency results in {{c1::masculinization}} of female (46,XX) infants
Placental {{c2::aromatase}} deficiency can present with maternal {{c1::virilization}} during pregnancy
{{c2::Androgen insensitivity}} syndrome is due to a defect in the androgen receptor, which results in a normal-appearing {{c1::female}} that is genotypically {{c1::XY}}
In general, sex chromosome disorders (e.g. Turners, Klinefelter) present with {{c1::decreased}} testosterone and/or estrogen and {{c1::increased}} LH
A defective androgen receptor presents with {{c1::increased}} testosterone and {{c1::increased}} LH
A testosterone-secreting tumor (or exogenous steroids) presents with {{c1::increased}} testosterone and {{c1::decreased}} LH
Primary hypogonadism presents with {{c1::decreased}} testosterone/estrogen and {{c1::increased}} LH
Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism presents with {{c1::decreased}} testosterone/estrogen and {{c1::decreased}} LH & FSH
{{c1::Kallmann}} syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a failure to complete puberty
{{c2::Kallmann}} syndrome is characterized by a defective migration of {{c1::GnRH}} cells and defective formation of the {{c1::olfactory bulb}}
Kallmann syndrome presents as {{c1::infertility}} in males and {{c1::amenorrhea}} in females; {{c2::anosmia}} may be present in both sexes
{{c2::Turner}} syndrome is most commonly characterized by a(n) {{c1::45}},{{c1::XO}} karyotype
In 5-alpha-reductase deficiency, there are {{c1::normal}} levels of testosterone and {{c1::normal/increased}} levels of LH
Alendronate, pamidronate, zoledronate are all examples of {{c2::bisphophonates}}, which are the first line treatment for {{c1::osteoporosis}}
Bisphosphonates have a chemical structure similar to {{c1::pyrophosphate}}

Which two drugs are useful in the acute treatment of hypercalcemia of malignancy?

{{c1::Bisphosphonates and calcitonin}}

{{c2::Bisphosphonates}} and {{c2::calcitonin}} are useful in the management of {{c1::Paget disease}}, which is characterized by uncontrolled osteoclast resorption with secondary disorganized bone formation
Oral bisphosphonates may cause {{c1::upper GI}} side effects

What osteoporosis drug has side effects that include acid reflux, esophagitis, and esophageal ulcers?

{{c1::Bisphosphonates (oral)}}
One rare side effect of {{c1::bisphosphonates}} and {{c2::denosumab}} is {{c3::osteonecrosis of the jaw}} (rare)
{{c2::Raloxifene}} is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that has estrogen {{c1::agonist}} activity on bone
{{c2::Raloxifene}} is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that has estrogen {{c1::antagonist}} activity on breast and uterus
Chronic exposure of PTH stimulates osteoblasts to express {{c1::RANKL}}, which binds to {{c1::RANK}} on osteoclast surfaces to increase activity
{{c1::Denosumab}} is a monoclonal antibody against {{c2::RANKL}}, useful in the treatment of osteoporosis
{{c1::Calcitonin}} is a peptide hormone that directly inhibits osteoclasts, causing decreased bone resorption
Calcitonin promotes Ca2+ {{c1::excretion}} by the kidney
ADH activation of the {{c1::V1}} receptor on vascular smooth muscle causes vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure
ADH-activated V2 receptors cause translocation of {{c1::aquaporin 2}} channels to the renal apical membrane, causing increased reabsorption of free water

What anti-psychotic drug is a common cause of drug-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?

{{c1::Lithium}}
One class of drugs that may treat nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is {{c1::thiazide diuretics}}, which enhances the uptake of NaCl and H2O in the {{c2::proximal tubule}}
{{c1::Amiloride}} is a K+ sparing diuretic that may be used to treat {{c1::Lithium}} induced {{c2::nephrogenic}} diabetes insipidus
Amiloride is useful for the treatment of {{c1::lithium}}-induced diabetes insipidus
NSAIDs, such as {{c1::indomethacin}}, may be used to treat {{c2::nephrogenic}} diabetes insipidus
Central diabetes insipidus may be treated with exogenous administration of {{c1::ADH}}
{{c1::Desmopressin (DDAVP)}}, a long-acting synthetic analog of ADH, may be used to treat {{c2::central}} diabetes insipidus
In addition to central diabetes insipidus, desmopressin (DDAVP) may be used to treat {{c1::von Willebrand disease}}, which is associated with increased bruisability and mucosal bleeding
In addition to central diabetes insipidus, desmopressin (DDAVP) may be used to treat {{c1::hemophilia A}}, which is associated with hemarthrosis and prolonged bleeding after minor procedures
Desmopressin may be used to treat night {{c1::enuresis (bed wetting)}}
{{c1::-Vaptans (tolvaptan, conivaptan)}} are the first line treatment for treatment of {{c2::SIADH}}

What adverse effect may -vaptans (tolvaptan, conivaptan) have on sodium levels?

{{c1::Hypernatremia}}

What is a serious complication of vaptans (e.g. tolvaptan, conivaptan) that may occur if SIADH-induced hyponatremia is corrected too quickly?

{{c1::Central pontine myelinolysis (osmotic demyelination syndrome)}}

Which tetracycline may be used as a second line treatment in the treatment of SIADH?

{{c1::Demeclocycline}}

Which treatment for SIADH may end up causing nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?

{{c1::Demeclocycline}}

Which type of receptor is associated with growth hormone?

{{c1::Receptor associated tyrosine kinase}}
{{c2::Growth hormone}} is a hormone that may be used for treatment of {{c1::Turner}} syndrome, which is characterized by an XO genotype
{{c1::Octreotide (somatostatin analog)}} may be used to treat acromegaly and gigantism if symptoms persist after {{c2::trans-sphenoidal resection}}

What hormone analog may be used to treat VIPoma and carcinoid syndrome?

{{c1::Octreotide (somatostatin analog)}}

What hormone analog may be used to treat insulinoma, glucagonoma, and gastrinoma?

{{c1::Octreotide (somatostatin analog)}}
Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, may be useful in the management of {{c1::esophageal variceal}} bleeding by reducing portal blood flow and variceal pressure

Which hormone-secreting pancreatic tumor is associated with necrolytic migratory erythema?

{{c1::Glucagonoma}}
Dexamethasone, hydrocortisone, and prednisone are all examples of {{c1::glucocorticoids}}
When unbound, the glucocorticoid receptor is located in the {{c1::cytoplasm}}
Once bound (activated), the glucocorticoid receptor enters the {{c2::nucleus}} and binds to {{c1::glucocorticoid response elements}} to regulate gene transcription

What is the effect of glucocorticoids on production of phospholipase A2?

{{c1::Decreased (inhibition)}}
Glucocorticoids prevent production of {{c1::arachidonic acid}} by inhibiting phospholipase A2
Glucocorticoids inhibit {{c1::NF-kB}}, which is a transcription factor that regulates the production of proinflammatory cytokines (e.g. IL-2, TNF-alpha)
Glucocorticoids are useful for treating {{c1::inflammatory}} disorders (e.g. gout, rheumatoid arthritis, asthma, IBD)
Glucocorticoids are useful in treating {{c1::adrenal}} insufficiency, which may progress to circulatory shock, hypoglycemia, and death
Abrupt withdrawal of glucocorticoids may cause {{c1::tertiary}} {{c2::adrenal}} insufficiency
Chronic glucocorticoid use may cause Iatrogenic {{c1::Cushing}} syndrome

Glucocorticoids may cause {{c1::osteoporosis}} due to inhibition of osteoblast activity

*bonus: what supplements should be taken to prevent this?

Which two hormones or hormone analogs may be used for the management of esophageal variceal bleeding?

{{c1::Desmopressin (ADH analog)}} and {{c1::octreotide (somatostatin analog)}}

How does cardiac output change during pregnancy?

{{c1::Increase (~50%)}}

How does plasma volume and RBC volume change during pregnancy?

{{c1::
Plasma volume increases by 50%
RBC volume increases by 30%
}}

What is the result of 50% increased plasma volume versus 30% increased RBC volume during pregnancy?

{{c1::Anemia (decreases viscosity to reduce postpartum bleeding)}}

How does blood pressure change during early pregnancy?

{{c1::Decreased}}

How does minute ventilation change during pregnancy?

{{c1::Increased}}

How does increased minute ventilation during pregnancy affect blood pH?

{{c1::Mild respiratory alkalosis}}

How do levels of PCO2 change during pregnancy?

{{c1::Decreased (due to increased ventilation rate)}}

How does coaguability change during pregnancy?

{{c1::Increased (hypercoagulability; decreases postpartum bleeding)}}

How does glomerular filtration rate change during pregnancy?

{{c1::Increase}}

How does insulin resistance change during pregnancy?

{{c1::Increase}}

When grading a females obstetrical status using GTPAL, what does G represent?

{{c1::Gravidity (the total # of pregnancies)}}

When grading a females obstetrical status using GTPAL, what does T represent?

{{c1::Term deliveries (the total # of deliveries after 37 weeks)}}

When grading a females obstetrical status using GTPAL, what does P represent?

{{c1::Pre-term deliveries (the total # of deliveries after 20 weeks, but before 37 weeks)}}

When grading a females obstetrical status using GTPAL, what does L represent?

{{c1::Number of living children}}

What range of weeks is considered a term gestation?

{{c1::37-42 weeks}}

The four components of a prenatal quad screen are:

1. {{c1::AFP}}
2. {{c2::hCG}}
3. {{c3::Estriol}}
4. {{c4::Inhibin A}}
Amniocentesis may be done as early as {{c1::15}} to {{c1::17}} weeks
Chorionic villus sampling may be done as early as {{c1::10}} to {{c1::13}} weeks

{{c1::0.5% in amniocentesis versus 1% in CVS}}

{{c1::Limb defects}}

{{c1::lecithin:sphingomyelin > 2}}

{{c1::Day 8 (thus twins that split after day 8 are monoamniotic)}}

The presence of cord entanglement is indicative of {{c1::monoamniotic}} twins

What is a possible complication of monochorionic twins as a result of anastamosis?

In twin-twin transfusion syndrome, the {{c1::donor}} is anemic, pale, and has restricted growth
In twin-twin transfusion syndrome, the {{c1::recipient}} is polycythemic, overloaded, and at risk for heart failure
A(n) {{c1::patent urachus}} occurs due to total failure of the urachus to obliterate

A(n) {{c1::urachal cyst}} is due to partial failure of the urachus to obliterate, resulting in a fluid-filled cyst
A(n) {{c1::urachal}} cyst presents as a fluid-filled cavity lined with uroepithelium, between the umbilicus and bladder
A(n) {{c1::vesicourachal diverticulum}} is a diverticulum due to a slight failure of the urachus to obliterate
A vesicourachal diverticulum presents as outpouching of the {{c1::bladder}}

Invasive moles are diagnosed by histologic evidence of villi invading the {{c1::myometrium}} on a hysterectomy specimen
One risk factor for placental abruption is {{c1::trauma}} (e.g. MVA, spouse abuse)
Causes of {{c1::hypertension}} (e.g. cocaine, smoking, and preeclampsia) all increase the risk for placental {{c2::abruption}}

Placental {{c2::abruption}} may be diagnosed using the {{c1::Kleihauer-Betke}} test, which looks for fetal RBC in the maternal blood

How is placenta previa usually diagnosed?

{{c1::Ultrasound}}

{{c1::Placental abruption}}

What is the treatment for preeclampsia or eclampsia to prevent seizures?

{{c1::≥ 300 mg/day}}

{{c1::Uterine atony}}

1. {{c1::Uterine aTony (most common)}}
2. {{c2::Trauma (lacerations, incisions, uterine rupture)}}

4. {{c4::Tissue (retained products of conception)}}

{{c1::Methotrexate}}

{{c1::No (45,XO)}}

{{c1::Spironolactone, Hormones, Cimetidine, and Ketoconazole::4}}

{{c1::Tachycardia, arrhythmias::2}}

What enzyme is responsible for metabolizing sorbitol into fructose?

What is the clinical use for orlistat?

{{c1::Weight loss}}

Which ulcerative colitis drug is associated with reversible oligospermia?

{{c1::H1}}

What class of histone is found outside the nucleosome and functions to condense the nucleosome together?

{{c1::H1}}

{{c1::H2A, H2B, H3, H4::4}}

{{c1::Condense/link the nucleosomes together}}

In {{c1::mitosis::cell cycle phase}}, DNA condenses to form chromosomes

What cell cycle phase do DNA and histone synthesis occur?

{{c1::S phase}}

What form of chromatin is highly condensed?

What form of chromatin is less condensed?

{{c1::Euchromatin}}

{{c1::Heterochromatin}}

What form of chromatin appears lighter on EM?

{{c1::Euchromatin}}

What process takes DNA and makes more DNA?

{{c1::Replication}}

What process takes DNA and makes RNA?

{{c1::transcription}}

What process takes RNA and makes protein?

{{c1::translation}}

How many ring(s) do purines have?

{{c1::Two}}

How many ring(s) do pyrimidines have?

{{c1::One}}

Which bases are purines?

{{c1::Adenine and guanine}}

Which bases are pyrimidines?

{{c1::Cytosine, uracil, and thymine}}

Which purine is characterized by no amino group at the 12 oclock position?

{{c1::Guanine}}

Which pyrimidine is characterized by an amino group at the 12 oclock position?

Which pyrimidine is characterized by the presence of methyl groups, but no amino group at the 12 oclock position?

Which carbon lacks a hydroxyl group in DNA strands?

{{c1::2 carbon}}

Generally, the 3 end of DNA or RNA is a(n) {{c1::hydroxyl}} group

What amino acids are necessary for purine synthesis?

{{c1::Glycine, Aspartate, Glutamine::3}}
One feature of the genetic code is that it is {{c1::unambiguous}}: each codon specifies only 1 amino acid
One feature of the genetic code is that it is {{c1::degenerate/redundant}}: most amino acids are coded by multiple codons
One feature of the genetic code is that it is {{c1::commaless, nonoverlapping}}: it is read from a fixed starting point as a continuous sequence of bases
One feature of the genetic code is that it is {{c1::universal}}: genetic code is conserved throughout evolution

Of the 64 possible codons, how many encode amino acids?

{{c1::61 (3 are stop codons)}}

Which sequence of bases is a start codon (methionine) in mRNA?

{{c1::AUG}}

What does AUG encode for in eukaryotes?

{{c1::Methionine (start codon)}}

What does AUG encode for in prokaryotes?

{{c1::N-formylmethionine, or fMet (start codon)}}

Which three sequences of bases are mRNA stop codons?

{{c1::UGA, UAA, UAG}}

Which enzyme is responsible for unwinding the DNA template at the replication fork?

Which enzyme is responsible for elongating the DNA strand?

{{c1::DNA polymerase (specifically, DNA polymerase III in prokaryotes)}}

DNA/RNA polymerase always read in the {{c1::3 to 5}} direction
DNA/RNA polymerase always build in the {{c1::5 to 3}} direction
DNA polymerase pauses and checks ("proof-reads") via {{c1::3 -> 5 exonuclease}} activity

Which enzymes are responsible for removing the RNA primer in eukaryotes?

{{c1::RNase H and FEN-1::2}}

Which enzyme catalyzes the formation of a phosphodiester bond between Okazaki fragments?

{{c1::DNA ligase}}
The enzyme which adds {{c2::TTAGGG::sequence}} to 3 ends of chromosomes to avoid loss of genetic material with every duplication is known as {{c1::Telomerase}}

Which replication enzyme is a RNA-dependent DNA polymerase, and thus a major example of reverse transcriptase activity, in humans?

{{c1::Telomerase}}
Telomerase is a rare example where {{c1::reverse transcriptase::enzyme}} activity occurs endogenously in humans

What pathology is associated with increased telomerase activity?

{{c1::Cancer}}
{{c1::RNA}} polymerase doesnt have to see a RNA primer to bind

Which type of DNA mutation causes the least severe damage?

{{c1::Silent mutations}}

Which type of DNA mutation causes the most severe damage?

{{c1::frameshift mutations}}
A(n) {{c1::transition}} is type of DNA mutation in which a purine is mutated to another purine (or pyrimidine to pyrimidine)
A(n) {{c1::transversion}} is a type of DNA mutation in which a purine is mutated into a pyrimidine, and vice versa

What class of DNA mutations are characterized by a single nucleotide change?

{{c1::Point mutations}}
A(n) {{c1::silent}} mutation occurs when a nucleotide substitution codes for the same amino acid
A(n) {{c1::missense}} mutation occurs when a nucleotide substitution codes for a different amino acid
A(n) {{c1::nonsense}} mutation occurs when a nucleotide substitution codes for a stop codon
A(n) {{c1::frameshift}} mutation occurs when there is a deletion or insertion of a number of nucleotides not divisible by {{c2::3}}, resulting in misreading of all nucleotides downstream
A mutation at a(n) {{c1::splice site}} results in a retained intron in the mRNA, leading to a protein with impaired or altered function

What mutation is induced by UV radiation?

{{c1::Pyrimidine dimers (e.g. thymine dimers)}}

What form of DNA repair fixes mutations induced by UV radiation?

{{c1::Nucleotide excision repair}}
The enzyme that recognizes and excises pyrimidine dimer mutations is {{c1::excision endonuclease}}
The enzymes that repair pyrimidine dimer mutations are {{c1::DNA polymerase}} and {{c1::DNA ligase}}

What phase of the cell cycle do nucleotide excision repairs occur?

{{c1::G1}}
Xeroderma Pigmentosum is an inherited pathology due to a defective {{c1::Nucleotide Excision Repair}} pathway

What form of DNA repair fixes mutations due to DNA replication errors?

{{c1::Mismatch repair}}
Recognition and facilitation of excision of {{c2::mismatched nucleotides}} occur via enzymes found on two genes: {{c1::MSH2 (MutS)}} or {{c1::MLH1 (MutL)}}
The enzymes that repair mismatched base mutations are {{c1::DNA polymerase}} and {{c1::DNA ligase}}

What pathology is characterized by a deficiency of the enzymes used in mismatch base repair?

{{c1::Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer [HNPCC])}}

What phase of the cell cycle do mismatch base repairs predominantly occur?

{{c1::S}}
{{c1::Deamination (e.g. cytosine to uracil)}} is a mutation that may occur spontaneously or due to heat or nitrates

What form of DNA repair fixes mutations due to spontaneous/toxic deamination?

{{c1::Base excision repair}}
In base excision repair, base-specific {{c1::glycosylases}} remove the altered base and create a(n) {{c2::AP (apurinic/apyrimidinic)}} site

Which base excision repair enzyme is responsible for removing nucleotides at the 5 end?

{{c1::AP-endonuclease}}

Which base excision repair enzyme is responsible for removing nucleotides at the 3 end?

{{c1::Lyase}}

Which base excision repair enzymes are responsible for filling and sealing the gap from the excised bases?

{{c1::DNA polymerase-β::specific}} (filling) and {{c1::DNA ligase III::specific}} (sealing)

What phase of the cell cycle do base excision repairs occur?

{{c1::Throughout the cell cycle}}

Which forms of DNA repair repairs double-stranded breaks (due to ionizing radiation)?

{{c1::Nonhomologous end joining}} and {{c2::homologous recombination}}
Mechanisms to repair {{c1::dsDNA}} breaks are defective in Ataxia telangiectasia, Fanconi anemia, and SCID
The {{c2::triphosphate}} bond of DNA is the target of {{c1::3 hydroxyl}} attack (strand elongation)

Does reverse transcriptase require a primer?

{{c1::Yes! Because it is a DNA polymerase (RNA dependent DNA polymerase)}}
While DNA polymerase binds to a primer, RNA polymerase binds to a(n) {{c1::promoter}}
The {{c1::template}} strand is the dsDNA strand used for transcription; it is complementary and antiparallel to mRNA
The {{c1::coding}} strand is the strand of dsDNA that is NOT used during transcription, but is identical to mRNA (substitute T/U)
The dsDNA sequence reported in databases is the {{c1::coding}} strand, unless specifically stated otherwise

Practice: If a DNA template sequence is TAGC, what is the mRNA sequence?

{{c1::GCUA}}
The {{c1::untranslated region (UTR)}} of mRNA is the portion of mRNA which contains no protein information

Does prokaryotic mRNA have introns and exons?

{{c1::No}}
In eukaryotes, each gene has its own {{c1::promoter}}, to which RNA polymerase II may bind
The initial mRNA of eukaryotes contains {{c1::introns}} and {{c1::exons}}, which undergo splicing
The {{c1::promoter}} is the site where {{c2::RNA polymerase II}} and general transcription factors bind to DNA upstream from a gene locus
The promoter is an AT-rich upstream sequence with {{c1::TATA}} and {{c1::CAAT}} boxes
A mutation in the promoter commonly results in a dramatic {{c1::decrease}} in the level of gene transcription
Promoters serve as binding sites for {{c1::general::general/specific}} transcription factors
{{c1::Enhancers}} are stretches of DNA that increase gene expression by binding specific transcription factors
{{c1::Silencers}} are sites where negative regulators (repressors) bind to DNA
Enhancers increase transcription via enhanced activity of the enzyme {{c1::RNA polymerase II}}
Enhancers serve as binding sites for {{c1::specific::specific/general}} transcription factors

Are enhancers/silencers close or far from the gene it regulates?

{{c1::May be close to, far from, or within the gene (in an intron)}}

How can enhancers be far away from the gene it regulates?

{{c1::DNA will bend to bring enhancer to promoter}}

What class of protein receptor is common to all steroid hormones, thyroid hormones, and vitamins A/D?

{{c1::Zinc finger}}

What morning sickness drug (no longer used) inadvertently prevents binding of homeodomain proteins to enhancers, thus causing limb abnormalities?

{{c1::Thalidomide}}

What class of drugs acts via activation of PPAR-alpha?

{{c1::Fibrates}}
{{c1::Nuclear factor kappa B (NF-kB)}} is a specific transcription factor that binds kB elements, which regulates expression of many genes in the immune system

What class of drugs acts via suppression of NF-kB signaling?

{{c1::Glucocorticoids}}
RNA polymerase {{c1::I}} makes {{c2::r}}RNA
RNA polymerase {{c1::II}} makes {{c2::m}}RNA
RNA polymerase {{c1::III}} makes {{c2::t}}RNA and 5S rRNA

Which RNA polymerase binds to DNA at a promoter site?

{{c1::RNA polymerase II}}
In eukaryotes, {{c2::RNA polymerase II}} may be inhibited by {{c1::α-amanitin}}

What drug is an inhibitor of prokaryotic RNA polymerase?

{{c1::Rifampin}}

What drug is an inhibitor of both prokaryotic AND eukaryotic RNA polymerase?

{{c1::Actinomycin D}}

How many different RNA polymerases do prokaryotes have?

{{c1::One (makes all 3 kinds of RNA)}}
The initial (primary) transcript transcribed from eukaryotic DNA is {{c1::heterogenous nuclear RNA (hnRNA)}}
Capped, tailed, and spliced hnRNA is called {{c1::mRNA}}

In what part of the cell is mRNA formed?

{{c1::Nucleus}}

In what part of the cell is mRNA translated?

{{c1::Cytosol}}
One co-transcriptional modification is the addition of a(n) {{c1::7-methylguanosine cap}} at the {{c2::5}} end
One post-transcriptional modification is the addition of a(n) {{c1::poly-A tail}} at the 3 end
One post-transcriptional modification is the {{c2::splicing out}} of {{c1::introns}}

Does Poly-A polymerase require a template (post-transcriptional processing)?

{{c1::No}}

What sequence of bases represents a polyadenylation signal?

{{c1::AAUAAA::6}}
mRNA quality control occurs at {{c1::cytoplasmic processing bodies (P-bodies)}}, which contain exonucleases, decapping enzymes, and microRNAs
mRNAs may be stored in {{c1::P-bodies}} for future translation
In the first step of alternative splicing, the primary transcript (hnRNA) combines with {{c1::small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPS)}} and other proteins to form the {{c2::spliceosome}}
After the spliceosome has been formed in alternative splicing, a(n) {{c1::lariat-shaped (looped)}} intermediate is generated
In the final step of alternative splicing, the {{c2::lariat}} is released to precisely remove the {{c1::intron}} and join two {{c1::exons}}
Antibodies to spliceosomal snRNPs, also known as {{c2::anti-Smith}} antibodies, are highly specific for {{c1::SLE}}
Antibodies to U1 RNP are highly associated with {{c1::mixed connective tissue}} disease
Every intron has a 5 {{c1::donor}} site and a 3 {{c1::acceptor}} site, which are brought together to form the Lariat-shaped loop

Which portion of eukaryotic hnRNA contains the actual genetic information coding for protein?

{{c1::Exons}}

Which portion of eukaryotic hnRNA contains intervening noncoding segments of DNA?

{{c1::Introns}}
Different exons are frequently combined by {{c1::alternative splicing}} to produce a larger number of unique proteins
One hematological pathology that is due to abnormal splicing variants is {{c1::β-thalassemia}}
{{c1::microRNAs}} are small, noncoding RNA molecules that post-transcriptionally regulate protein expression
microRNA often leads to the {{c1::silencing/inactivation}} of target mRNA, thus causing {{c1::decreased}} translation into protein
{{c1::tRNAs}} are the smallest RNAs and have a clover-leaf structure
At the base of a tRNA molecule is a(n) {{c1::anti-codon loop}}, which base pairs with a codon of mRNA in a complementary, antiparallel fashion
At the {{c2::3}} end of a tRNA molecule is a(n) {{c1::5-CCA-3}} sequence, which is the amino acid acceptor stem
The {{c1::T-arm}} of tRNA contains the TΨC sequence (ribothymidine, pseudouridine, cytidine) necessary for tRNA-ribosome binding

What is the function of the T-arm of tRNA?

{{c1::tRNA-ribosome binding}}
The {{c1::D-arm}} of tRNA contains dihydrouridine residues necessary for tRNA recognition by the correct aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase

What is the function of the D-arm of tRNA?

{{c1::Recognition of tRNA by the correct aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase}}
tRNA is joined with its specific amino acid via the enzyme {{c1::aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase}}
Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase requires {{c1::ATP}} and releases inorganic PPi
A(n) {{c1::mischarged}} tRNA reads its usual codon but inserts the wrong amino acid
Accurate base pairing is usually required only in the first two nucleotide positions of a mRNA codon because codons differing in the 3rd "{{c1::wobble}}" position may code for the same amino acid
Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase and binding of charged tRNA to the codon are responsible for {{c1::accuracy}} of amino acid selection
Peptide bond formation is facilitated by the ribozyme {{c1::peptidyl transferase}}

What is the smaller ribosomal subunit used in prokaryotic translation?

{{c1::30s}}

What is the larger ribosomal subunit used in prokaryotic translation?

{{c1::50s}}

What is the total size of the ribosome used in prokaryotic translation?

{{c1::70s}}

What is the smaller ribosomal subunit used in eukaryotic translation?

{{c1::40s}}

What is the larger ribosomal subunit used in eukaryotic translation?

{{c1::60s}}

What is the total size of the ribosome used in eukaryotic translation?

{{c1::80s}}
Eukaryotic {{c1::Initiation Factors}} help assemble the 40s ribosomal subunit with the initiator tRNA

Which nucleotide triphosphate is used in the charging of tRNA?

{{c1::ATP}}

Where in the cell does translation begin?

{{c1::Cytoplasm}}
Translation is initiated by {{c1::GTP}} hydrolysis

At what site of the ribosome does tRNA bind to for translation initiation?

{{c1::P site}}

Which tRNA binds to the P site of the ribosome to initiate translation?

{{c1::Methionine-tRNA}}

At what site of the ribosome does tRNA bind to for translation elongation?

{{c1::A site}}
In the first step of strand elongation, a(n) {{c1::aminoacyl-tRNA}} binds to the A site
After aminoacyl-tRNA binds to the A site of the ribosome, {{c1::peptidyl transferase}}, a ribozyme, catalyzes peptide bond formation (translation)
In the final step of translation elongation, {{c1::translocation}} of the ribosome occurs, advancing the ribosome 3 nucleotides towards the 3 end of mRNA
Translocation of the ribosome during translation moves peptidyl tRNA from the {{c1::A}} site to the {{c1::P}} site
In addition to GTP, translocation of the ribosome during translation also requires eukaryotic {{c1::elongation factor 2 (eEF-2)}}
The {{c1::E}} site of the ribosome holds empty tRNA as it exits
In the final step of translation, a stop codon is recognized by {{c1::release factor}} and the completed polypeptide is released from the ribosome
One class of post-translational modifications is {{c1::covalent alterations}}, which include phosphorylation, glycosylation, hydroxylation, methylation, acetylation, and ubiquitination
A(n) {{c1::chaperone}} protein, is an intracellular protein involved in facilitating and/or maintaining protein {{c2::folding}}

What is the shortest phase of the cell cycle?

{{c1::M phase (mitosis + cytokinesis)}}

Which cell cycle phase is characterized by resting, non-dividing cells?

{{c1::G0}}

What cell type remains in G0 and can only regenerate from stem cells?

{{c1::Permanent}}

What type of cells are the following examples?

{{c1::Permanent::Labile, Stable, or Permanent?}}

What cell type enters G1 from G0 when stimulated?

{{c1::Stable (quiescent)}}

What type of cells are the following examples?

{{c1::Stable (Quiescent)::Labile, Stable, or Permanent?}}

What cell type never enters G0 and divides rapidly with a short G1?

{{c1::Labile}}

What cell type is affected most by chemotherapy?

{{c1::Labile (gut epithelium, skin, hair follicles, etc)}}

Which cell cycle phase is characterized by DNA synthesis and replication?

{{c1::S}}

Which cell cycle phase(s) are part of interphase?

{{c1::G1, S, G2}}

Which cell cycle phase(s) are NOT part of interphase?

{{c1::M}}

Transcription occurs throughout which cell cycle phases?

{{c1::Interphase (G1, S, G2)}}

Which tumor suppressor protein acts at the G1 check point?

{{c1::p53}}

What part of the cell is the site of synthesis of secretory proteins?

{{c1::Rough endoplasmic reticulum}}

Where in a cell does N-linked oligosaccharide addition take place?

{{c1::Rough endoplasmic reticulum}}
The {{c2::RER}} in neurons, known as {{c1::Nissl bodies}}, synthesize peptide neurotransmitters for secretion

What cellular structure are mucus-secreting goblet cells (small intestine) and antibody-secreting plasma cells rich in?

{{c1::Rough endoplasmic reticulum}}
{{c1::Free}} ribosomes are unattached to any membrane and are the site of synthesis for cytosolic and organellar proteins

What part of the cell is the site of steroid synthesis and detoxification of drugs and poisons?

{{c1::Smooth endoplasmic reticulum}}

How can the smooth endoplasmic reticulum be distinguished from the rough ER?

{{c1::Smooth ER lacks surface ribosomes}}
When proteins are misfolded, multiple {{c1::ubiquitins}} are added, which aids in trafficking to the proteasome
The {{c1::proteasome}} is a barrel-shaped protein complex that degrades damaged or ubiquitin-tagged proteins
Defects in the ubiquitin-proteasome system have been implicated in some cases of {{c1::Parkinson}} disease
Inside the proteasome, {{c1::proteases}} cleave ubiqutinated proteins into peptide fragments

Which membrane-bound organelle is involved in the catabolism of very-long-chain fatty acids, branched-chain fatty acids, amino acids, and ethanol?

{{c1::Peroxisome}}
The {{c1::golgi apparatus}} is the distribution center for proteins and lipids from the endoplasmic reticulum to the vesicles and plasma membrane
On the N terminal side of newly synthesized protein, a stretch of 10-15 hydrophobic amino acids forms the {{c1::N-terminal signal}} sequence
The N-terminal signal sequence of a newly synthesized protein is bound by a(n) {{c1::signal recognition particle (SRP)}}, which attaches the complex to the {{c2::ER}} membrane
{{c1::Signal recognition particles (SRPs)}} are abundant, cytosolic ribonucleoproteins that traffic proteins from the ribosome to the RER

What would happen if there is absent or dysfunctional signal recognition particles (SRPs)?

{{c1::proteins accumulate in the cytosol}}
In the {{c3::ER}}, co-translational {{c1::N-glycosylation}} adds sugars onto the amino acid {{c2::asparagine}}
In the {{c3::Golgi apparatus}}, post-translational {{c1::O-glycosylation}} adds sugars onto the amino acids {{c2::serine}} and {{c2::threonine}}

Which enzyme phosphorylates mannose in the Golgi apparatus, facilitating protein trafficking?

{{c1::Phosphotransferase}}
In the Golgi apparatus, {{c1::mannose-6-phosphate}} is added to proteins for trafficking to {{c2::lysosomes}}

What pathology is associated with a defect in the enzyme N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase?

{{c1::I-cell disease (inclusion cell disease/mucolipidosis type II)}}
{{c1::Endosomes}} are sorting centers for material from outside the cell or from the Golgi, sending it to lysosomes for destruction or back to the membrane/Golgi for further use

Which inherited lysosomal storage disorder is characterized by coarse facial features, clouded corneas, and restricted joint movement with high serum levels of multiple lysosomal enzymes?

{{c1::I-cell disease}}
I-cell disease is characterized by high plasma levels of {{c1::lysosomal}} enzymes

What differentiates I-cell disease from other inclusion body diseases?

{{c1::I-cell has a mixed accumulation of junk forming the inclusion bodies}}

Which vesicular trafficking protein is responsible for retrograde Golgi transport (cis-Golgi and ER) and intra-Golgi transport?

{{c1::COPI}}

Which vesicular trafficking protein is responsible for anterograde Golgi transport (ER to cis Golgi)?

{{c1::COPII}}

Which vesicular trafficking protein is responsible for transport between the trans-Golgi and lysosomes?

{{c1::Clathrin}}

Which vesicular trafficking protein is responsible for transport between the plasma membrane and endosomes (receptor-mediated endocytosis)?

{{c1::Clathrin}}
{{c1::Cytoskeletal elements}} are a network of protein fibers within the cytoplasm that support cell structure, cell and organelle movement, and cell division

Which type of filament is predominantly involved in muscle contraction and cytokinesis?

{{c1::Microfilaments (e.g. actin, microvilli)}}

Which type of filament is predominantly involved in maintainence of cell structure?

{{c1::Intermediate filaments (e.g. desmin, cytokeratin)}}

Which type of filament is predominantly involved in movement and cell division?

{{c1::Microtubules (e.g. cilia, flagella)}}

What type of filament are actin and microvilli?

{{c1::Microfilament}}

What type of filament are cytokeratin and desmin?

{{c1::Intermediate filaments}}

What type of filament are cilia and flagella?

{{c1::Microtubule}}
{{c1::Microtubules}} are a cylindrical outer structure composed of a helical array of polymerized heterodimers of {{c2::α-}} and {{c2::β-tubulin}}
Each α- and β-tubulin heterodimer of a microtubule has 2 {{c1::GTP}} bound
Microtubules grow {{c1::slowly::speed}} and collapse {{c1::quickly::speed}}

Which type of filament is involved in slow axoplasmic transport in neurons?

{{c1::Microtubules}}

Which molecular motor protein is responsible for retrograde transport to the microtubule (+ to -)?

{{c1::Dynein}}

Which molecular motor protein is responsible for anterograde transport to the microtubule (- to +)?

{{c1::Kinesin}}

Drugs that act on microtubules may be remembered with the mnemonic "Microtubules Get Constructed Very Poorly":

M: {{c1::Mebendazole (antihelminthic)}}
G: {{c2::Griseofulvin (antifungal)}}
C: {{c3::Colchicine (antigout)}}
V: {{c4::Vincristine/Vinblastine (anticancer)}}
P: {{c5::Palcitaxel (anticancer)}}
{{c1::Cilia}} are organized in a(n) {{c2::9+2}} arrangement of microtubule doublets
The base of a cilium below the cell membrane, called the {{c1::basal body}}, consists of 9 microtubule triplets with no central microtubules
Axonemal {{c2::dynein}} is a(n) {{c1::ATPase}} that links peripheral 9 doublets and causes bending of cilium (movement)
{{c1::Kartagener}} syndrome is a(n) {{c3::autosomal recessive::inheritance}} disease characterized by immotile cilia due to a(n) {{c2::dynein arm}} defect
Kartagener syndrome results in decreased male and female {{c1::fertility}}

Which developmental pathology is characterized by bronchiectasis, recurrent sinusitis, and situs inversus?

{{c1::Kartagener syndrome}}

What is the most abundant protein in the human body?

{{c1::Collagen}}
The function of collagen is to organize and strengthen the {{c1::extracellular matrix}}

What type of collagen is the most common (90%)?

{{c1::Type I}}

What type of collagen makes up bone, skin, and tendon?

{{c1::Type I}}

What type of collagen makes up cartilage?

{{c1::Type II}}

What type of collagen makes up reticulin fibers?

{{c1::Type III}}

What type of collagen makes up the basement membrane?

{{c1::Type IV}}

What type of collagen is decreased in osteogenesis imperfecta type I?

{{c1::Type I}}

What pathology is characterized by a defective type IV collagen?

{{c1::Alport syndrome}}
Type {{c1::IV}} collagen is targeted by autoantibodies in {{c2::Goodpasture}} syndrome
Collagen is a repeat of a tripeptide following the pattern {{c1::Gly-X-Y}}, made by fibroblasts
One third of the collagen strand is made of the amino acid {{c1::glycine}}
In the first step of collagen synthesis, translation of collagen alpha chains forms {{c1::preprocollagen}}
Collagen Synthesis: After the collagen alpha chains are synthesized, specific residues of the amino acids {{c1::proline}} and {{c1::lysine}} are {{c2::hydroxylated}}
Collagen Synthesis: Hydroxylation of selected prolines and lysines during collagen synthesis requires vitamin {{c1::C}}
Collagen Synthesis: Following hydroxylation of proline and lysine, there is {{c1::glycosylation}} of pro-α-chain {{c2::hydroxylysine}} residues
Collagen Synthesis: After hydroxylation and glycosylation, hydrogen and disulfide bonds help form a(n) {{c1::triple helix}} of collagen α chains (procollagen)
Collagen Synthesis: After the triple helix is formed, the procollagen is {{c1::exocytosed}} into the extracellular space

Where in the cell does synthesis, hydroxylation, and glycosylation of preprocollagen occur?

{{c1::Rough endoplasmic reticulum}}
Collagen Synthesis: Once in the extracellular space, cleavage of disulfide-rich terminal regions of procollagen by {{c2::procollagen peptidase}} forms the insoluble {{c1::tropocollagen}}
Collagen Synthesis: Staggered tropocollagen molecules are reinforced by covalent {{c1::lysine-hydroxylysine}} {{c2::cross-linkages}} to make collagen fibrils
Formation of lysine-hydroxylysine cross-linkages (collagen synthesis) requires both {{c1::copper}} and the enzyme {{c1::lysyl oxidase}}

Where in the cell does the synthesis and formation of tropocollagen and collagen fibrils occur?

{{c1::Extracellular space}}

Which collagen synthesis pathologies are associated with problems forming the triple helix?

{{c1::Osteogenesis imperfecta and Scurvy}}

What genetic bone disorder is also known as brittle bone disease?

{{c1::Osteogenesis imperfecta}}
Osteogenesis imperfecta is most commonly caused by gene defects in {{c1::COL1A1}} and {{c1::COL1A2}}

What is the inheritance of osteogenesis imperfecta (most common)?

{{c1::Autosomal dominant}}
Osteogenesis imperfecta may be confused with {{c1::child abuse}}
Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by multiple recurrent {{c1::fractures}} with minimal trauma
{{c2::Osteogenesis imperfecta}} may present with {{c1::blue sclerae}} due to translucent connective tissue over choroidal veins
Osteogenesis imperfecta may present with {{c1::hearing loss}} due to abnormal ossicles
Some forms of osteogenesis imperfecta have tooth abnormalities, including opalescent teeth that wear easily due to lack of {{c1::dentin}}

What is the inheritance of Menkes disease?

{{c1::X-linked recessive}}
{{c1::Menkes}} disease is caused by impaired {{c2::copper}} absorption and transport due to a defect in the ATP7A gene

What gene is defective in Menkes disease?

{{c1::ATP7A}}
The defective Menkes protein (Menkes disease) leads to decreased activity of the enzyme {{c1::lysyl oxidase}}
{{c2::Menkes}} disease results in {{c1::brittle, "kinky"}} hair, growth retardation, and hypotonia
{{c1::Elastin}} is a stretchy protein within skin, lungs, large arteries, elastic ligaments, vocal cords, and ligamentum flava
Elastin is rich in non-hydroxylated {{c1::proline}}, {{c1::glycine}}, and {{c1::lysine}} residues (amino acids)
Elastin is broken down by the enzyme {{c2::elastase}}, which is normally inhibited by {{c1::α1-antitrypsin}}
Elastin is tropoelastin with {{c1::fibrillin}} scaffolding

What gives elastin its elastic "rubber-like" properties?

{{c1::Cross-linking}}

Where in the cell does cross-linking of elastin take place?

{{c1::Extracellular space}}
{{c1::Marfan}} syndrome is caused by a defect in {{c2::fibrillin}}, a glycoprotein that forms a sheath around {{c3::elastin}}
{{c1::Emphysema}} may be caused by a(n) {{c2::α1-antitrypsin}} deficiency, resulting in excess elastase activity in alveoli
{{c1::Wrinkles}} of aging are due to decreased {{c2::collagen}} and elastin production
DNA requires {{c1::fragmentation}} for analysis, RNA and proteins do not (analyzed directly)
All RNA/DNA is {{c1::negatively}} charged
Most proteins are {{c1::negatively}} charged (except histones)
Gel electrophoresis separates fragments on the basis of {{c1::size}}
When using blotting procedures, the {{c1::probe}} determines what sequences are detected
A(n) {{c2::Southern}} blot is used to analyze {{c1::DNA}}
A(n) {{c2::Northern}} blot is used to analyze {{c1::RNA}}

Does a Southern blot require gel electrophoresis before analysis?

{{c1::Yes}}

Does a Northern blot require gel electrophoresis before analysis?

{{c1::Yes}}
A Northern blot is useful for studying gene {{c1::expression}}
A(n) {{c2::Western}} blot is used to analyze {{c1::protein}}

What type of probe is used to bind protein when using a Western blot?

{{c1::Labeled antibody}}

What type of probe is used to bind DNA/RNA when using a Southern/Northern blot?

{{c1::Labeled single stranded DNA / RNA oligonucleotide}}

Does a Dot (slot) blot require gel electrophoresis before analysis?

{{c1::No!}}
A(n) {{c1::Southwestern}} blot is used to identify {{c2::DNA-binding}} proteins using labeled oligonucleotide probes
{{c1::RFLP}} analysis analyzes DNA using variations in restriction enzyme sites between homologous DNA strands
{{c1::Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)}} is a powerful diagnostic tool used to amplify a desired fragment of DNA
In the first step of PCR, DNA is {{c1::denatured}} by using {{c2::heat}} to separate the strands
In the second step of PCR, {{c2::DNA primers}} {{c1::anneal}} to specific sequences on each DNA strand to be amplified
In the final step of PCR, heat-stable {{c2::Taq DNA polymerase}} {{c1::elongates}} the DNA sequence following each primer

How many primers are needed for polymerase chain reaction (PCR)?

{{c1::Two (one for the 3 end of each DNA strand)}}

What type of primer is used in a polymerase chain reaction (PCR)?

{{c1::DNA primer}}

Which end of the DNA strand does the DNA primer bind to during PCR?

{{c1::3 end}}
PCR requires the addition of all four {{c1::deoxynucleotide triphosphates (dNTPs)}} for DNA synthesis
{{c1::Flow cytometry}} is a laboratory technique used to assess size, granularity, and protein expression of individual cells in a sample

What laboratory technique is useful in determining CD4 cell count in HIV patients?

{{c1::Flow cytometry}}
In flow cytometry, cells are tagged with {{c1::antibodies}} specific to surface or intracellular proteins
In flow cytometry, antibodies are tagged with a unique {{c1::fluorescent dye}}, which is detected and counted during analysis
Flow Cytometry Example: Cells in the left lower quadrant are CD3{{c1::-}} and CD8{{c1::-}}
Flow Cytometry Example: Cells in the left upper quadrant are CD3{{c1::+}} and CD8{{c1::-}}
Flow Cytometry Example: Cells in the right lower quadrant are CD3{{c1::-}} and CD8{{c1::+}}
Flow Cytometry Example: Cells in the right upper quadrant are CD3{{c1::+}} and CD8{{c1::+}}
{{c1::Microarrays}} analyze thousands of nucleic acid sequences arranged in grids on glass or silicon
{{c1::Microarrays}} are a laboratory technique used to profile gene expression levels of thousands of genes simultaneously to study certain diseases and treatments
Microarrays use a(n) {{c1::labeled DNA/RNA}} probe, which is hybridized to the chip, and a scanner detects the relative amounts of complementary binding

What two types of variations in DNA are detected when using microarrays? (DNA markers)

{{c1::
- Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs)
- Copy number variations (CNVs)
}}
{{c1::Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)::not Coombs}} is an immunologic test used to detect the presence of either a specific antigen or antibody in a patients blood sample
When using ELISA, detection involves the use of a(n) {{c1::antibody}} linked to a(n) {{c2::enzyme}}
{{c1::Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH)}} uses a fluorescent DNA/RNA probe to bind to a specific gene of interest on chromosomes
{{c1::Fluoresence in situ hybridization (FISH)}} is a laboratory technique used for specific localization of genes and direct visualization of chromosomal anomalies
A(n) {{c1::microdeletion}} is detected with FISH as no fluorescence on a chromosome compared to fluorescence at the same locus on the second copy of that chromosome
A(n) {{c1::translocation}} is detected with FISH as fluorescence outside the original chromosome
A(n) {{c1::duplication}} is detected with FISH as an extra site of fluorescence on one chromosome relative to its homologous chromosome
A(n) {{c1::locus}} is the specific location of a gene on a chromosome
{{c1::Alleles}} are different forms of a single gene
When looking at a pedigree, a square is indicative of a(n) {{c1::male}}
When looking at a pedigree, a circle is indicative of a(n) {{c1::female}}
When looking at a pedigree, a(n) {{c1::shaded}} circle/square is indicative of a diseased individual
If a disease has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, it is usually {{c1::doesnt}} skip generations
Autosomal dominant diseases are often due to defects in {{c1::structural}} genes
Autosomal {{c1::dominant}} diseases are often pleiotropic and variably expressive
If a disease has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, it is usually {{c1::does}} skip generations
Autosomal recessive diseases are often due to {{c1::enzyme}} deficiences
There is an increased risk of autosomal recessive diseases in {{c1::consanguineous}} families
If a disease has an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, it usually {{c1::does}} skip generations
If a disease has an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, there is NO {{c1::male-to-male}} transmission
X-linked recessive diseases are commonly more severe in {{c1::males}}
If a male has an X-linked recessive disease, all of his daughters will be {{c1::carriers}}
In females, one of two X-chromosomes is condensed and its genes turned off by {{c1::cytosine methylation::specific action}}, forming heterochromatin (lyonization)
The formation of Barr bodies (X-chromosome inactivation) is also known as {{c1::lyonization}}
If a disease has an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern, it usually {{c1::doesnt}} skip generations
If a disease has an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern, there is NO {{c1::male-to-male}} transmission
If a male has an X-linked dominant disease, all of his daughters will be {{c1::affected}}

What is the mode of inheritance of hypophosphatemic rickets (vitamin D-resistant rickets)?

{{c1::X-linked dominant}}
Muscle biopsies of patients with {{c2::mitochondrial}} myopathies often show "{{c1::ragged red}}" fibers
Mitochondrial myopathies often present with myopathy, {{c1::lactic acidosis}}, and {{c2::CNS}} disease
If a mother has a mitochondrial disease, all her children are {{c1::affected}}
If a father has a mitochondrial disease, all his children are {{c1::unaffected}}
{{c1::Codominance}} describes an inheritance in which both alleles contribute to the phenotype of the heterozygote
{{c1::Variable expressivity}} describes phenotypic variation among individuals with the same genotype
If some individuals who have the disease genotype do not display the disease phenotype, the disease is said to have {{c1::incomplete penetrance}}
{{c1::Pleiotropy}} describes the contribution of one gene to multiple phenotypic effects

What class of diseases is characterized by anticipation?

{{c1::Trinucleotide repeat diseases (e.g. Huntington disease)}}
If a patient inherits or develops a mutation in a(n) {{c1::tumor suppressor}} gene, the complementary allele must be deleted/mutated before cancer develops
If mutations at different loci can produce a similar phenotype, a disease has {{c1::locus heterogeneity}}
If different mutations at the same locus produce the same phenotype, a disease has {{c1::allelic heterogeneity}}
{{c1::Uniparental disomy}} is the inheritance of 2 copies of a chromosome from one parent and no copies from the other

Does a uniparental disomy result in euploidy or aneuploidy?

{{c1::Euploidy}}
If a uniparental disomy results in a(n) {{c2::heterozygous}} offspring, there may have been a(n) {{c1::meiosis I}} error
If a uniparental disomy results in a(n) {{c2::homozygous}} offspring, there may have been a(n) {{c1::meiosis II}} error
{{c1::Genetic imprinting}} is the normal differential expression of an allele depending on parental origin (e.g. only one allele is active)
Both Prader-Willi and Angelman syndrome are due to a mutation or deletion of genes on chromosome {{c1::15}}
In {{c2::Prader-Willi::Prader-Willi OR Angelman}} syndrome, the {{c1::maternal}} gene is imprinted and the {{c1::paternal}} gene is mutated/deleted
In {{c2::Angelman}} syndrome, the {{c1::paternal}} gene is imprinted and the {{c1::maternal}} gene is mutated/deleted
25% of cases of Prader-Willi syndrome are due to {{c1::maternal}} uniparental disomy
5% of cases of Angelman syndrome are due to {{c1::paternal}} uniparental disomy

What pathology is characterized by insatiable appetite (hyperphagia), obesity, intellectual disability, and hypogonadism?

{{c1::Prader-Willi syndrome}}

What pathology is characterized by inappropriate laughter, seizures, ataxia, and severe intellectual disability?

{{c1::Angelman syndrome}}

What pathology is also known as "happy puppet" syndrome?

{{c1::Angelman syndrome}}
In both Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome, the most common abnormality is a gene {{c1::deletion}}
When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, p and q represent {{c1::allelic}} frequencies
When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, p2, 2pq, and q2 represent {{c1::genotypic}} frequencies

What equation is used to calculate allele frequency when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics?

{{c1::p + q = 1}}

What equation is used to calculate genotypic frequency when using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics?

{{c1::p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1}}
When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, the frequency of an X-linked recessive disease in males is equal to {{c1::q}}
When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, the frequency of an X-linked recessive disease in females is equal to {{c1::q2}}
When using Hardy-Weinberg population genetics, the frequency of a carrier of a recessive disease is equal to {{c1::2pq}}
One assumption of Hardy-Weinberg population genetics is that there is no net {{c1::migration}}
One assumption of Hardy-Weinberg population genetics is that there is {{c1::completely random}} mating
One assumption of Hardy-Weinberg population genetics is that {{c1::natural selection}} is not occurring
One assumption of Hardy-Weinberg population genetics is that no {{c1::mutations}} have occurred at the locus
{{c1::Mosaicism}} describes the presence of genetically distinct cell lines in the same individual
{{c1::Somatic}} mosaicism occurs when a mutation arises from {{c2::mitotic}} errors after fertilization and propagates through multiple tissues or organs
McCune-Albright syndrome is lethal if the mutation occurs before fertilization (affecting all cells), but survivable in patients with {{c1::mosaicism}}
McCune-Albright syndrome is due to a mutation affecting {{c1::G-protein}} signaling
{{c1::McCune-Albright}} syndrome is characterized by unilateral {{c2::café-au-lait}} spots, {{c3::precocious}} puberty, and {{c4::polyostotic fibrous}} dysplasia

What type of chromosome is most commonly involved in a robertsonian translocation?

{{c1::Acrocentric chromosomes}}
A(n) {{c1::Robertsonian translocation}} occurs when the long arms of 2 acrocentric chromosomes fuse at the centromere and the 2 short arms are lost

How can a Robertsonian translocation cause chromosomal imbalance in offspring?

{{c1::A gamete with the mutated chromosome is passed on (e.g. gamete with t(14;21))}}

Do Robertsonian translocations usually cause pathology in the individual who acquired the mutation?

{{c1::No, it usually is a balanced translocation}}
{{c1::Cri-du-chat}} syndrome is caused by a congenital microdeletion of chromosome {{c2::5p (short arm)}}

What pathology is associated with microcephaly, intellectual disability, and a high-pitched cry?

{{c1::Cri-du-chat syndrome}}
{{c1::Williams}} syndrome is caused by a congenital microdeletion of chromosome {{c2::7q (long arm)}}

What pathology is associated with "elfin" facies, intellectual disability, and extreme friendliness with strangers?

{{c1::Williams syndrome}}
{{c1::Linkage disequilibrium}} describes the tendency of alleles at two loci on the same chromosome to be inherited together more or less often than expected by chance
Linkage disequlibrium is measured in a(n) {{c1::population}}, not in a family
If alleles at two loci are inherited equally as expected by chance, the loci are said to be in {{c1::linkage equilibrium}}
The closer the recombination frequency is to {{c1::0}}%, the closer alleles in a haplotype are to each other

If two linked genes have a recombination frequency of 15%, approximately how far apart are they?

{{c1::15 centiMorgans (cM)}}
{{c1::LOD}} scores are used to calculate the probability that two loci are linked (linkage disequilibrium)
An LOD score greater than {{c1::3}} indicates linkage
An LOD score less than {{c1::-2}} indicates no linkage
{{c1::Marfan}} syndrome is due to a(n) {{c2::FBN1}} gene mutation on chromosome {{c3::15}}

What protein is defective in Marfan syndrome?

{{c1::Fibrillin (scaffold for elastin)}}

What pathology is associated with long, tapering fingers and toes (arachnodactyly) and subluxation of lenses?

{{c1::Marfan syndrome}}
Marfan syndrome typically presents with subluxation of the lenses {{c1::upward::direction}} and {{c1::temporally::direction}}
Marfan syndrome is associated with a floppy {{c1::mitral}} valve

What is the mode of inheritance of Marfan syndrome?

{{c1::Autosomal dominant}}

What is the mode of inheritance of Fragile X syndrome?

{{c1::X-linked dominant}}

What class of diseases is Fragile X syndrome a part of?

{{c1::Trinucleotide repeat expansion diseases}}
{{c2::Fragile X}} syndrome is due to a trinucleotide repeat in the {{c1::FMR1}} gene

What pathology is associated with an enlarged jaw, testes, and ears?

{{c1::Fragile X syndrome}}

What sequence of nucleotides is repeated in Fragile X syndrome?

{{c1::CGG}}

What is the second most common cause of genetic intellectual disability?

{{c1::Fragile X syndrome (#1 is Down syndrome)}}

What class of diseases is Huntington disease a part of?

{{c1::Trinucleotide repeat expansion diseases}}

What class of diseases is Friedreich ataxia a part of?

{{c1::Trinucleotide repeat expansion diseases}}

What class of diseases is myotonic dystrophy a part of?

{{c1::Trinucleotide repeat expansion diseases}}

What sequence of nucleotides is repeated in Friedreich ataxia?

{{c1::GAA}}

What sequence of nucleotides is repeated in Huntington disease?

{{c1::CAG}}

What sequence of nucleotides is repeated in myotonic dystrophy?

{{c1::CTG}}

What is the most common cause (95%) of Down syndrome?

{{c1::Meiotic nondisjunction}}
4% of cases of Down syndrome are due to unbalanced {{c1::Robertsonian translocation}}
1% of cases of Down syndrome are due to {{c1::mosaicism}}

What is the most common cause of genetic intellectual disability?

{{c1::Down syndrome}}
Down syndrome may present with {{c1::increased}} nuchal translucency on ultrasound
Down syndrome presents with {{c1::decreased}} serum PAPP-A
Down syndrome presents with {{c1::increased}} free β-hCG
Down syndrome presents with {{c1::increased}} inhibin A
Down syndrome presents with {{c1::decreased}} estriol
Down syndrome presents with {{c1::decreased}} free α-fetoprotein (AFP)

What pathology is associated with intellectual disability, prominent epicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease?

{{c1::Down syndrome}}

What chromosomal abnormality is associated with Down syndrome?

{{c1::Trisomy 21}}

What chromosomal abnormality is associated with Edwards syndrome?

{{c1::Trisomy 18}}

What chromosomal abnormality is associated with Patau syndrome?

{{c1::Trisomy 13}}

The findings in Edwards Syndrome may be remembered with PRINCE Edward:

- P{{c2::rominent occiput}}
- Rocker-bottom feet
- Intellectual disability
- Nondisjunction
- C{{c3::lenched fists with overlapping fingers}}
- low-set E{{c1::ars}}
Patients with Edwards syndrome and Patau syndrome often die within {{c1::1}} year(s) of birth
Edward syndrome and Patau syndrome present with {{c1::decreased}} serum PAPP-A
Edward syndrome and Patau syndrome present with {{c1::decreased}} free β-hCG
Edward syndrome presents with {{c1::decreased}} or {{c1::normal}} inhibin A
Edward syndrome presents with {{c1::decreased}} estriol
Edward syndrome presents with {{c1::decreased}} free α-fetoprotein (AFP)

The findings in Patau Syndrome may be remembered with the 5Ps

- cleft Palate
- holoP{{c2::rosencephaly}}
- P{{c1::olydactyly}}
- aP{{c4::lasia cutis}}
- P{{c3::olycystic Kidney disease}}

How does the cardiac output of the left heart compare to the right heart?

{{c1::Equal (in steady state)}}
The rate at which blood is returned to the atria is called the {{c1::venous return}}
Oxygenated blood flows from the lungs to the {{c2::left atrium}} via the {{c1::pulmonary vein}}
Blood flows from the left atrium to the left ventricle through the {{c1::mitral (bicuspid)}} valve
Blood flows from the left ventricle to the {{c1::aorta}} through the {{c2::aortic}} valve
Blood flows from the {{c1::aorta}} to the systemic arteries and tissues
Blood flows from the tissues to the systemic veins and ultimately the {{c1::vena cava}} before returning to the right atrium
Deoxygenated blood flows from the vena cava to the {{c1::right atrium}}
Blood flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle through the {{c1::tricuspid}} valve
Blood flows from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery through the {{c1::pulmonic}} valve
Blood flows from the pulmonary artery to the {{c1::lungs}} for oxygenation
{{c1::Arterioles}} are a type of blood vessel with the {{c2::highest}} resistance in the cardiovascular system
When activated, β2-adrenergic receptors cause {{c1::relaxation}} of vascular smooth muscle

What equation may be used to calculate the velocity of blood flow (v) given the flow rate (Q)?

{{c1::v = Q/A}}
Velocity of blood (v) is {{c1::inversely}} proportional to the total cross-sectional area

What type of blood vessel has the lowest flow velocity?

{{c1::Capillaries}}

What equation may be used to calculate the blood flow (Q) given pressure and resistance?

{{c1::Q = ΔP/R}}
Blood flow (Q) is {{c1::inversely}} proportional to the resistance of blood vessels
The magnitude of blood flow (Q) is {{c1::directly}} proportional to the size of the pressure difference between blood vessels
The direction of blood flow is determined by the direction of the {{c1::pressure gradient}} and is always from high to low pressure
The resistance of the entire systemic vasculature is called the {{c1::total peripheral resistance (TPR)}}
In Poiseulles equation, Resistance is {{c1::directly}} proportional to the {{c2::viscosity (η)}} of the blood
Resistance is {{c1::directly}} proportional to the {{c2::length}} of the blood vessel
Resistance is {{c1::inversely}} proportional to the {{c3::fourth}} power of the {{c2::radius}} of the blood vessel

What type of resistance is illustrated by the arrangement of blood vessels within a given organ?

{{c1::Series resistance}}
The equation {{c2::Rtotal = R1 + R2 ...}} may be used to calculate the total resistance of a system arranged in {{c1::series}}
