Which type of blood vessel causes the greatest decrease in pressure in a vascular system arranged in series?

{{c1::Arterioles}}
When resistances are arranged in {{c1::series}}, the total {{c2::flow}} through each level of the system is the same

What type of resistance is illustrated by the arrangement of blood vessels in systemic circulation?

{{c1::Parallel resistance}}
The equation {{c2::1/Rtotal = 1/R1 + 1/R2 ...}} may be used to calculate the total resistance of a system arranged in {{c1::parallel}}
When a blood vessel is added to a system in series, the total resistance {{c1::increases}}
When a blood vessel is added to a system in parallel, the total resistance {{c1::decreases}}
When vessels are arranged in {{c1::parallel}}, the total resistance is less than the resistance of any of the individual arteries
When resistances are arranged in {{c1::parallel}}, the {{c2::pressure}} through each level of the system is the same
Ideally, blood flow in the cardiovascular system is {{c1::laminar}}, or streamlined
If blood flow is laminar, the highest velocity occurs at the {{c1::center}} of the blood vessel
{{c1::Reynolds}} number predicts whether blood flow will be laminar or turbulent
When Reynolds number is {{c2::increased}}, there is a greater tendency for {{c1::turbulent}} blood flow
Turbulent flow in a blood vessel causes audible vibrations known as {{c1::bruits or murmurs::2}}
A(n) {{c1::increase}} in velocity of blood causes an increase in Reynolds number
A(n) {{c1::decrease}} in viscosity of blood causes an increase in Reynolds number

What is the effect of blood vessel narrowing (e.g. thrombus) on Reynolds number?

{{c1::Increased}}
Viscosity of blood depends mostly on {{c1::hematocrit}}

What is the effect of anemia on blood viscosity?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What is the effect of polycythemia on blood viscosity?

{{c1::Increased}}
The {{c1::capacitance (compliance)}} of a blood vessel describes the volume of blood the vessel can hold at a given pressure
The greater the amount of elastic tissue there is in a blood vessel (elastance), the {{c1::lower}} the compliance is

What is the result of aging on the capacitance (compliance) of arteries?

{{c1::Decreased (more stiff, less distensible)}}
{{c1::Systolic}} pressure is the highest arterial pressure during the cardiac cycle
{{c1::Diastolic}} pressure is the lowest arterial pressure during the cardiac cycle
The {{c1::pulse}} pressure is the difference between the systolic and diastolic pressures
Pulse pressure is {{c1::directly}} proportional to stroke volume
Pulse pressure is {{c1::inversely}} proportional to arterial compliance

What equation may be used to calculate mean arterial pressure given a patients blood pressure?

{{c1::MAP = 2/3 diastolic pressure + 1/3 systolic pressure}}
Action potentials in the heart are usually initiated in the {{c1::SA node}}, which serves as the {{c2::pacemaker}}
Action potentials spread from the SA node to the {{c1::AV}} node and right/left {{c1::atria}}, simultaneously
Conduction velocity through the AV node is {{c1::slower}} than in the other cardiac tissues
From the AV node, the myocardial action potential enters the {{c1::Bundle of His}}
From the Bundle of His, the myocardial action potential enters the {{c1::Purkinje fibers}} and ultimately the ventricles
The resting membrane potential of cardiac cells is determined primarily by {{c1::potassium (K+)}} ions
In a cardiac cell, the conductance to K+ at rest is {{c1::high::high/low}}
The Na+ and K+ concentration gradients across the cardiac cell are maintained by the {{c1::Na+-K+-ATPase}} pump
Phase {{c1::0}} of the myocardial action potential is characterized by rapid {{c2::upstroke/depolarization}}
Phase 0 of the myocardial action potential is caused by opening of voltage-gated {{c1::Na+}} channels
Phase {{c1::1}} of the myocardial action potential is characterized by {{c2::initial repolarization}}
Phase 1 of the myocardial action potential is caused by inactivation of voltage-gated {{c1::Na+}} channels and opening of voltage-gated {{c1::K+}} channels
Phase {{c1::2}} of the myocardial action potential is characterized by {{c2::plateau}}
Phase 2 of the myocardial action potential (plateau) is caused by a balance of {{c1::K+}} efflux and {{c1::Ca2+}} influx through voltage-gated channels
The calcium channels that open during the plateau phase (myocardial action potential) are {{c1::L}}-type channels
The influx of calcium during the plateau phase of a myocardial action potential triggers release of Ca2+ from the {{c1::sarcoplasmic reticulum}}, causing myocyte {{c2::contraction}}
Phase {{c1::3}} of the myocardial action potential is characterized by {{c2::rapid repolarization}}
Phase 3 of the myocardial action potential is caused by massive efflux of {{c1::K+}} and closure of voltage-gated {{c1::Ca2+}} channels
Phase {{c1::4}} of the myocardial action potential is characterized by a return to {{c2::resting membrane potential}}

What type of action potential occurs in the ventricles, atria, and Purkinje system?

{{c1::Myocardial action potentials (phase 0 through phase 4)}}
Phase {{c1::0}} of the SA node action potential is characterized by {{c2::upstroke}}
Phase 0 of the SA node action potential is caused by opening of voltage-gated {{c1::Ca2+}} channels

How does the rate of upstroke in a SA node action potential compare to that of a myocardial action potential?

{{c1::SA node is slower}}

What type of calcium channels exist in the SA node?

{{c1::L-type (primary) and T-type::2}}

What phases of the myocardial action potential are not present in an SA node action potential?

{{c1::Phase 1 & 2 (initial repolarization & plateau)}}
Phase {{c1::3}} of the SA node action potential is characterized by {{c2::repolarization}}
Phase 3 of the SA node action potential is caused by activation of {{c1::K+}} channels and inactivation of {{c1::Ca2+}} channels
Phase {{c2::4}} of the SA node action potential is characterized by {{c1::slow depolarization}}
The rate of phase {{c1::4}} in the SA node action potential cycle determines {{c2::heart rate}}

Which phase in the SA node accounts for its pacemaker activity and automaticity?

{{c1::Phase 4 (slow depolarization)}}
Phase 4 of the SA node action potential is caused by a slow, mixed Na+/K+ inward current via {{c1::If ("funny")}} channels

What three cell types are considered latent pacemakers?

{{c1::Cells of the AV node, bundle of His, and Purkinje fibers}}
{{c1::Conduction velocity}} is the speed at which action potentials are propagated within the tissue

Where in the heart is conduction velocity the slowest?

{{c1::AV node}}

Where in the heart is conduction velocity the fastest?

{{c1::Purkinje fibers}}
Conduction velocity depends on the {{c1::size (magnitude)}} of the inward current during the upstroke of an action potential
{{c1::Excitability}} is the ability of cardiac cells to initiate action potentials in response to inward, depolarizing current
The {{c1::absolute}} refractory period refers to the period in which no action potential can be initiated
In cardiac cells, the absolute refractory period begins with the {{c1::upstroke}} and ends after the {{c2::plateau}}
The {{c1::effective}} refractory period refers to the period in which a(n) {{c2::conductive}} action potential cannot be generated
The {{c1::relative}} refractory period refers to the period in which a second action potential is possible, but requires a greater-than-normal stimulus
The effects of the autonomic nervous system on heart rate are called {{c1::chronotropic}} effects
A negative chronotropic effect {{c1::decreases}} heart rate
A positive chronotropic effect {{c1::increases}} heart rate

What is the result of sympathetic stimulation on heart rate?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the result of parasympathetic stimulation on heart rate?

{{c1::Decreased}}

Through what receptor does the sympathetic nervous system increase heart rate?

{{c1::β1 adrenergic receptor}}
Activation of β1 receptors in the SA node produces an increase in {{c1::If}} channel activity, which increases the rate of phase 4 depolarization and thus heart rate

Through what receptor does the parasympathetic nervous system decrease heart rate?

{{c1::M2 muscarinic receptor::specific#}}
Activation of M2 receptors in the SA node produces a decrease in {{c1::If}} channel activity, which decreases the rate of phase 4 depolarization and thus heart rate
A negative dromotropic effect {{c1::decreases}} conduction velocity through the AV node
A positive dromotropic effect {{c1::increases}} conduction velocity through the AV node

What is the result of sympathetic stimulation on conduction velocity?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the result of parasympathetic stimulation on conduction velocity?

{{c1::Decreased}}
The {{c1::P wave}} on ECG represents {{c2::atrial depolarization}}
Atrial repolarization is not seen on an ECG because it is masked by the {{c1::QRS complex}}
The duration of the P wave correlates with the {{c1::conduction velocity}} through the atria
The {{c1::PR interval}} on ECG is the time from the initial depolarization of the atria to the initial depolarization of the ventricles
The PR interval on ECG depends on the conduction velocity through the {{c1::AV node}}
The {{c1::QRS complex}} on ECG represents {{c2::ventricular depolarization}}
The {{c2::T wave}} on ECG represents {{c1::ventricular repolarization}}
T-wave inversion may indicate recent {{c1::myocardial infarction (MI)}}
The {{c1::QT interval}} on ECG represents the entire period of ventricular depolarization, contraction, and repolarization
The {{c1::ST segment}} on ECG is an isoelectric period (horizontal line) when the ventricles are depolarized
The U wave on ECG is prominent in {{c1::hypokalemia}} and {{c2::bradycardia}}
The {{c1::J point}} on ECG is the junction between the end of QRS complex and start of ST segment

Which pacemaker in the heart has the fastest rate?

{{c1::SA node (hence why it is dominant)}}
The {{c1::left}} bundle branch of the bundle of His divides into anterior and posterior {{c2::fascicles}}
Slowed conduction through the AV node normally causes a(n) {{c1::100}}-msec delay, allowing time for ventricular filling
Serotonin syndrome as a side effect of ondansetron is more common in patients with concommitant use of drugs that increase levels of {{c2::serotonin}}
The {{c1::sarcomere}} is the contractile unit of the myocardial cell

What part of a myocardial cell is responsible for carrying action potentials into the cell interior?

{{c1::T tubules}}

What part of a myocardial cell is the site of storage and release of Ca2+ for excitation-contraction coupling?

{{c1::Sarcoplasmic Reticulum (SR)}}
During the plateau of a myocardial action potential, Ca2+ enters the cell through {{c1::dihydropyridine}} receptors (L-type Ca2+ channels)
Entry of Ca2+ into the myocardial cell during the myocardial action potential triggers further release of Ca2+ through {{c1::ryanodine}} receptors (Ca2+ release channels)
The magnitude of the tension that develops during myocardial excitation-contraction coupling is proportional to levels of intracellular {{c1::Ca2+}}

Relaxation of a myocardial cell occurs when:
- Ca2+ is reaccumulated in the sarcoplasmic reticulum by the action of {{c1::Ca2+ ATPase (SERCA)}}
- Ca2+ is pumped out of the cell by the {{c2::Na+/Ca2+ exchanger (NCX)}}
{{c1::Gap junctions}} are low-resistance paths between cardiac cells that allow for rapid electrical spread of action potentials
Contractility, or {{c1::inotropism}}, is the intrinsic ability of myocardial cells to develop force at a given muscle length
A positive inotropic effect {{c1::increases}} heart contractility
A negative inotropic effect {{c1::decreases}} heart contractility
Cardiac contractility correlates directly with intracellular {{c1::Ca2+}} concentration
Sympathetic stimulation increases myocardial contractility via {{c1::β1}} receptors
Sympathetic stimulation increases the activity of {{c2::Ca2+ ATPase aka SERCA}} via phosphorylation/inhibition of {{c1::phospholamban}}
Parasympathetic stimulation decreases {{c3::atrial}} contractility via {{c1::M2}} receptors

What effect does increased heart rate have on cardiac contractility?

{{c1::Increased contractility (to an extent)}}

What effect does decreased heart rate have on cardiac contractility?

{{c1::Decreased contractility}}
Cardiac contractility increases with {{c1::increased::increased or decreased}} catecholamines
Cardiac contractility increases with {{c1::increased}} intracellular Ca2+
Cardiac contractility increases with {{c1::decreased}} extracellular Na+

What is the effect of cardiac glycosides on contractility?

{{c1::Increased contractility}}
Increased intracellular [Na+] in cardiac myocytes causes decreased activity of the {{c1::Ca2+-Na+}} exchanger
{{c1::Stroke volume}} is defined as the volume of blood ejected by one ventricular contraction
{{c1::Ejection fraction}} is defined as the fraction of the end-diastolic volume that is ejected in each stroke volume
The equation {{c1::SV = EDV - ESV}} may be used to calculate stroke volume
The equation {{c1::ejection fraction = SV/EDV}} may be used to calculate ejection fraction
Cardiac {{c2::contractility}} can be estimated by the left ventricular {{c1::ejection fraction}}
Ejection fraction is normally > {{c1::55}}%

What equation is used to calculate cardiac output given a patients stroke volume and heart rate?

{{c1::CO = SV x HR}}
The Frank-Starling relationship states that the force of {{c1::contraction}} is proportional to the {{c2::end-diastolic length}} of the cardiac muscle fiber

What is the effect of increased venous return on end-diastolic volume (EDV)?

{{c1::Increased EDV}}
Increases in contractility cause the Starling curve to shift {{c1::upward}}
Decreases in contractility (e.g. heart failure) cause the Starling curve to shift {{c1::downward}}
Exercise causes the Starling curve to shift {{c1::upward}}
{{c1::Isovolumetric contraction}} is the first phase of a cardiac cycle and represents the period between mitral valve closing and aortic valve opening
{{c1::Ventricular (systolic) ejection}} is the second phase of a cardiac cycle and represents the period between aortic valve opening and closing
{{c1::Isovolumetric relaxation}} is the third phase of a cardiac cycle and represents the period between aortic valve closing and mitral valve opening
{{c1::Rapid ventricular filling}} is the fourth phase of a cardiac cycle and represents the period just after mitral valve opening
{{c1::Reduced filling}} is the fifth phase of a cardiac cycle and represents the period just before mitral valve closing
The {{c2::width}} of a pressure-volume loop is the {{c1::stroke volume}}
Preload is approximated by ventricular {{c1::end-diastolic volume (EDV)}}

What effect does increased venous return have on preload?

{{c1::Increased preload}}
Afterload is approximated by {{c1::mean arterial pressure}}

What effect does increased aortic pressure have on afterload?

{{c1::Increased afterload}}
Increased {{c2::preload}} results in a(n) {{c1::increased}} width on a pressure-volume loop curve
Increased {{c2::afterload}} results in a(n) {{c1::decreased}} width and {{c1::increased}} height on a pressure-volume loop curve
Increased {{c2::contractility}} results in a(n) {{c1::increased}} width and {{c1::increased}} height on a pressure-volume loop curve

What effect does increased preload have on stroke volume?

{{c1::Increased SV}}

What effect does increased afterload have on stroke volume?

{{c1::Decreased SV}}

What effect does increased afterload have on end-systolic volume?

{{c1::Increased ESV}}

What effect does increased contractility have on end-systolic volume?

{{c1::Decreased ESV}}

What effect does increased contractility have on stroke volume?

{{c1::Increased SV}}

What effect does increased preload have on ejection fraction?

{{c1::Increased EF}}
According to the law of Laplace, cardiac wall stress = {{c1::P*r / 2H}}
Cardiac O2 consumption is directly related to the amount of {{c1::tension}} developed by the ventricles

What is the effect of increased afterload (increased aortic pressure) on cardiac O2 consumption?

{{c1::Increased O2 consumption}}

What is the effect of increased ventricular diameter on cardiac O2 consumption?

{{c1::Increased O2 consumption}}

What is the effect of increased contractility on cardiac O2 consumption?

{{c1::Increased O2 consumption}}

What is the effect of increased heart rate on cardiac O2 consumption?

{{c1::Increased O2 consumption}}

The reasons there is concentric left ventricular hypertrophy in response to systemic hypertension is that {{c1::increased}} wall thickness {{c1::decreases}} wall stress by offsetting {{c1::increased}} wall tension
The left ventricle compensates for increased afterload by {{c1::thickening (hypertrophy)}} in order to decrease wall tension

What effect does increased aortic pressure (afterload) have on cardiac wall stress?

{{c1::Increased wall stress}}

According to the Fick principle:
{{c2::Cardiac Output (CO)}} = {{c1::O2 consumption / (arterial O2 content - venous O2 content)}}
The resistance of a vessel may be calculated using Poiseuilles equation, which states R = {{c1::8ηl/πr4}}
The likelihood of turbulent flow may be calculated using Reynolds number, which states NR = {{c1::ρdv/η}}
The heart sound S1 is due to {{c2::mitral}} and {{c2::tricuspid}} valve closure
The heart sound {{c1::S2}} is due to {{c2::aortic}} and {{c2::pulmonic}} valve closure
The normal heart sound {{c1::S2}} is loudest at the left upper sternal border
Atrial {{c1::systole}} is preceded by the {{c2::P}} wave on ECG, which marks depolarization of the atria
The increase in atrial pressure caused by atrial systole appears on the venous pulse curve as the {{c1::a}} wave

Is the fourth heart sound (S4) normally audible in adults?

{{c1::No}}
The heart sound {{c1::S4}} can be associated with ventricular {{c2::noncompliance}}
The abnormal heart sounds S3 and S4 are best heard at the heart {{c1::apex}}, with the patient in left lateral decubitus position
The abnormal heart sound {{c1::S4}} may be audible during atrial systole (late ventricular diastole)

What phase of the cardiac cycle begins during the QRS complex on ECG?

{{c1::Isovolumetric ventricular contraction::specific}}
The heart sound {{c1::S1}} may be audible during isovolumetric contraction
When the left ventricle contracts, the left ventricular pressure becomes greater than left atrial pressure and the {{c1::mitral}} valve closes
During rapid ventricular ejection, the ventricular pressure becomes greater than aortic pressure and the {{c1::aortic}} valve opens
The end of rapid ventricular ejection corresponds with the onset of the {{c1::T}} wave on ECG
During right ventricular contraction, the tricuspid valve bulges into the right atrium, which appears as the {{c1::c}} wave on the venous pulse curve
The onset of reduced ventricular ejection corresponds with the onset of the {{c1::T}} wave on ECG
During atrial relaxation, the tricuspid valve returns to its downward position, which appears as the {{c1::x}} descent on the venous pulse curve
The heart sound {{c1::S2}} may be audible during isovolumetric relaxation

How does ventricular pressure change during isovolumetric relaxation?

{{c1::Decrease}}
Increased right atrial pressure, due to filling against a closed tricuspid valve, appears as the {{c1::v}} wave on the venous pulse curve
Isovolumetric {{c1::relaxation}} corresponds to the end of the {{c2::T}} wave on ECG
During isovolumetric relaxation, the ventricular pressure becomes less than aortic pressure and the {{c1::aortic}} valve closes
Inspiration delays closure of the {{c1::pulmonic}} valve which causes {{c2::splitting}} of the S2 heart sound
During rapid ventricular filling, the left ventricular pressure becomes less than the left atrial pressure and the {{c1::mitral}} valve opens
The abnormal heart sound {{c1::S3}} may be audible during rapid ventricular filling (early diastole)

In what demographics may the heart sound S3 be normal?

{{c1::Children, young adults, pregnant women, athletes::4 options}}
The presence of the heart sound S3 in middle-aged or older adults indicates volume {{c1::overload}}
During rapid ventricular filling, the right atrium empties into the right ventricle, which appears as the {{c1::y}} descent on the venous pulse curve
The {{c2::cardiac}} function curve is a plot of the relationship between {{c1::cardiac output}} of the left ventricle and {{c1::pressure}} of the right atrium
The {{c2::vascular}} function curve is a plot of the relationship between {{c1::pressure}} of the right atrium and {{c1::venous return}}
The {{c1::mean systemic pressure}} is the point at which the vascular function curve intersects the x-axis
The mean systemic pressure is equal to the right atrial pressure when the venous return is {{c1::zero}}

What effect does increased blood volume have on mean systemic pressure?

{{c1::Increased}}
An increase in mean systemic pressure is reflected in a shift of the {{c2::vascular}} function curve to the {{c1::right}}
A decrease in mean systemic pressure is reflected in a shift of the {{c2::vascular}} function curve to the {{c1::left}}

What effect does increased venous tone (decreased compliance) have on mean systemic pressure?

{{c1::Increased}}

What two factors influence the value for mean systemic pressure?

{{c1::Blood volume, venous tone}}
The slope of the vascular function curve is determined primarily by {{c1::total peripheral resistance (TPR)}}
A(n) {{c1::positive}} inotropic agent causes the {{c3::cardiac}} function curve to shift {{c2::upwards}}
A(n) {{c1::negative}} inotropic agent causes the cardiac function curve to shift {{c2::downwards}}
The {{c1::intersection}} of the cardiac and vascular function curves is the operating point of the heart
A positive inotropic agent causes the cardiac output to {{c1::increase}} and right atrial pressure to {{c1::decrease}}
A negative inotropic agent causes the cardiac output to {{c1::decrease}} and right atrial pressure to {{c1::increase}}
An increased blood volume (or venous tone) causes the cardiac output to {{c1::increase}} and right atrial pressure to {{c1::increase}}
A decreased blood volume (or venous tone) causes the cardiac output to {{c1::decrease}} and right atrial pressure to {{c1::decrease}}
An increased TPR causes the cardiac output to {{c1::decrease}} and venous return to {{c1::decrease}}
A decreased TPR causes the cardiac output to {{c1::increase}} and venous return to {{c1::increase}}
A(n) {{c2::decrease}} in TPR causes a(n) {{c1::clockwise}} rotation of the vascular function curve
A(n) {{c2::increase}} in TPR causes a(n) {{c1::counterclockwise}} rotation of the vascular function curve
A(n) {{c2::decrease}} in TPR causes a(n) {{c1::upward}} shift of the cardiac function curve
A(n) {{c2::increase}} in TPR causes a(n) {{c1::downward}} shift of the cardiac function curve

What equation is used to calculate mean arterial pressure using a patients cardiac output?

{{c1::MAP = CO x TPR}}
Mean arterial pressure is maintained at a constant level of approximately {{c1::100}} mmHg
Baroreceptors are stretch mechanoreceptors located within the {{c1::carotid sinus}} and the {{c1::aortic arch}}

Which baroreceptors are responsive to both increases and decreases in arterial pressure?

{{c1::Carotid sinus receptors}}

Which baroreceptors are responsive to increases in arterial pressure only?

{{c1::Aortic arch receptors}}
Information from the carotid sinus baroreceptor is carried to the {{c2::nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS)}} via the {{c1::glossopharyngeal}} nerve
Information from the aortic arch baroreceptors is carried to the {{c2::nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS)}} via the {{c1::vagus}} nerve

How does decreased efferent parasympathetic firing (e.g. baroreceptor reflex) affect heart rate?

{{c1::Increased HR}}

How does increased efferent sympathetic firing (e.g. baroreceptor reflex) affect heart rate?

{{c1::Increased HR}}

How does increased efferent sympathetic firing (e.g. baroreceptor reflex) affect contractility?

{{c1::Increased contractility}}
The integrity of the {{c2::baroreceptor}} reflex can be tested with the {{c1::Valsalva}} maneuver
The a wave on jugular venous pulse corresponds to {{c1::atrial contraction}}
The c wave on jugular venous pulse corresponds to {{c1::right ventricle contraction}}
The x descent on jugular venous pulse corresponds to {{c1::atrial relaxation}}
The v wave on jugular venous pulse corresponds to {{c1::right atrial filling}}
The y descent on jugular venous pulse corresponds to {{c1::right atrial emptying into the right ventricle}}
The {{c1::renin-angiotensin II-aldosterone system}} is a slow, hormonally mediated mechanism of regulating arterial pressure
The renin-angiotensin II-aldosterone system regulates mean arterial pressure primarily by adjusting blood {{c1::volume}}
The renin-angiotensin II-aldosterone system is activated in response to a(n) {{c1::decrease}} in mean arterial pressure
A decrease in renal perfusion pressure causes the {{c2::juxtaglomerular}} cells of the afferent arterioles to secrete {{c1::renin}}
{{c1::Renin}} is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of {{c2::angiotensinogen}} to {{c2::angiotensin I}} in the plasma
{{c1::Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)}} catalyzes the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II

In which organ does angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) catalyze conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II?

{{c1::Lungs (primarily)}}
Angiotensin II stimulates the synthesis and secretion of {{c1::aldosterone}} by the adrenal cortex
Angiotensin II increases {{c1::Na+-H+}} exchange in the proximal convoluted tubule
Angiotensin II increases {{c1::thirst}} via its action on the hypothalamus
Angiotensin II causes {{c1::constriction}} of arterioles
{{c1::Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)}} is released from atrial myocytes in response to {{c2::increased}} blood volume and atrial pressure

Through which secondary messenger does ANP exert its actions?

{{c1::cGMP}}
Atrial natriuretic peptide generally causes {{c1::dilation}} of arterioles

What effect does atrial natriuretic peptide have on Na+ reabsorption at the renal collecting tubule?

{{c1::Decreased reabsorption}}

Atrial natriuretic peptide dilates afferent renal arterioles and constricts efferent renal arterioles, which {{c1::increases}} excretion of Na+ and water, along with downregulating {{c2::ENaC}} on the collecting tubules
Atrial baroreceptors respond to {{c2::decreased}} blood volume by increasing release of {{c1::vasopressin (ADH)}} from the posterior pituitary
Vasopressin (ADH) causes {{c1::constriction}} of arterioles by activating {{c2::V1}} receptors
Vasopressin (ADH) causes water reabsorption by the renal distal tubule and collecting ducts by activating {{c2::V2}} receptors
The effective osmotic pressure contributed by protein is called the {{c1::oncotic}} pressure
The Starling equation is used to determine fluid flow (Jv) and states that Jv = {{c1::Kf [(Pc - Pi) - σ(πc −πi)]}}

What does Kf represent in regards to capillary fluid exchange?

{{c1::Permeability to fluid (water)}}

What does Pc represent in regards to capillary fluid exchange?

{{c1::Capillary hydrostatic pressure}}
Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc) pushes fluid {{c1::out of}} the capillary
Capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pc) is highest at the {{c1::arteriolar}} end of the capillary and lowest at the {{c1::venous}} end

What does Pi represent in regards to capillary fluid exchange?

{{c1::Interstitial hydrostatic pressure}}
Increased interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi) pushes fluid {{c1::into}} the capillary

What does πc represent in regards to capillary fluid exchange?

{{c1::Capillary oncotic pressure}}
Increased capillary oncotic pressure (πc) pulls fluid {{c1::into}} the capillary

What does πi represent in regards to capillary fluid exchange?

{{c1::Interstitial oncotic pressure}}
Increased interstitial oncotic pressure (πi) pulls fluid {{c1::out of}} the capillary
Edema may be caused by {{c1::increased}} capillary pressure (Pc)
Edema may be caused by {{c1::decreased}} plasma proteins (πc)
Edema may be caused by {{c1::increased}} capillary permeability (Kf)
Edema may be caused by {{c1::increased}} interstitial proteins (πi)
{{c1::Autoregulation}} is the maintenance of a constant blood flow to an organ in the face of changing arterial pressures
{{c1::Active hyperemia}} is the concept that blood flow to an organ is proportional to its metabolic activity

The vasodilator metabolites produced by tissues as a result of increased metabolic activity may be remembered using the mnemonic "CHALK":

C: {{c1::CO2}}
H: {{c2::H+}}
A: {{c3::Adenosine}}
L: {{c4::Lactate}}
K: {{c5::K+}}
Histamine causes arteriolar {{c1::dilation}} and venous {{c1::constriction}}
Bradykinin causes arteriolar {{c1::dilation}} and venous {{c1::constriction}}
Thromboxane A2 is a vaso-{{c1::constrictor}}

What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the heart?

{{c1::Local metabolites}}
The most important local metabolic factors for coronary circulation are {{c1::nitric oxide (NO)}} and {{c1::adenosine}} (vasodilatory)

What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the brain?

{{c1::Local metabolites (vasodilatory)}}

What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the lungs?

{{c1::Hypoxia (causes vasoconstriction)}}
In the {{c2::lungs}}, hypoxia causes vaso-{{c1::constriction}}

What are the major factors determining autoregulation of blood flow to the kidney?

{{c1::Myogenic and tubuloglomerular feedback::2}}

What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the resting skeletal muscle?

{{c1::Sympathetic innervation}}
Sympathetic stimulation of {{c1::α1}} receptors in skeletal muscle causes vaso-{{c2::constriction}}
Sympathetic stimulation of {{c1::β2}} receptors in skeletal muscle causes vaso-{{c2::dilation}}

What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the exercising skeletal muscle?

{{c1::Local metabolites}}

What is the major factor determining autoregulation of blood flow to the skin?

{{c1::Sympathetic innervation}}
The primary function of autoregulation of blood flow to the skin is {{c1::temperature}} regulation
Exposure to cold temperatures activates centers in the {{c2::posterior}} hypothalamus, which then activate α and γ motoneurons innervating skeletal muscle, causing {{c1::shivering}}
Mechanisms for dissipating heat are coordinated in the {{c1::anterior}} hypothalamus
Pyrogens induce fever via increased production of {{c1::IL-1}}, which acts on the anterior hypothalamus to increase local production of {{c2::prostaglandins}}

How does exercise affect total peripheral resistance?

{{c1::Decreased TPR}}
{{c1::Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)}} is a good approximation of {{c2::left atrial}} pressure

How is pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) measured?

{{c1::Pulmonary artery catheter (Swan-Ganz catheter)}}

What is the approximate normal pressure in the right atrium?

{{c1::< 5 mmHg}}

What is the approximate normal pressure in the right ventricle (systolic and diastolic)?

{{c1::25/5 mmHg}}

What is the approximate normal pressure in the left atrium?

{{c1::< 12 mmHg}}

What is the approximate normal pressure in the left ventricle (systolic and diastolic)?

{{c1::130/10 mmHg}}

What is the approximate normal pressure in the pulmonary artery (systolic and diastolic)?

{{c1::25/10 mmHg}}

What is the approximate normal pressure in the aorta (systolic and diastolic)?

{{c1::130/90 mmHg}}
{{c1::B-type (brain) natriuretic peptide (BNP)}} is released from ventricular myocytes in response to increased {{c2::tension}}
A B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) blood test is used for diagnosing {{c1::heart failure}}
{{c1::Torsades de pointes}} is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with shifting sinusoidal waveforms on ECG
A long {{c1::QT interval}} predisposes to torsades de pointes
Treatment for torsades de pointes includes {{c1::magnesium sulfate}}

Deficiencies of which two cations are associated with torsades de pointes?

{{c1::K+ and Mg2+}}
Congenital long QT syndrome is an inherited disorder of myocardial repolarization, typically due to {{c1::ion channel}} defects
Congenital long QT syndrome has increased risk of sudden cardiac death (SCD) due to {{c1::torsades de pointes}}

What is the inheritance of Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome (a form of long QT syndrome)?

{{c1::Autosomal recessive}}

What is the inheritance of Brugada syndrome?

{{c1::Autosomal dominant}}

What demographic is most commonly affected by Brugada syndrome?

{{c1::Asian males}}
{{c3::Brugada}} syndrome presents with an ECG pattern of {{c1::pseudo-right bundle branch block}} and {{c2::ST elevations}} in leads {{c4::V1 - V3}}
Patients with Brugada syndrome are at increased risk of ventricular {{c1::tachyarrhythmias}} and sudden cardiac death (SCD)
Patients with Brugada syndrome may prevent sudden cardiac death with an implantable {{c1::cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD)}}
{{c1::Wolff-Parkinson-White}} syndrome is the most common type of ventricular pre-excitation syndrome
{{c2::Wolff-Parkinson-White}} syndrome is due to an abnormally fast accessory conduction pathway from the atria to ventricle via the bundle of {{c1::Kent}}, which bypasses the slower AV node
Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome presents with a characteristic {{c1::delta}} wave on ECG
Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome presents with a(n) {{c1::widened}} QRS complex and {{c1::shortened}} PR interval on ECG
Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome may result in re-entry circuit, causing supraventricular {{c1::tachycardia}}
During inspiration there is a(n) {{c1::decrease}} in intrathoracic pressure, which {{c2::increases}} venous return
Increased venous return during inspiration leads to {{c1::increased}} RV filling and ejection time
{{c1::Wide}} splitting is a delayed pulmonic sound, especially on inspiration, seen in conditions that delay {{c2::right ventricle}} emptying
{{c1::Fixed}} splitting is a delayed pulmonic sound, regardless of inspiration

What pathology is associated with fixed splitting?

{{c1::Atrial septal defect (ASD)}}
{{c1::Paradoxical}} splitting is heard in conditions that delay {{c2::aortic}} valve closure
In {{c1::paradoxical}} splitting, the P2 sound occurs before a delayed A2 sound

Does aortic stenosis cause a systolic or diastolic murmur?

{{c1::Systolic murmur}}

What is the shape of a murmur due to aortic stenosis?

{{c1::Crescendo-decrescendo}}

Where is a murmur due to aortic stenosis the loudest?

{{c1::Heart base (aortic area)}}
A murmur due to {{c2::aortic stenosis}} may radiate to the {{c1::carotid}} arteries

Does mitral/tricuspid regurgitation cause a systolic or diastolic murmur?

{{c1::Holo-systolic murmur}}

A holosystolic high-pitched "blowing" murmur is indicative of what pathology?

{{c1::Mitral/tricuspid regurgitation}}

Where is a murmur due to mitral regurgitation the loudest?

{{c1::Apex (mitral area)}}
A murmur due to {{c2::mitral regurgitation}} may radiate to the {{c1::axilla}}

Where is a murmur due to tricuspid regurgitation the loudest?

{{c1::Tricuspid area}}
A murmur due to tricuspid regurgitation may radiate to the {{c1::right sternal border}}

Does mitral valve prolapse cause a systolic or diastolic murmur?

{{c1::Late systolic (with midsystolic click)}}

A murmur with a midsystolic click is indicative of what pathology?

{{c1::Mitral valve prolapse}}

What causes the midsystolic click in a murmur due to mitral valve prolapse?

{{c1::Sudden tensing of chordae tendinae}}

What is the shape of a murmur due to mitral valve prolapse?

{{c1::Late crescendo}}

Where is a murmur due to mitral valve prolapse the loudest?

{{c1::Apex (mitral area)}}

A murmur due to mitral valve prolapse is loudest just before which heart sound?

{{c1::S2}}

Does a ventricular septal defect cause a systolic or diastolic murmur?

{{c1::Holo-systolic}}

Where is a murmur due to ventricular septal defect the loudest?

{{c1::Tricuspid area}}

Does aortic regurgitation cause a systolic or diastolic murmur?

{{c1::Diastolic}}

What is the shape of a murmur due to aortic regurgitation?

{{c1::Early decrescendo}}

Does mitral stenosis cause a systolic or diastolic murmur?

{{c1::Diastolic}}

A delayed, rumbling late diastolic murmur is indicative of what pathology?

{{c1::Mitral stenosis}}

A murmur with an opening snap is most likely indicative of what pathology?

{{c1::Mitral stenosis}}

A continuous, machine-like murmur is indicative of what pathology?

{{c1::Patent ductus arteriosus}}

A murmur due to patent ductus arteriosus is loudest at which heart sound?

{{c1::S2}}
What is the likely cause of this murmur: {{c1::aortic stenosis}}
What is the likely cause of this high-pitched, "blowing" murmur: {{c1::mitral/tricuspid regurgitation}}
What is the likely cause of this murmur: {{c1::mitral valve prolapse}}
What is the likely cause of this murmur: {{c1::aortic regurgitation}}
What is the most likely cause of this murmur: {{c1::mitral stenosis}}
What is the likely cause of this murmur? {{c1::Patent ductus arteriosus}}
{{c1::Vasculitis}} is defined as inflammation of the blood vessel wall
The innermost layer of the arterial wall is the {{c1::intima}}, which consists of endothelial cells on a basement membrane
The middle layer of the arterial wall is the {{c1::media}}, which consists of smooth muscle
The outer layer of the arterial wall is the {{c1::adventitia}}, which consists of connective tissue surrounding blood vessel
Vasculitides often present with symptoms of organ ischemia due to {{c1::thrombosis}} of inflamed vessels or luminal narrowing from {{c2::fibrosis}}
Giant cell (temporal) arteritis is a form of {{c1::large}}-vessel vasculitis
{{c2::Giant cell (temporal)}} arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis that classically involves branches of the {{c1::carotid}} artery

What demographic is classically affected by giant cell (temporal) arteritis?

{{c1::Elderly females (> 50)}}
Giant cell (temporal) arteritis may present with {{c1::unilateral headache}} due to involvement of the temporal artery
Giant cell (temporal) arteritis may present with {{c1::jaw}} claudication
Giant cell (temporal) arteritis may present with {{c1::visual}} disturbances due to involvement of the ophthalmic artery
{{c2::Giant cell (temporal)}} arteritis is associated with {{c1::polymyalgia rheumatica}}, which is characterized by aching/stiffness of the shoulders and hips

How does the ESR change in a patient with giant cell (temporal) arteritis?

{{c1::Increased (often >100)}}
Biopsy of a patient with giant cell (temporal) arteritis reveals an inflamed vessel with {{c1::giant}} cells and focal {{c2::granulomatous}} inflammation
Biopsy of a patient with giant cell (temporal) arteritis reveals {{c1::intimal}} fibrosis
The lesions of giant cell (temporal) arteritis are {{c1::segmental}}, therefore diagnosis requires biopsy of a long segment of the vessel

What is the treatment for a patient with giant cell (temporal) arteritis?

{{c1::High-dose corticosteroids}} and {{c2::tocilizumab}}
Without treatment, patients with {{c2::giant cell (temporal)}} arteritis are at high risk for {{c1::blindness}}
Takayasu arteritis is a form of {{c1::large}}-vessel vasculitis
{{c2::Takayasu}} arteritis is a granulomatous thickening and narrowing of the {{c1::aortic arch}} and proximal great vessels

What demographic is classically affected by Takayasu arteritis?

{{c1::Young Asian females (< 40)}}
Takayasu arteritis may present with {{c1::visual}} and {{c1::neurologic}} symptoms
{{c1::Takayasu}} arteritis is associated with a(n) {{c2::weak or absent}} pulse in the upper extremity

How does the ESR change in a patient with Takayasu arteritis?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the treatment for a patient with Takayasu arteritis?

{{c1::Corticosteroids}}
Polyarteritis nodosa is a form of {{c1::medium}}-vessel vasculitis

What demographic is classically affected by polyarteritis nodosa?

{{c1::Middle-aged men::age group}}
Polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing vasculitis that involves most organs, except the {{c1::lungs}}
Polyarteritis nodosa may present with {{c1::hypertension}} due to involvement of the renal artery
Polyarteritis nodosa may present with {{c1::abdominal}} pain and {{c1::melena}} due to involvement of the mesenteric artery
Polyarteritis nodosa may present with {{c1::neurologic}} disturbances/dysfunction
Polyarteritis nodosa may present with {{c1::skin}} lesions (e.g. cutaneous eruptions) in up to 1/3 of patients
{{c2::Polyarteritis nodosa}} is a necrotizing vasculitis that is associated with positive serum {{c1::HBsAg}} in 30% of patients
Early lesions of polyarteritis nodosa are characterized by transmural inflammation with {{c1::fibrinoid necrosis}}
Late lesions of polyarteritis nodosa are characterized by {{c1::fibrosis}}, leading to vessel narrowing
The combination of dilatation (aneurysms) and narrowing (fibrosis) in polyarteritis nodosa gives blood vessels a(n) {{c1::"string of pearls"}} appearance on imaging
Polyarteritis nodosa is characterized by innumerable renal {{c1::microaneurysms}} and spasms on arteriogram

What drugs may be used to treat a patient with polyarteritis nodosa?

{{c1::Corticosteroids, cyclophosphamide::2}}
Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) is a form of {{c1::medium}}-vessel vasculitis

What demographic is classically affected by Kawasaki disease?

{{c1::Asian children < 4 years old}}

Which artery is commonly affected in Kawasaki disease?

{{c1::Coronary artery}}
Patients with Kawasaki disease may develop coronary artery {{c1::thrombosis}}, which can lead to myocardial infarction
Patients with Kawasaki disease may develop coronary artery {{c1::aneurysms}}, which can rupture; therefore, get a(n) {{c1::echo::diagnostic test}}

The symptoms of {{c7::Kawasaki}} disease may be remembered with the mnemonic "CRASH and burn":

C: {{c1::Conjunctivitis}}
R: {{c2::Rash (polymorphous -> desquamating)}}
A: {{c3::Adenopathy (cervical lymph nodes)}}
S: {{c4::Strawberry tongue (oral mucositis)}}
H: {{c5::Hand-foot erythema and edema}}
&
Burn: {{c6::Fever}}
Treatment for Kawasaki disease includes {{c1::aspirin}} and {{c1::IVIG}}
Buerger disease (thromboangiitis obliterans) is a form of segmenting {{c1::medium}}-vessel vasculitis that extends into contiguous {{c2::veins}} and {{c2::nerves}}

What demographic is classically affected by Buerger disease?

{{c1::Heavy smokers, males < 40 years old}}
{{c2::Buerger}} disease is a segmental thrombosing vasculitis that commonly involves the {{c1::digits}}
Buerger disease often presents with intermittent claudication that may lead to {{c2::gangrene}} and {{c1::autoamputation}} of digits
Patients with Buerger disease often experience {{c1::Raynauds}} phenomenon

What is the treatment for Buerger disease?

{{c1::Smoking cessation}}
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener) is a form of {{c1::small}}-vessel vasculitis
{{c2::Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener)}} is a form of necrotizing, granulomatous vasculitis that classically involves the {{c1::nasopharynx}}, {{c1::lungs}}, and {{c1::kidneys}}
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis most commonly affects {{c1::middle aged men}} and these patients commonly have a(n) {{c2::saddle nose}} deformity
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis often presents with upper respiratory tract symptoms, such as {{c1::sinusitis}} or {{c2::nasopharyngeal ulceration}}
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis often presents with lower respiratory tract symptoms, such as {{c1::hemoptysis}}, cough, and dyspnea
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis often presents with kidney-related symptoms, such as {{c1::hematuria}}, red cell casts, and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)

Which vasculitis is characterized by a triad of:
(1) Focal necrotizing vasculitis
(2) Necrotizing granulomas in the lung and upper airway
(3) Necrotizing glomerulonephritis

{{c1::Granulomatosis with polyangiitis}}

What does a chest X-ray of a patient with Granulomatosis with polyangiitis show?

{{c1::Bilateral large nodular densities/infiltrates}}

What significant laboratory finding is associated with Wegener granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis)?

{{c1::Positive c-ANCA}}

What drugs may be used to treat Granulomatosis with polyangiitis?

{{c1::Cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids::2}}
Microscopic polyangiitis is a form of {{c1::small}}-vessel vasculitis
Microscopic polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that commonly involves the {{c1::lungs}}, {{c1::kidneys}}, and skin

How does microscopic polyangiitis present differently from granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener)?

{{c1::Microscopic polyangiitis lacks nasopharyngeal involvement and granulomas::2}}

What significant laboratory finding is associated with microscopic polyangiitis?

{{c1::Positive p-ANCA}}

What drugs may be used to treat microscopic polyangiitis?

{{c1::Cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids::2}}
Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-strauss) is a form of {{c1::small}}-vessel vasculitis

What type of white blood cell is elevated in Churg-Strauss syndrome?

{{c1::Eosinophils}}

Which serum immunoglobulin is elevated in Churg-Strauss syndrome?

{{c1::IgE}}

What vasculitis is a granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis with eosinophilia?

{{c1::Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)}}

What two organs are commonly affected by Churg-Strauss syndrome?

{{c1::Heart and lungs}}

What respiratory pathology is commonly associated with Churg-Strauss syndrome?

{{c1::Asthma}}

{{c2::Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss)}}, a small-vessel vasculitis, commonly presents with asymmetric multifocal neuropathy, typically manifesting with {{c1::wrist drop}} and {{c1::foot drop}}

What significant laboratory finding is associated with Churg Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)?

{{c1::Positive p-ANCA}}
Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a form of {{c1::small}}-vessel vasculitis

What demographic is classically affected by Henoch-Schonlein purpura?

{{c1::Children::age group}}
{{c2::Henoch-Schonlein purpura}} is a vasculitis that occurs secondary to {{c1::IgA immune complex}} deposition
The classic clinical triad of {{c2::Henoch-Schonlein purpura}} is {{c1::palpable purpura}} on the buttocks and legs, {{c3::arthralgias}}, and {{c4::abdominal}} pain
Henoch-Schonlein purpura is associated with {{c1::IgA nephropathy}} ({{c2::Berger}} disease)
Henoch-Schonlein purpura often occurs following a(n) {{c1::upper respiratory tract}} infection, which leads to generation of IgA

What is the treatment for Henoch-Schonlein purpura?

{{c1::Disease is self-limited; treat with steroids if severe}}
Hypertension is defined as persistent systolic BP > {{c1::130}} mmHg and/or diastolic BP > {{c1::80}} mmHg

What ethnicity has the highest risk of developing hypertension?

{{c1::African Americans}}

What ethnicity has the lowest risk of developing hypertension?

{{c1::Asians}}
{{c1::Primary (essential)}} hypertension (90-95% of cases) has no known etiology
Primary hypertension is related to increased {{c1::cardiac output}} and {{c2::TPR}}
Secondary hypertension may be caused by {{c1::renal artery stenosis}}, which leads to increased plasma {{c2::renin}} and unilateral atrophy of the affected kidney

What is a possible cause of secondary hypertension that occurs in young females?

{{c1::Fibromuscular dysplasia}}
Fibromuscular dysplasia results in the irregular thickening of medium/large arteries which manifests as a "{{c1::string of beads}}" appearance on imaging
Secondary hypertension may be caused by primary {{c1::hyper}}-aldosteronism
Hypertensive {{c1::urgency}} is defined as severe hypertension (>180 / >120 mmHg) without acute end-organ damage
Hypertensive {{c1::emergency}} is defined as severe hypertension (>180 / >120 mmHg) with acute end-organ damage
{{c1::Arteriosclerosis}} is defined as the hardening of arteries, with arterial wall thickening and loss of elasticity
{{c1::Atherosclerosis}} is a form of arteriosclerosis that damages large- and medium-sized vessels due to buildup of cholesterol plaques

Which part of the blood vessel wall is affected by atherosclerosis?

{{c1::Intima}}
Atherosclerosis is caused by a buildup of intimal {{c1::plaques}} that obstruct blood flow
The intimal plaque that causes atherosclerosis consists of a necrotic lipid core (mostly {{c1::cholesterol}}) with a(n) {{c2::fibromuscular}} cap
The intimal plaque that causes atherosclerosis often undergoes dystrophic {{c1::calcification}}

What four arteries are most commonly affected by atherosclerosis?

{{c1::Lower abdominal aorta}} > {{c2::coronary}} > {{c3::popliteal}} > {{c4::carotid}} artery

What are the four modifiable risk factors for atherosclerosis?

{{c1::Hypertension}}, {{c1::hypercholesterolemia (LDL)}}, {{c2::smoking}}, {{c2::diabetes}}

What are the three non-modifiable risk factors for atherosclerosis?

{{c1::Age}}, {{c1::gender}}, {{c1::genetics}}
Atherosclerosis begins with endothelial cell dysfunction which allows {{c1::lipids}} to leak into the intima
Lipids in the intima of an artery are {{c1::oxidized}} and then consumed by {{c2::macrophages}} via {{c3::scavenger receptor A}} receptors
Macrophage consumption of oxidized lipids in the intima results in {{c1::foam}} cell formation and "fatty streaks"
In response to fatty streaks in the intima, there is {{c1::smooth muscle}} cell migration/proliferation and {{c2::extracellular matrix}} deposition
Smooth muscle proliferation and ECM deposition in the arterial intima leads to the formation of fibrous {{c1::plaques}} and ultimately complex atheromas
Symptoms of atherosclerosis generally present when >{{c1::70}}% of a vessel has been occluded (stenosis)
One complication of atherosclerosis is {{c1::peripheral vascular disease}}, which may result from stenosis of the popliteal artery
One complication of atherosclerosis is {{c1::angina}}, which may result from stenosis of the coronary artery
One complication of atherosclerosis is {{c1::chronic mesenteric ischemia}}, which may result from stenosis of the mesenteric artery
One complication of atherosclerosis is {{c1::myocardial infarction}}, which may result from plaque rupture with {{c2::thrombosis}} of the coronary artery
One complication of atherosclerosis is {{c1::stroke}}, which may result from plaque rupture with thrombosis of the middle cerebral artery
Plaque rupture from atherosclerosis may result in atherosclerotic {{c1::emboli}}, which are characterized by {{c2::cholesterol clefts}}
Atherosclerosis may cause weakening of the blood vessel wall, which can result in {{c1::aneurysm}}
{{c1::Arteriolosclerosis}} is a form of arteriosclerosis that damages small arteries and arterioles
{{c1::Hyaline}} arteriolosclerosis is caused by proteins leaking into the vessel wall, producing vascular thickening

What type of arteriolosclerosis is demonstrated in the image below?

{{c1::Hyaline arteriolosclerosis}}

What two underlying pathologies are associated with hyaline arteriolosclerosis?

{{c1::Benign hypertension, diabetes}}
Hyaline arteriolosclerosis results in reduced vessel caliber with end-organ ischemia, which classically produces {{c1::glomerular}} scarring
{{c1::Hyperplastic}} arteriolosclerosis is caused by hyperplasia of smooth muscle, resulting in thickening of the vessel wall

What type of arteriolosclerosis is demonstrated in the image below?

{{c1::Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis}}
Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis has an {{c1::onion-skin}} appearance on histology

What underlying pathology is associated with hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis?

{{c1::Severe (malignant) hypertension}}
Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis may lead to {{c1::fibrinoid}} necrosis of the vessel wall with hemorrhage
{{c3::Hyperplastic}} arteriolosclerosis classically causes {{c1::acute kidney injury}} with a {{c2::flea-bitten::gross}} appearance
Monckeberg sclerosis is {{c1::non-obstructive}} and therefore is not clinically significant
Risk of atherosclerosis is increased in men and {{c1::postmenopausal}} women
{{c1::Aortic dissection}} is a longitudinal intimal tear with transmission of blood through the media of the aortic wall
Hyaline arteriolosclerosis of the {{c1::vasa vasorum}} results in atrophy of the aortic media and weakening of the vessel wall
Aortic dissection is associated with inherited {{c1::connective tissue}} disorders
Aortic dissection may present with sudden sharp, tearing {{c1::chest}} pain that radiates to the {{c1::back}}
Chest X-ray of a patient with aortic {{c2::dissection}} shows {{c1::mediastinal}} widening
Aortic dissection may lead to obstruction of branching arteries, thus causing end-organ {{c1::ischemia}}
Aortic dissection may result in {{c1::cardiac tamponade}} as a result of backflow into the pericardium
{{c1::Stanford type A (proximal)}} aortic dissection involves the ascending aorta
{{c1::Stanford type B (distal)}} aortic dissection involves the descending aorta and/or the aortic arch

What is the treatment for Stanford type A aortic dissection?

{{c1::Surgery}}

What is the treatment for Stanford type B aortic dissection?

{{c1::β-blockers, then vasodilators}}
{{c1::Aortic aneurysm}} is a localized pathologic dilatation of the aorta
Aortic aneurysm may cause {{c1::abdominal}} and/or {{c1::back}} pain, which is a sign of leaking, dissection, or imminent rupture
Thoracic aortic aneurysm is classically seen in patients with {{c1::tertiary syphilis}} due to {{c2::endarteritis}} of the vasa vasorum
{{c2::Thoracic}} aortic aneurysm is associated with {{c1::cystic medial}} degeneration (e.g. Marfan syndrome)
Risk factors for thoracic aneurysm include {{c1::bicuspid}} aortic valve and {{c2::hypertension}}
Thoracic aneurysm is associated with inherited {{c1::connective tissue}} disorders
A major complication of thoracic aneurysm is dilation of the aortic valve root resulting in {{c1::aortic regurgitation (insufficiency)}}
Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) usually arises below the {{c1::renal arteries}}, but above the {{c1::aortic birfucation}}
The two underlying pathological processes that are associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm are {{c1::chronic transmural inflammation}} and {{c2::atherosclerosis}}

What demographic is commonly associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm?

{{c1::Males > 60 (usually a smoker with HTN)}}
{{c1::Abdominal aortic aneurysm}} may present as a palpable, pulsatile abdominal mass that grows with time
A major complication associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm is {{c1::rupture}}, especially when >{{c2::5}} cm in diameter
Abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture presents with a triad of {{c1::hypotension}}, a pulsatile abdominal mass, and {{c2::flank}} pain

Where is a murmur due to aortic regurgitation the loudest?

{{c1::Left sternal border}}

Where is a murmur due to atrial septal defect the loudest?

{{c1::Pulmonic Area}}

Where is a murmur due to pulmonic stenosis the loudest?

{{c1::Pulmonic area}}
Ischemic heart disease is usually due to {{c1::atherosclerosis}} of {{c2::coronary}} arteries
{{c1::Angina}} is chest pain due to myocardial ischemia (secondary to coronary artery narrowing or spasm)

Does angina cause myocyte necrosis?

{{c1::No, damage is reversible}}
{{c1::Stable}} angina is characterized by chest pain that arises with {{c2::exertion}} or emotional stress
Stable angina is often due to {{c2::atherosclerosis}} of coronary arteries with >{{c1::70}}% stenosis
Stable angina often presents with chest pain lasting {{c1::< 20}} minutes that radiates to the {{c2::left arm}} or {{c2::jaw}}
Stable angina is often relieved by {{c1::rest}} or with {{c2::nitroglycerin}}

What ECG findings are associated with stable angina?

{{c1::ST-segment depression (subendocardial ischemia)}}
Unstable angina is characterized by chest pain that occurs during {{c1::rest}}
{{c3::Unstable}} angina is due to rupture of atherosclerotic plaque with {{c1::thrombosis}} and {{c2::incomplete}} occlusion of a coronary artery

What ECG findings are associated with unstable angina?

{{c1::ST-segment depression and/or T-wave inversion::2}}

What drug may be used to relieve symptoms due to unstable angina?

{{c1::Nitroglycerin}}
Unstable angina has a high risk of progression to {{c1::myocardial infarction}}
{{c1::Vasospastic (variant/prinzmetal)}} angina is characterized by episodic chest pain during {{c2::rest}} due to coronary artery {{c3::spasm}}

What ECG findings are associated with vasospastic angina?

{{c1::ST-segment elevation (transmural ischemia)}}
Vasospastic angina is relieved by {{c1::nitrate}} drugs, {{c2::dihydropyridine Ca2+}} channel blockers, and smoke cessation (if applicable)
Known triggers of Vasospastic angina include {{c1::tobacco}}, {{c2::cocaine}}, and {{c3::triptans}}
{{c2::Coronary steal}} syndrome occurs when administration of {{c3::vasodilators}} shunts blood towards well-perfused areas, increasing ischemia in post-{{c1::stenotic}} regions
Coronary steal syndrome occurs because distal to coronary stenosis, vessels are maximally {{c1::dilated}} at baseline
Coronary steal syndrome is the principle behind {{c1::pharmacologic}} stress tests

Does myocardial infarction cause myocyte necrosis?

{{c1::Yes, damage is irreversible}}
Myocardial infarction is often due to rupture of atherosclerotic plaque with {{c1::thrombosis}} and {{c2::complete}} occlusion of a coronary artery
Myocardial infarction often presents with severe crushing chest pain lasting {{c1::> 20}} minutes that radiates to the {{c2::left arm}} or {{c2::jaw}}
One less common cause of myocardial infarction is coronary artery {{c1::vasospasm}} (e.g. vasospastic angina, cocaine use)
One less common cause of myocardial infarction is {{c1::vasculitis}} (e.g. Kawasaki disease)
Myocardial infarction may present with {{c1::dyspnea}} due to pulmonary congestion and edema

What heart chamber is most commonly affected by myocardial infarction?

{{c1::Left ventricle}}
Myocardial infarction most commonly involves the {{c1::left anterior descending (LAD)}} artery (45%)
The second most common artery involved in a myocardial infarction is the {{c1::right coronary artery}}
The third most common artery involved in a myocardial infarction is the {{c1::left circumflex artery}}
The initial phase of myocardial infarction leads to {{c1::subendocardial}} necrosis involving < 50% of the myocardial thickness
The initial phase of myocardial infarction (subendocardial infarcts) shows ST-segment {{c1::depression}} on ECG
The later phase of myocardial infarction (transmural infarcts) shows ST-segment {{c1::elevation}} and Q waves on ECG
When suspecting a myocardial infarction, laboratory tests are used to detect elevated {{c1::cardiac}} enzymes
In the first 6 hours, {{c1::ECG}} is the gold standard for diagnosis of myocardial infarction

What is the most sensitive and specific cardiac biomarker used for diagnosis of myocardial infarction?

{{c1::Troponin I}}
Troponin I levels rise {{c1::2-4}} hours after an MI and peak at {{c2::24}} hours
Troponin I levels return to normal {{c1::7-10 days}} after an MI
{{c1::CK-MB}} is a cardiac biomarker that is useful for detecting {{c2::reinfarction}} following acute MI
CK-MB levels rise {{c1::6-12}} hours after an MI and peak at {{c2::16-24}} hours
CK-MB levels return to normal {{c1::48-72 hours}} after an MI
Large myocardial infarctions lead to {{c1::greater}} elevations in troponin I and CK-MB
CK-MB is predominantly found in myocardium, but can also be released from {{c1::skeletal muscle}}

What anti-coagulation drug is frequently used to treat acute coronary syndromes (e.g. unstable angina, STEMI, NSTEMI)?

{{c1::Heparin}}
Treatment of acute coronary syndromes (e.g. unstable angina, STEMI, NSTEMI) often includes antiplatelet therapy such as {{c1::aspirin}}
Treatment of acute coronary syndromes often includes a(n) {{c1::ADP}} receptor inhibitor such as clopidogrel
Treatment of acute coronary syndromes often includes {{c1::β-blockers}}, which decrease heart rate and reduces risk of arrhythmia
Treatment of acute coronary syndromes often includes {{c1::ACE}} inhibitors to decrease left ventricular dilation
Treatment of acute coronary syndromes often includes supplemental {{c1::O2}} to minimize ischemia

Initial treatment of acute coronary syndrome includes MONA (MONA greets chest pain patients at the door)

- M{{c1::orphine}}
- O{{c2::xygen}}
- N{{c3::itroglycerin}}
- A{{c4::spirin}}
The most important treatment for STEMI is {{c1::reperfusion}} therapy, such as {{c2::angioplasty}} (preferred) or {{c3::fibrinolysis}}
Reperfusion of irreversibly-damaged cells post-MI may result in {{c1::Ca2+}} influx, leading to {{c2::hypercontraction}} of myofibrils ({{c3::contraction band necrosis}})
Reperfusion of irreversibly-damaged cells post-MI may result in {{c1::free radical}} formation (due to O2), further damaging myocytes (known as {{c2::reperfusion injury}})

What gross changes occur during the first 4 hours of a myocardial infarction?

{{c1::None :)}}

What microscopic changes occur during the first 4 hours of a myocardial infarction?

{{c1::None :)}}
One complication that may occur during the first 4 hours post-MI is {{c1::cardiogenic shock}}, which occurs due to lack of blood flow to vital organs
One complication that may occur during the first 4 hours post-MI is {{c1::congestive heart failure}}, which occurs due to inefficient pumping of the left ventricle
One complication that may occur during the first 24 hours post-MI is {{c1::arrhythmia}}, which is an important cause of death before reaching the hospital

What gross changes occur from 4 - 24 hours post-MI?

{{c1::Dark discoloration}}

What microscopic changes occur from 4 - 24 hours post-MI?

{{c1::Coagulative necrosis}}

What gross changes occur from 1 - 3 days post-MI?

{{c1::Yellow pallor}}

What microscopic changes occur from 1 - 3 days post-MI?

{{c1::Neutrophils (acute inflammation)}}
{{c1::Fibrinous pericarditis}} is an inflammatory post-MI complication that occurs after {{c2::2*}} to {{c2::4*}} days
{{c1::Fibrinous pericarditis}} is a post-MI complication that presents as chest pain with {{c2::friction}} rub

What gross changes occur from 4 - 7 days post-MI?

{{c1::Yellow pallor}}

What microscopic changes occur from 3 - 10 days post-MI?

{{c1::Macrophage infiltration (acute inflammation)*}}
One complication that may occur {{c3::5}} - {{c3::14}} days post-MI is {{c1::ventricular free wall rupture}}, which causes {{c2::cardiac tamponade}}
One complication that may occur {{c2::3}} - {{c2::5}} days post-MI is {{c1::interventricular septal rupture}}, which causes a ventricular septal defect (VSD)
One complication that may occur {{c3::3}} - {{c3::5}} days post-MI is {{c1::papillary muscle rupture}}, which often causes {{c2::mitral regurgitation}}
At 10 - 14 days post-MI, the following gross changes occur: emergence of the {{c1::red border}}; due to {{c2::granulation tissue}} entering from the edge of the {{c2::infarct}}

What microscopic changes occur from 3 - 14 days post-MI?

{{c1::Granulation tissue*}}

What gross changes occur months after an MI?

{{c1::White scar}}

What microscopic changes occur months after an MI?

{{c1::Fibrosis}}
{{c1::True ventricular aneurysm}} is a complication that may occur months after an MI and increases risk for mural {{c2::thrombus}}
{{c1::Dressler}} syndrome is an autoimmune complication that may occur several weeks (6-8) after an MI
{{c1::Dressler}} syndrome is a(n) {{c2::autoimmune}} phenomenon that results in fibrinous pericarditis following an MI (> 1 month)
{{c1::Sudden cardiac death}} is death from cardiac causes within 1 hour of onset of symptoms
Sudden cardiac death is most commonly due to a lethal {{c1::arrhythmia (e.g. ventricular fibrillation)}}
Sudden cardiac death may be prevented with an implantable {{c1::cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD)}}
90% of patients who suffer sudden cardiac death have pre-existing severe {{c1::atherosclerosis}}
{{c1::Chronic ischemic heart disease}} is the progressive onset of heart failure over many years due to chronic ischemic myocardial damage
Ventricular {{c1::pseudo-aneurysm}} is a contained free wall rupture that may occur {{c2::3}} - {{c2::14}} days post-MI

Which artery is associated with anteroseptal myocardial infarction?

{{c1::Left anterior descending (LAD) artery}}

What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an anteroseptal myocardial infarction?

{{c1::V1 - V2::2}}

Which artery is associated with anteroapical myocardial infarction?

{{c1::Distal left anterior descending (LAD) artery}}

What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an anteroapical myocardial infarction?

{{c1::V3 - V4::2}}

Which arteries may be associated with anterolateral myocardial infarction?

{{c1::LAD or LCX::2}}

What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an anterolateral myocardial infarction?

{{c1::V5 - V6::2}}

Which artery is associated with lateral myocardial infarction?

{{c1::Left circumflex (LCX) artery}}

What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in a lateral myocardial infarction?

{{c1::I, aVL::2}}

Which artery is typically associated with inferior myocardial infarction?

{{c1::Right coronary artery (RCA)}}

What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in an inferior myocardial infarction?

{{c1::II, III, aVF::3}}

Which artery is associated with posterior myocardial infarction?

{{c1::Posterior descending artery (PDA)}}

What leads show ST elevations or Q waves in a posterior myocardial infarction?

{{c1::V7 - V9}}
{{c1::Heart failure}} is a clinical syndrome of cardiac pump dysfunction which causes congestion and low perfusion

How does ejection fraction change in heart failure with systolic dysfunction?

{{c1::Reduced EF}}

How does EDV change in heart failure with systolic dysfunction?

{{c1::Increased EDV}}
Systolic dysfunction (heart failure) occurs due to decreased {{c1::contractility}}, often secondary to ischemia/MI or dilated cardiomyopathy

How does ejection fraction change in heart failure with diastolic dysfunction?

{{c1::Preserved EF}}

How does EDV change in heart failure with diastolic dysfunction?

{{c1::Normal EDV}}
Diastolic dysfunction (heart failure) occurs due to decreased {{c1::compliance}}, often secondary to myocardial concentric hypertrophy

What is the most common cause of right heart failure?

{{c1::Left heart failure}}
Right heart failure may be caused by a long-standing {{c1::left-to-right}} shunt
{{c2::Cor pulmonale}} refers to isolated {{c1::right heart failure}} due to pulmonary cause
Clinical features of left heart failure are due to {{c2::decreased}} forward perfusion with consequent {{c1::pulmonary}} congestion
{{c2::Left::Left or Right}} heart failure may present with {{c1::orthopnea}}, which is shortness of breath when supine
{{c2::Left}} heart failure may present with {{c1::paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea}}, which is breathless awakening from sleep
{{c2::Left}} heart failure may present with pulmonary {{c1::edema}} due to increased pulmonary venous pressure
{{c3::Left}} heart failure may present with {{c1::hemosiderin-laden macrophages}}, known as {{c2::heart failure}} cells, in the lungs
Left heart failure causes decreased forward perfusion to the kidneys, resulting in activation of the {{c1::renin-angiotensin}} system
Clinical features of right heart failure are due to {{c1::systemic}} congestion
{{c2::Right}} heart failure may cause {{c1::jugular venous}} distension due to increased systemic venous pressure
{{c2::Right}} heart failure is associated with a characteristic "{{c1::nutmeg}}" appearance of the liver
Right heart failure is associated with peripheral {{c1::edema}} due to increased venous pressure and thus fluid transudation
Heart failure may present with dependent {{c1::pitting}} edema due to increased hydrostatic pressure

What sound on respiratory exam may be associated with heart failure?

{{c1::Rales / crackles}}
Defects with left-to-right shunting may be relatively asymptomatic at birth, but the shunt can eventually {{c1::reverse}}
Left-to-right shunting results in increased flow through the pulmonary circulation, causing pulmonary {{c1::hypertension}}
The pulmonary hypertension seen with long-standing left-to-right shunts causes the right ventricle to {{c1::hypertrophy}}
The combination of right ventricle hypertrophy and pulmonary hypertension in response to left-to-right shunting results in shunt {{c1::reversal}}
Uncorrected left-to-right shunting eventually results in reversal, which presents with late {{c1::cyanosis}} ({{c2::Eisenmenger}} syndrome)
Eisenmenger syndrome is characterized by a triad of {{c1::late cyanosis}}, {{c2::clubbing}}, and {{c3::polycythemia}}
Compared to right-to-left shunts, left-to-right shunts lead to cyanosis at a(n) {{c1::later}} age
Compared to left-to-right shunts, right-to-left shunts lead to cyanosis at a(n) {{c1::earlier}} age
Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is associated with {{c1::fetal alcohol}} syndrome
Ventricular septal defect (VSD) results in a(n) {{c1::left}}-to-{{c1::right}} shunt
Smaller ventricular septal defects are often {{c1::asymptomatic}} and may close spontaneously, but on physical exam will present with a(n) {{c2::murmur}}

How is a large ventricular septal defect treated?

{{c1::Surgical closure}}
Larger ventricular septal defects may lead to left ventricle {{c1::overload}} and, consequently, {{c2::heart failure}}

What is the most common type of Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)?

{{c1::Ostium secundum (90%)}}
Ostium {{c1::primum}} is a less common type of atrial septal defect that is associated with {{c2::Down}} syndrome
Atrial septal defect (ASD) results in a(n) {{c1::left}}-to-{{c1::right}} shunt

What effect does atrial septal defect (ASD) have on S2 splitting?

{{c1::Causes a wide, fixed split}}
{{c1::Paradoxical}} emboli, an important complication of atrial septal defect, are emboli that arise on the right-side of the body and crossover to lodge on the left side
Patent ductus arteriosus is associated with congenital {{c1::rubella}} infection
In the fetal period, the ductus arteriosus acts as a(n) {{c1::right}}-to-{{c1::left}} shunt
Patency of a patent ductus arteriosus is maintained by {{c1::PGE}} synthesis and low O2 tension
Uncorrected patent ductus arteriosus may eventually result in late cyanosis in the {{c1::lower}} extremities
Treatment of a patent ductus arteriosus involves {{c1::indomethacin}}, which decreases PGE, resulting in PDA closure

{{c1::Tetralogy of Fallot}} is a congenital heart disease that is characterized by:

1. {{c2::Pulmonary infundibular stenosis}}
2. {{c3::Right ventricular hypertrophy}}
3. {{c4::Overriding aorta}}
4. {{c5::Ventricular septal defect (VSD)}}
Tetralogy of Fallot results in a(n) {{c1::right}}-to-{{c1::left}} shunt with {{c2::early}} cyanosis
The degree of shunting in Tetralogy of Fallot is determined by the degree of {{c1::right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (from pulmonary stenosis)}}
{{c2::Tetralogy of Fallot}} is characterized by a(n) {{c1::boot}}-shaped heart on CXR
Patients with Tetralogy of Fallot often experience "{{c1::tet}} spells" which may be caused by crying, fever, and exercise due to exacerbation of RV outflow obstruction
Patients with Tetralogy of Fallot may {{c1::squat}} in response to cyanotic spells, which decreases right-to-left shunting by increasing {{c2::systemic vascular resistance (SVR)}}

What is the most common congenital heart defect that causes early cyanosis?

{{c1::Tetralogy of Fallot}}
Tetralogy of Fallot is caused by {{c1::anterosuperior}} displacement of the infundibular septum
{{c3::D-transposition of the great vessels}} is characterized by the {{c1::pulmonary artery}} arising from the left ventricle and {{c1::aorta}} from the right ventricle
D-transposition of the great vessels and VSD are associated with {{c1::maternal diabetes::endocrine disorder}}
D-transposition of great vessels is not compatible with life unless a(n) {{c1::shunt}} is created
D-transposition of great vessels is due to failure of the {{c1::aorticopulmonary septum}} to spiral
{{c1::PGE}} may be administered to patients with D-transposition of great vessels to maintain a PDA until definitive surgical repair is performed
D-transposition of great vessels results in {{c1::hypertrophy}} of the right ventricle and {{c1::atrophy}} of the left ventricle
D-transposition of great vessels is an example of a(n) {{c1::right}}-to-{{c1::left}} shunt
{{c1::Persistent truncus arteriosus}} is a congenital heart disease characterized by a single large vessel arising from both ventricles before eventually splitting
Truncus arteriosus is an example of a(n) {{c1::right}}-to-{{c1::left}} shunt
Most patients with truncus arteriosus have accompanying {{c1::ventricular septal}} defect
{{c1::Tricuspid atresia}} is the failure of the tricuspid valve orifice to develop
Tricuspid atresia leads to right ventricle {{c1::hypoplasia}}
Tricuspid atresia requires both {{c1::ASD}} and {{c1::VSD}} for viability
Tricuspid atresia is an example of a(n) {{c1::right}}-to-{{c1::left}} shunt
{{c1::Coarctation of the aorta}} is the narrowing of the aorta near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus
The {{c2::infantile}} form of coarctation of the aorta is associated with a(n) {{c1::PDA}}
In the infantile form, coarctation of the aorta lies {{c1::after}} the aortic arch, but {{c1::before}} the PDA
Coarctation of the aorta in infants presents as {{c1::lower}} extremity cyanosis, often at birth
The infantile form of coarctation of the aorta is associated with {{c1::Turner}} syndrome
In the adult form, coarctation of the aorta lies {{c2::after}} the aortic arch
Coarctation of the aorta in adults presents as {{c1::hypertension}} in the upper extremities and {{c1::hypotension}} in the lower extremities
In the adult form of coarctation of the aorta, collateral circulation develops most notably across the {{c1::intercostal}} arteries

What X-ray finding is associated with the adult form of coarctation of the aorta?

{{c1::Notching of ribs (due to engorged intercostal arteries)}}
Coarctation of the aorta is associated with a(n) {{c1::bicuspid}} aortic valve and an increased risk of developing {{c2::berry}} aneurysms

What congenital heart defect is associated with lithium exposure in utero?

{{c1::Ebstein anomaly}}
{{c1::Ebstein anomaly}} is a congenital heart disease characterized by downward displacement of tricuspid leaflets into the right ventricle
Ebstein anomaly is associated with tricuspid {{c2::regurgitation}} and right {{c1::heart failure}}
{{c1::Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR)}} is a congenital heart disease characterized by drainage of pulmonary veins into the right circulation
Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR) is associated with {{c1::ASD}} and sometimes PDA to allow for right-to-left shunting
Class I antiarrhythmics exert their actions by blocking {{c1::Na+}} channels
Class I antiarrhythmics {{c3::decrease}} the {{c2::slope}} of phase {{c1::0 (upstroke)}} of the myocardial action potential

What effect do class I antiarrhythmics have on conduction velocity of the myocardial action potential?

{{c1::Decreased CV}}
Class I antiarrhythmics bind to Na+ channels in their {{c1::open}} or {{c1::inactivated}} state
Na+ channels in rapidly depolarizing tissue (e.g. tachycardia) spend the {{c1::most}} time in open or inactivated states
Class I antiarrhythmics have {{c1::use dependence}} and thus selectively depress tissue that is frequently depolarized

What effect do class I antiarrhythmics have on the action potentials of the SA and AV nodes?

{{c1::No effect (only affects Na+-dependent action potentials)}}
Class I antiarrhythmics {{c1::widen}} the QRS complex on ECG

What drug class does quinidine belong to?

{{c1::Class IA antiarrhythmics}}
Toxic doses of {{c4::quinidine}}, an antiarrhythmic drug, may cause {{c1::cinchonism}}, which is a syndrome of {{c2::tinnitus}}, {{c3::headache}}, and {{c5::dizziness}}
{{c2::Quinidine}} is an anti-arrhythmic that rarely causes immunologic reactions, resulting in {{c1::thrombocytopenia}}

What drug class does procainamide belong to?

{{c1::Class IA antiarrhythmics}}
{{c2::Procainamide}}, a class IA antiarrhythmic, can cause a reversible {{c1::SLE}}-like syndrome as an adverse effect

What drug class does disopyramide belong to?

{{c1::Class IA antiarrhythmics}}
One adverse effect associated with disopyramide is exacerbation of {{c1::heart failure}}, due to its negative inotropic effects
Class I{{c3::A}} antiarrhythmics can cause {{c1::QT interval}} prolongation which precipitates {{c2::torsades de pointes}}
Class IA antiarrhythmics have a(n) {{c1::intermediate}} binding affinity for the Na+ channel
In addition to Na+ channels, Class IA antiarrhythmics also block {{c1::K+}} channels

What effect do class IA antiarrhythmics have on action potential duration?

{{c1::Increased duration}}

What effect do class IA antiarrhythmics have on the effective refractory period in the ventricular tissue?

{{c1::Increased ERP}}

Are class IA antiarrhythmics used to treat supraventricular or ventricular arrhythmias?

{{c1::Both :)}}
Class I{{c1::A}} antiarrhythmics may be used to treat Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, a type of SVT

What drug class does lidocaine belong to?

{{c1::Class IB antiarrhythmics}}

What antiarrhythmic drug class does phenytoin belong to?

{{c1::Class IB antiarrhythmics (anti-epileptic but has class IB properties)}}

What drug class does mexiletine belong to?

{{c1::Class IB antiarrhythmics}}
Class IB antiarrhythmics have a(n) {{c1::low}} binding affinity for the Na+ channel

What effect do class IB antiarrhythmics have on action potential duration?

{{c1::Shortened duration}}
Class {{c3::IB}} antiarrhythmics treat {{c1::ventricular}} arrhythmias, especially in {{c2::ischemic}} tissue (e.g. post-MI)
Class I{{c1::B}} antiarrhythmics may be used to treat digitalis-induced arrhythmias
Class I{{c2::B}} antiarrhythmics can cause {{c1::neurological}} side effects (e.g. paresthesias, tremor, convulsions)

What drug class does flecainide belong to?

{{c1::Class IC antiarrhythmics}}

What drug class does propafenone belong to?

{{c1::Class IC antiarrhythmics}}
Class IC antiarrhythmics have a(n) {{c1::strong}} binding affinity for the Na+ channel

What effect do class IC antiarrhythmics have on action potential duration?

{{c1::No effect}}

What effect do class IC antiarrhythmics have on the effective refractory period in the AV node and accessory bypass tracts?

{{c1::Significant prolongation of ERP}}

What effect do class IC antiarrhythmics have on the effective refractory period in the Purkinje and ventricular tissue?

{{c1::No effect}}

Are class IC antiarrhythmics used to treat supraventricular or ventricular arrhythmias?

{{c1::Both :)}}
Class I{{c2::C}} antiarrhythmics are especially effective at treating {{c1::atrial}} fibrillation (and flutter)
Class IC antiarrhythmics can restore and maintain normal sinus rhythm in {{c1::atrial}} fibrillation and flutter
Class I{{c4::C}} antiarrhythmics may have {{c3::proarrhythmic}} effects and are thus contraindicated in patients with {{c1::structural}} heart disease or {{c2::ischemic}} heart disease
Acute rheumatic fever is a consequence of pharyngeal infection with {{c1::group A β-hemolytic streptococci}}
Acute rheumatic fever most commonly affects children 2 - 3 {{c1::weeks}} after an episode of streptococcal pharyngitis ("strep throat")
Acute rheumatic fever is {{c1::immune}}-mediated, not a direct effect of bacteria
Acute rheumatic fever is caused by {{c1::molecular mimicry}} due to resemblance of bacterial {{c2::M}} protein with proteins in human tissue
Evidence of prior group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infection includes elevated {{c1::anti-streptolysin O (ASO)}} or anti-{{c2::DNase B}} titers
