Minor criteria for rheumatic fever are nonspecific and include {{c1::fever}} and elevated {{c2::ESR}}
The major criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are the {{c2::J♥NES}} criteria

What does the J in J♥NES criteria represent?

{{c1::Joint (migratory polyarthritis)}}

What does the ♥ in J♥NES criteria represent?

{{c1::Pancarditis (includes endocarditis, myocarditis, and pericarditis)}}
Endocarditis secondary to rheumatic fever most commonly affects the {{c1::mitral}} valve
{{c2::Endocarditis}}, secondary to rheumatic fever, is characterized by small vegetations along valvular lines of closure, which cause {{c1::regurgitation}}
Severe {{c1::pancarditis}} is the most common cause of death during the acute phase of rheumatic fever
{{c2::Myocarditis}}, secondary to {{c3::rheumatic fever}}, is associated with {{c1::Aschoff bodies}}, which are granulomas with giant cells and fibrinoid material
{{c2::Myocarditis}}, secondary to {{c3::rheumatic fever}}, is associated with {{c1::Anitschkow cells}}, which are reactive histiocytes with slender, wavy nuclei
{{c1::Pericarditis}} most often presents with friction rub and chest pain

What does the N in J♥NES criteria represent?

{{c1::Nodules in skin (subcutaneous)}}

What does the E in J♥NES criteria represent?

{{c1::Erythema marginatum}}

What does the S in J♥NES criteria represent?

{{c1::Sydenham chorea}}
Acute rheumatic fever attack usually resolves, but may progress to {{c1::chronic rheumatic heart}} disease

What drug is used for treatment or prophylaxis of rheumatic fever?

{{c1::Penicillin}}

What is the most common heart valve affected by rheumatic heart disease?

{{c1::Mitral valve}}

What is the second most common heart valve affected by rheumatic heart disease?

{{c1::Aortic valve}}
Early (acute) lesions of rheumatic heart disease cause mitral {{c1::regurgitation}}
Late (chronic) lesions of rheumatic heart disease cause mitral {{c1::stenosis}}
Chronic rheumatic heart disease results in stenosis with a classic {{c1::fish-mouth}} appearance
Occasionally, chronic rheumatic heart disease involves the aortic valve, leading to {{c1::fusion}} of the commissures
Complications of chronic rheumatic heart disease include infectious {{c1::endocarditis}}
The most common cause of aortic stenosis is {{c1::degenerative calcification}} from "wear and tear"

What demographic is most commonly affected by aortic stenosis?

{{c1::Older adults (> 60)::age group}}
Symptomatic aortic stenosis may present in patients around age 50 with a(n) {{c1::bicuspid}} aortic valve
Aortic {{c1::stenosis}} may arise as a consequence of chronic rheumatic valve disease

Aortic stenosis due to rheumatic disease may be distinguished from stenosis due to "wear and tear" by the presence of:
1. {{c1::Coexisting mitral stenosis}}
2. {{c2::Fusion of the commissures}}
Compensation for aortic stenosis leads to a prolonged {{c1::asymptomatic}} stage
Aortic stenosis may present with {{c1::syncope}}, {{c2::angina}}, and {{c3::dyspnea}} on exertion
Aortic {{c2::stenosis}} may lead to {{c1::concentric::con/e-centric}} left ventricular hypertrophy, which can further progress to heart failure
Aortic {{c2::stenosis}} may cause {{c1::macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia}} as RBCs are damaged while crossing the calcified valve, producing schistocytes
Aortic {{c1::stenosis}} is associated with "Pulsus parvus et tardus", meaning pulses are weak with a delayed peak
Treatment for aortic stenosis is {{c1::valve replacement}} after the onset of complications

What is the most common cause of aortic regurgitation?

{{c1::Isolated aortic root dilation}}
Aortic regurgitation arises due to aortic root dilation (e.g. syphilitic aneurysm, aortic dissection) or {{c1::valve damage}} (e.g. infectious endocarditis)
One clinical feature of aortic {{c3::regurgitation}} is {{c1::hyperdynamic}} circulation due to increased (widened) {{c2::pulse}} pressure

What is the effect of aortic regurgitation on diastolic pressure?

{{c1::Decreased pressure}}

What is the effect of aortic regurgitation on systolic pressure?

{{c1::Increased pressure}}
Aortic {{c2::regurgitation}} may present with a(n) {{c3::bounding}} pulse (Corrigan / Water-hammer pulse), {{c4::pulsating}} nail bed (Quincke pulse), and head {{c1::bobbing}} when severe
Aortic {{c2::regurgitation}} may lead to left ventricle dilation with {{c1::eccentric}} hypertrophy, which can progress to left heart failure
Treatment for aortic regurgitation is {{c1::valve replacement}} before LV dysfunction develops
{{c1::Mitral valve prolapse}} is the ballooning of the mitral valve into the left atrium during systole
Mitral valve prolapse is caused by {{c1::myxoid}} degeneration of the valve, making it floppy
Mitral valve prolapse complications are rare but include infective {{c1::endocarditis}}, arrhythmia, and severe mitral regurgitation

What is the treatment for mitral valve prolapse?

{{c1::Valve replacement}}
Mitral regurgitation usually arises as a complication of mitral valve {{c1::prolapse}}
Mitral regurgitation may be caused by left ventricle {{c1::dilatation}}
Chronic mitral regurgitation may result in volume overload and {{c1::left}}-sided heart failure
Mitral stenosis is usually due to {{c1::chronic rheumatic valve}} disease
A(n) {{c2::decreased}} interval between A2 (of S2) and the opening snap sounds of a mitral stenosis murmur correlates with {{c1::increased}} disease severity
Chronic mitral stenosis may result in left {{c1::atrium}} dilatation due to volume overload
Increased {{c1::LA}} pressure as a result of mitral stenosis may lead to pulmonary congestion with edema and alveolar hemorrhage
One possible complication of mitral stenosis is pulmonary {{c1::hypertension}} and eventual {{c2::right}}-sided heart failure
One possible complication of mitral stenosis is {{c1::atrial fibrillation}} with associated risk for mural thrombi
{{c1::Endocarditis}} is inflammation of endocardium that lines the surface of cardiac valves (usually due to bacterial infection)

What bacteria is the most common cause of subacute endocarditis?

{{c1::Viridans streptococci}}

What type of heart valve does viridans streptococci infect?

{{c1::Previously damaged valves::normal vs damaged}}
viridans streptococci cause {{c1::subacute}} endocarditis, which is characterized by {{c2::small::size}} vegetations that do not destroy the valve
When the surface of the endocardium is damaged, thrombotic vegetations of {{c1::platelets}} and {{c1::fibrin}} may develop
Subacute endocarditis is often a sequela of {{c1::dental}} procedures
Prophylactic {{c1::antibiotics}} decrease risk of subacute endocarditis

What bacteria is the most common cause of endocarditis in IV drug users?

{{c1::Staphylococcus aureus}}

Which heart valve is most frequently involved in bacterial endocarditis?

{{c1::Mitral valve}}

Which heart valve is most frequently involved in bacterial endocarditis in IV drug users?

{{c1::Tricuspid valve}}

What type of heart valve does Staphylococcus aureus infect?

{{c1::Normal heart valves (undamaged)::damaged vs normal}}
Staphylococcus aureus causes {{c1::acute}} endocarditis, which is characterized by {{c2::large::size}} vegetations that destroy the valve
{{c2::Staphylococcus epidermidis}} infection is associated with endocarditis in patients with {{c1::prosthetic}} valves
{{c2::Streptococcus bovis (gallolyticus)}} infection is associated with endocarditis in patients with underlying {{c1::colorectal carcinoma}}
Endocarditis due to S. aureus is characterized by {{c1::high}} virulence and {{c1::rapid}} onset
Endocarditis due to viridans streptococci is characterized by {{c1::low}} virulence and {{c1::gradual}} onset
The HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella) are associated with endocarditis with {{c1::negative}} blood cultures

What is the most common symptom of bacterial endocarditis?

{{c1::Fever}}
One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is {{c1::Roth spots}}, which are round, white spots on the retina surrounded by hemorrhage
One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is {{c1::Osler nodes}}, which are tender, raised lesions on the finger or toe pads
One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is {{c1::murmur}}, which occurs as blood flows over vegetations on the heart valve
One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is {{c1::Janeway lesions}}, which are small, nontender, erythematous lesions on the palm or sole
One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is {{c1::anemia of chronic disease}}, which occurs as a result of increased release of hepcidin
One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is {{c1::splinter hemorrhages}} in the nail bed
One symptom associated with bacterial endocarditis is septic arterial or pulmonary {{c1::emboli}}
Bacterial endocarditis requires multiple {{c1::blood}} cultures for diagnosis
{{c1::Transesophageal}} echocardiogram may be used to detect lesions on heart valves, which aids in the diagnosis of bacterial endocarditis
{{c3::Non-bacterial thrombotic}} endocarditis is due to sterile vegetations that arise in association with a(n) {{c2::hypercoagulable}} state or underlying {{c1::adenocarcinoma}}
Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis often results in sterile vegetations on the {{c1::mitral}} valve along lines of closure, which results in regurgitation
{{c1::Libman-Sacks (verrucous)}} endocarditis is due to sterile vegetations that arise in association with {{c2::SLE}}
{{c1::Libman-Sacks (verrucous) endocarditis}} is unique in that vegetations typically present on {{c1::both}} side(s) of the {{c2::mitral}} valve, resulting in regurgitation
{{c1::Dilated}} cardiomyopathy is the dilation of all four chambers of the heart

What is the most common form of cardiomyopathy (90%)?

{{c1::Dilated cardiomyopathy}}
Dilated cardiomyopathy results in {{c1::systolic::systolic or diastolic}} dysfunction
Systolic dysfunction as a result of dilated cardiomyopathy may lead to biventricular {{c1::congestive heart failure}}

What type of hypertrophy is seen in dilated cardiomyopathy?

{{c1::Eccentric hypertrophy (sarcomeres added in series)}}
The cause of dilated cardiomyopathy is most commonly {{c1::idiopathic}}
Chronic alcohol abuse increases risk for {{c1::dilated}} cardiomyopathy
Dilated cardiomyopathy may be caused by {{c1::Chagas}} disease, which is the result of a parasitic infection

What anti-neoplastic agent is associated with dilated cardiomyopathy?

{{c1::Doxorubicin}}
{{c1::Dilated}} cardiomyopathy may be seen during the last month of pregnancy or within five months of childbirth ("peripartum cardiomyopathy")
Dilated cardiomyopathy may be caused by {{c1::wet beriberi}}, which is the result of a vitamin B1 deficiency

What pathologic heart sound may be heard with dilated cardiomyopathy?

{{c1::S3}}
{{c1::Hypertrophic}} cardiomyopathy is characterized by massive ventricular hypertrophy, often with septal predominance
{{c2::Hypertrophic}} cardiomyopathy usually arises due to genetic mutations (60-70%), especially in {{c1::sarcomere}} proteins
Mutations that cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy most commonly have a(n) {{c1::autosomal dominant}} inheritance pattern
{{c2::Hypertrophic}} cardiomyopathy is associated with the trinucleotide repeat expansion disease {{c1::Friedreich ataxia}}
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy causes {{c1::diastolic::systolic or diastolic}} dysfunction
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy leads to {{c1::decreased}} cardiac output due to decreased compliance of the left ventricle
{{c1::Hypertrophic}} cardiomyopathy is associated with sudden death in young athletes due to {{c2::ventricular arrhythmia}}
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy causes {{c1::syncope}} with exercise due to subaortic hypertrophy of the ventricular septum, resulting in functional aortic {{c2::stenosis}}
{{c2::Hypertrophic}} cardiomyopathy is characterized by myofibrillar hypertrophy with {{c1::disarray}} and fibrosis on biopsy

What pathologic heart sound may be heard with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?

{{c1::S4}}
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may impair {{c1::mitral}} valve closure, thus causing regurgitation
{{c1::Restrictive}} cardiomyopathy is primarily characterized by decreased compliance of the ventricular endomyocardium
Causes of {{c1::restrictive}} cardiomyopathy include amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, post-radiation fibrosis, and eosinophilic syndromes of the heart (loeffler endocarditis, endomyocardial fibrosis)
Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes {{c1::diastolic::systolic or diastolic}} dysfunction
{{c3::Restrictive}} cardiomyopathy may be caused by {{c1::endocardial fibroelastosis}}, which is a thick fibroelastic tissue in the endocardium; most commonly affects {{c2::young children}}
{{c3::Restrictive}} cardiomyopathy may be caused by {{c1::Loeffler}} syndrome, which is an endomyocardial fibrosis with a prominent {{c2::eosinophilic}} infiltrate
{{c3::Restrictive}} cardiomyopathy presents with a(n) {{c1::low-voltage}} ECG with a diminished {{c2::QRS}} amplitude

What is the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults?

{{c1::Myxoma}}
Cardiac {{c2::myxomas}} usually form a pedunculated mass in the {{c1::left atrium (80%)}}, which may cause {{c3::syncope}} due to obstruction of the mitral valve
{{c1::Rhabdomyomas}} are benign hamartomas of cardiac muscle

What is the most common primary cardiac tumor in children?

{{c1::Rhabdomyoma}}
{{c2::Rhabdomyoma}} is a cardiac tumor associated with {{c1::tuberous sclerosis}}
The most common heart tumor is a(n) {{c1::metastasis}}

What type of drug are class II antiarrhythmics?

{{c1::β-blockers}}
Metoprolol, propranolol, and esmolol are all examples of class {{c1::II}} antiarrhythmics
Atenolol, timolol, and carvedilol are all examples of class {{c1::II}} antiarrhythmics
Class {{c3::II}} antiarrhythmics treat arrhythmias by blocking {{c1::sympathetic}} input to the {{c2::SA}} and {{c2::AV nodes}}

What effect do Class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) have on cAMP levels?

{{c1::Decreased cAMP}}
Decreased cAMP as a result of class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) leads to the closure of membrane {{c1::Ca2+}} channels
Class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) suppress abnormal pacemakers by decreasing the {{c1::slope}} of phase {{c2::4}} of the nodal action potential
The {{c1::AV}} node is particularly sensitive to class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers)

Are class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) used to treat supraventricular or ventricular arrhythmias?

{{c1::Supraventricular}}
{{c1::Intravenous::mode of delivery}} class II antiarrhythmics, such as {{c2::esmolol}}, can be used for intra-operative or other acute supraventricular arrhythmias (very short acting)
One possible adverse effect of class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) is {{c1::heart block}} due to decreased conduction through the AV node
Class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) may induce heart (AV) block, which manifests as a prolonged {{c1::PR interval}} on ECG
Class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) are useful in the treatment of {{c1::atrial}} fibrillation (and flutter)
Class II antiarrhythmics (β-blockers) are useful in preventing {{c1::rapid ventricular response (RVR)}} in atrial fibrillation and flutter ("rate control")

What classes of antiarrhythmics are used for ventricular rate control in atrial fibrillation and flutter?

{{c1::Class II and IV::2}}

What classes of antiarrhythmics are used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation and flutter?

{{c1::Class IC and III::2}}

What type of drug are class III antiarrhythmics?

{{c1::K+ channel blockers}}

What effect do class III antiarrhythmics have on action potential duration?

{{c1::Increased AP duration}}

What effect do class III antiarrhythmics have on effective refractory period?

{{c1::Increased ERP}}
Class III antiarrhythmics (K+ channel blockers) exert their effects by prolonging phase {{c1::2}} and {{c1::3}} of the myocardial action potential
{{c1::Amiodarone}} is a lipophilic class {{c2::III}} antiarrhythmic that also shares properties with class I, II, and IV antiarrhythmics

What drug class do dofetilide and ibutilide belong to?

{{c1::Class III antiarrhythmics (K+ channel blockers)}}
{{c3::Sotalol}} is a class {{c1::III}} antiarrhythmic that also has class {{c2::II (β-blocker)}} activity

Are class III antiarrhythmics used to treat supraventricular or ventricular arrhythmias?

{{c1::Both :)}}
Class III antiarrhythmics may be used to treat {{c1::atrial}} fibrillation (and flutter)
Class III antiarrhythmics can restore and maintain normal sinus rhythm in {{c1::atrial}} fibrillation and flutter
{{c1::Amiodarone}}, a class III antiarrhythmic, has many neurologic side effects (e.g. tremor, ataxia, peripheral neuropathy, sleep disturbances)
Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, can act as a(n) {{c1::hapten}}, resulting in gray {{c2::corneal}} microdeposits
{{c2::Amiodarone}}, a class III antiarrhythmic, can cause both hyper- or hypo-{{c1::thyroidism}}
Amiodarone can cause pulmonary {{c1::fibrosis}} with progression to {{c2::restrictive lung}} disease
Amiodarone can cause {{c1::heart block}} as a result of its class II antiarrhythmic activity
Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, can induce heart {{c1::failure}}, especially with rapid IV administration
Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic, can cause hypersensitivity {{c1::hepatitis}}
Amiodarone may act as a hapten resulting in {{c1::gray-blue}} skin discoloration with {{c2::photodermatitis}}
{{c2::Amiodarone}}, a class III antiarrhythmic, is a(n) {{c3::inhibitor}} of {{c1::cytochrome P450}} and thus may have many drug interactions

What adverse effect is common to sotalol, dofetilide, and ibutilide (class III antiarrhythmics)?

{{c1::Torsades de pointes}}
All type III antiarrhythmics (K+ channel blockers) can {{c2::widen}} the {{c1::QT interval}} on ECG
{{c2::Amiodarone}} and {{c3::sotalol}} (class III antiarrhythmics) may be used to treat {{c1::ventricular}} tachycardia

What laboratory function tests should be checked when using amiodarone?

{{c1::Pulmonary (PFTs), Liver (LFTs), and Thyroid (TFTs)::3}}

What adverse effect may amiodarone have on bowel movement?

{{c1::Constipation}}
During the early stages of exercise, cardiac output is maintained by increased {{c1::heart rate}} and {{c1::stroke volume}}
During the late stages of exercise, cardiac output is maintained by increased {{c1::heart rate}} only as {{c1::stroke volume}} plateaus

Which phase of the cardiac cycle (systole or diastole) is preferentially shortened with increased heart rate?

{{c1::Diastole}}

What is the effect of obstructive sleep apnea on pulse pressure?

{{c1::Increased pulse pressure}}

What is the effect of exercise on pulse pressure?

{{c1::Increased pulse pressure, transiently}}
{{c1::Decreased}} pulse pressures are seen in conditions that decrease left ventricular stroke volume

What is the effect of cardiogenic shock on pulse pressure?

{{c1::Decreased pulse pressure}}

What is the effect of advanced heart failure on pulse pressure?

{{c1::Decreased pulse pressure}}

What is the effect of β1-blockade on contractility (and SV)?

{{c1::Decreased contractility}}
{{c1::Vaso}}-dilators (e.g. hydralazine) cause decreased {{c2::after}}-load

What is the effect of dilated cardiomyopathy on contractility?

{{c1::Decreased (systolic dysfunction)}}
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may present with a(n) {{c1::systolic::systolic/diastolic}} murmur

Where is a murmur due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy best heard?

{{c1::Left sternal border}}

What effect does inspiration have on venous return to the right atrium?

{{c1::Increased venous return}}
Inspiration as a bedside maneuver may be used to increase the intensity of {{c1::right}} heart sounds
The hand grip maneuver is used to {{c1::increase}} {{c2::after}}-load

What effect does the hand grip maneuver have on the intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs?

{{c1::Increased intensity}}

What effect does the hand grip maneuver have on the intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmurs?

{{c1::Decreased intensity}}

What effect does the hand grip maneuver have on the "click" onset time of MVP murmurs?

{{c1::Later onset of click/murmur}}
Standing up and the valsalva maneuver are both used to {{c1::decrease}} {{c2::pre}}-load

What effect does standing up or the valsalva maneuver have on the intensity of MR, AR, MS, and AS murmurs?

{{c1::Decreased intensity}}

What effect does standing up or the valsalva maneuver have on the intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmurs?

{{c1::Increased intensity}}

What effect does standing up or the valsalva maneuver have on the "click" onset time of MVP murmurs?

{{c1::Earlier onset of click/murmur}}
{{c1::Rapid squatting}} is a maneuver that is used to {{c2::increase}} preload, afterload, and venous return

What effect does the rapid squatting maneuver have on the intensity of aortic stenosis murmurs?

{{c1::Increased intensity}}

What effect does the rapid squatting maneuver have on the intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmurs?

{{c1::Decreased intensity}}

What effect does the rapid squatting maneuver have on the "click" onset time of MVP murmurs?

{{c1::Later onset of click/murmur}}

Where is a murmur due to patent ductus arteriosus best heard?

{{c1::Left infraclavicular area}}
The Cushing reaction is a triad of {{c1::hypertension}}, {{c2::bradycardia}}, and {{c3::respiratory}} depression due to increased {{c4::intracranial}} pressure

What effect does carotid massage have on conduction through the AV node?

{{c1::Slowed conduction}}
{{c1::Atrial fibrillation}} is characterized by a chaotic and erratic baseline with no discrete {{c2::P}} waves in between irregularly spaced QRS complexes on ECG
Atrial fibrillation is characterized by a(n) {{c1::irregularly}}, {{c1::irregular}} patterned rhythm
Atrial fibrillation can lead to thromboembolic events, particularly {{c1::stroke}} (brain complication)
The most common risk factors for atrial fibrillation include {{c1::hypertension}} and {{c2::coronary artery disease (CAD)}}
Atrial {{c1::flutter}} is characterized by a rapid succession of identical, back-to-back atrial depolarization waves
Atrial {{c2::flutter}} typically has a 4:1 "{{c1::sawtooth}}" pattern appearance on ECG

What is the definitive treatment for atrial flutter?

{{c1::Catheter ablation}}
{{c1::Ventricular fibrillation}} is characterized by a completely erratic rhythm with no identifiable waves on ECG
{{c1::1st}} degree AV block is characterized by a PR interval > {{c2::200}} msec on ECG
{{c1::2nd degree Mobitz type I (Wenckebach)::(aka)}} AV block is characterized by progressive lengthening of the {{c2::PR}} interval until a beat is "dropped"
2nd degree Mobitz type I AV block is characterized by a(n) {{c1::regularly}}, {{c1::irregular}} patterned rhythm on ECG
{{c1::2nd degree Mobitz type II}} AV block is characterized by dropped beats that are not preceded by a change in length of the PR interval on ECG
2nd degree Mobitz type II AV block may progress to {{c1::3rd}}-degree block
2nd degree Mobitz type II AV block is often treated with a(n) {{c1::pacemaker}}
{{c1::3rd}} degree AV block is characterized by independent beating of the atria and ventricles (P waves and QRS complexes are not rhythmically associated)
3rd degree AV block is usually treated with a(n) {{c1::pacemaker}}
3rd degree AV block can be caused by {{c1::Lyme}} disease

What pathology is indicated on the ECG below?

{{c1::Atrial fibrillation}}

What pathology is indicated on the ECG below?

{{c1::Atrial flutter}}

What pathology is indicated on the ECG below?

{{c1::Ventricular fibrillation}}

What pathology is indicated on the ECG below?

{{c1::1st degree AV block}}

What pathology is indicated on the ECG below?

{{c1::2nd degree AV block, Mobitz type I (Wenckebach)}}

What pathology is indicated on the ECG below?

{{c1::2nd degree AV block, Mobitz type II}}

What pathology is indicated on the ECG below?

{{c1::3rd degree AV block}}
{{c1::Atrial}} septal defect leads to an increased O2 saturation in the {{c2::RA}}, RV and pulmonary artery
One sign of hyperlipidemia is {{c1::xanthomas}}, which are plaques or nodules composed of {{c3::lipid-laden histiocytes}} in {{c2::skin}}
When a xanthoma affects the eyelids, it is known as {{c1::xanthelasma}}
One sign of hyperlipidemia is {{c1::tendinous xanthomas}}, which are plaques or nodules composed of lipid-laden histiocytes in {{c2::tendon (especially Achilles)}}
One sign of hyperlipidemia is {{c1::corneal arcus}}, which are lipid deposits in the cornea
Corneal arcus is common in the {{c1::elderly}} (arcus senilis), but appears earlier in life in patients with {{c2::hypercholesterolemia}}
Diagnosis of a current or previous myocardial infarction may be aided by the presence of pathologic {{c1::Q}} waves on ECG
There is an increased risk for {{c1::posteromedial}} papillary muscle rupture (post-MI) due to its single blood supply from the {{c2::posterior descending}} artery
{{c1::Obstructive}} hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a subset of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in which asymmetric septal hypertrophy interferes with the outflow of blood from the left ventricle
{{c1::Shock}} is defined as inadequate organ perfusion and delivery of nutrients necessary for normal tissue and cellular function
{{c1::Hypovolemic}} shock may be caused by hemorrhage, dehydration, and burns (volume loss)
Hypovolemic shock is characterized by skin that is {{c1::cold}} and {{c1::clammy}}

How do PCWP and preload change during hypovolemic shock?

{{c1::Severely decreased}}

How does cardiac output change during hypovolemic shock?

{{c1::Decreased}}

How do SVR and afterload change during hypovolemic shock?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the treatment for hypovolemic shock?

{{c1::IV fluids}}
{{c1::Cardiogenic}} shock may be caused by acute MI, HF, valvular dysfunction, and arrhythmia (pump failure)
{{c1::Obstructive}} shock may be caused by cardiac tamponade and pulmonary embolism
Cardiogenic and obstructive shock are characterized by skin that is {{c1::cold}} and {{c1::clammy}}

How do PCWP and preload change during cardiogenic and obstructive shock?

{{c1::Increased or decreased}}

How does cardiac output change during cardiogenic and obstructive shock?

{{c1::Severely decreased}}

How do SVR and afterload change during cardiogenic and obstructive shock?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the main treatment for cardiogenic shock?

{{c1::IV Inotropes}}

What is the treatment for obstructive shock?

{{c1::Relieve obstruction}}
{{c1::Distributive}} shock may be caused by sepsis, anaphylaxis, or CNS injury (excessive vasodilation)
Distributive shock is characterized by skin that is {{c1::warm}} and {{c1::dry}}

How do PCWP and preload change during distributive shock?

{{c1::Decreased}}

How does cardiac output change during distributive shock due to sepsis and anaphylaxis?

{{c1::Increased}}

How does cardiac output change during distributive shock due to CNS injury?

{{c1::Decreased}}

How do SVR and afterload change during distributive shock?

{{c1::Severely decreased}}

What is the treatment for distributive shock?

{{c1::IV fluids, pressors::2}}

What kidney complication may be associated with bacterial endocarditis?

{{c1::Glomerulonephritis}}
{{c1::Kussmaul}} sign is {{c2::increased}} jugular venous pressure on {{c3::inspiration}}
The Kussmaul sign (increased JVP on inspiration) occurs due to failure of negative intrathoracic pressure to be transmitted to the {{c1::heart}} during inspiration

Failure of negative intrathoracic pressure to be transmitted to the heart results in impaired filling of the {{c1::right}} ventricle, with a consequent back-up of blood into the {{c1::vena cava::one step past the atria}} (Kussmaul sign)
Kussmaul sign (increased JVP on inspiration) may be seen with constrictive {{c1::pericarditis}} and {{c2::restrictive}} cardiomyopathies
Kussmaul sign (increased JVP on inspiration) may be seen with {{c1::right::left or right}} atrial or ventricular tumors
Tertiary syphilis disrupts the {{c1::vasa vasorum}} of the aorta with consequent atrophy of the vessel wall and dilatation of the aorta and valve ring
Acute {{c1::pericarditis}} is defined as inflammation of the pericardium
Acute {{c3::pericarditis}} commonly presents with sharp pain that is aggravated by {{c1::inspiration}} and relieved by {{c2::sitting up and leaning forward}}
Acute pericarditis is often complicated by pericardial {{c1::effusion}}
ECG changes associated with acute {{c4::pericarditis}} include widespread, diffuse {{c1::ST segment}} {{c2::elevation}} and/or {{c1::PR}} {{c2::depression}}

What is the most common cause of acute pericarditis?

{{c1::Idiopathic (presumed viral)}}
{{c1::Cardiac tamponade}} is defined as compression of the heart by fluid

What is the effect of cardiac tamponade on cardiac output?

{{c1::Decreased CO}}

What is the effect of cardiac tamponade on heart rate?

{{c1::Increased HR}}
Cardiac tamponade leads to equilibration of {{c1::diastolic}} pressures in all 4 chambers
{{c4::Cardiac tamponade}} may present with Becks triad of {{c1::hypotension}}, {{c2::distended neck veins}}, and {{c3::distant heart sounds}}
One ECG change associated with cardiac tamponade is a(n) {{c1::low-voltage}} QRS complex
One ECG change associated with cardiac tamponade is {{c1::electrical alternans}}, which occurs due to "swinging" movement of the heart in a large effusion
Cardiac tamponade may be associated with {{c1::pulsus paradoxus}}, which is a(n) {{c4::decrease}} in amplitude of systolic BP > {{c3::10}} mmHG during {{c2::inspiration}}

What type of drug are class IV antiarrhythmics?

{{c1::Non-dihydropyridine Ca2+ channel blockers}}
Class {{c2::IV}} antiarrhythmics block activated and inactivated {{c1::L}}-type calcium channels
Class IV antiarrhythmics (non-dihydropyridine CCBs) are specific for the L-type calcium channel receptors in the {{c1::heart::overall location in the body}}

What drug class do diltiazem and verapamil belong to?

{{c1::Class IV antiarrhythmics (non-dihydropyridine Ca2+ channel blockers)}}
Class {{c3::IV}} antiarrhythmics treat arrhythmias by directly blocking {{c1::Ca2+}} current in the {{c2::SA}} and {{c2::AV nodes}}
Class IV antiarrhythmics decrease pacemaker activity by decreasing the slope of phase {{c1::0}} of the nodal action potential

What is the effect of class IV antiarrhythmics (non-dihydropyridine Ca2+ channel blockers) on effective refractory period?

{{c1::Increased ERP}}
Class IV antiarrhythmics (non-dihydropyridine CCBs) {{c1::decrease}} conduction velocity through the AV node

Are class IV antiarrhythmics used to treat supraventricular or ventricular arrhythmias?

{{c1::Supraventricular}}
Class IV antiarrhythmics may prolong the {{c1::PR interval}} on ECG
One possible adverse effect of class IV antiarrhythmics is AV {{c1::block}} due to decreased conduction through the AV node
Class IV antiarrhythmics are useful in the treatment of {{c1::atrial}} fibrillation (and flutter)
Class IV antiarrhythmics are useful in preventing {{c1::rapid ventricular response (RVR)}} in atrial fibrillation and flutter ("rate control")
{{c1::Digoxin}} is a cardiac glycoside that has antiarrhythmic properties
Digoxin exerts parasympathomimetic effects via direct stimulation of the {{c1::vagus}} nerve, causing {{c2::AV}} nodal inhibition
Digoxin is useful in the treatment of {{c1::atrial}} fibrillation (and flutter)
Digoxin is useful in preventing {{c1::rapid ventricular response (RVR)}} in atrial fibrillation and flutter ("rate control")
{{c2::Magnesium}} is an ion that may be used as an antiarrhythmic to treat {{c1::torsades de pointes}}
Magnesium may be used as an antiarrhythmic to treat {{c1::digoxin}} toxicity

What changes in potassium levels (hyper- or hypokalemia) can induce arrhythmias?

{{c1::Both hyper- and hypokalemia :)}}
{{c2::Hyper}}-kalemia induced arrhythmias may present on ECG with {{c1::peaked}} T waves and a(n) {{c1::shortened}} QT interval
{{c2::Hypo}}-kalemia induced arrhythmias may present on ECG with {{c1::U}} waves at the end of the T wave
{{c1::Adenosine}} is a purine nucleoside with antiarrhythmic properties
Adenosine activates inhibitory {{c1::A1}} receptors on the myocardium of the {{c2::SA}} and {{c2::AV nodes}}
Activation of A1 receptors in the myocardium by adenosine {{c1::increases}} outward {{c2::K+}} current
Activation of A1 receptors in the myocardium by adenosine {{c1::decreases}} inward {{c2::Ca2+}} current
Adenosine {{c1::decreases}} conduction velocity through the AV node

What is the effect of adenosine on effective refractory period?

{{c1::Increased ERP}}
Adenosine may cause transient high grade {{c1::heart block}} due to direct AV node inhibition
Adenosine may be used as a very {{c1::short}} acting antiarrhythmic
{{c2::Adenosine}} is a first line agent for acute treatment of {{c1::supraventricular}} arrhythmias
Adenosine causes coronary {{c1::dilation}} via its action on {{c2::A2}} receptors
One adverse effect associated with adenosine is cutaneous {{c1::flushing}}
Adverse effects associated with adenosine include {{c1::chest}} pain and a sense of {{c2::impending doom}}

What effect may adenosine have on blood pressure?

{{c1::Decreased (hypotension)}}
{{c3::Adenosine}} is an antiarrhythmic that is less effective in the presence of {{c1::theophylline}} and {{c2::caffeine}} (methylxanthines)

What pulmonary side effect is associated with adenosine?

{{c1::Bronchospasm}}
{{c2::Hypertrophic}} cardiomyopathy is commonly due to {{c1::β-myosin heavy chain}} or {{c3::myosin-binding protein C}} mutations
The heart is maximally softened {{c1::7}} to {{c1::10}} days post-MI
The embryonic {{c1::truncus arteriosus}} gives rise to the {{c2::ascending aorta}} and {{c2::pulmonary trunk}}
The embryonic {{c1::bulbus cordis}} gives rise to the {{c3::smooth}} parts (outflow tracks) of the left and right {{c2::ventricles}}
The embryonic {{c1::primitive atria}} gives rise to the {{c2::trabeculated}} parts of the left and right {{c3::atria}}
The embryonic {{c1::primitive ventricle}} gives rise to the {{c3::trabeculated}} parts of the left and right {{c2::ventricles}}
The embryonic {{c1::right horn of sinus venosus}} gives rise to the {{c2::smooth}} part of the {{c3::right atrium}}
The embryonic {{c1::left horn of sinus venosus}} gives rise to the {{c2::coronary sinus}}
The embryonic {{c1::right common cardinal vein}} and {{c1::right anterior cardinal vein}} give rise to the {{c2::superior vena cava}}
The embryonic {{c1::endocardial cushion}} gives rise to the atrial septum and membranous interventricular septum
The embryonic {{c1::endocardial cushion}} gives rise to the AV and semilunar valves
The heart beats spontaneously by week {{c1::4}} of embryonic development
The primary heart tube {{c1::loops}} to establish left-right polarity beginning in week 4 of gestation
A defect in left-right dynein during heart morphogenesis can result in {{c1::dextrocardia}}
In the first step of atrial partitioning, the {{c1::septum primum}} grows toward the endocardial cushions, forming a narrow {{c2::ostium primum}}
In the second step of atrial partitioning, the {{c1::ostium secundum}} forms in place of the ostium primum
In the third step of atrial partitioning, the sinus venosus is "pulled" into the developing right atrium, forming the {{c1::septum secundum}}
In the fourth step of atrial partitioning, the septum secundum expands and covers most of the foramen secundum, leaving the residual {{c1::foramen ovale}}
The remaining portion of the septum primum, following foramen ovale formation, forms the {{c1::valve of foramen ovale}}
Shortly after birth, the septum secundum and septum primum fuse to form the {{c1::atrial septum}}
The foramen ovale usually closes shortly after birth because of increased {{c1::left atrial}} pressure
Failure of the septum primum and septum secundum to fuse after birth results in a(n) {{c1::patent foramen ovale}}
Patent foramen ovale can lead to {{c1::paradoxical}} emboli, which are venous thromboemboli that enter systemic arterial circulation
In the first step of ventricular partitioning, the {{c1::muscular}} interventricular septum develops and forms the {{c2::interventricular foramen}}

In the second step of ventricular partitioning, the aorticopulmonary septum rotates and fuses with the muscular interventricular septum to form the {{c1::membranous interventricular septum}}, resulting in closure of the interventricular foramen
In the third step of ventricular partitioning, growth of {{c1::endocardial cushions}} separates atria from ventricles
Ventricular septal defects usually occur in the {{c1::membranous}} portion of the interventricular septum
The mitral and tricuspid valves are derived from the fused {{c1::endocardial cushions}} of the common AV canal
Outflow tracts from the heart are formed by migrations of {{c1::neural crest}} and {{c2::endocardial}} cells, which spiral and fuse to form the {{c3::aorticopulmonary::long}} septum

What is the embryonic origin of endocardial cushion cells?

{{c1::Neural crest cells and lateral plate mesoderm::2}}

What is the embryonic origin of the aorticopulmonary septum?

{{c1::Neural crest cells}}
Blood in the umbilical vein has a Po2 of approximately {{c1::30}} mmHg
Blood in the umbilical vein has a O2 saturation of approximately {{c1::80}}%
Compared to the umbilical vein, the umbilical arteries have {{c1::low}} O2 saturation
Oxygenated blood from the placenta enters the fetal circulation via the {{c1::umbilical vein}}
From the umbilical vein, blood is conducted into the {{c1::IVC}} via the {{c2::ductus venosus}}, which bypasses {{c3::hepatic}} circulation
Mixed blood in the fetal IVC enters the {{c1::right atrium}}
Most of the highly oxygenated blood reaching the heart via the fetal IVC is directed from the RA to the LA via the {{c1::foramen ovale}} and pumped into the aorta to supply the head and body
Most of the deoxygenated blood from the fetal SVC is conducted to the {{c1::descending aorta}} via the {{c2::ductus arteriosus}}, which bypasses the {{c3::lungs}}
Deoxygenated blood is returned to the placenta via the {{c1::umbilical arteries}}
Once the foramen ovale has closed, it is re-named the {{c1::fossa ovalis}}
Closure of the ductus arteriosus occurs in response to increased {{c1::O2}} and decreased {{c2::PGE}} (from respiration and placental separation, respectively)
The remnant of the ductus arteriosus is the {{c1::ligamentum arteriosum}}, which connects the aorta and pulmonary artery
The SA node is commonly supplied by the {{c1::right coronary}} artery while the AV node is supplied by the {{c1::Posterior Descending}} Artery
The posterior descending artery (PDA) most commonly arises from the {{c1::right coronary}} artery (85%)
When the {{c1::posterior descending artery (PDA)}} arises from the {{c2::right coronary}} artery, it is referred to as right-dominant circulation (85%)
When the {{c1::posterior descending artery (PDA)}} arises from the {{c2::left circumflex}} artery, it is referred to as left-dominant circulation (8%)
When the {{c1::posterior descending artery (PDA)}} arises from both the right coronary artery and left circumflex artery, it is referred to as {{c2::codominant}} circulation (7%)
Coronary blood flow peaks in early {{c1::diastole::systolic/diastolic}}
The most posterior part of the heart is the {{c1::left atrium}}
The outermost layer of the pericardium is the {{c1::fibrous pericardium}}
The middle layer of the pericardium is the {{c1::parietal layer of serous pericardium}}
The inner layer of the pericardium is the {{c1::visceral layer of serous pericardium}}
The {{c1::pericardial cavity}} lies between parietal and visceral layers of serous pericardium

Which artery supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum?

{{c1::Left anterior descending artery (LAD)}}

Which arteries supply the anterolateral papillary muscle?

{{c1::LCX, LAD::2}}
If ΔG for a reaction is {{c1::less}} than zero, the reaction happens spontaneously
If ΔG for a reaction is {{c1::greater}} than zero, energy must be added for the reaction to occur
Enzymes exert their effects by decreasing the energy of {{c1::activation}}
The rate of a reaction depends on the concentration of both the {{c1::enzyme}} and the {{c1::substrate}}
The Michaelis-Mentin constant, Km is defined as the {{c1::substrate}} concentration at which rate is equal to {{c1::Vmax/2}}
The Michaelis-Mentin constant, Km is {{c1::inversely}} proportional to the affinity of the enzyme for its substrate
The Vmax of a reaction is {{c1::directly}} proportional to enzyme concentration
In {{c1::first}} order kinetics, the rate of reaction is directly proportional to the substrate (drug) concentration
In {{c1::zero}} order kinetics, the rate of reaction is constant
If the amount of enzymes doubles, the Vmax {{c1::doubles}}, while Km {{c1::remains constant}}
The {{c1::X}}-intercept of a lineweaver-burke plot represents -1/Km
The {{c1::Y}}-intercept of a lineweaver-burke plot represents 1/Vmax
If the Y-intercept increases on a lineweaver-burke plot, the Vmax has {{c1::decreased}}
When using a(n) {{c1::reversible competitive}} inhibitor, the {{c2::Km}} changes, while the {{c2::Vmax}} remains the same
When using a(n) {{c1::noncompetitive}} inhibitor, the {{c2::Vmax}} changes, while the {{c2::Km}} remains the same
When using an irreversible competitive inhibitor, the {{c1::Vmax}} changes, while the {{c1::Km}} remains the same

Do reversible competitive inhibitors resemble the substrate?

{{c1::Yes}}

Do irreversible competitive inhibitors resemble the substrate?

{{c1::Yes}}

Do noncompetitive inhibitors resemble the substrate?

{{c1::No}}

Can reversible competitive inhibitors be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, [S]?

{{c1::Yes}}

Can irreversible competitive inhibitors be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, [S]?

{{c1::No}}

Can noncompetitive inhibitors be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, [S]?

{{c1::No}}

Do reversible competitive inhibitors bind to the active site of the enzyme?

{{c1::Yes}}

Do irreversible competitive inhibitors bind to the active site of the enzyme?

{{c1::Yes}}

Do noncompetitive inhibitors bind to the active site of the enzyme?

{{c1::No}}
While most enzymatic reactions follow a hyperbolic curve (Michaelis-Menten kinetics), {{c2::allosteric}} kinetics follow a(n) {{c1::sigmoidal}} curve
One adverse effect associated with digoxin is {{c1::hyperkalemia}}, which is an indicator of {{c2::poor}} prognosis
Digitalis toxicity may induce {{c1::arrhythmias}}, such as premature ventricular contractions
Chronic {{c3::digoxin}} use leads to Peaked T wave and QT interval shortening (due to hyperkalemia), and ST {{c1::depression}} with a "{{c2::scooped}}" appearance on ECG
One factor that predisposes to digoxin toxicity is {{c1::hypokalemia}}, which increases binding of digoxin to Na+-K+ ATPase
Milrinone and inamrinone are {{c1::PDE-3}} inhibitors used in the treatment of acute heart failure

What effect does milrinone have on cardiac contractility?

{{c1::Increased contractility}}
Milrinone causes arteriolar {{c1::dilation}} and thus {{c1::decreased}} afterload
Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) target voltage-gated {{c1::L}}-type calcium channels
{{c2::Dihydropyridine}} CCBs primarily block L-type calcium channels in {{c1::smooth}} muscle
{{c2::Non-dihydropyridine}} CCBs primarily block L-type calcium channels in {{c1::cardiac}} muscle
Dihydropyridine CCBs cause vaso-{{c1::dilation}}
Dihydropyridine CCBs have a(n) {{c1::-dipine}} suffix
Verapamil and diltiazem are both examples of {{c1::non-dihydropyridine}} Ca2+ channel blockers
Diltiazem has some vaso-{{c1::dilatory}} activity
{{c2::Non-dihydropyridine}} CCBs {{c1::decrease}} cardiac contractility and cardiac output
Inhibition of the SA node by non-dihydropyridine CCBs can cause {{c1::bradycardia}}
{{c1::Ca2+}} channel blockers are useful for treating hypertension
{{c2::Nifedipine}} is a dihydropyridine CCB that is used to treat {{c3::hypertension}} during {{c1::pregnancy}}
Ca2+ channel blockers may be used to treat {{c1::stable angina}} if β-blockers/nitrates have not worked or are contraindicated
{{c2::Dihydropyridine}} CCBs are useful for treating angina due to their ability to cause coronary vaso-{{c1::dilation}}

What effect do dihydropyridine CCBs have on afterload?

{{c1::Decreased afterload (via peripheral vasodilation)}}
Non-dihydropyridine CCBs are useful for treating angina due to their ability to decrease {{c1::myocardial oxygen}} demand
{{c2::Ca2+ channel}} blockers are a first-line treatment for {{c1::Prinzmetal}} angina, due to their ability to prevent vasoconstriction in the coronary vasculature
{{c2::Dihydropyridine}} CCBs may be used to treat {{c1::Raynauds phenomenon}}, which is an exaggerated vascular response to cold temperature or emotional stress
{{c3::Nimodipine}} is a Ca2+ channel blocker that is used to prevent cerebral {{c2::vasospasm}} following a(n) {{c1::subarachnoid hemorrhage}}
Calcium channel blockers, such as {{c2::verapamil}}, may be used for {{c1::migraine}} prophylaxis
Nonspecific adverse effects of dihydropyridine CCBs include headache, {{c1::dizziness}}, and {{c2::flushing}}
One adverse effect associated with dihydropyridine CCBs is {{c1::peripheral edema}}, secondary to dilation of pre-capillary vessels
Dihydropyridine CCBs may cause reflex {{c1::tachycardia::HR}}

Which Ca2+ channel blocker is contraindicated in patients with unstable angina or MI due to its ability to exacerbate myocardial ischemia?

{{c1::Nifedipine}}

What major GI side effect is associated with verapamil?

{{c1::Constipation}}
One adverse effect associated with Ca2+ channel blockers (e.g. verapamil) is {{c1::gingival}} hyperplasia
{{c2::Non-dihydropyridine}} CCBs are relatively contraindicated in patients with heart {{c1::block}} or heart {{c1::failure}} due to their ability to cause cardiac depression
Dihydropyridine CCBs can worsen heart failure due to increased {{c1::sympathetic}} activity induced by baroreceptor reflex activation

Which Ca2+ channel blockers have the most potent effects on vascular smooth muscle?

{{c1::Amlodipine, Nifedipine::2}}

Which Ca2+ channel blocker has the most potent effects on cardiac muscle?

{{c1::Verapamil}}
Black and elderly patients respond well to {{c1::hydrochlorothiazide}} and long-acting {{c2::dihydropyridine Ca2+ channel blockers}} for treatment of primary hypertension
IV Ca2+ channel blockers such as {{c1::nicardipine}} and {{c2::clevidipine}} may be used in hypertensive {{c3::emergency}}
Hydralazine primarily dilates {{c1::arterioles}}, leading to a decreased {{c1::after}}-load
Hydralazine is often combined with a(n) {{c1::organic nitrate}} to treat {{c2::heart failure}} due to LV systolic dysfunction
Hydralazine combined with a(n) {{c2::nitrate}} provides a(n) {{c1::mortality}} benefit for some patients with heart failure
Hydralazine can rarely cause {{c1::drug-induced lupus}}, which may manifest as myalgias, arthralgias, and joint swelling

Nitroprusside is associated with {{c1::cyanide}} poisoning, which may present as

- {{c2::lactic acidosis}}
- {{c2::seizures}}
- altered mental status
After being absorbed from the GI tract, free cholesterol is packaged into a(n) {{c1::chylomicron}} as cholesterol ester
The main component of chylomicrons is {{c1::triglycerides}}
{{c1::Chylomicrons}} deliver triglycerides from the intestine to peripheral tissues
Triglycerides in chylomicrons are hydrolyzed by the enzyme {{c1::lipoprotein lipase (LPL)}}, releasing {{c2::free fatty acids}}
Free fatty acids can be converted back to {{c1::triglycerides}} and stored in adipose tissue
Once depleted of their triglycerides, chylomicron {{c1::remnants}} return to the {{c2::liver}}
The remnant receptor on the liver binds to {{c2::ApoE}} of the chylomicron remnant, causing subsequent endocytosis
Hepatocytes synthesize {{c2::cholesterol}} using the rate-limiting enzyme {{c1::HMG CoA reductase}}
The first intermediate in cholesterol synthesis is {{c1::mevalonate}} (from HMG CoA)
Cholesterol from the liver may be repackaged into the interior of {{c1::VLDLs}}
The main component of VLDL is {{c1::triglycerides}} (60%)
Apolipoprotein {{c1::B-100}} is found on the lipoproteins {{c2::LDL}}, {{c2::IDL}}, and {{c2::VLDL}}
{{c1::VLDLs}} deliver triglycerides directly from the liver to peripheral tissues
Depletion of triglycerides from VLDLs produces IDLs, which may undergo further removal of triglycerides via the enzyme {{c2::hepatic TG lipase}}, forming LDL
The main component of LDL is a core of {{c1::cholesterol esters}}
{{c1::LDLs}} are the main source of cholesterol delivery to peripheral tissues in the body
Nascent HDL is secreted by the {{c1::liver}} and {{c1::intestine}}
{{c1::Lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT)}} converts free cholesterol into cholesterol esters for transport by HDL
{{c1::Mature}} HDL particles contain LCAT-generated cholesterol esters
HDL transfers cholesterol esters to LDLs, IDLs, and VLDLs via {{c1::cholesterol ester transfer protein (CETP)}} to be transported back to the liver
{{c2::HDL}} delivers cholesterol esters directly to the liver via {{c1::scavenger receptor B-1}} receptors
{{c2::Statins (e.g. simvastatin, atorvastatin, rosuvastatin)}} exert their effects by inhibiting the enzyme {{c1::HMG CoA reductase}}, thus decreasing cholesterol production
Statins indirectly cause {{c1::increased}} LDL receptor expression on hepatocytes
{{c1::Statins}} significantly reduce {{c2::LDL}} levels (30-60% reductions)

What effect do statins have on triglyceride levels?

{{c1::Mild decrease}}

What effect do statins have on HDL levels?

{{c1::Mild increase}}
The first line treatment for hypercholesterolemia (LDL) is with lifestyle modification and {{c1::statins}}
{{c1::Statins}} are the most effective lipid lowering medications for preventing future cardiovascular events
{{c1::Statins}} are the only lipid-lowering drugs consistently proven to reduce risk of atherosclerotic heart disease
Statins reduce risk of future vascular events in patients with a history of TIA or {{c1::stroke}}
Statins may be {{c1::teratogenic}}, therefore avoid during the first trimester of pregnancy
The most common side effect of statins is {{c1::myopathy}}, which occurs weeks to months after starting therapy
Statins may cause mild {{c1::hepato}}-toxicity, and thus mild elevations in {{c1::liver}} function tests
All statins, except for {{c2::pravastatin}}, are metabolized by {{c1::cytochrome p450}}

What drug class do cholestyramine, colestipol, and colesevelam belong do?

{{c1::Bile acid resins}}
{{c1::Bile acid resins (e.g. cholestyramine)}} bind bile acids in the intestinal lumen, preventing absorption and recycling to the liver
Bile acid resins (e.g. cholestyramine) interrupt bile acid recycling and promote synthesis of new bile acids, depleting liver {{c1::cholesterol}} stores
Bile acid resins indirectly cause {{c1::increased}} LDL receptor expression

What effect do bile acid resins have on LDL levels?

{{c1::Moderately decreased}}
Bile acid resins are used in patients with primary {{c1::hypercholesterolemia}}, usually in conjunction with statins
Bile acid resins increase the cholesterol content of bile acids and thus may cause {{c1::cholesterol gallstones}}
Bile acid resins frequently cause GI side effects, such as {{c1::constipation}} and {{c2::bloating}}
Bile acid resins can lead to {{c1::steatorrhea}}, which may impair the absorption of {{c2::fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K)}}
{{c1::Ezetimibe}} is a lipid-lowering agent that blocks absorption of {{c2::cholesterol}} at the small intestinal brush border
Ezetimibe restricts the livers access to exogenous {{c1::cholesterol}}
Ezetimibe indirectly causes {{c1::increased}} LDL receptor expression

What effect does ezetimibe have on LDL levels?

{{c1::Moderately decreased}}

What GI side effect is associated with ezetimibe?

{{c1::Diarrhea/steatorrhea::2}}
Ezetimibe may cause increased {{c1::liver}} function tests
Evolocumab and alirocumab are lipid-lowering agents that inhibit {{c1::PCSK9::what enzyme?}}
{{c2::PCSK9}} is a protease produced by the liver that leads to degradation of {{c3::hepatocyte}} {{c1::LDL}} receptors
Evolocumab binds PCSK9 and {{c1::prevents}} degradation of hepatic LDL receptors

What drug class do gemfibrozil and fenofibrate belong to?

{{c1::Fibrates}}
{{c1::Fibrates}} upregulate the enzyme {{c2::lipoprotein lipase (LPL)}} by activating {{c3::PPAR-α}}
Fibrates significantly decrease serum {{c1::triglycerides}} by increasing {{c2::hydrolysis}} of VLDLs and chylomicrons

Fibrates lead to {{c1::mild decreases}} in serum LDL by reducing VLDL
Fibrates may cause {{c1::myopathy}} as an adverse effect, especially when combined with {{c2::statins}}

{{c1::Niacin (B3)}} is the most effective drug for increasing serum {{c2::HDL}}
{{c1::Fibrates}} are the most effective drugs for decreasing serum {{c2::triglycerides}}
Niacin (Vitamin B3) {{c1::mildly}} decreases serum triglycerides by decreasing hepatic {{c1::VLDL}} secretion
Niacin leads to {{c1::moderately decreased}} serum LDL by {{c2::reducing VLDL synthesis}}
A common adverse effect associated with niacin is cutaneous {{c1::flushing}} and {{c2::warmth}} due to increased {{c3::prostaglandin}} activity
Flushing and warmth, secondary to niacin use, may be prevented with {{c1::NSAIDs}}

What effect may niacin have on blood glucose levels?

{{c1::Increased (Hyperglycemia)}}
Niacin may cause {{c1::hyperuricemia}} as an adverse effect, which can precipitate {{c2::gout}}
{{c1::Fish oil}}, a supplement high in {{c2::omega-3 fatty}} acids, may be used to lower serum {{c3::triglyceride}} levels
