Nitrates primarily cause {{c1::venous}} dilation, causing decreased {{c1::pre}}-load
Nitrates may provide symptomatic relief of chronic, stable {{c1::angina}}
Nitrates {{c1::reduce}} myocardial oxygen requirements
{{c1::Sublingual}} administration of nitroglycerine avoids first pass metabolism, which is useful for immediate relief of angina
{{c1::Oral}} nitrate preparations have a longer duration of action than sublingual

What drug class do isosorbide mononitrate/dinitrate and nitroglycerin belong to?

{{c1::Nitrates}}
Oral nitrate preparations require {{c1::large}} dosing due to {{c2::first}} pass metabolism
Nitrates may be used to treat {{c1::Prinzmetal}} angina, which is characterized by vasospasm
Nitrates are useful in treatment of acute {{c1::coronary}} syndromes
Nitrates should be avoided in {{c1::right}}-sided myocardial infarction
IV nitroglycerine can be used in the treatment of hypertensive {{c1::emergency}}
Nitroglycerine may be used as an acute treatment for pulmonary {{c1::edema}}
Adverse effects associated with nitrates include {{c1::orthostatic hypotension}} and syncope due to pooling of blood in veins
Nitrate-induced hypotension may cause reflex {{c1::tachycardia}}
Nitrates are often combined with {{c1::β-blockers}} to help prevent reflex {{c2::sympathetic}} activation

What calcium channel blocker may be combined with nitrates, producing similar effects to β-blockers?

{{c1::Verapamil}}
Nitrates may cause throbbing {{c1::headaches}} and cutaneous {{c2::flushing}} as possible side effects

What hematological complication is associated with nitrates?

{{c1::Methemoglobinemia}}
Patients on nitrates have a nitrate-free interval everyday to prevent {{c1::tolerance}}
Industrial workers may develop "{{c3::Monday}} disease" due to excessive {{c4::nitrate}} exposure, which presents with {{c1::headache}}, {{c2::dizziness}}, and tachycardia
Patients on {{c1::PDE-5 inhibitors}} should avoid nitrate therapy for 24 hours
Nitrates are contraindicated in patients with {{c1::hypertrophic obstructive}} cardiomyopathy
Ranolazine is a drug used to treat {{c1::angina}} refractory to other medical therapies

What effect does ranolazine have on heart rate and blood pressure?

{{c1::No effect}}
Ranolazine inhibits the late phase of {{c1::Na+}} current, thereby reducing diastolic wall tension and O2 consumption
Ranolazine may cause {{c1::QT}} prolongation on ECG
Adverse effects of ranolazine include {{c1::dizziness}}, headache, and nausea

What GI side effect may be caused by ranolazine?

{{c1::Constipation}}

What is the effect of β-blockers alone on heart rate?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What is the effect of nitrates and β-blockers on heart rate?

{{c1::No effect or decreased}}

What is the effect of nitrates alone on ejection time?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What is the effect of β-blockers alone on ejection time?

{{c1::Increased}}

What is the effect of nitrates and β-blockers on ejection time?

{{c1::Little/no effect}}

What is the effect of nitrates alone on myocardial O2 consumption?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What is the effect of β-blockers alone on myocardial O2 consumption?

{{c1::Mildly decreased}}

What is the effect of nitrates and β-blockers on myocardial O2 consumption?

{{c1::Very decreased}}

Which aneurysm, true ventricular aneurysm or pseudo-aneurysm, is more likely to rupture?

{{c1::Pseudo-aneurysm}}
The alveolar walls are lined with epithelial cells called {{c1::type I}} and {{c1::type II pneumocytes}}
Type {{c1::II}} pneumocytes are responsible for synthesis of pulmonary {{c2::surfactant}}
Type {{c1::II}} pneumocytes have regenerative capacity for both type I and type II pneumocytes
The alveoli contain phagocytic cells called {{c1::alveolar macrophages (dust cells)}}, which clear debris and participate in the immune response
When a person is standing, pulmonary blood flow is highest at the {{c1::base (bottom)}} of the lungs
The volume that moves into the lung with each quiet inspiration is the {{c1::tidal volume}}

What is the typical normal value for tidal volume (mL)?

{{c1::500 mL}}
The additional volume that can be inspired above tidal volume is the {{c1::inspiratory reserve volume}}
The additional volume that can be expired below tidal volume is the {{c1::expiratory reserve volume}}
The volume that remains in the lungs after maximal forced expiration is the {{c1::residual volume}}

Which lung volume cannot be measured on spirometry?

{{c1::Residual volume}}
The sum of the tidal volume plus the inspiratory reserve volume is known as {{c1::inspiratory capacity}}
The sum of the residual volume plus the expiratory reserve volume is known as {{c1::functional residual capacity}}
The volume of gas remaining in the lungs after normal expiration is the {{c1::functional residual capacity}}
The sum of the tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, and expiratory reserve volume is known as the {{c1::vital capacity}}
The maximum volume of gas that can be expired after maximal inspiration is known as the {{c1::(forced) vital capacity}}
The sum of the tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume is known as the {{c1::total lung capacity}}
The volume of gas present in the lungs after a maximal inspiration is known as the {{c1::total lung capacity}}

Which lung capacities cannot be measured on spirometry?

{{c1::Functional residual capacity, Total lung capacity::2}}
Functional residual capacity may be measured using {{c1::helium dilution}} or {{c2::body plethysmograph}}

What is the typical normal value for anatomic dead space (mL)?

{{c1::150 mL}}
The volume of the {{c2::anatomic}} dead space plus the {{c2::alveolar}} dead space comprises the "{{c1::physiologic}} dead space"
The {{c1::apex}} of a healthy lung is the largest contributor of alveolar dead space
{{c1::Physiologic dead space}} is the total volume of the lungs that does not participate in gas exchange
In healthy lungs, the physiologic dead space is approximately equal to the {{c1::anatomic dead space}}
In certain pathologic situations, the physiologic dead space may become greater than the anatomic dead space, suggesting a(n) {{c1::ventilation/perfusion (V/Q)}} defect
Pathologic dead space is when part of the respiratory zone is {{c1::ventilated::perfused/ventilated}}, but not {{c1::perfused::perfused/ventilated}}

What equation may be used to determine the physiologic dead space (VD)?

{{c1::}}
{{c1::Minute}} ventilation is the total volume of gas that enters the lungs per unit time
{{c1::Alveolar}} ventilation is the volume of gas per unit time that reaches the alveoli (accounts for physiologic dead space)

What equation may be used to calculate minute ventilation?

Minute Ventilation (VE) = {{c1::VT * Respiratory Rate}}

What equation may be used to calculate alveolar ventilation?

Alveolar Ventilation (VA) = {{c1::(VT - VD) * Respiratory Rate}}

What is the normal range of respiratory rates for a healthy adult (breaths/min)?

{{c1::12-20 breaths/min}}
If CO2 production is constant, then the arterial and alveolar {{c2::Pco2}} is determined by {{c1::alveolar ventilation}}

What is the effect of increased alveolar ventilation on arteriolar (and alveolar) Pco2?

{{c1::Decreased Pco2}}

What is the effect of decreased alveolar ventilation on arteriolar (and alveolar) Pco2?

{{c1::Increased Pco2}}

The alveolar gas equation states that the alveolar Po2 (PAo2) equals:

{{c1::}}
When using the alveolar gas equation, the respiratory quotient (R) is equal to the ratio of {{c1::CO2 produced}} / {{c1::O2 consumed}}
In the steady state, the respiratory quotient, R, is normally equal to {{c1::0.8}}
The approximate Po2 in inspired, humidified air (PIO2) at sea level is {{c1::150}} mmHg
The gradient between PAo2 - Pao2 is known as the {{c1::A-a gradient}} and is normally {{c2::10}} - {{c2::15}} mmHg
The total volume of air that can be forcibly expired after a maximal inspiration is known as the {{c1::forced vital capacity (FVC)}}
The volume of air that can be forcibly expired after a maximal inspiration in one second is known as the {{c1::FEV1}}
The normal value for the ratio of FEV1/FVC is approximately {{c1::0.8}}
In {{c1::obstructive}} lung disease, the FEV1/FVC is {{c2::decreased}}
In {{c1::restrictive}} lung disease, the FEV1/FVC is {{c2::normal or increased}}
Lung {{c1::compliance}} describes the change in lung volume for a given change in lung pressure
The compliance of the lungs and chest wall is {{c1::inversely}} proportional to their elastance
The compliance of the lungs and chest wall is {{c1::inversely}} proportional to the wall stiffness
{{c1::Elastic recoil}} is the force generated due to the tendency for the lungs to collapse inward and the chest wall to spring outward
Elastic recoil is {{c1::inversely}} proportional to compliance and {{c1::directly}} proportional to elastance
A lung with {{c1::low}} compliance is harder to fill
The {{c1::slope}} of a respiratory system pressure-volume curve represents lung {{c2::compliance}}
The slope (compliance) of the pressure-volume loop curves for inspiration and expiration are different due to a phenomenon known as {{c1::hysteresis}}
Hysteresis occurs due to the need to overcome {{c1::surface tension}} forces during lung {{c2::inflation (inspiration)}}

Are the lungs generally more compliant during inspiration or expiration?

{{c1::Expiration (due to hysteresis)}}
The intermolecular forces between liquid molecules lining the lung are much {{c1::stronger}} than the forces between liquid and air
During initial inspiration, liquid molecules are {{c1::close}} together and intermolecular forces are {{c1::high}}
During expiration, the slope of the pressure-volume loop {{c1::increases}} as the density of surfactant molecules rapidly {{c1::increases}}
At FRC, the intrapleural space normally has a(n) {{c1::negative}} pressure relative to the atmosphere
At {{c3::functional residual capacity}}, the {{c1::inward}} pull of the {{c2::lung}} is balanced by the {{c1::outward}} pull of the {{c2::chest}}
If a sharp object punctures the intrapleural space ({{c2::pneumothorax}}), the intrapleural pressure becomes {{c1::equal to atmospheric pressure}}
The compliance of the lung-chest wall system is {{c1::less}} than that of the lungs or chest wall alone
At FRC, airway and alveolar pressures are equal to {{c1::0 (atmospheric pressure)}}
When lung volume is {{c2::less}} than FRC, there is a net {{c1::expanding}} force on the lung-chest wall system
When lung volume is {{c2::greater}} than FRC, there is a net {{c1::collapsing}} force on the lung-chest wall system
At highest lung volumes, both the lungs and the chest wall contribute to {{c1::collapsing}} forces on the lung-chest wall system

What is the effect of emphysema on lung compliance?

{{c1::Increased compliance}}
At the original FRC, the tendency of the lung to collapse in a patient with emphysema is {{c1::less}} than the tendency of the chest wall to expand

What is the effect of emphysema on functional residual capacity (FRC)?

{{c1::Increased FRC}}
A patient with {{c2::emphysema}} breathes at a higher lung volume and will thus have a(n) {{c1::barrel}}-shaped chest (increased anterior-posterior diameter)

What is the effect of normal aging on lung compliance?

{{c1::Increased compliance}}

What is the effect of pulmonary fibrosis on lung compliance?

{{c1::Decreased compliance}}
At the original FRC, the tendency of the lung to collapse in a patient with pulmonary fibrosis is {{c1::greater}} than the tendency of the chest wall to expand

What is the effect of pulmonary fibrosis on functional residual capacity (FRC)?

{{c1::Decreased FRC}}

What is the effect of pulmonary edema on lung compliance?

{{c1::Decreased compliance}}

What is the effect of pneumonia on lung compliance?

{{c1::Decreased compliance}}
The law of Laplace states that the collapsing pressure of an alveoli, P, is equal to {{c1::2T / r}}
According to the law of Laplace, a large alveolus will have a(n) {{c1::low}} collapsing pressure
According to the law of Laplace, a small alveolus will have a(n) {{c1::high}} collapsing pressure
{{c1::Surfactant}} is a mixture of phospholipids that line the alveoli and reduce their surface tension
Without surfactant, small alveoli are more likely to collapse, which is termed {{c1::atelectasis}}
Pulmonary surfactant is a mix of lecithins, the most important of which is {{c1::dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC)}}
In the developing fetus, surfactant synthesis begins as early as gestastional week {{c1::20}}
In the developing fetus, mature levels of surfactant are not achieved until around week {{c1::35}}
The major site of airway resistance is the {{c1::medium-sized bronchi}}
The {{c1::transpulmonary}} pressure across the lungs is calculated as {{c2::alveolar}} pressure minus {{c2::intrapleural}} pressure

How does the volume of breath change during inspiration?

{{c1::Increased}}

How does the intrapleural pressure change during inspiration (relative to atmosphere)?

{{c1::More negative relative to atmosphere}}

How does the alveolar pressure change during mid-inspiration (relative to atmosphere)?

{{c1::More negative relative to atmosphere}}
As the alveolar pressure becomes negative relative to the atmosphere (mid-inspiration), air flows {{c1::inwards}}

How does the volume of breath change during expiration?

{{c1::Decreased}}

How does the intrapleural pressure change during expiration (relative to atmosphere)?

{{c1::Less negative relative to atmosphere}}

How does the alveolar pressure change during mid-expiration (relative to atmosphere)?

{{c1::More positive relative to atmosphere}}
As the alveolar pressure becomes positive relative to the atmosphere (mid-expiration), air flows {{c1::outwards}}

In what normal scenario may intrapleural pressure be positive (relative to the atmosphere)?

{{c1::Forced expiration::specific}}
Transfer of gases across cell membranes or capillary walls occurs by {{c1::simple diffusion}}

According to Ficks law, the rate of diffusion of a gas (Vgas) is equal to:

{{c1::}}
The diffusion coefficient (DK) for CO2 is approximately 20x {{c1::higher}} than that of O2
The lung diffusing capacity (DL) is the equivalent of {{c1::permeability}} of the alveolar-pulmonary capillary barrier
The lung diffusing capacity (DL) can be measured with {{c1::carbon monoxide (CO)}} because it is exclusively diffusion-limited
DLCO may be used to estimate the extent to which {{c1::oxygen}} passes from the air sacs of lungs into blood
The lung diffusing capacity, DL, is {{c1::directly}} proportional to the surface area available for diffusion
The lung diffusing capacity, DL, is {{c1::directly}} proportional to the diffusion coefficient of the gas
The lung diffusing capacity, DL, is {{c1::inversely}} proportional to the alveolar wall thickness
The lung diffusing capacity, DL, {{c1::decreases}} in emphysema due to decreased {{c2::surface area (A)}}
The lung diffusing capacity, DL, {{c1::decreases}} in pulmonary fibrosis due to increased {{c2::wall thickness (Δx)}}
The lung diffusing capacity, DL, {{c1::increases}} during exercise due to increased {{c2::surface area (A)}}
The Po2 in dry inspired air is normally approximately {{c1::160}} mmHg
The Po2 in humidified tracheal air is normally approximately {{c1::150}} mmHg
The partial pressure of oxygen in the alveolar air (PAO2) and arterial blood (PaO2) is normally approximately {{c1::100}} mmHg
The partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the alveolar air (PACO2) and arterial blood (PaCO2) is normally approximately {{c1::40}} mmHg
The partial pressure of oxygen in the venous blood (PvO2) is normally approximately {{c1::40}} mmHg
The partial pressure of carbon dioxide in mixed venous blood (PvCO2) is normally approximately {{c1::46}} mmHg
The partial pressure of O2 in arteriolar blood is slightly {{c1::lower}} than alveolar air due to the "{{c2::physiologic shunt}}"
The two sources of the physiologic shunt are {{c1::bronchial}} blood flow and a small portion of {{c2::coronary}} venous blood (drains into the left ventricle via the thebesian vein)
The total gas concentration in solution is the sum of the {{c1::dissolved}} gas plus {{c2::bound}} gas plus {{c3::chemically}} modified gas
The {{c1::partial pressure}} gradient is the driving force for the diffusion of a gas
Only {{c1::free, dissolved}} gas contributes to the partial pressure of a gas in solution
In {{c1::diffusion}}-limited gas exchange, the gas does not equilibrate by the time blood reaches the end of the capillary
In {{c1::perfusion}}-limited gas exchange, the gas equilibrates early along the length of the capillary
In {{c2::perfusion}}-limited gas exchange, diffusion can be increased only if {{c1::blood flow}} increases
In normal health, O2 exhibits {{c1::perfusion}}-limited gas exchange
CO2 exhibits {{c1::perfusion}}-limited gas exchange
N2O exhibits {{c1::perfusion}}-limited gas exchange
CO exhibits {{c1::diffusion}}-limited gas exchange
When patients have diseased lung tissue (e.g. fibrosis/emphysema) O2 transfer becomes {{c1::diffusion}}-limited
At {{c1::high}} altitude the partial pressure gradient of O2 is {{c2::lower}} and thus equilibration takes {{c2::longer}}
O2 is carried in blood in two forms: {{c2::dissolved}} (2%) or {{c1::bound to hemoglobin}} (98%)
Hemoglobin is a globular protein consisting of {{c1::four}} subunits
Each subunit of hemoglobin contains a(n) {{c1::heme}} moiety, which is a(n) {{c2::iron}}-binding porphyrin, and a polypeptide chain
Iron in hemoglobin is normally in the {{c1::ferrous (Fe2+)}} state
If the iron in hemoglobin is in the {{c1::ferric (Fe3+)}} state, it is called {{c2::methemoglobin}}
Methemoglobin (Fe3+) binds O2 much {{c1::less::more/less}} readily than hemoglobin (Fe2+)
Methemoglobin has a(n) {{c1::increased}} affinity for {{c2::cyanide}} relative to hemoglobin
{{c1::Methemoglobinemia}} may present with {{c3::cyanosis}} and {{c2::chocolate}}-colored blood
Induced-{{c1::methemoglobinemia}} (i.e. {{c3::nitrites}} followed by {{c3::thiosulfate}}) may be used to treat {{c2::cyanide}} poisoning
Methemoglobinemia can be treated with {{c1::methylene blue}} or {{c2::vitamin C}}

What two drug classes are associated with methemoglobinemia?

{{c1::Nitrates (and nitrites) & Sulfa drugs}}
Polluted/high altitude H2O may contain {{c1::nitrites}}, which can cause methemoglobinemia
{{c1::Benzocaine}} is a local anesthetic that may cause methemoglobinemia in toxic doses
Methemoglobinemia is associated with {{c1::decreased}} SaO2, {{c1::decreased}} O2 content, and {{c1::normal}} PaO2
Most adult hemoglobin is composed of 2 {{c1::α}} and 2 {{c1::β}} subunits; known as {{c2::HbA}}
Fetal hemoglobin, known as {{c2::HbF}}, is composed of 2 {{c1::alpha}} and 2 {{c1::gamma}} subunits
Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) has a much {{c1::higher}} binding affinity for O2 than adult hemoglobin (HbA)

Why must fetal hemoglobin have a much higher O2 binding affinity than HbA?

{{c1::Drives O2 diffusion across placenta from mother to fetus}}
The increased O2 binding affinity of fetal hemoglobin results from {{c1::decreased}} affinity of HbF for {{c2::2,3-BPG}}
Hemoglobin exists in two forms: {{c1::taut}} (deoxygenated) and {{c1::relaxed}} (oxygenated)
The {{c2::taut}} form of hemoglobin has a(n) {{c1::low}} affinity for O2
The {{c2::relaxed}} form of hemoglobin has a(n) {{c1::high}} affinity for O2
The {{c1::taut}} form of hemoglobin is found in most tissues
The {{c1::relaxed}} form of hemoglobin is found in the respiratory tract
Normally 1g of hemoglobin can bind {{c1::1.34}} mL of O2
Normally there is ~{{c1::15}} g/dL of hemoglobin in blood
The O2-binding capacity of blood is {{c1::20.1}} mL O2/ 100 mL blood

What equation may be used to calculate the O2 content of blood?

O2 content = {{c1::(1.34 * Hb * SaO2) + (0.003 * PaO2)}}
Decreased hemoglobin (e.g. anemia) is associated with {{c1::normal}} SaO2, {{c1::decreased}} O2 content, and {{c1::normal}} PaO2

What equation may be used to calculate O2 delivery to tissues?

O2 delivery = {{c1::cardiac output * O2 content of blood}}
The {{c2::sigmoidal}} shape of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is due to {{c1::positive cooperativity}} (increased affinity for each sucessive O2 bound)
A(n) {{c2::hemo}}-globin molecule has the potential to bind {{c1::4}} O2 molecule(s)
A(n) {{c2::myo}}-globin molecule has the potential to bind {{c1::1}} O2 molecule(s)
The {{c1::P50}} of the oxygen-Hb dissociation curve is the Po2 at which hemoglobin is 50% saturated
The oxygen-Hb dissociation curve is roughly flat when the Po2 is between {{c1::60}} and {{c1::100}} mmHg

Does the oxygen-myoglobin dissociation curve have a sigmoidal shape? Why?

{{c1::No, myoglobin is monomeric (no positive cooperativity)}}
Shifts of the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the {{c1::right}} occur when there is {{c2::decreased}} affinity of hemoglobin for O2
Shifts of the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the {{c1::right}} cause {{c2::increased}} unloading of O2 at tissues
Increased pCO2 and resulting decrease of pH enhancing the release of O2 from hemoglobin is called the {{c1::Bohr}} effect
{{c1::Increases}} in Pco2 cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the {{c2::right}}
{{c1::Decreases}} in pH cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the {{c2::right}}
{{c1::Increases}} in temperature cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the {{c2::right}}
{{c1::Increases}} in 2,3-BPG cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the {{c2::right}}
2,3-BPG decreases the affinity of hemoglobin for O2 by binding to hemoglobin {{c2::β}} chains

How do levels of 2,3-BPG change at high altitudes?

{{c1::Increased}}
2,3-BPG increases under {{c1::hypoxic}} conditions (e.g. high altitude)
High altitudes indirectly cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the {{c2::right}}
Factors that shift the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the {{c1::right}} favor the {{c2::taut}} form of hemoglobin
Shifts of the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the {{c1::left}} occurs when there is {{c2::increased}} affinity of hemoglobin for O2
Shifts of the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the {{c1::left}} cause {{c2::decreased}} unloading of O2 at tissues
{{c1::Decreases}} in Pco2 cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the {{c2::left}}
{{c1::Increases}} in pH cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the {{c2::left}}
Decreases in temperature cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the {{c2::left}}
{{c1::Decreases}} in 2,3-BPG cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the {{c2::left}}
{{c1::Increases}} in hemoglobin F cause the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the {{c2::left}}
{{c1::Carboxyhemoglobin}} is a form of hemoglobin bound to {{c2::CO}} in place of O2
Carbon monoxide binds competitively to Hb and with 200-250x {{c1::greater}} affinity than O2
Carboxyhemoglobin causes the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve to shift to the {{c2::left}}
Carboxyhemoglobin heme groups not bound by CO have a(n) {{c1::increased}} affinity for O2
Carboxyhemoglobin causes {{c2::decreased}} unloading of O2 at tissues
Carboxyhemoglobin causes {{c1::decreased}} O2-binding capacity
Carboxyhemoglobinemia (CO poisoning) may be treated with {{c1::100% O2}} and {{c2::hyperbaric O2}}
Carboxyhemoglobinemia is associated with {{c1::decreased*}} SaO2, {{c1::decreased}} O2 content, and {{c1::normal}} PaO2

What is the hemoglobin concentration in carboxyhemoglobinemia?

{{c1::Normal}}
Anemia is associated with {{c1::normal}} SaO2, {{c1::decreased}} O2 content, and {{c1::normal}} PaO2

How does the hemoglobin concentration change in anemia?

{{c1::Decreased}}
{{c1::Erythropoietin (EPO)}} is a hormone synthesized in the kidneys in response to {{c2::hypoxia}}
Decreased O2 delivery to the kidneys due to hypoxia causes increased production of {{c1::hypoxia-inducible factor 1α}}, which then stimulates synthesis of EPO
Erythropoietin (EPO) causes differentiation of {{c1::proerythroblasts}}, which undergo further development to form mature erythrocytes
Hemoglobin may act as a(n) {{c2::buffer}} for {{c1::H+}} ions
One way in which CO2 is carried in the blood is as {{c1::dissolved}} CO2 (5%)
One way in which CO2 is carried in the blood is bound to hemoglobin, known as {{c1::carbaminohemoglobin (HbCO2)}} (5%)
The majority of CO2 transported in blood is in the form of {{c1::HCO3- (bicarbonate)}} (90%)
CO2 binding to hemoglobin favors the {{c1::taut}} form, thus {{c1::reducing}} Hb affinity for O2
CO2 binds to hemoglobin at the N-terminus of {{c1::globin}} (heme or globin)
{{c1::Decreased}} O2 binding to hemoglobin causes {{c2::increased}} affinity for CO2 and H+ (Haldane effect)
{{c1::Increased}} O2 binding to hemoglobin causes {{c2::decreased}} affinity for CO2 ({{c3::Haldane}} effect)
In {{c1::red blood}} cells (in plasma), {{c2::CO2}} is combined with {{c2::H2O}} via the enzyme {{c3::carbonic anhydrase}}, forming {{c4::H2CO3}}
H2CO3, formed from CO2 and H2O in red blood cells, dissociates into {{c1::H+}} and {{c1::HCO3-}}
The {{c2::H+}} in red blood cells (from H2CO3) is buffered by {{c1::deoxyhemoglobin}}
The {{c2::HCO3-}} in red blood cells (from H2CO3) is transported into the plasma in exchange for {{c1::Cl-}}
The HCO3- transported out of RBCs is carried to the lungs in the {{c1::plasma}} of venous blood
In the {{c2::lungs}}, oxygenation of hemoglobin promotes {{c1::H+}} release from its buffering sites
In the {{c1::lungs}}, {{c2::HCO3-}} enters the red blood cells in exchange for Cl-
In the {{c1::lungs}}, H2CO3 in the red blood cell is reconverted to CO2 and H2O and expired
The mnemonic FROM JANE describes the symptoms of {{c1::bacterial endocarditis}}

Which two vasculitides are associated with positive serum p-ANCA?

{{c1::Churg-Strauss syndrome and Microscopic polyangiitis}}
The Cl--HCO3- exchange that occurs across the RBC membrane is accomplished by an anion exchange protein called {{c1::band three protein}}
The pulmonary circulation is normally characterized as a(n) {{c1::low::high/low}} resistance, {{c1::high::high/low}} compliance system
A decrease in PAO2 causes a hypoxic {{c1::vasoconstriction}} that shunts blood away from poorly ventilated regions of the lung
Fetal pulmonary vascular resistance is very {{c1::high}} because of generalized hypoxic vaso-{{c1::constriction}}
Decreased Po2 (hypoxia) causes vaso-{{c1::constriction}} in the pulmonary circulation
Increased Pco2 (hypercapnia) causes vaso-{{c1::constriction}} in the pulmonary circulation
Decreased Po2 (hypoxia) causes vaso-{{c1::dilation}} in the systemic circulation
Increased Pco2 (hypercapnia) causes vaso-{{c1::dilation}} in the systemic circulation
In zone {{c2::1 (apex)}} of the lung, blood flow (Q) is {{c1::lowest}}
In zone {{c2::3 (base)}} of the lung, blood flow (Q) is {{c1::highest}}

Rank the following variables for zone 1 of the lung: PA, Pa, and Pv

{{c1::PA > Pa > Pv}}

Rank the following variables for zone 2 of the lung: PA, Pa, and Pv

{{c1::Pa > PA > Pv}}

Rank the following variables for zone 3 of the lung: PA, Pa, and Pv

{{c1::Pa > Pv > PA}}
In zone {{c1::1}} of the lung, high alveolar pressure may compress the capillaries and reduce blood flow in this zone
In zone 2 of the lung, blood flow is driven by the difference between {{c1::arteriolar}} and {{c1::alveolar}} pressure
In zone 3 of the lung, blood flow is driven by the difference between {{c1::arteriolar}} and {{c1::venous}} pressure
In {{c1::right}}-to-{{c1::left}} shunts, {{c2::hypoxemia}} always occurs because a significant fraction of the cardiac output is not delivered to the lungs
A defining characteristic of hypoxemia caused by a right-to-left shunt is that it {{c1::cannot}} be corrected with high O2 gas

Do left-to-right shunts result in hypoxemia?

{{c1::No}}
A consequence of pulmonary hypertension is right ventricular hypertrophy with eventual {{c1::cor pulmonale}}
The {{c1::ventilation/perfusion (V/Q)}} ratio is the ratio of alveolar ventilation to pulmonary blood flow
The normal average value for V/Q is {{c1::0.8}}
In zone {{c2::1 (apex)}} of the lung, alveolar ventilation (V) is {{c1::lowest}}
In zone {{c2::3 (base)}} of the lung, alveolar ventilation (V) is {{c1::highest}}
Both ventilation and perfusion are {{c1::greater}} at the base of the lung than at the apex of the lung
The V/Q ratio is {{c1::highest}} in zone {{c2::1 (apex)}} of the lung
The V/Q ratio is {{c1::lowest}} in zone {{c2::3 (base)}} of the lung
The V/Q ratio at the apex of the lung is normally {{c1::3}}, indicating wasted {{c2::ventilation}}
The V/Q ratio at the base of the lung is normally {{c1::0.6}}, indicating wasted {{c2::perfusion}}

What is the ideal V/Q ratio for adequate gas exchange?

{{c1::1 (ventilation matches perfusion)}}
If there is a(n) {{c1::blood flow}} obstruction, the V/Q ratio = {{c2::∞ (dead space)*}}
{{c1::Dead space}} is ventilation of lung regions that are not perfused (V/Q = ∞)
If there is a(n) {{c1::airway}} obstruction, the V/Q ratio = {{c2::0 (shunt)}}
{{c1::Shunt}} is perfusion of lung regions that are not ventilated (V/Q = 0)

What type of V/Q mismatch occurs due to pulmonary embolus?

{{c1::Dead space*}}

What type of V/Q mismatch occurs due to airway obstruction?

{{c1::Shunt (perfusion but no ventilation)}}

Does 100% O2 improve PaO2 in V/Q mismatch due to physiologic dead space?

{{c1::Yes, assuming < 100% dead space}}

Does 100% O2 improve PaO2 in V/Q mismatch due to shunt?

{{c1::No}}
Certain organisms that thrive in high O2 (e.g. TB) flourish in the {{c1::apex}} of the lung
With exercise (increased cardiac output), there is vasodilation of {{c2::apical}} capillaries in the lung, which causes the V/Q ratio to approach a value of {{c1::1}}
Breathing as an involuntary process is controlled by the {{c1::medulla}} and {{c2::pons}} of the brain stem
The {{c1::medullary}} respiratory center is located in the reticular formation and contains an inspiratory and expiratory center
The dorsal and ventral respiratory groups are located in the {{c1::medulla}} of the brain stem
The {{c1::dorsal}} respiratory group is primarily responsible for {{c2::inspiration}} and generates the basic rhythm for breathing
The dorsal respiratory group receives sensory input from peripheral chemoreceptors via the {{c1::glossopharyngeal (CN IX)}} and {{c1::vagus (CN X)}} nerves
The dorsal respiratory group receives sensory input from lung stretch receptors via the {{c1::vagus (CN X)}} nerve
The dorsal respiratory group sends its motor output to the diaphragm via the {{c1::phrenic}} nerve
The {{c1::ventral}} respiratory group is primarily responsible for {{c2::expiration}} and is not active during normal, quiet breathing
The {{c1::apneustic}} center is located in the lower pons and {{c2::stimulates}} inspiration
The {{c1::pneumotaxic}} center is located in the upper pons and {{c2::inhibits}} inspiration
Commands from the {{c1::cerebral cortex}} can temporarily override the automatic respiratory brain stem centers

Where are the central chemoreceptors located?

{{c1::Medulla}}
Central chemoreceptors are especially sensitive to the {{c1::pH}} of the {{c2::cerebrospinal fluid}}
In response to {{c2::decreased}} pH sensed by chemoreceptors, the breathing rate {{c1::increases (hyperventilation)}}
Central chemoreceptors respond indirectly to increased {{c1::Pco2}} and directly to decreased {{c1::pH}}

Where are the peripheral chemoreceptors located?

{{c1::Carotid bodies and aortic bodies::2}}
Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to decreases in {{c1::Pao2}} and {{c1::pH}}
Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to increases in {{c1::Pco2}}
Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to decreased Po2 when the arterial Po2 is less than {{c1::60}} mmHg
Increases in arterial H+ stimulate the {{c1::carotid}} body peripheral chemoreceptors only, independent of changes in Pco2
{{c1::Lung stretch}} receptors are mechanoreceptors located in the smooth muscle of the airways
Lung stretch receptors cause a(n) {{c1::decreased}} breathing frequency in response to distention of the lungs (Hering-Breuer reflex)
{{c1::Irritant}} receptors are located between the airway epithelial cells and are stimulated by noxious substances
{{c1::Joint}} and {{c1::muscle}} receptors are activated during movement of the limbs and stimulate early breathing during exercise
{{c1::Juxtacapillary (J)}} receptors are located in the alveolar walls and cause rapid, shallow breathing in response to pulmonary capillary engorgement (e.g. left heart failure)
In response to exercise, there is {{c1::increased}} CO2 production
In response to exercise, there is {{c1::increased}} O2 consumption
In response to exercise, there is {{c1::increased}} ventilation rate to meet O2 demand
In response to exercise, the V/Q ratio from apex to base becomes more {{c1::even}} (even or uneven)
In response to exercise, there is {{c1::increased}} pulmonary blood flow, due to increased {{c2::cardiac output}}
In response to strenuous exercise, there is {{c1::decreased}} pH, secondary to {{c1::lactic acidosis}}

How does Paco2 change in response to exercise?

{{c1::No change}}

How does Pao2 change in response to exercise?

{{c1::No change}}
In response to exercise, there is {{c1::increased}} venous CO2 content
In response to exercise, there is {{c1::decreased}} venous O2 content
In response to decreased atmospheric oxygen (e.g. high altitude), there is a(n) {{c1::decreased}} Pao2
In response to decreased Pao2 (e.g. high altitude), there is {{c1::increased}} ventilation
Increased ventilation (e.g. high altitude) causes {{c1::decreased}} Paco2
High altitude initially causes {{c3::respiratory}} {{c2::alkalosis}} and hypoxia, which may cause acute {{c1::altitude}} sickness
In response to high altitude, there is a chronic {{c1::increase}} in ventilation
The respiratory alkalosis that occurs as a result of ascent to high altitude may be treated with {{c1::carbonic anhydrase}} inhibitors
Living at high altitude chronically causes hypoxia which increases the synthesis of {{c1::erythropoietin}}, causing polycythemia
In response to high altitude, there is a(n) {{c1::increase}} in 2,3-BPG
In response to respiratory alkalosis (e.g. due to high altitude), there is increased renal excretion of {{c1::HCO3-}}
In response to high altitude, there is chronic hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction which results in pulmonary {{c2::hypertension}} and {{c1::RV}} hypertrophy
{{c1::Hypoxemia}} is defined as a decrease in {{c2::Pao2}}

Is the A - a gradient normal, increased, or decreased, in response to high altitude?

{{c1::Normal}}

Is the A - a gradient normal, increased, or decreased, in response to hypoventilation (e.g. opioid use, obesity hypoventilation syndrome)?

{{c1::Normal}}

Is the A - a gradient normal, increased, or decreased, in response to diffusion defects (e.g. fibrosis, pulmonary edema)?

{{c1::Increased}}

Is the A - a gradient normal, increased, or decreased, in response to V/Q mismatch?

{{c1::Increased}}

Is the A - a gradient normal, increased, or decreased, in response to right-to-left shunts?

{{c1::Increased}}

What cause of hypoxemia is not greatly helped by supplemental O2?

{{c1::Right-to-left shunt}}
{{c1::Hypoxia}} is defined as a decrease of {{c2::O2 delivery to tissues}}
Hypoxia may be caused by a(n) {{c1::decreased}} cardiac output
{{c1::Hypoxia}} may be caused by {{c1::hypoxemia::hypoxia or hypoxemia}}
Hypoxia may be caused by {{c1::anemia}}, due to decreased levels of hematocrit and Hb
Hypoxia may be caused by {{c1::carbon monoxide}} poisoning, which decreases the O2 content of blood
{{c1::Ischemia}} is a cause of O2 deprivation due to a loss of blood flow (e.g. impeded arterial flow, decreased venous drainage)

What clinical features are seen in 21β-hydroxylase deficiency that are a result of increased androgen levels in males?

{{c1::Precocious puberty}}
Allergic rhinitis is associated with other atopic disorders, such as {{c1::asthma}} and {{c2::eczema}}
Nasal polyps are associated with {{c1::aspirin-induced asthma}} in adults
{{c1::Aspirin-induced asthma}} is characterized by a triad of asthma, aspirin-induced bronchospasms, and nasal polyps
Acute epiglottitis may present with muffled voice and inspiratory {{c1::stridor}}
{{c1::Pneumonia}} is defined as an infection of the lung parenchyma
Pneumonia often occurs when normal defenses are {{c1::impaired}}
Viral pneumonia may damage the {{c1::mucociliary escalator}}, which consequently predisposes to superimposed bacterial pneumonia
Clinical features of pneumonia include productive cough with {{c1::yellow-green}} or {{c2::rusty}}-colored sputum (due to pus and blood, respectively)
Pneumonia may present with {{c1::decreased}} breath sounds and {{c2::dullness}} to percussion
Pneumonia may present as {{c1::tachypnea}} (respiratory rate) with {{c2::pleuritic}} chest pain
Diagnosis of pneumonia is made by {{c1::CXR}} and sputum & blood gram stain/culture
{{c1::Lobar}} pneumonia is characterized by consolidation of an entire lobe or lung
{{c2::Lobar}} pneumonia is characterized by neutrophils in the air sacs with a(n) {{c1::intra-alveolar::location}} exudate
{{c2::Lobar}} pneumonia is commonly caused by {{c1::Streptococcus pneumoniae}} (95%) and {{c3::Klebsiella pneumoniae}} (5%)
Initially, lobar pneumonia presents with {{c1::congestion}} on gross imaging due to congested vessels and proteinaceous edema in the alveolar airspaces
Following the congestion phase, lobar pneumonia presents grossly with {{c1::red hepatization}}, due to exudate, neutrophils, and hemorrhage filling the alveolar air spaces
Following red hepatization, lobar pneumonia presents grossly with {{c1::gray hepatization}}, due to degradation of red blood cells within exudate
The final phase of lobar pneumonia is {{c1::resolution}} with regeneration of tissue via type {{c2::II}} pneumocytes
{{c1::Streptococcus pneumoniae}} is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia
{{c1::Klebsiella pneumoniae::bug}} is a cause of pneumonia that most commonly affects the elderly, alcoholics, and diabetics (due to aspiration)
Pneumonia due to Klebsiella pneumoniae is caused by enteric flora that are {{c1::aspirated}}
{{c2::Klebsiella pneumoniae}} infection is characterized by a thick mucoid capsule that results in gelatinous, {{c1::currant jelly}} sputum
Klebsiella pneumoniae is often complicated by {{c1::abscess}} formation in the lungs and liver
{{c1::Bronchopneumonia}} is characterized by {{c2::scattered, patchy}} consolidation centered around {{c3::bronchioles}}
Bronchopneumonia is often multifocal and {{c1::bilateral::uni- or bilateral}}

What type of pneumonia is characterized by acute inflammatory infiltrates from bronchioles into adjacent alveoli?

{{c1::Bronchopneumonia}}

What type of pneumonia is typically caused by S. pneumoniae, S. aureus, H. influenzae, and Klebsiella?

{{c1::Bronchopneumonia}}

{{c1::Streptococcus pneumoniae}} is the most common cause of secondary pneumonia

2nd and 3rd are...
Pneumonia due to Staphylococcus aureus is often complicated by {{c1::abscess}} formation or {{c2::empyema}} (pus in the pleural space)
{{c1::Haemophilus influenzae}}, {{c2::Moraxella catarrhalis}}, and {{c3::Legionella}} are common causes of pneumonia superimposed on {{c4::COPD}}
{{c1::Legionella pneumophila}} is a cause of pneumonia that is transmitted from {{c2::water}} sources
{{c1::Legionella pneumophila}} is a cause of pneumonia in immunocompetent patients that is best visualized by {{c2::silver}} stain
{{c1::Interstitial (atypical)}} pneumonia is characterized by diffuse interstitial infiltrates
{{c1::Atypical}} pneumonia is characterized by diffuse, patchy inflammation that is localized to {{c2::interstitial}} areas at alveolar walls

How many lobes does interstitial (atypical) pneumonia typically involve?

{{c1::> 1}}
{{c1::Interstitial (atypical)}} pneumonia presents with relatively mild upper respiratory symptoms

What type of pneumonia is typically caused by Mycoplasma, Chlamydia, Legionella and viruses (RSV, CMV, influenza, adenovirus)?

{{c1::Interstitial (atypical) pneumonia}}
{{c1::Mycoplasma pneumoniae}} is the most common cause of atypical pneumonia in young adults

What demographic is commonly affected by Mycoplasma pneumoniae?

{{c1::Young adults, especially those living in close quarters}}
One complication of Mycoplasma pneumoniae is autoimmune {{c1::hemolytic anemia}} due to high concentrations of cold agglutinins (IgM)

What gram stain is Mycoplasma pneumoniae characterized by?

{{c1::No stain (lacks cell wall)}}
{{c2::Chlamydia pneumoniae}} is the second most common cause of {{c1::atypical}} pneumonia in young adults
{{c1::Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)}} is the most common cause of atypical pneumonia in infants
{{c1::Cytomegalovirus (CMV)}} is a common cause of atypical pneumonia in post-transplant patients on immunosuppressive therapy
{{c1::Influenza}} is a common viral cause of atypical pneumonia in the elderly

{{c1::Coxiella burnetii}} infection is a cause of atypical pneumonia with high fever (Q fever)
Lung {{c1::abscess}} is a localized collection of pus within the parenchyma
Lung abscess is often caused by {{c1::aspiration}} of oropharyngeal contents
Lung abscess commonly occurs in patients predisposed to {{c1::loss of consciousness}} (e.g. alcoholics, epileptics)
Lung abscess may occur in patients with {{c1::bronchial obstruction}} (e.g. cancer)
Lung abscesses are commonly due to {{c1::anaerobic}} bacteria such as {{c2::Bacteroides}}, {{c3::Fusobacterium}}, {{c4::Peptostreptococcus}}, and Prevotella
Lung abscesses may present with {{c1::air-fluid levels}} on CXR, which suggests {{c2::cavitation}}

What drug is commonly used to treat lung abscesses?

{{c1::Clindamycin}}
Lung abscess secondary to aspiration is most commonly found in the {{c1::right::left/right}} lung
Primary TB classically forms a(n) {{c1::Ghon complex}}, which is a calcified granulomatous lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy

What type of pneumonia may be caused by tuberculosis?

{{c1::Tuberculous bronchopneumonia}}

What stain is Mycobacterium tuberculosis characterized by?

{{c1::Acid fast}}

Which zone of the lung has the highest Pao2?

{{c1::Zone 1}}
In paradoxical splitting, the split sound is "paradoxically" eliminated with {{c1::inspiration}}
Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by obstruction of air flow resulting in air {{c1::trapping}} in lungs
{{c2::Obstructive}} lung diseases are characterized by a(n) {{c1::decreased}} FEV1/FVC ratio
Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by a(n) {{c1::increased}} total lung capacity
Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by a(n) {{c1::increased}} residual volume and functional residual capacity
{{c3::Chronic bronchitis}} is defined as a(n) {{c1::productive cough}} lasting > {{c2::3}} months per year for > {{c2::2}} years
Chronic bronchitis is highly associated with {{c1::smoking::risk factor}}
Chronic bronchitis is characterized by hypertrophy/hyperplasia of bronchial {{c1::mucinous}} glands
{{c3::Chronic bronchitis}} leads to an increased {{c1::Reid}} index, which is the thickness of {{c2::mucus glands}} relative to the {{c2::overall bronchial wall}} thickness
In chronic bronchitis, the Reid index is > {{c1::50}}% (normal is < {{c1::40}}%)
Chronic bronchitis is associated with {{c1::cyanosis}}, due to early-onset hypoxemia from shunting
Chronic bronchitis is associated with {{c1::(hypercapnia) CO2}} retention due to mucus plug trapping

What sounds may be heard on respiratory exam in a patient with chronic bronchitis?

{{c1::Wheezing, crackles::2}}
Chronic complications of chronic bronchitis include pulmonary hypertension with progression to {{c1::cor pulmonale}}
Chronic bronchitis patients have increased risk of acquiring {{c1::infection}}

What effect may chronic bronchitis secondarily have on RBC levels?

{{c1::Increased (polycythemia)}}
Chronic bronchitis is associated with {{c1::increased}} Paco2 and {{c1::decreased}} Pao2
Chronic bronchitis presents with {{c1::productive cough}} due to excessive mucus production and late-onset {{c2::dyspnea}}
Emphysema is characterized by {{c1::enlargement}} of air spaces
{{c3::Emphysema}} is characterized by the {{c1::destruction}} of {{c2::alveolar air sacs}}
Emphysema is characterized by loss of {{c1::elastic recoil}}, which inhibits the ability to exhale air from the alveoli (air trapping)
Emphysema is characterized by loss of elastic recoil, which may lead to airway {{c1::collapse}} during exhalation
Emphysema is due to an imbalance of {{c1::proteases}} (e.g. elastase) and {{c1::antiproteases}} (e.g. α1-antitrypsin)
Inflammation in the lung normally leads to release of {{c1::proteases}} by {{c2::neutrophils}} and {{c2::macrophages}}

Emphysema may be caused by excessive {{c1::inflammation/proteases::general}} or
lack of {{c2::α1-antitrypsin}}
The most common cause of emphysema is {{c1::smoking}}
{{c3::Smoking}} results in {{c1::centriacinar}} emphysema that is most severe in the {{c2::upper}} lobes of the lung
{{c3::α1-antitrypsin deficiency}} results in {{c1::panacinar}} emphysema that is most severe in the {{c2::lower}} lobes of the lung

What liver pathology is associated with α1-antitrypsin deficiency?

{{c1::Cirrhosis}}
Mutant α1-antitrypsin polymerizes and accumulates in the {{c1::endoplasmic reticulum}} of hepatocytes, resulting in liver damage (e.g. cirrhosis)
{{c3::α1-antitrypsin}} deficiency is characterized by {{c2::pink/purple}} colored, {{c1::PAS}}-positive globules in hepatocytes

What is the normal allele for α1-antitrypsin?

{{c1::PiM}}

What is the most clinically significant mutant allele for α1-antitrypsin?

{{c1::PiZ}}

What genotype is associated with an asymptomatic phenotype with decreased α1-antitrypsin?

{{c1::PiMZ heterozygotes}}
PiMZ heterozygotes (α1-antitrypsin) are at significant risk for emphysema if they {{c1::smoke}}

What genotype is associated with significant risk for panacinar emphysema and liver cirrhosis (α1-antitrypsin)?

{{c1::PiZZ homozygotes}}
Clinical features of emphysema include dyspnea and cough with {{c1::minimal::quantity}} sputum production
{{c3::Emphysema}} often presents with {{c1::prolonged}} expiration with {{c2::pursed}} lips
Emphysema may present with weight {{c1::loss}}
Emphysema is characterized by increased {{c1::AP}} diameter with a flattened {{c2::diaphragm}} on CXR
Emphysema may present with {{c1::increased}} lung field lucency on CXR
Chronic complications of emphysema include {{c1::hypoxemia}} (due to destruction of capillaries in the alveolar sac) with eventual cor pulmonale
{{c1::Asthma}} is defined as bronchial hyperresponsiveness with reversible airway bronchoconstriction
Asthma is most often due to {{c2::allergic stimuli}} (type {{c1::I}} HSR), but may also be triggered by viral URIs and stress
Asthma is often associated with {{c1::allergic rhinitis}}, {{c2::eczema}}, and a family history of {{c3::atopy}}
Asthma most commonly presents in {{c1::childhood::age group}}

In an asthmatic response, mast cells release preformed {{c1::histamine}} granules (early-phase reaction)
In an asthmatic response, mast cells lead to generation of leukotrienes {{c1::C4}}, {{c1::D4}}, and {{c1::E4}} (early-phase reaction)

Asthma classically presents with episodic cough, dyspnea, and {{c1::wheezing}} (lung sound)
Asthma may present with {{c1::tachypnea::respiratory rate}}

Which form of lung disease is associated with pulsus paradoxus?

{{c1::Obstructive::restrictive or obstructive?}}
Asthma may present with a(n) {{c1::decreased}} inspiratory/expiratory ratio
Asthma may cause excessive production of mucus with resultant mucus {{c1::plugging}}
Asthma may present with {{c1::peribronchial cuffing}} on CXR
Severe, unrelenting asthma attacks can result in {{c1::status asthmaticus}} and death
{{c1::Bronchiectasis}} is defined as the permanent dilatation of bronchioles and bronchi

Which obstructive lung disease may be caused by Kartagener syndrome?

{{c1::Bronchiectasis}}

Bronchiectasis is associated with {{c1::allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis}}, which is a hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus

Which obstructive lung disease may be caused by allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?

{{c1::Bronchiectasis}}

Bronchiectasis may present with dyspnea and cough with {{c1::hemoptysis}}

Which obstructive lung disease is associated with secondary (AA) amyloidosis?

{{c1::Bronchiectasis}}
{{c1::Restrictive}} lung diseases are characterized by a FEV1/FVC ratio {{c2::>}} 80%
Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by a(n) {{c1::decreased}} total lung capacity
Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by a(n) {{c1::decreased}} residual volume and functional residual capacity
Restrictive lung diseases are most commonly due to {{c1::interstitial}} diseases of the lung

What is the treatment for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis?

{{c1::Lung transplant}}
{{c1::Pneumoconioses}} are a subset of {{c3::restrictive}} lung diseases characterized by interstitial fibrosis due to {{c2::occupational}} exposure
Pneumoconioses requires chronic exposure to small particles that are {{c1::fibrogenic}}
Pneumoconioses are due to release of {{c2::fibrogenic}} factors from {{c1::alveolar macrophages}} that have engulfed foreign, fibrogenic particles
Coal workers pneumoconiosis results from prolonged {{c1::coal (carbon) dust}} exposure
{{c2::Coal workers pneumoconiosis}} is also known as "{{c1::black lung}} disease"

What pneumoconiosis has an increased risk for TB?

{{c1::Silicosis}}

Asbestosis is associated with increased risk for {{c2::lung carcinoma}} and {{c2::mesothelioma}} (cancers)

Which is more common in individuals exposed to asbestos: lung (bronchogenic) carcinoma or mesothelioma?

{{c1::Lung carcinoma}}
{{c1::Asbestosis}} presents with "Ivory white", calcified supradiaphragmatic and pleural plaques
Asbestosis lesions may contain {{c1::Asbestos (ferruginous)}} bodies, which are golden-brown fusiform rods resembling dumbbells

Asbestos bodies contain {{c1::iron}} and thus may be visualized using a(n) {{c1::Prussian blue}} stain
Asbestosis most commonly affects the {{c1::lower}} lobes of the lung
{{c1::Caplan}} syndrome is a combination of {{c2::rheumatoid arthritis}} and {{c2::pneumoconiosis}} with intrapulmonary nodules
Sarcoidosis is a systemic disease characterized by widespread {{c1::noncaseating}} granulomas

What demographic is associated with sarcoidosis?

{{c1::African American females}}
Sarcoidosis is likely due to CD{{c1::4}}+ T-cell response to an unknown antigen
Granulomas due to sarcoidosis often have characteristic {{c1::stellate}}-shaped inclusions ({{c2::asteroid}} bodies) within giant cells
Granulomas due to sarcoidosis may have {{c1::Schaumann}} bodies, which are calcium and protein inclusions inside of giant cells

What eye pathology is associated with sarcoidosis?

{{c1::Uveitis}}

What skin pathologies are associated with sarcoidosis?

{{c1::Cutaneous nodules}}, {{c2::Erythema nodosum}}, {{c3::Lupus Pernio}}
Sarcoidosis is associated with {{c1::lupus pernio}}, which are skin lesions on the face resembling lupus
Sarcoidosis may involve the salivary and lacrimal glands, which mimics {{c1::Sjögrens}} syndrome

Sarcoidosis is associated with {{c1::hypercalcemia}} due to increased {{c2::1α-hydroxylase}} activity in epithelioid histiocytes
Sarcoidosis is associated with elevated serum levels of the enzyme {{c1::angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE)::lung}}

What is the treatment for sarcoidosis?

{{c1::Steroids (if symptomatic)}}

What are the most common presenting symptoms of pulmonary sarcoidosis?

{{c1::Dyspnea, Cough::2}}
Sarcoidosis is associated with {{c1::elevated}} CD{{c2::4}}+/CD{{c2::8}}+ ratio in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid
Sarcoidosis is often asymptomatic except for enlarged {{c1::lymph nodes}}
Sarcoidosis may be visualized on CXR as {{c1::bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy}} and coarse reticular opacities
{{c1::Hypersensitivity pneumonitis}} is an autoimmune reaction that generates {{c2::granulomas}} in response to inhaled organic antigens (e.g. pigeon breeders lung)
Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a mixed type {{c1::III}}/{{c1::IV}} hypersensitivity reaction
Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is often seen in {{c1::farmers}} and those exposed to {{c2::birds}}

Which dyslipidemia drug is associated with hyperglycemia and hyperuricemia as possible adverse effects?

{{c1::Niacin}}
{{c2::Verapamil::Drug}} is a Ca2+ channel blocker that may cause hyper-{{c1::prolactinemia}} as an adverse effect
The normal mean pulmonary artery pressure is between {{c1::10}} and {{c1::14}} mmHg
Pulmonary hypertension is defined as a mean pulmonary artery pressure > {{c1::25}} at rest
Pulmonary hypertension is characterized by {{c1::atherosclerosis}} of the pulmonary trunk
Pulmonary hypertension is characterized by {{c1::smooth muscle (medial)}} {{c2::hypertrophy}} of pulmonary arteries
{{c1::Plexiform}} lesions are small, vascular channels that may be seen with severe, long standing pulmonary {{c2::hypertension}}
Pulmonary hypertension leads to RV {{c1::hypertrophy}} with eventual {{c2::cor pulmonale}}
Pulmonary hypertension may present with exertional {{c1::dyspnea}} and {{c2::right}}-sided heart failure

What demographic is classically associated with primary pulmonary hypertension?

{{c1::Young adult females}}
Heritable {{c3::pulmonary hypertension}} can be due to {{c1::inactivating}} mutations of the {{c2::BMPR2}} gene
The BMPR2 gene normally inhibits {{c1::vascular smooth muscle}} proliferation

What is the prognosis of heritable pulmonary hypertension?

{{c1::Poor prognosis}}
The cause of primary pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is often {{c1::idiopathic}}

Secondary pulmonary hypertension due to Lung Disease may arise due to {{c1::damage / inflammation}} of lung parenchyma (e.g. COPD / Interstitial lung disease) or {{c2::hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction}} (e.g. obstructive sleep apnea, high altitude)
Secondary pulmonary hypertension due to Heart Disease may arise due to increased {{c1::volume}} in the pulmonary circuit (e.g. left heart failure, congenital heart disease)
Secondary pulmonary hypertension due to Chronic {{c1::Thromboemboli}} may arise with recurrent pulmonary {{c1::embolism}} or {{c2::microthrombi}}
Another type of secondary pulmonary hypertension may arise due to {{c1::multifactorial}} causes, such as hematologic, systemic, and metabolic disorders
Acute {{c2::(aka Adult) respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)}} is caused by diffuse alveolar damage with impairment of the {{c1::alveolar-capillary}} interface
Damage to the alveolar-capillary interface leads to {{c1::increased}} alveolar-capillary permeability
In ARDS, leakage of protein-rich fluid leads to noncardiogenic pulmonary {{c1::edema}} (normal PCWP)
In ARDS, leakage of protein-rich fluid leads to formation of intra-alveolar {{c1::hyaline}} membranes
Clinical features of ARDS include hypoxemia and cyanosis with respiratory distress due to a(n) {{c1::thickened}} diffusion barrier
Clinical features of ARDS include hypoxemia and cyanosis with respiratory distress due to {{c1::collapse}} of air sacs
Acute respiratory distress syndrome presents with a "{{c1::white-out}}" appearance on CXR
{{c1::Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)}} is a clinical syndrome characterized by acute onset respiratory failure with bilateral lung opacities and no evidence of HF/fluid overload

ARDS is a diagnosis of exclusion with the following criteria (ARDS)

- Abnormal chest x-ray
- Respiratory failure within {{c1::1 week}} of insult
- Decreased {{c2::Pao2 / FIO2}} ratio
- Symptoms of respiratory failure are not due to HF/fluid overload

The causes of {{c8::acute respiratory distress}} syndrome may be remembered with "SPARTAS"

S: {{c1::Sepsis}}
P: {{c2::Pancreatitis}}, {{c2::Pneumonia}}
A: {{c3::Aspiration}}
R: {{c4::uRemia}}
T: {{c5::Trauma}}
A: {{c6::Amniotic fluid embolism}}
S: {{c7::Shock}}
In ARDS, activation of {{c2::neutrophils}} by proinflammatory cytokines induces {{c3::free radical}} and {{c3::protease}}-mediated damage of {{c1::both type I and II}} pneumocytes
Treatment of ARDS includes addressing the {{c1::underlying cause}}
Treatment of ARDS includes mechanical ventilation with {{c2::positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)}} and most importantly {{c1::low}} tidal volumes
Recovery of ARDS may be complicated by {{c1::interstitial fibrosis/scarring}} due to loss of type II pneumocytes
{{c2::Neonatal respiratory distress}} syndrome is respiratory distress due to inadequate {{c1::surfactant}} levels
Surfactant decreases {{c2::surface tension}} in the lung, preventing {{c1::collapse}} of alveolar air sacs after expiration
Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is associated with {{c1::premature}} birth
The {{c1::lecithin}}:{{c2::sphingomyelin}} ratio in amniotic fluid is used to screen for {{c3::lung}} maturity
As surfactant production is increased (fetal lung maturation), {{c1::lecithin}} levels {{c2::increase}}, while {{c1::sphingomyelin}} levels {{c2::remain constant}}

What lecithin:sphingomyelin ratio is indicative of adequate surfactant production?

{{c1::> 2}}

What lecithin:sphingomyelin ratio is predictive of NRDS?

{{c1::< 1.5}}
Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is associated with {{c1::C-section delivery}} due to decreased stress-induced release of fetal {{c2::glucocorticoids}}
Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is associated with {{c1::maternal diabetes}} due to increased levels of fetal {{c2::insulin}}

What is the effect of increased fetal insulin on surfactant production?

{{c1::Decreased surfactant production}}
NRDS presents with {{c1::increased}} respiratory effort after birth
NRDS may present with {{c1::tachypnea}} (respiratory rate) with use of accessory muscles and grunting
Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is associated with diffuse granularity of the lung with a "{{c1::ground-glass}}" appearance on CXR
NRDS increases risk for persistence of a(n) {{c1::patent ductus arteriosus}} due to persistently {{c2::low}} O2 tension (hypoxemia)

What GI pathology is associated with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome due to hypoxemia?

{{c1::Necrotizing enterocolitis}}
In patients with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, {{c2::supplemental O2}} therapy increases the risk for {{c1::free radical}} injury
{{c1::Retinopathy of prematurity}} is an eye complication associated with {{c2::supplemental O2}} therapy in NRDS patients (due to neovascularization)
{{c1::Bronchopulmonary dysplasia}} is a respiratory complication associated with {{c2::supplemental O2}} therapy in NRDS patients

What treatment may be used to treat neonatal respiratory distress syndrome before birth?

{{c1::Maternal steroids}}

What treatment may be used to treat neonatal respiratory distress syndrome after birth?

{{c1::Artificial surfactant for the infant}}
One test for fetal lung maturity is the {{c2::surfactant}}:{{c1::albumin}} ratio in the amniotic fluid
{{c1::Lung}} cancer is the most common cause of cancer mortality in the U.S.
The average age of presentation for lung cancer is {{c1::60}} years old
The key risk factors for lung cancer are {{c1::cigarette smoke}}, {{c2::radon::not arsenic}}, and {{c3::asbestos}}; family history is also a risk factor
{{c1::Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons::main}} and {{c2::arsenic}} are particularly mutagenic carcinogens found in cigarette smoke
Lung cancer risk is directly related to the duration and the amount of smoking, which is measured in {{c1::pack-years}}
{{c1::Radon}} is formed by radioactive decay of uranium, which is present in soil
Radon accumulates in closed spaces, such as {{c1::basements}}
{{c1::Radon}} is responsible for most of the public exposure to ionizing radiation
{{c1::Radon}} exposure is the 2nd most frequent cause of lung carcinoma in the U.S.
Increased risk of lung cancer is seen in {{c1::uranium}} miners, due to increased exposure to radon
Presenting symptoms of lung cancer are non-specific and include cough, hemoptysis, weight {{c2::loss}}, and post-obstructive {{c1::pneumonia}}
Lung cancer often presents on CXR with a "{{c1::coin}}-lesion" or on CT with a non-calcified nodule
One benign cause of a coin-lesion on CXR is {{c1::granuloma}} (e.g.TB or fungus)
One benign cause of a coin-lesion on CXR is {{c1::bronchial hamartoma}}, which is benign tumor of {{c2::lung tissue}} and {{c2::cartilage}}
Lung carcinoma is classically divided into two categories: {{c1::small cell carcinoma}} (15%) and {{c1::non-small cell carcinoma}} (85%)
{{c1::Small}} cell carcinoma of the lung is usually not amenable to surgical resection and is thus treated with {{c2::chemotherapy +/- radiation}}
{{c1::Non-small}} cell carcinomas of the lung usually do not respond well to chemotherapy and are thus treated upfront with {{c2::surgical resection}}
{{c1::Small (oat) cell}} lung carcinoma arises from {{c2::neuroendocrine (Kulchitsky)::general (specific name)}} cells, which are small, dark blue cells

What demographic is associated with small (oat) cell carcinoma?

{{c1::Male smokers}}
Small (oat) cell carcinoma is {{c1::centrally}} located
Small cell carcinoma is characterized histologically by {{c1::poorly}} differentiated small cells and is thus {{c1::very}} aggressive
{{c2::Small (oat) cell}} lung carcinoma may produce the anterior pituitary hormone {{c1::ACTH}} leading to {{c1::Cushing syndrome}}
{{c2::Small (oat) cell}} lung carcinoma may produce the posterior pituitary hormone {{c1::ADH}} leading to {{c1::SIADH}}
{{c3::Small (oat) cell}} lung carcinoma may produce antibodies against {{c1::presynaptic Ca2+ channels}}, causing {{c2::Lambert-Eaton myasthenic}} syndrome
{{c3::Small (oat) cell}} lung carcinoma may produce {{c2::antibodies}} against {{c1::neurons}}, which may cause paraneoplastic myelitis, encephalitis, and subacute cerebellar degeneration
Small (oat) cell carcinoma is commonly associated with amplification of the {{c1::myc}} oncogene
{{c3::Small (oat) cell}} carcinoma of the lung is characterized by positive staining for {{c1::chromogranin A}}, {{c2::neuron-specific enolase}}, {{c4::synaptophysin}}, and {{c5::NCAM}} (CD56)
Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is {{c1::centrally}} located
{{c3::Squamous cell}} carcinoma of the lung is characterized histologically by {{c2::keratin pearls}} and {{c1::intercellular bridges}}
{{c1::Squamous cell}} carcinoma of the lung is the most common tumor in {{c2::male smokers}}
{{c2::Squamous cell}} carcinoma of the lung may produce {{c1::PTHrP}} leading to hyper-{{c1::calcemia}}
Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung commonly presents as a hilar mass arising from the {{c1::bronchus}}
Adenocarcinoma of the lung is {{c1::peripherally}} located
{{c3::Adenocarcinoma}} of the lung is characterized histologically by a(n) {{c1::glandular}} pattern that often stains positive for {{c2::mucin}}
{{c1::Adenocarcinoma}} of the lung is the most common cancer in nonsmokers and female smokers
{{c2::Adenocarcinoma}} of the lung is associated with {{c1::hypertrophic osteoarthropathy}} (clubbing)
{{c4::Adenocarcinoma}} of the lung is associated with {{c5::activating}} mutations in the {{c1::KRAS}}, {{c2::EGFR}}, and {{c3::ALK}} genes
Large cell carcinoma is characterized histologically by {{c1::poorly}} differentiated large cells
Large cell carcinoma of the lung may present histologically with pleomorphic {{c1::giant}} cells
{{c2::Large cell}} carcinoma of the lung may secrete the hormone {{c1::β-hCG}}

Is large cell carcinoma related to smoking?

{{c1::Yes}}
Large cell carcinoma of the lung is {{c1::peripherally}} located

What is the prognosis of large cell carcinoma?

{{c1::Poor}}
{{c2::Adenocarcinoma in situ}} is characterized histologically by {{c1::columnar::shape}} cells containing mucus that grow along pre-existing bronchioles and alveoli
{{c2::Adenocarcinoma in situ}} is a subtype of adenocarcinoma that typically arises from {{c1::club (Clara)}} cells

Is bronchioloalveolar carcinoma related to smoking?

{{c1::No}}
In regards to lung neoplasias; adenocarcinoma in situ is {{c1::peripherally}} located
{{c2::Adenocarcinoma in situ}} of the lung presents similarly to {{c1::pneumonia}} on CXR (hazy infiltrates, consolidation)

What is the prognosis of bronchioloalveolar carcinoma?

{{c1::Excellent}}
Bronchial {{c3::carcinoid}} tumor is characterized histologically by nests of {{c1::well}} differentiated {{c2::neuroendocrine}} cells
Bronchial carcinoid tumor is characterized by positive staining for {{c1::chromogranin A}}

Is bronchial carcinoid tumor related to smoking?

{{c1::No}}

What is the prognosis of bronchial carcinoid tumor?

{{c1::Excellent (low-grade malignancy; rarely metastasizes)}}
Bronchial carcinoid tumor classically forms a polyp-like mass in the {{c1::bronchus}}
Symptoms of bronchial carcinoid tumor are related to {{c2::mass effect}} or {{c1::carcinoid syndrome}}

What does the T of TNM staging for lung cancer represent?

{{c1::Tumor size and local extension}}

What does the N of TNM staging for lung cancer represent?

{{c1::Spread to regional lymph nodes (hilar and mediastinal)}}

What does the M of TNM staging for lung cancer represent?

{{c1::Metastasis}}
The {{c1::adrenal gland}} is a unique site of distant metastasis from lung cancer
Lung cancer has a(n) {{c1::low}} 5-year survival rate because the disease often presents {{c1::late}} in its course

Which is more common, primary lung tumors or metastasis to the lung?

{{c1::Metastasis}}
Metastasis to the lung usually presents as multiple {{c1::cannon ball}} nodules on imaging

Does metastasis to the lung typically present as single or multiple lesions?

{{c1::Multiple}}
Metastasis to the lung is most often from {{c1::breast}}, {{c2::colon}}, prostate, and bladder cancer
Common sites of metastasis from lung cancer include the {{c1::adrenal gland}}, {{c2::brain}}, {{c3::bone}}, and {{c4::liver}}
Lung cancer is the most common cause of metastasis to the {{c1::brain}}
One complication associated with lung cancer is {{c1::pleural effusion}}, which is classically seen with {{c2::adenocarcinoma}}
{{c1::Superior sulcus}} tumor ({{c3::pancoast}} tumor) is any kind of lung carcinoma that occurs in the {{c2::apex}} of the lung
Pancoast tumors may cause {{c1::Pancoast}} syndrome, which is characterized by shoulder pain, Horner syndrome, atrophy of hand/arm muscles, and edema (due to vascular compression)
One complication associated with lung cancer is {{c1::hoarseness}} due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve
One complication associated with lung cancer is {{c1::diaphragmatic paralysis}} due to compression of the phrenic nerve
One complication associated with lung cancer is {{c1::superior vena cava}} syndrome due to compression of the SVC
One complication associated with lung cancer is {{c1::Horner}} syndrome due to compression of the {{c2::superior cervical}} or {{c3::stellate}} ganglia
{{c2::Horner}} syndrome is a triad of ipsilateral {{c1::ptosis}}, {{c1::miosis}}, and {{c1::anhidrosis}}
SVC syndrome is characterized by impaired drainage of the upper extremities, resulting in {{c1::edema}} and dilated collateral veins in the {{c2::upper torso}}
SVC syndrome is characterized by impaired drainage of the head, resulting in "facial {{c1::plethora}}"
SVC syndrome is characterized by impaired drainage of the neck, resulting in {{c1::jugular venous distention}}
SVC syndrome can be caused by {{c1::thromboemboli}} from indwelling central venous catheters
SVC syndrome can raise {{c1::intracranial}} pressure (if obstruction is severe), leading to headaches and dizziness
{{c1::Pneumothorax}} is defined as the accumulation of air in the pleural space
Pneumothorax presents with {{c1::unilateral::uni- or bilateral}} chest pain and expansion, as well as dyspnea
Pneumothorax presents with {{c1::decreased}} tactile fremitus on the affected side
Pneumothorax presents with {{c1::hyper}}-resonance on the affected side
Pneumothorax presents with {{c1::diminished}} breath sounds on the affected side
{{c1::Primary spontaneous}} pneumothorax is due to rupture of apical subpleural blebs or cysts

What demographic is associated with primary spontaneous pneumothorax?

{{c1::Tall, thin, young males}}
{{c1::Secondary spontaneous}} pneumothorax may be due to diseased lung (e.g. bullae in emphysema, infections) or {{c2::meconium}} aspiration
In {{c2::tension}} pneumothorax, the trachea +/- mediastinum shifts {{c1::away from}} the side of collapse
{{c1::Tension}} pneumothorax arises when air enters the pleural space but cannot exit
Tension pneumothorax needs immediate needle decompression and {{c1::chest tube}} placement
{{c1::Mesothelioma}} is a malignancy of the lung {{c2::pleura}} that is highly associated with {{c3::asbestosis}}
Mesothelioma presents with recurrent {{c1::pleural effusions}}, dyspnea, and chest pain
Mesothelioma may result in {{c1::hemorrhagic}} pleural effusion (exudative) and pleural thickening

What histological finding may be associated with mesothelioma?

{{c1::Psammoma bodies}}
Almost all {{c2::mesotheliomas}} are {{c1::calretinin}} positive, which is negative in most carcinomas

Is smoking a risk factor for mesothelioma?

{{c1::No}}
{{c1::Adenocarcinoma}} is the most common type of primary lung carcinoma (40%)
Aldosterone increases {{c1::K+}} and {{c1::H+}} secretion at the distal tubules and collecting duct
Primary hemostasis is mediated by interactions between {{c1::platelets}} and the {{c2::vessel wall}}
Secondary hemostasis is mediated by the {{c1::coagulation cascade}}

The first step of primary hemostasis is {{c1::transient vasoconstriction}} of the damaged vessel; which is mediated by {{c2::reflex neural}} stimulation and {{c3::endothelin-1}} release from endothelial cells

Aggregation is a balance between pro and anti-aggregation factors:

Pro-aggregation - {{c2::TXA2}} - released by platelets

Anti-aggregation - {{c1::PGI2}} and {{c1::NO}} - released by endothelial cells
Following transient vasoconstriction (primary hemostasis), there is platelet {{c1::adhesion}} to the surface of the disrupted vessel
When a blood vessel is injured, {{c1::von Willebrand factor (vWF)}} binds exposed {{c2::subendothelial collagen}}
In order to adhere to the damaged endothelium, platelets bind {{c1::vWF}} using the {{c2::GPIb}} receptor
One source of von Willebrand factor (vWF) is from the {{c1::Weibel-Palade bodies}} of {{c2::endothelial cells}}
One source of von Willebrand factor (vWF) is from the {{c1::α}} granules of {{c2::platelets}}
Following platelet adhesion (primary hemostasis), there is platelet {{c1::degranulation::not aggregation}}
Binding of ADP to the P2Y12 receptor in primary hemostasis causes {{c1::shape}} change by upregulating intracellular {{c2::Ca2+}}, promoting effective platelet plug formation
Binding of ADP to the P2Y12 receptor promotes optimal exposure of the {{c1::GPIIb/IIIa}} receptor on platelets
Binding of ADP to the P2Y12 receptor leads to {{c2::decreased}} {{c1::cAMP}} formation which favors platelet activation

What ion is released from dense granules of platelets during degranulation?

{{c1::Ca2+}}
Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is synthesized by the platelet enzyme {{c1::cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1)::specific}}
Thromboxane A2 promotes platelet {{c1::aggregation}}
Following upregulation of GpIIb/IIIa, platelets aggregate at the site of injury via crosslinking of GpIIb/IIIa receptors with {{c1::fibrinogen}} to make a temporary platelet plug
Binding between GPIIb/IIIa and fibrinogen results in formation of a(n) {{c1::weak platelet plug}}
Disorders of primary hemostasis present with symptoms of mucosal and skin {{c1::bleeding}}
Disorders of primary hemostasis present with symptoms of mucosal bleeding, such as {{c1::epistaxis}} (most common overall symptom)
Quantitative disorders of primary hemostasis present with symptoms of skin bleeding, such as {{c1::petechiae}} (1-2 mm)
Petechiae are a sign of thrombocytopenia and are not usually seen with {{c1::qualitative}} platelet disorders
Bleeding time is normally between {{c1::2}} and {{c1::7}} minutes
{{c2::Bleeding time}} is {{c1::prolonged}} in all platelet disorders (both quantitative and qualitative)
{{c1::Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)}} is due to autoimmune production of Ig{{c2::G}} against {{c3::GPIIb/IIIa}}
The autoantibodies in ITP are produced by plasma cells in the {{c1::spleen}}
The antibody-bound platelets in ITP are consumed by {{c1::splenic macrophages}}, resulting in thrombocytopenia

What demographic is associated with the chronic form of immune thrombocytopenic purpura?

{{c1::Women of childbearing age}}
Immune thrombocytopenic purpura presents with {{c1::increased}} bleeding time / PFA
The initial treatment for immune thrombocytopenic purpura is {{c1::corticosteroids}}
The treatment for refractory cases of ITP is {{c1::splenectomy}}
{{c1::Microangiopathic hemolytic}} anemia occurs when RBCs are "sheared" as they cross {{c2::microthrombi}}
Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is often associated with formation of platelet {{c1::microthrombi}} in small vessels
Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is seen in {{c1::TTP}}, {{c2::HUS}}, and {{c3::HELLP}} syndrome

What type of red blood cell is associated with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia?

{{c1::Schistocytes ("helmet cells")}}
{{c2::Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)}} is due to inhibition or deficiency of the {{c1::ADAMTS13 (vWF metalloprotease)}} enzyme
In TTP, large, uncleaved vWF multimers lead to increased platelet {{c1::adhesion}} with consequent {{c2::microthrombi}} formation
Decreased ADAMTS13 (e.g. TTP) is usually due to an acquired {{c1::autoantibody}}

The pentad of classical symptoms seen in {{c6::thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)}} may be remembered using the mnemonic FAT RN:

F: {{c1::Fever (1/5 patients)}}
A*: {{c2::Anemia (Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anemia)}}
T*: {{c3::Thrombocytopenia}}

R: {{c4::Renal symptoms (1/2 of patients)-More common in HUS}}
N: {{c5::Neurologic symptoms (2/3 of patients)-More common in TTP}}

What is the treatment (3) for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)?

{{c1::plasmapheresis}}, {{c2::corticosteroids}}, {{c3::rituximab}}
{{c1::Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)}} is characterized by thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and {{c2::acute renal failure}}
{{c2::Hemolytic uremic}} syndrome is classically seen in {{c3::children}} with {{c1::E. coli O157:H7}} dysentery, which results from exposure to undercooked beef
TTP and HUS present with {{c1::increased}} bleeding time
TTP and HUS present with {{c1::decreased}} platelet count
TTP and HUS typically present with {{c1::normal}} PT and {{c1::normal}} PTT
The initial treatment for hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is {{c1::plasmapheresis}}
{{c2::Bernard-Soulier}} syndrome is a qualitative platelet disorder due to a genetic {{c1::GPIb}} deficiency
{{c2::Bernard-Soulier}} syndrome is characterized by {{c1::enlarged platelets}} on blood smear
In Bernard-Soulier syndrome there is a defect in platelet {{c1::adhesion}}
{{c2::Glanzmann thrombasthenia}} is a qualitative platelet disorder due to a genetic {{c1::GPIIb/IIIa}} deficiency
In Glanzmann thrombasthenia there is a defect in platelet {{c1::aggregation}}
Glanzmann thrombasthenia is characterized by no {{c1::platelet}} clumping on blood smear
Bernard-Soulier syndrome presents with {{c1::increased}} bleeding time
Bernard-Soulier syndrome presents with {{c1::normal}} or {{c1::decreased}} platelet count
Glanzmann thrombasthenia presents with {{c1::increased}} bleeding time
Glanzmann thrombasthenia presents with {{c1::normal}} platelet count
Aspirin irreversibly inactivates the enzyme {{c1::cyclooxygenase}}, thus decreasing synthesis of {{c2::TXA2}} and impairing platelet {{c3::aggregation}}

The coagulation cascade generates {{c1::thrombin (factor IIa)}}, which converts fibrinogen in the platelet plug to {{c2::fibrin (factor Ia)}}

*BnB expansion: which 4 factors does this activate (positive feedback)?
After fibrin is formed from fibrinogen, it is {{c1::cross-linked}} by factor {{c2::XIII}} yielding a stable platelet-fibrin thrombus
Factors of the coagulation cascade are produced by the {{c1::liver}} in an inactive state
Activation of the coagulation cascade requires the {{c1::phospholipid}} surface of platelets
Activation of the coagulation cascade requires {{c1::Ca2+}} ions derived from platelet {{c2::dense}} granules
Disorders of secondary hemostasis typically present with {{c1::deep tissue::location}} bleeding
{{c1::Prothrombin time (PT)}} measures the {{c2::extrinsic}} and common pathways of the coagulation cascade
{{c1::Partial thromboplastin time (PTT)}} measures the {{c2::intrinsic}} and common pathways of the coagulation cascade
International normalized ratio (INR) is calculated from {{c1::PT::PT or PTT}}

Which coagulation factor(s) are part of the extrinsic coagulation cascade?

{{c1::Factor VII}}

Which coagulation factor(s) are part of the intrinsic coagulation cascade?

{{c1::Factor 8, 9, 11, 12}}

Which coagulation factor(s) are part of the common coagulation cascade?

{{c1::Factor 10, 5, 2 (thrombin), 1 (fibrinogen)}}
Factor XI of the coagulation cascade is activated by factor {{c1::XIIa}}
Factor IX of the coagulation cascade is activated by factor {{c1::XIa}}
Factor X of the coagulation cascade may be activated by factor {{c1::VIIa}} (extrinsic pathway)
Factor V of the coagulation cascade is activated by factor {{c1::IIa}}
Factor II (prothrombin) is activated to thrombin by factor {{c1::Xa}}
{{c1::Tissue thromboplastin}} activates factor {{c2::VII}}, which initiates the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade
{{c1::Subendothelial collagen}} activates factor {{c2::XII}}, which initiates the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade
Hemophilia {{c1::A}} is a coagulation disorder due to a genetic factor {{c2::VIII}} deficiency

What is the mode of inheritance of hemophilia A?

{{c1::X-linked recessive}}
Hemophilia A can arise from a(n) {{c1::new (de novo)}} mutation without any family history (20%)

Which coagulation disorder presents with recurrent hemarthroses, spontaneous / easy bruising, and bleeding after surgery?

{{c1::Hemophilia (A, B, C)}}
Hemophilia {{c1::B (Christmas disease)}} is a coagulation disorder due to a genetic factor {{c2::IX}} deficiency

What is the mode of inheritance of hemophilia B?

{{c1::X-linked recessive}}
Hemophilia {{c1::C}} is a coagulation disorder due to a genetic factor {{c2::XI}} deficiency

{{c1::Omalizumab}} is used in allergic asthma with increased IgE levels and resistance to inhaled steroids and long-acting β2 agonists
Cromolyn sodium is an asthma therapeutic that inhibits {{c1::mast cell degranulation}}

What is the treatment for an acute, severe asthma exacerbation?

{{c1::Short-acting β2 agonist +/- systemic corticosteroids OR Epinephrine}}
In acute, severe asthma exacerbation, corticosteroids are administered {{c1::IV}} or {{c1::orally}}
Nebulized {{c1::ipratropium}} is a muscarinic antagonist that may be used to treat acute, severe asthma exacerbation
Ipratropium is a competitive {{c1::M3}} receptor antagonist that is used to prevent {{c2::bronchoconstriction}} in asthmatic and COPD patients
In addition to asthma, ipratropium may also be used to treat {{c1::COPD}}
Tiotropium is a(n) {{c2::long}}-acting {{c1::M3}} antagonist

What catecholamine may be administered to treat acute, severe asthma exacerbation?

{{c1::Epinephrine}}
Methacoline is a(n) {{c1::M3}} receptor agonist used in the bronchial challenge to help diagnose asthma
Theophylline causes broncho-{{c1::dilation}}
Muscarinic antagonists cause broncho-{{c1::dilation}}

What classes of drugs are used to treat asthma by blocking inflammation (late response)?

{{c1::Inhaled corticosteroids}}, {{c2::anti-leukotrienes}}, and anti-IL-5 monoclonal antibodies

What classes of drugs are used to treat asthma by blocking
bronchoconstriction (early response)?

{{c1::β2 agonists}}, {{c2::theophylline (methylxanthines)}}, {{c3::muscarinic antagonists}}
