{{c1::N-acetylcysteine}} is a(n) {{c2::mucolytic}} agent that liquifies mucus by disrupting {{c4::disulfide}} bonds; useful in {{c3::Chronic Bronchitis / COPD}} and {{c3::Cystic Fibrosis}} patients
Pseudoephedrine and phenylephrine are {{c2::α-adrenergic}} {{c3::agonists}} that may be used as {{c1::nasal decongestants}}

Pseudoephedrine and phenylephrine may be used clinically to reduce
- {{c1::hyperemia}}
- {{c2::edema}}
- {{c3::nasal congestion}}

What adverse effect may pseudoephedrine and phenylephrine have on blood pressure?

{{c1::Increased BP (Hypertension)}}
Dextromethorphan may cause {{c1::serotonin syndrome}} if combined with other serotonergic agents
{{c4::Bosentan}} is a competitive {{c1::endothelin-1 receptor}} {{c2::antagonist}} used to treat {{c3::pulmonary hypertension}}
Sildenafil inhibits {{c1::PDE-5}} and prolongs the vasodilatory effect of {{c2::nitric oxide}}
In addition to erectile dysfunction, sildenafil may also be used to treat {{c1::pulmonary hypertension}}
Epoprostenol and iloprost may be used to treat pulmonary {{c1::hypertension}}

What is the mode of inheritance of cystic fibrosis?

{{c1::Autosomal recessive}}
{{c3::Cystic fibrosis}} is due to a defect in the {{c1::CFTR}} gene on chromosome {{c2::7}}
Cystic fibrosis most commonly occurs due to a(n) {{c2::in-frame}} deletion of {{c1::Phe508}}

What is the most common lethal, genetic disease in Caucasians?

{{c1::Cystic fibrosis}}
The CFTR gene encodes a(n) {{c2::ATP}}-gated Cl- channel
The CFTR Cl- channel {{c1::secretes::secretes or absorbs}} Cl- in the {{c2::lungs}} and {{c2::GI tract}}
The CFTR Cl- channel {{c1::reabsorbs::secretes or absorbs}} Cl- in the {{c2::sweat glands}}
The most common CFTR gene mutation (cystic fibrosis) results in a misfolded protein that is retained in the {{c1::RER}}
In cystic fibrosis, there is {{c1::decreased}} Cl- and H2O secretion in the lungs and GI tract
In cystic fibrosis, increased intracellular Cl- results in compensatory increased Na+ {{c1::reabsorption}} via epithelial Na+ channels
Increased Na+ reabsorption due to decreased Cl- secretion (cystic fibrosis) results in increased {{c1::H2O}} reabsorption
Increased H2O reabsorption in CF results in abnormally {{c1::thick}} mucus secreted into the {{c2::lungs}} and {{c3::GI tract}}
Increased Na+ reabsorption in cystic fibrosis causes a more {{c1::negative}} transepithelial potential difference (TEPD)
Increased {{c2::Cl-}} concentration (> {{c1::60}} meQ/L) in {{c3::sweat}} is diagnostic of cystic fibrosis
Cystic fibrosis may present with {{c1::contraction::volume}} {{c2::alkalosis::pH}}

How does cystic fibrosis affect K+ levels?

{{c1::Decreased (hypokalemia)}}

What newborn screening blood test is used to screen for cystic fibrosis?

{{c1::Immunoreactive trypsinogen}}
A(n) {{c1::increased}} immunoreactive trypsinogen may be indicative of {{c2::cystic fibrosis}}

What organism is responsible for recurrent pulmonary infections in an infant cystic fibrosis patient?

{{c1::Staphylococcus aureus}}

What organism is responsible for recurrent pulmonary infections in an adolescent cystic fibrosis patient?

{{c1::Pseudomonas aeruginosa}}
Chronic bronchitis and bronchiectasis in a cystic fibrosis patient leads to a(n) {{c1::reticulonodular}} pattern on CXR
Cystic fibrosis may cause {{c1::pancreatic}} insufficiency, resulting in malabsorption
Cystic fibrosis may cause malabsorption with {{c1::steatorrhea::bowel condition}} and consequent {{c1::fat-soluble}} vitamin deficiencies
Cystic fibrosis may cause {{c1::biliary}} cirrhosis and/or {{c2::liver}} disease
Cystic fibrosis may present as {{c1::meconium ileus (10-20% of patients)}} in newborns due to abnormally thick ("inspissated") stool
Cystic fibrosis may cause {{c1::infertility}} in men due to congenital bilateral absence of the {{c2::vas deferens}}

Is spermatogenesis possible in a patient with cystic fibrosis?

{{c1::Yes}}
Cystic fibrosis may cause {{c1::subfertility}} in women due to abnormally thick {{c2::cervical mucus}} and amenorrhea
Cystic fibrosis may present with {{c1::nasal}} polyps and nail {{c2::clubbing}}
Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes replacement of {{c1::pancreatic}} enzymes
Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes {{c1::azithromycin}}, which is used as an anti-inflammatory agent
Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes {{c1::hyper}}-tonic saline, which facilitates mucus clearing
Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes aerosolized {{c1::dornase alfa (DNase)}}, which hydrolyzes DNA in mucus causing decreased viscosity
Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes {{c1::albuterol}}, a β2 agonist
Treatment of cystic fibrosis includes chest {{c1::physiotherapy}}, which aids in mucus clearance
The site of synthesis, storage, and release of renin is the {{c1::juxtaglomerular apparatus}} of the kidney
Renin is responsible for the conversion of {{c1::angiotensinogen}} to {{c1::angiotensin I}}
ACE is primarily located in the vascular endothelium of the {{c1::lungs}}
Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II by {{c1::ACE}} in the lungs (primarily)
Angiotensin II is a potent vaso-{{c1::constrictor}}

What effect do normal levels of angiotensin II have on GFR?

{{c1::Increased GFR}}
Angiotensin II normally constricts the {{c2::efferent}} arteriole of the kidney
Angiotensin II acts directly at the {{c1::PCT::location}} to {{c2::increase}} NaHCO3 reabsorption
Angiotensin II increases {{c1::aldosterone}} release from the adrenal cortex

What effect does angiotensin II indirectly have on serum potassium levels?

{{c1::Decreased K+ (via aldosterone)}}

What drug class do captopril, enalapril, lisinopril, and ramipril belong to?

{{c1::ACE inhibitors}}

What effect do ACE inhibitors have on levels of angiotensin II?

{{c1::Decreased AT II}}

What effect do ACE inhibitors and ARBs have on GFR?

{{c1::Decreased GFR}}
ACE inhibitors and ARBs primarily cause {{c1::dilation}} of the {{c2::efferent}} arteriole of the kidney
ACE inhibitors and ARBs {{c1::decrease}} sodium and bicarbonate reabsorption at the {{c2::proximal convoluted tubule}}
ACE inhibitors and ARBs {{c1::decrease}} aldosterone release from the adrenal cortex
ACE inhibitors can cause a(n) {{c1::elevation}} in creatinine levels within the first few days of starting treatment
ACE inhibitors can cause significant {{c1::hypotension}} which can lead to {{c1::syncope}} in patients with high {{c2::renin}} levels (e.g. heart failure, diuretic use)

What effect do ACE inhibitors have on levels of angiotensin I and renin?

{{c1::Increased levels}}

What effect may ACE inhibitors have on potassium levels?

{{c1::Increased (hyperkalemia)}}
ACE inhibitors are first line agents in the treatment of heart {{c1::failure}}

Do ACE inhibitors reduce mortality in patients with heart failure and MI?

{{c1::Yes}}
{{c2::ACE}} inhibitors decrease heart {{c1::remodeling}} induced by high levels of angiotensin II (e.g. chronic hypertension)
ACE inhibitors are a first line agent in the treatment of primary {{c1::hypertension}}
{{c2::ACE}} inhibitors slow the progression of diabetic {{c1::nephropathy}}
In diabetics, {{c2::ACE}} inhibitors decrease intraglomerular pressure, thus slowing {{c1::glomerular basement membrane}} thickening
After checking a patient on urinalysis, patients with {{c1::proteinuria}} should be started on a(n) {{c2::ACE}} inhibitor, especially if they have concommitant BP > 130/80
{{c2::ACE}} inhibitors may cause a(n) {{c1::dry cough}} due to lung irritation, secondary to increased {{c3::bradykinin}}

What effect do ACE inhibitors have on bradykinin activity?

{{c1::Increased}}

What effect do ARBs have on bradykinin activity?

{{c1::No effect}}
{{c3::ACE}} inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with {{c1::hereditary angioedema}}, which is characterized by a(n) {{c2::C1 esterase inhibitor}} deficiency
ACE inhibitors may cause angioedema due to increased {{c1::bradykinin}}
ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during {{c1::pregnancy}} due to possible {{c1::teratogenic}} effects
Coadministration of ACE inhibitors with {{c1::NSAIDs}} can precipitate acute {{c2::kidney}} injury
NSAIDs decrease prostaglandins, which normally {{c1::dilate}} the {{c2::afferent}} arterioles of the kidney

What effect may NSAIDs have on GFR?

{{c1::Decreased GFR}}
ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in bilateral {{c1::renal artery stenosis}}
ACE inhibitors may precipitate {{c1::acute renal failure}} in bilateral {{c2::renal}} artery stenosis, causing significantly increased serum creatinine

What drug class do losartan, candesartan, and valsartan belong to?

{{c1::Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs)}}
ARBs are used to treat hypertension, proteinuria, HF, or diabetic nephropathy in patients intolerant to {{c1::ACE inhibitors}}
ARBs selectively block binding of angiotensin II to the {{c1::AT1}} receptor

What effect may ARBs have on potassium levels?

{{c1::Increased (hyperkalemia)}}
ARBs are contraindicated during {{c1::pregnancy}} due to possible {{c1::teratogenic}} effects

What effect may ARBs have on blood pressure?

{{c1::Decreased (hypotension)}}
{{c2::Aliskiren}} is a direct {{c1::renin}} inhibitor

What effect may aliskiren have on potassium levels?

{{c1::Increased (hyperkalemia)}}

What effect may aliskiren have on blood pressure?

{{c1::Decreased (hypotension)}}

What effect does aliskiren have on GFR?

{{c1::Decreased GFR}}
Aliskiren is relatively contraindicated in patients already taking {{c1::ACE inhibitors}} or {{c1::ARBs}}

What is the primary clinical use for aliskiren?

{{c1::Treatment of hypertension}}
The kidneys lie in the {{c1::retroperitoneal}} cavity of the body
The outer region of the kidney is the {{c1::cortex}}
The central region of the kidney is the {{c1::medulla}}
The innermost tip of the kidney medullary pyramid is called the {{c1::papilla}}
The medullary pyramids (papillae) of the kidney empty into {{c1::major}} and {{c1::minor calyces}}
The major and minor calyces of the kidney drain into the {{c1::renal pelvis}}, which is the dilated proximal part of the {{c2::ureter}}
Following Bowmans capsule, glomerular filtrate enters the {{c1::proximal convoluted tubule}}
Following the proximal straight tubule, glomerular filtrate enters the {{c1::thin descending limb (loop of Henle)}}
Following the thin descending limb, glomerular filtrate enters the {{c1::thin ascending limb (loop of Henle)}}
Following the thin ascending limb, the glomerular filtrate enters the {{c1::thick ascending limb (loop of Henle)}}
The thin descending limb, thin ascending limb, and thick ascending limb of the kidney form the {{c1::loop of Henle}}
Following the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle), glomerular filtrate enters the {{c1::distal convoluted tubule}}
At the beginning of the distal convoluted tubule, glomerular filtrate passes the {{c1::macula densa}}
Following the distal convoluted tubule, glomerular filtrate enters the {{c2::collecting ducts}}
Blood enters the kidney via a(n) {{c1::renal}} artery, which branches into {{c2::segmental}} arteries
Segmental arteries of the kidney further branch into {{c1::interlobar}} arteries
Interlobar arteries of the kidney further branch into {{c1::arcuate}} arteries
Arcuate arteries of the kidney further branch into {{c1::interlobular}} arteries
The interlobular arteries of the kidney divide into the {{c1::afferent arterioles}}
Blood enters the glomerular capillaries via the {{c1::afferent}} arterioles
Blood exits the glomerular capillaries via the {{c1::efferent}} arterioles
Blood from the efferent arterioles is delivered to the {{c1::peritubular}} capillaries

Which kidney is taken during donor transplantation? Why?

{{c1::Left; has a longer renal vein}}
On average, total body water (TBW) is {{c1::60}}% of body weight
Extracellular fluid is divided into {{c1::interstitial fluid}} ({{c2::75}}% of ECF) and {{c1::plasma}} ({{c2::25}}% of ECF)
In addition to ICF and ECF, a small {{c1::transcellular}} fluid compartment consists of cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, and digestive fluids
Intracellular fluid comprises {{c1::two-thirds}} of total body water
The major cations of {{c3::intracellular}} fluid are {{c1::K+}} and {{c2::Mg2+}}
Extracellular fluid comprises {{c1::one-third}} of total body water
Plasma constitutes {{c1::55}}% of blood volume, while RBCs constitute the remaining {{c1::45}}%
The percent of blood volume occupied by RBCs is called the {{c1::hematocrit}}, which averages {{c2::45}}%
{{c2::Plasma}} volume can be measured by using {{c1::radiolabeled albumin}} or Evans blue
{{c2::Extracellular}} fluid volume can be measured using {{c1::inulin}} or mannitol
The volume of a body fluid compartment depends on the amount of {{c1::solute}} it contains
{{c1::Osmolarity}} is the concentration of osmotically active particles, expressed in mOsm/L
Plasma osmolarity may be estimated by Posm = {{c1::(2 * Na+) + (Glucose/18) + (BUN/2.8)}}
In the steady state, intracellular osmolarity is {{c1::equal to}} extracellular osmolarity (less than, greater than, or equal to)
Solutes such as NaCl and mannitol do not cross cell membranes and are thus confined to the {{c1::extracellular}} fluid compartment
Volume {{c2::contraction}} refers to a decrease in {{c1::ECF}} volume
Volume {{c2::expansion}} refers to an increase in {{c1::ECF}} volume

How does ECF volume change with diarrhea?

{{c1::Decreased}}

How does ICF volume change with hyposmotic volume contraction (e.g. adrenal insufficiency)?

{{c1::Increased}}

How does osmolarity change with adrenal insufficiency?

{{c1::Decreased (loss of Na+ due to lack of aldosterone)}}
Adrenal insufficiency is a cause of {{c1::hypo}}-osmotic volume contraction

How does plasma protein concentration change with hyposmotic volume contraction (e.g. adrenal insufficiency)?

{{c1::Increased}}

How does hematocrit change with hyposmotic volume contraction (e.g. adrenal insufficiency)?

{{c1::Increased}}

How does ECF volume change with excessive NaCl intake?

{{c1::Increased}}

How does ICF volume change with excessive NaCl intake?

{{c1::Decreased}}

How does osmolarity change with excessive NaCl intake?

{{c1::Increased}}
Excessive NaCl intake is a cause of {{c1::hyper}}-osmotic volume {{c2::expansion}}

How does ECF volume change with SIADH?

{{c1::Increased}}

How does ICF volume change with hyposmotic volume expansion (e.g. SIADH)?

{{c1::Increased}}

How does osmolarity change with SIADH?

{{c1::Decreased (hyposmolarity)}}
SIADH is a cause of {{c1::hypo}}-osmotic volume expansion

How does plasma protein concentration change with hyposmotic volume expansion (e.g. SIADH)?

{{c1::Decreased}}

How does hematocrit change with hyposmotic volume expansion (e.g. SIADH)?

{{c1::No change}}
Normal serum osmolality is ~ {{c1::290}} mOsm/kg H2O

What type of adrenergic receptor is found on the renal afferent and efferent arterioles?

{{c1::α1-adrenergic receptors}}
In both the afferent and efferent arterioles of the kidney, angiotensin II activity causes vaso-{{c1::constriction}}

Which arterioles of the kidney (afferent or efferent) are more sensitive to angiotensin II?

{{c1::Efferent arterioles}}
{{c2::Low (normal)}} levels of angiotensin II primarily causes vasoconstriction of the renal {{c1::efferent}} arterioles

What effect does angiotensin II activity have on renal blood flow?

{{c1::Decreased RBF}}

What effect does normal levels of angiotensin II have on GFR?

{{c1::Increased GFR}}

What effect do high levels of angiotensin II have on GFR?

{{c1::Decreased GFR}}
Atrial natriuretic peptide causes vaso-{{c2::dilation}} of {{c1::afferent}} arterioles and, to a lesser extent, vaso-{{c2::constriction}} of {{c1::efferent}} arterioles
Prostaglandins {{c2::E2}} and {{c2::I2}} cause vaso-{{c1::dilation}} of both afferent and efferent arterioles in the kidney

What drug class inhibits synthesis of prostaglandins and thus interferes with the protective effect of PGs on renal function?

{{c1::NSAIDs}}
At {{c1::low}} levels, dopamine causes vaso-{{c2::dilation}} of renal arterioles and interlobular arteries
Renal blood flow (RBF) remains relatively constant between blood pressure ranges of {{c1::80}} to {{c1::200}} mmHg
Renal autoregulation is primarily controlled by changing {{c2::vascular resistance}} of the {{c1::afferent}} arteriole
The {{c3::myogenic}} mechanism of renal autoregulation states that renal afferent arterioles {{c2::contract}} in response to increased {{c1::stretch}} on the arterial wall
The {{c2::tubuloglomerular feedback}} mechanism of renal autoregulation states that renal afferent arterioles contract in response to vasoactive substances released by the {{c1::macula densa}}
{{c2::Para-aminohippuric acid (PAH)}} clearance can be used to calculate {{c1::effective renal plasma flow (eRPF)}} because it is both filtered and secreted
Effective RPF (eRPF) {{c1::under}}-estimates true renal plasma flow slightly (~10%)

Effective renal plasma flow may be estimated using the equation:

eRPF = C{{c1::PAH}} = {{c1::[U]PAH * V / [P]PAH}}

Renal blood flow (RBF) is calculated using the equation:

RBF = {{c1::RPF / (1 - Hct)}}
The fraction of blood volume occupied by plasma = {{c1::1 - hematocrit}}
The glomerular filtration barrier is responsible for filtering the plasma according to the properties of a compounds {{c1::size}} and {{c1::net charge}}
One component of the glomerular filtration barrier is a(n) {{c2::endothelial}} cell layer with large {{c1::fenestrations}}
One component of the glomerular filtration barrier is a(n) {{c1::basement}} membrane
One component of the glomerular filtration barrier is a layer of {{c3::epithelial}} cells, called {{c1::podocytes}}, which attach to the basement membrane by {{c2::foot processes}}

Does the basement membrane of the glomerular filtration barrier normally permit plasma proteins?

{{c1::No}}
The {{c3::basement membrane}} of the glomerular filtration barrier contains {{c1::heparan sulfate}}, which acts as a(n) {{c2::negative}} charge barrier
In {{c2::nephrotic}} syndrome, the {{c1::charge}} barrier of the glomerular filtration barrier is lost
Loss of the charge barrier of the glomerular filtration barrier (e.g. nephrotic syndrome) results in {{c1::protein}}-uria

What does PGC represent in regards to GFR (fluid exchange)?

{{c1::Glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure}}

What does PBS represent in regards to GFR (fluid exchange)?

{{c1::Bowmans space hydrostatic pressure}}

What does πGC represent in regards to GFR (fluid exchange)?

{{c1::Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure}}

What effect does afferent arteriolar constriction have on RPF?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What effect does afferent arteriolar constriction have on GFR?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What effect does efferent arteriolar constriction have on RPF?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What effect does efferent arteriolar constriction have on GFR?

{{c1::Increased}}

What effect does increased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on GFR?

{{c1::Decreased GFR}}

What effect does increased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on RPF?

{{c1::No change}}

What effect does decreased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on GFR?

{{c1::Increased GFR}}

What effect does decreased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on RPF?

{{c1::No change}}

What effect does constriction of the ureter have on GFR?

{{c1::Decreased GFR}}

What effect does constriction of the ureter have on RPF?

{{c1::No change}}
{{c2::Inulin}} clearance can be used to calculate {{c1::GFR}} because it is freely filtered and is not reabsorbed or secreted

Glomerular filtration rate may be estimated using the equation:

GFR = Cinulin = {{c1::[U]inulin * V / [P]inulin}}
In addition to inulin, {{c1::creatinine}} clearance may also be used to estimate GFR
Creatinine clearance slightly {{c1::over}}-estimates GFR because creatinine is moderately {{c1::secreted}} by renal tubules
Volume contraction results in decreased renal perfusion with consequent decreased GFR, thus increasing nitrogenous waste products in the blood ({{c1::prerenal}} azotemia)
In prerenal azotemia, decreased GFR causes {{c1::increased}} levels of BUN and serum creatinine
In prerenal azotemia, there is a(n) {{c1::increase}} in the ratio of BUN/creatinine to more than 20
The filtration fraction may be calculated using the equation FF = {{c1::GFR / RPF}}

What effect does afferent arteriolar constriction have on filtration fraction?

{{c1::No change}}

What effect does efferent arteriolar constriction have on filtration fraction?

{{c1::Increased FF}}

What effect does increased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on filtration fraction?

{{c1::Decreased FF}}

What effect does decreased plasma protein concentration (πGC) have on filtration fraction?

{{c1::Increased FF}}

What effect does constriction of the ureter have on filtration fraction?

{{c1::Decreased FF}}
Fluid exits the glomerular capillaries and enters Bowmans space via the process of {{c1::filtration}}
Fluid exits PCT cells and enters the peritubular capillaries via the process of {{c1::reabsorption}}
Fluid exits peritubular capillaries and enters PCT cells via the process of {{c1::secretion}}
The sum of filtration, secretion, and reabsorption is {{c1::excretion}}
The amount of substance filtered in Bowmans space per unit time is called the {{c1::filtered load}}

Filtered load (mg/min) can be calculated using the equation:

Filtered load = {{c1::GFR (mL/min) * [Px] (mg/mL)}}

Excretion rate can be calculated using the equation:

Excretion rate = {{c1::V * [U]x}}
If the filtered load is {{c2::less}} than the excretion rate, there has been net {{c1::secretion::reabsorption or secretion}}
If the filtered load is {{c2::greater}} than the excretion rate, there has been net {{c1::reabsorption::reabsorption or secretion}}
The rate of {{c1::reabsorption}} is equal to filtered load - excretion rate
The rate of {{c1::secretion}} is equal to excretion rate - filtered load
Glucose is reabsorbed in the {{c2::early PCT}} by {{c1::Na+/glucose (SGLT)}} cotransporters
Glucose in the cells of the PCT enter the peritubular capillary blood through {{c1::GLUT1}} and {{c1::GLUT2}} transporters

What type of transport mechanism is glucose transport through GLUT1 and GLUT2?

{{c1::Facilitated diffusion}}
Glucose at a normal plasma level (60 - 120 mg/dL) is completely {{c1::reabsorbed}} in the PCT
In adults, all glucose transporters are fully saturated (Tm) at a plasma glucose of ~ {{c1::350}} mg/dL

What pathology is commonly associated with glucosuria?

{{c1::Diabetes mellitus}}

What non-pathologic state is commonly associated with glucosuria?

{{c1::Pregnancy}}

How does GFR change during pregnancy?

{{c1::Increased}}
Normal pregnancy may decrease the ability of the PCT to reabsorb {{c1::glucose}} and {{c2::amino acids}} by increasing {{c3::GFR}}
In the {{c1::thin descending limb (Henles loop)}} of the nephron, urea is {{c2::secreted}} by simple diffusion
The thick ascending limb, distal tubule, and cortical/outer medullary collecting ducts are {{c1::impermeable}} to urea (permeable or impermeable)
In the {{c1::inner medullary collecting ducts}}, 70% of the filtered urea is {{c2::reabsorbed}} via {{c3::facilitated}} diffusion (if ADH is present)
Tubular inulin {{c1::increases}} in concentration along the PCT as a result of water reabsorption
The bulk of Na+ reabsorption occurs in the {{c1::proximal convoluted tubule}} (67%)
The proximal tubule is characterized by {{c1::iso}}-osmotic reabsorption
{{c1::HCO3-}} is the major anion reabsorbed in the {{c2::early PCT}}
Usually, 100% of glucose and amino acids are reabsorbed in the {{c1::early PCT}}
Phosphate is primarily reabsorbed in the {{c1::early PCT}} through {{c2::Na+-phosphate}} cotransport
H+ is secreted into the lumen of the early PCT via the {{c2::Na+-H+}} exchanger, where it combines with filtered {{c1::HCO3-}}, forming H2CO3
In the lumen of the early PCT, H2CO3 is converted into {{c1::H2O}} and {{c1::CO2}} via the enzyme carbonic anhydrase
The H2O and CO2 in the lumen of the early PCT (from H2CO3) is {{c1::reabsorbed into::excreted out or reabsorbed into}} the cell
Inside the cells of the early PCT, H2O and CO2 form H2CO3, which then dissociates into {{c1::H+}} and {{c1::HCO3-}}
The HCO3- inside the cells of the early PCT (from H2CO3) is {{c1::reabsorbed (into the blood)}} via facilitated diffusion
The H+ inside the cells of the early PCT (from H2CO3) is {{c1::re-secreted (into the lumen)}} by the Na+-H+ exchanger
{{c1::Cl-}} is the major anion reabsorbed in the {{c2::late PCT}} of the nephron
Cl- is partially reabsorbed via the {{c1::Cl--formate-}} anion exchanger in the luminal membrane of the late PCT
In the late PCT, Na+ reabsorption may occur through the {{c1::Na+-H+}} exchange

What is the driving force for reabsorption of NaCl in the late PCT?

{{c1::High Cl- gradient}}
The major solutes absorbed in the proximal tubule are {{c1::NaCl}} and {{c2::NaHCO3}}

Does solute follow water reabsorption, or does water follow solute reabsorption?

{{c1::Water follows solute}}

How is Na+ pumped out of the cell of the proximal tubule and into the blood?

{{c1::Na+-K+-ATPase pump}}

What component of tubular fluid is sensed at the macula densa?

{{c1::Na+ and Cl-}}
The {{c1::thin descending}} limb (loop of Henle) is {{c2::permeable}} to water
The {{c1::thin descending}} limb (loop of Henle) is {{c2::impermeable}} to Na+
In the thin descending limb (loop of Henle), tubular fluid becomes progressively {{c1::hyper}}-osmotic as it descends
The thin descending limb absorbs water {{c1::passively::actively or passively}}
The {{c1::thin}} and {{c1::thick ascending}} limbs (loop of Henle) are {{c2::impermeable}} to water
The {{c1::thin}} and {{c1::thick ascending}} limbs (loop of Henle) are {{c2::permeable}} to Na+
In the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle), tubular fluid becomes progressively {{c1::hypo}}-osmotic as it ascends
The thin ascending limb absorbs Na+ {{c1::passively::actively or passively}}
The thick ascending limb absorbs Na+ {{c1::actively::actively or passively}}
The thick ascending limb (of Henle) normally reabsorbs approximately {{c1::10-20}}% of the filtered Na+
Na+ is reabsorbed in the {{c2::thick ascending limb (of Henle)}} via the {{c1::Na+-K+-2Cl-}} cotransporter in the luminal membrane

In addition to Na+, what two other ions are reabsorbed through the lumen of the thick ascending limb?

{{c1::K+, Cl- (Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter)}}

How is Na+ extruded out of the cell of the thick ascending limb and into the blood?

{{c1::Na+-K+-ATPase pump}}

How is Cl- extruded out of the cell of the thick ascending limb and into the blood?

{{c1::Diffusion down its electrochemical gradient (via membrane channels)}}

How is K+ extruded out of the cell of the thick ascending limb and into the blood?

{{c1::Diffusion down its electrochemical gradient (via membrane channels)}}
Some {{c1::K+}} in the cells of the thick ascending limb diffuse back into the lumen, creating a lumen {{c2::positive}} potential difference
The {{c2::thick ascending limb (of Henle)}} is the site of action of {{c1::loop}} diuretics
Travel through the thick ascending limb (of Henle) results in {{c1::dilution::concentration or dilution}} of the tubular fluid
The early DCT normally reabsorbs approximately {{c1::5}}% of the filtered Na+
Na+ is reabsorbed in the {{c2::early DCT}} via the {{c1::Na+-Cl-}} cotransporter in the luminal membrane

In addition to Na+, what other ion is reabsorbed through the lumen of the early DCT?

{{c1::Cl- (Na+-Cl- cotransporter)}}

How is Na+ extruded out of the cell of the early DCT and into the blood?

{{c1::Na+-K+-ATPase pump}}

How is Cl- extruded out of the cell of the early DCT and into the blood?

{{c1::Diffusion down its electrochemical gradient (via membrane channels)}}
The {{c1::early}} DCT is always {{c2::impermeable::permeability}} to water

What are the two main cell types of the late distal tubule and collecting duct?

{{c1::Principal cells, α-intercalated cells}}
The {{c2::principal}} cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct reabsorb {{c1::Na+}} and {{c1::H2O}}
The {{c2::principal}} cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct secrete {{c1::K+}}
The {{c2::α-intercalated}} cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct secrete {{c1::H+}}
The late distal convoluted tubule and collecting ducts normally reabsorb approximately {{c1::3}}% of the filtered Na+
Na+ is reabsorbed in the principal cells of the late DCT and collecting duct via the {{c1::epithelial Na+}} channels in the luminal membrane

How is Na+ extruded out of the cells of the late DCT & collecting duct and into the blood?

{{c1::Na+-K+-ATPase pump}}
Aldosterone leads to {{c1::increased}} epithelial Na+ channel (ENaC) activity
Aldosterone leads to {{c1::increased}} apical {{c2::K+}} conductance
In principal cells, increased ENaC activity (due to aldosterone) causes increased lumen {{c1::negativity::charge}}
Increased lumen negativity in principal cells causes increased {{c1::K+}} secretion
In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is {{c1::decreased}} sympathetic activity
In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is {{c1::increased}} ANP activity
In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is {{c1::decreased}} peritubular capillary oncotic pressure
In response to increased Na+ intake (and ECF volume), there is {{c1::decreased}} renin-angiotensin-aldosterone activity
Insulin causes K+ to shift {{c1::into}} cells, causing {{c1::hypokalemia}}

How does insulin cause K+ to shift into cells?

{{c1::Increased Na+-K+ ATPase}}
Insulin deficiency (e.g. T1DM) causes K+ to shift {{c1::out of}} cells, causing {{c1::hyperkalemia}}

What acid-base disturbance is associated with hypokalemia?

{{c1::Alkalosis}}

What acid-base disturbance is associated with hyperkalemia?

{{c1::Acidosis}}
Acid-base disturbances may affect serum K+ levels via altering activity and directionality of the {{c1::H+-K+}} exchanger
Alkalosis may cause K+ to shift {{c1::into}} cells, causing {{c1::hypokalemia}}
Acidosis may cause K+ to shift {{c1::out of}} cells, causing {{c1::hyperkalemia}}
{{c2::β}}-adrenergic antagonists cause K+ to shift {{c1::out of}} cells, causing {{c1::hyperkalemia}}
{{c2::β}}-adrenergic agonists cause K+ to shift {{c1::into}} cells, causing {{c1::hypokalemia}}
{{c2::α}}-adrenergic antagonists cause K+ to shift {{c1::into}} cells, causing {{c1::hypokalemia}}
{{c2::Hyper}}-osmolarity may cause K+ to shift {{c1::out of}} cells, causing {{c1::hyperkalemia}}
{{c2::Hypo}}-osmolarity may cause K+ to shift {{c1::into}} cells, causing {{c1::hypokalemia}}
Lysis of cells may cause K+ to shift {{c1::out of}} cells, causing {{c1::hyperkalemia}}
Hyperaldosteronism {{c2::increases}} K+ secretion and causes {{c2::hypo}}-kalemia
Hypoaldosteronism {{c2::decreases}} K+ secretion and causes {{c2::hyper}}-kalemia
Aldosterone {{c1::increases}} the number of luminal membrane K+ channels in the late distal tubule and collecting duct
Thiazide and loop diuretics {{c1::increase}} K+ excretion and cause {{c1::hypo}}-kalemia
Increased Na+ delivery to principal cells (e.g. thiazide and loop diuretics) causes {{c1::increased}} K+ secretion
Thiazide and loop diuretics {{c1::increase}} flow rate through the late DCT and collecting duct, thus {{c2::decreasing}} luminal K+ concentration
K+-sparing diuretics {{c1::decrease}} K+ secretion and cause {{c1::hyper}}-kalemia
{{c1::PTH}} is a hormone that inhibits {{c2::Na+-phosphate}} cotransport in the proximal tubule
PTH action causes increased urinary {{c1::cAMP}} and {{c2::phosphat}}-uria
{{c2::Loop}} diuretics indirectly inhibit {{c1::Ca2+}} and {{c1::Mg2+}} reabsorption in the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle)

What effect do loop diuretics have on serum Ca2+ levels?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What is the site of regulation for Ca2+ reabsorption?

{{c1::Distal tubule}}
{{c1::Parathyroid}} hormone stimulates {{c2::Ca2+-Na+}} exchange in the basolateral membrane of distal tubule cells
PTH action causes {{c1::hypo}}-calciuria

What effect do thiazide diuretics have on serum Ca2+ levels?

{{c1::Increased}}
The bulk of Mg2+ reabsorption occurs in the {{c1::thick ascending limb (of Henle)}} (60%)
Mg2+ is reabsorbed in the thick ascending limb (on Henle) via a(n) {{c1::paracellular}} route

What effect do loop diuretics have on serum Mg2+ levels?

{{c1::Decreased (hypomagnesemia)}}
The {{c1::cortical}} and {{c1::outer medullary}} collecting ducts are permeable to H2O and impermeable to urea (ADH present)
The {{c1::inner medullary}} collecting duct is permeable to both H2O and urea (ADH present)

What effect does the urea cycle have on interstitial fluid osmolarity?

{{c1::Increased osmolarity}}
ADH {{c1::enhances}} the activity of the urea cycle
In the absence of {{c2::ADH}}, the principal cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct are {{c1::impermeable}} to water
In the presence of {{c2::ADH}}, {{c1::aquaporin 2}} channels are inserted in the luminal membrane of {{c3::principal}} cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct
{{c1::Hyper}}-osmotic urine is produced when the circulating levels of ADH are {{c2::high}}
{{c1::Hypo}}-osmotic urine is produced when the circulating levels of ADH are {{c2::low}}
{{c1::Free-water clearance (CH2O)}} is used to estimate the ability to concentrate or dilute the urine
When CH2O is {{c1::zero}}, urine is {{c2::iso}}-osmotic relative to plasma
When CH2O is {{c1::positive}}, urine is {{c2::hypo}}-osmotic relative to plasma
When CH2O is {{c1::negative}}, urine is {{c2::hyper}}-osmotic relative to plasma
Cholinomimetic drugs mimic the neurotransmitter {{c1::acetylcholine}}
{{c2::Nicotinic}} acetylcholine receptors are found on autonomic {{c1::ganglia}}
{{c2::Nicotinic}} acetylcholine receptors are found on {{c1::motor end plates}} at the NMJ of skeletal muscle
{{c2::Nicotinic}} acetylcholine receptors are found on the {{c1::adrenal}} gland
{{c1::Muscarinic::Muscarinic or Nicotinergic?}} acetylcholine receptors are found in effector tissues (e.g. heart, smooth muscle, brain, glands)
{{c2::Nicotinic}} Ach receptors are ligand-gated {{c1::Na+/K+ (ion)}} channels
{{c2::Muscarinic}} Ach receptors are {{c1::G-protein coupled}} receptors

What G-protein is the M1 muscarinic receptor coupled to?

{{c1::Gq}}

What G-protein is the M2 muscarinic receptor coupled to?

{{c1::Gi}}

What G-protein is the M3 muscarinic receptor coupled to?

{{c1::Gq}}
Gq proteins {{c2::activate}} the {{c1::IP3-DAG}} signaling cascade

{{c3::M1}} muscarinic receptors are found in the
- {{c1::CNS}}
- {{c2::ENS}}

What organ does the M2 receptor primarily effect?

{{c1::Heart}}
{{c2::M2}} muscarinic receptors are found in the {{c1::atria}}, SA node, and AV node of the heart

What is the effect of M2 muscarinic agonists on heart rate?

{{c1::Decreased HR (SA node)}}

What is the effect of M2 muscarinic agonists on conduction velocity?

{{c1::Decreased CV (AV node)}}

What is the effect of M2 muscarinic agonists on heart contractility?

{{c1::Decreased atrial contractility}}
The {{c1::M3}} muscarinic receptor is found in glands, the bladder, and smooth muscle
In healthy patients, M3 receptor activation indirectly causes vaso-{{c1::dilation}} via release of {{c1::nitric oxide}}
In atherosclerotic patients, M3 receptor activation directly causes vaso-{{c1::constriction}}

What drug class does bethanechol belong to?

{{c1::Cholinomimetics (muscarinic agonists)}}
Bethanechol activates {{c1::bowel}} and {{c2::bladder}} smooth muscle
{{c3::Bethanechol}} is a cholinomimetic agent used to treat {{c2::post-operative}} and {{c4::neurogenic}} {{c1::ileus}}
{{c3::Bethanechol}} is a cholinomimetic agent used to treat urinary {{c2::retention}}

What drug class does pilocarpine belong to?

{{c1::Cholinomimetics (muscarinic agonists)}}
Pilocarpine is a potent {{c1::stimulator}} of tears, sweat, and salivary secretion
Pilocarpine contracts {{c1::pupillary sphincter}} muscle, which may be used to treat {{c2::closed}}-angle glaucoma
Carbachol contracts {{c1::pupillary sphincter}} muscle, which may be used to treat {{c2::closed}}-angle glaucoma

Is carbachol a muscarinic or nicotinic Ach agonist?

{{c1::Both :)}}

What drug class does methacholine belong to?

{{c1::Cholinomimetics (muscarinic agonists)}}
{{c1::Methacholine}} challenge instigates asthma for pulmonary testing

The normal range for arterial pH is {{c1::7.35}} to {{c1::7.45}}

compatible with life is between {{c1::6.8}} and {{c1::8}}

What is the normal average arterial pH?

{{c1::7.4}}
{{c1::CO2}} is also known as {{c2::volatile}} acid
CO2 combines with H2O to form the weak acid H2CO3 via the enzyme {{c1::carbonic anhydrase}}
H2CO3 dissociates into {{c1::H+}} and {{c1::HCO3-}}
Non-volatile acids are also called {{c1::fixed}} acids
One non-volatile acid is {{c1::sulfuric}} acid, which is generated from metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids (protein)
One non-volatile acid is {{c1::phosphoric}} acid, which is generated from metabolism of phospholipids

What non-volatile acids are commonly elevated in type 1 diabetes?

{{c1::Acetoacetic acid and β-hydroxybutyric acid (ketoacidosis)::2}}

What non-volatile acid may be elevated with strenuous exercise?

{{c1::Lactic acid}}

What non-volatile acid may be elevated with aspirin overdose?

{{c1::Salicylic acid}}

What non-volatile acid may be elevated with methanol ingestion?

{{c1::Formic acid}}

What non-volatile acid may be elevated with ethylene glycol ingestion?

{{c1::Oxalic acid}}

The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation for any buffer states that:

{{c2::pH}} = {{c1::pK + log [A-]/[HA]}}
The [A-] form of the bicarbonate buffer is {{c1::HCO3-}}

The Henderson-Hasselbalch equation for the HCO3-/CO2 buffer states that:

{{c2::pH}} = {{c1::6.1 + log ([HCO3-] / (0.03 * PCO2))}}
The most significant intracellular buffer for H+ is {{c1::deoxyhemoglobin}}

Which is a better intracellular buffer in physiologic pH range, oxy- or deoxyhemoglobin?

{{c1::Deoxyhemoglobin}}
In the lumen of the early PCT, H2CO3 is converted to CO2 and H2O by brush border {{c1::carbonic anhydrase}}
In the cells of the early PCT, H2CO3 is converted to CO2 and H2O by intracellular {{c1::carbonic anhydrase}}
HCO3- is transported from the cells of proximal tubule into the blood by {{c1::Na+-HCO3-}} cotransport and {{c2::Cl--HCO3-}} exchange
ECF volume contraction results in {{c1::increased}} HCO3- reabsorption
Angiotensin II stimulates {{c1::Na+-H+}} exchange in the proximal tubule

What effect does angiotensin II have on HCO3- reabsorption?

{{c1::Increased reabsorption}}
Increased PCO2 (respiratory acidosis) results in {{c1::increased}} HCO3- reabsorption
Decreased PCO2 (respiratory alkalosis) results in {{c1::decreased}} HCO3- reabsorption
Fixed H+ (e.g. from protein and phospholipid catabolism) is excreted in the urine as {{c1::titratable acid (e.g. H2PO4-)}} and {{c2::NH4+}}
Titratable acid is primarily excreted in the {{c1::α-intercalated}} cells of the late distal tubule and collecting duct

H+ secretion from α-intercalated cells occurs via the luminal membrane {{c1::H+ ATPase}}
and {{c2::H+-K+ ATPase}} pumps
The {{c2::H+ ATPase}} pump in the luminal membrane of the α-intercalated cells is stimulated by {{c1::aldosterone}}
In the lumen of late distal tubule and collecting duct, secreted H+ combines with the HPO4- to form H2PO4, which is a(n) {{c1::titratable}} acid
For each H+ excreted as titratable acid, one new {{c1::HCO3-}} is synthesized and reabsorbed
The amount of H+ excreted as titratable acid depends on the amount of {{c1::urinary buffer}} present and the {{c2::pK}} of the buffer
In the cells of the proximal tubule, the enzyme {{c1::glutaminase}} metabolizes glutamine to glutamate and {{c2::NH4+}}
For each NH4+ generated in the proximal tubule, one new {{c1::HCO3-}} is synthesized and reabsorbed

Which form (NH4+ or NH3) is secreted into the lumen of the cells of the proximal tubule?

{{c1::NH3}}
In the {{c1::α-intercalated}} cells of the collecting duct, NH3 and H+ are secreted into the lumen
As pH of the tubular fluid {{c1::decreases}}, the excretion of H+ as NH4+ {{c2::increases}}
In chronic {{c2::acidosis}}, there is an adaptive {{c1::increase}} in NH3 synthesis in the cells of the proximal tubule
{{c1::Hyper}}-kalemia {{c2::inhibits}} NH3 synthesis

What is the normal average blood HCO3- concentration (mEq/L)?

{{c1::24 mEq/L}}
The plasma anion gap represents unmeasured ions in serum and is equal to {{c1::[Na+] - ([HCO3-] + [Cl-])::formula}}
The range of normal values for the plasma anion gap is {{c1::8}} to {{c1::16}} mEq/L
The plasma anion gap is useful primarily in the differential diagnosis of {{c1::metabolic acidosis}}
If the "lost" HCO3- in metabolic acidosis is replaced by {{c2::Cl-}}, the anion gap is {{c1::normal}}
If the "lost" HCO3- in metabolic acidosis is replaced by {{c2::unmeasured ions}}, the anion gap is {{c1::increased}}
{{c1::Osmolar gap}} is the difference between measured plasma osmolarity and estimated plasma osmolarity

Which acid-base disturbance is caused by decreased HCO3-?

{{c1::Metabolic acidosis}}
The primary disturbance in metabolic acidosis is a(n) {{c2::decrease}} in {{c1::HCO3-}}
Decreased HCO3- (metabolic acidosis) causes a(n) {{c1::decrease}} in arterial pH
Decreased arterial pH (metabolic acidosis) causes compensatory {{c1::hyper}}-ventilation with consequent {{c1::decreased}} PCO2

The arterial blood profile seen in compensated metabolic acidosis is:

pH: {{c1::decreased}}
[HCO3-]: {{c1::decreased}}
PCO2: {{c1::decreased}}
Hyperventilation as a respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis is known as {{c1::Kussmaul}} breathing
Respiratory compensation in response to metabolic acidosis or alkalosis is {{c1::immediate::timing}}

Which acid-base disturbance is caused by increased HCO3-?

{{c1::Metabolic alkalosis}}
The primary disturbance in metabolic alkalosis is a(n) {{c2::increase}} in {{c1::HCO3-}} OR a(n) {{c2::decrease}} in {{c1::H+}}
Increased HCO3- causes a(n) {{c1::increase}} in arterial pH
Increased arterial pH (metabolic alkalosis) causes compensatory {{c1::hypo}}-ventilation with consequent {{c1::increased}} PCO2

The arterial blood profile seen in compensated metabolic alkalosis is:

pH: {{c1::increased}}
[HCO3-]: {{c1::increased}}
PCO2: {{c1::increased}}
If metabolic alkalosis is accompanied by ECF volume {{c1::contraction}}, the reabsorption of HCO3- increases, worsening the metabolic alkalosis
The primary disturbance in respiratory acidosis is {{c1::hypo}}-ventilation, which results in {{c1::increased}} CO2
Increased CO2 causes a(n) {{c1::decrease}} in arterial pH
Increased CO2 (respiratory acidosis) causes a(n) {{c1::increase}} in HCO3- by mass action

The arterial blood profile seen in compensated respiratory acidosis is:

pH: {{c1::decreased}}
[HCO3-]: {{c1::increased}}
PCO2: {{c1::increased}}
Renal correction of respiratory acidosis includes increased excretion of excess fixed H+ as {{c1::titratable acid}} and {{c1::NH4+}}
Renal correction of respiratory acidosis includes increased reabsorption of "new" {{c1::HCO3-}}
Metabolic compensation in response to respiratory acidosis or alkalosis is {{c1::delayed::timing}}
The primary disturbance in respiratory alkalosis is {{c1::hyper}}-ventilation, which results in {{c1::decreased}} CO2
Decreased CO2, secondary to hyperventilation, causes a(n) {{c1::increase}} in arterial pH
Decreased CO2 (respiratory alkalosis) causes a(n) {{c1::decrease}} in HCO3- by mass action

The arterial blood profile seen in compensated respiratory alkalosis is:

pH: {{c1::increased}}
[HCO3-]: {{c1::decreased}}
PCO2: {{c1::decreased}}
The compensatory response to an acid-base disturbance is always in {{c1::the same::(same or different)}} direction as the original acid-base disturbance
Winters formula is used to calculate the predicted respiratory compensation for a simple {{c1::metabolic acidosis}}

Winters formula for simple metabolic acidosis states that:

{{c2::PCO2}} = {{c1::1.5[HCO3-] + 8 +/- 2}}
If the measured PCO2 {{c2::>}} predicted PCO2 using Winters formula, then the metabolic acidosis has a concomitant {{c1::respiratory acidosis}}
If the PCO2 {{c2::<}} predicted PCO2 using Winters formula, then the metabolic acidosis has a concomitant {{c1::respiratory alkalosis}}
{{c1::Horseshoe kidney}} occurs when the {{c2::inferior}} poles of the kidney are fused together

What is the most common congenital renal anomaly?

{{c1::Horseshoe kidney}}
As horseshoe kidneys ascend from the pelvis during fetal development, they get trapped under the {{c1::inferior mesenteric}} artery and remain low in the abdomen

Is kidney function in horseshoe kidney normal or abnormal?

{{c1::Normal}}
Horseshoe kidney is associated with {{c1::hydronephrosis}} (e.g due to ureteropelvic junction obstruction)
Horseshoe kidney is associated with increased risk for kidney {{c1::stones}} and infection

What sex chromosome disorder is associated with horseshoe kidney?

{{c1::Turner syndrome}}

Which congenital kidney disease is associated with chromosomal aneuploidy (e.g. trisomy 13, 18, 21)?

{{c1::Horseshoe kidney}}
Horseshoe kidney is rarely associated with renal {{c1::cancer}}

What congenital kidney disease is associated with unilateral or bilateral absent kidney and ureter formation?

{{c1::Renal agenesis}}
Renal agenesis occurs due to failure of the {{c2::ureteric buds}} to develop and induce differentiation of {{c1::metanephric mesenchyme}}
Renal agenesis is often diagnosed prenatally via {{c1::ultrasound}}
Unilateral renal agenesis leads to {{c1::hypertrophy}} of the existing kidney
Hyperfiltration of the existing kidney in unilateral renal agenesis increases risk of {{c1::renal failure}} later in life
{{c1::Bilateral}} renal agenesis increases risk for {{c2::Potter}} sequence
The primary abnormality in Potter sequence is {{c1::oligo}}-hydramnios
In Potter sequence, oligohydramnios leads to pulmonary {{c1::hypoplasia}}
In Potter sequence, oligohydramnios causes {{c1::compression}} of the developing fetus
In Potter sequence, compression of the developing fetus results in a(n) {{c1::flat}} face with {{c2::low-set}} ears
In Potter sequence, compression of the developing fetus results in limb {{c1::deformities}}
Potter sequence may cause {{c1::retrognathia}}, which is the abnormal positioning of the mandible

What is the cause of death in Potter sequence?

{{c1::Pulmonary hypoplasia}}

Which form of polycystic kidney disease may cause Potter sequence?

{{c1::Autosomal recessive PKD}}
Potter sequence may be caused by chronic {{c1::placental}} insufficiency
Potter sequence may be caused by {{c1::bladder outlet obstruction}} (e.g. posterior urethral valves)

Is dysplastic kidney heritable?

{{c1::No}}

What cystic congenital kidney disease is non-inherited?

{{c1::(Multicystic) dysplastic kidney}}
Dysplastic kidney occurs due to failure of the {{c2::ureteric buds}} to induce differentiation of {{c1::metanephric mesenchyme}}
Multicystic dysplastic kidney is often diagnosed prenatally via {{c1::ultrasound}}
In dysplastic kidney, cysts are usually {{c1::uni}}-lateral
In polycystic kidney disease, cysts are usually {{c1::bi}}-lateral

Is polycystic kidney disease heritable?

{{c1::Yes}}

Is polycystic kidney disease associated with enlargement of the kidneys?

{{c1::Yes}}
The {{c2::autosomal recessive}} form of polycystic kidney disease typically presents in {{c1::infants}}
Autosomal recessive PKD presents in infants as worsening renal failure and {{c1::hypertension::BP}}

Which form of PKD (autosomal dominant or recessive) is associated with hepatic cysts?

{{c1::Both :)}}
Autosomal {{c3::recessive}} PKD is associated with congenital {{c1::hepatic fibrosis}} which may lead to {{c2::portal}} hypertension

What congenital renal defect may cause portal hypertension in an infant?

{{c1::Autosomal recessive PKD}}
Autosomal dominant PKD may present in young adults with {{c1::hypertension}} due to increased {{c2::renin}}
Autosomal dominant PKD may present in young adults as worsening renal failure and {{c1::hemat}}-uria
Autosomal dominant PKD is associated with {{c1::berry aneurysm}}, which is an important cause of death
Autosomal dominant and recessive PKD are associated with {{c1::hepatic}} cysts in addition to renal cysts (benign)

What heart defect is associated with autosomal dominant PKD?

{{c1::Mitral valve prolapse}}

Is Autosomal Dominant Tubulointerstitial Kidney Disease (Medullary Cystic Kidney Disease) heritable?

{{c1::Yes}}

What is the mode of inheritance of medullary cystic kidney disease?

{{c1::Autosomal dominant}}

What congenital renal defect is a condition of being born with only one functioning kidney (one non-functional)?

{{c1::Congenital solitary functioning kidney}}
Congenital solitary functioning kidney leads to {{c1::hypertrophy}} of the functioning kidney
Fetal kidney development begins with the {{c2::pronephros}}, which develops by week {{c1::4}}
After the pronephros develops, it then {{c1::degenerates}}
The {{c1::mesonephros}} forms after the pronephros and functions as an interim kidney for the 1st trimester
The mesonephros later contributes to the {{c1::male}} genital system

Which embryologic kidney becomes the permanent kidney?

{{c1::Metanephros}}
The metanephros first appears in the {{c1::5th}} week of gestation
Nephrogenesis continues through {{c1::32}} to {{c1::36}} weeks of gestation
The {{c1::ureteric}} bud is derived from the caudal end of the {{c2::mesonephric}} duct
The embryonic {{c1::ureteric bud}} gives rise to the ureter, pelvises, calyces, and collecting ducts
The ureteric bud is fully canalized by the {{c1::10th}} week of gestation, allowing the metanephros to make urine
The embryonic {{c3::metanephric mesenchyme (blastema)}} differentiates into renal structures from the {{c1::glomerulus}} through the {{c2::DCT}}

The embryonic {{c1::metanephric mesenchyme}} interacts via {{c2::reciprocal-inductive signaling}} with the ureteric bud, inducing differentiation of these tissues into their respective parts of the kidney
The {{c1::ureteropelvic junction}} is the last structure of the embryologic kidney to canalize

What is the most common site of obstruction (hydronephrosis) in the fetal kidney?

{{c1::Ureteropelvic junction}}
{{c3::Duplex collecting system}} is a congenital renal disease characterized by {{c2::bifurcation}} of the {{c1::ureteric bud}} before it enters the metanephric mesenchyme

What congenital renal disease is characterized by a Y-shaped bifid ureter?

{{c1::Duplex collecting system}}
{{c1::Duplex}} collecting system may occur due to two ureteric buds reaching and interacting with one metanephric mesenchyme
Duplex collecting system is strongly associated with vesicoureteral {{c2::reflux}} and/or ureteral {{c1::obstruction}}
Duplex collecting system is associated with increased risk for {{c1::urinary}} tract infection
The hallmark of acute kidney injury is {{c1::azotemia}}, often with {{c2::oliguria::urinary change}}
Azotemia typically refers to an increase in serum {{c1::BUN}} and {{c1::creatinine}}

What is the most common cause of acute renal failure in hospitalized patients?

{{c1::Acute tubular necrosis}}

What is the effect of acute tubular necrosis on GFR?

{{c1::Decreased GFR}}
In acute tubular necrosis, the BUN:creatinine ratio is {{c1::<}} 15
Acute tubular necrosis is caused by {{c1::ischemic}} or {{c2::nephrotoxic}} injury
Acute tubular necrosis caused by {{c1::ischemia}} is due to decreased renal blood flow
Acute tubular necrosis due to ischemic injury is often preceded by {{c1::prerenal azotemia}}
Acute tubular necrosis due to ischemic injury most commonly affects the {{c1::proximal tubule}} and the medullary segment of the {{c2::thick ascending limb}}
Acute tubular necrosis caused by {{c1::nephrotoxicity}} is due to toxic substances
Acute tubular necrosis due to nephrotoxic injury most commonly affects the {{c1::proximal tubule}}

What class of anti-microbials is a common cause of acute tubular necrosis?

{{c1::Aminoglycosides}}
Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by heavy metals such as {{c1::lead}}
Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by {{c1::myoglobinuria}}, which can occur with crush injuries
Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by ingestion of {{c1::ethylene glycol}}, which is associated with {{c2::oxalate}} crystals in the urine
Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by {{c1::radio}}-contrast dyes
Acute tubular necrosis may be caused by high levels of {{c1::uric acid}} (e.g. tumor lysis syndrome)

What chemotherapeutic agent may cause acute tubular necrosis?

{{c1::Cisplatin}}
{{c2::Acute tubular necrosis}} is associated with {{c1::granular "muddy brown"}} casts in the urine
The first stage of acute tubular necrosis is the {{c1::inciting event}}
The second stage of acute tubular necrosis is the {{c1::maintenance}} phase

Does the maintenance phase of acute tubular necrosis present with oliguria or polyuria?

{{c1::Oliguria}}

How long does the maintenance phase of acute tubular necrosis last?

{{c1::1-3 weeks}}
During the maintenance phase of acute tubular necrosis, there is increased risk for {{c1::hyper}}-kalemia and uremia

What acid-base disturbance is associated with the maintenance phase of acute tubular necrosis?

{{c1::Metabolic acidosis}}
The third (final) stage of acute tubular necrosis is the {{c1::recovery}} phase

Does the recovery phase of acute tubular necrosis present with oliguria or polyuria?

{{c1::Polyuria}}
During the recovery phase of acute tubular necrosis, there is increased risk for {{c1::hypo}}-kalemia and renal {{c2::wasting}} of other electrolytes and minerals
During the recovery phase of acute tubular necrosis, BUN and serum creatinine levels {{c1::decrease}}
Acute tubular necrosis is reversible but often requires supportive {{c1::dialysis}} due to electrolyte imbalances (e.g. hypokalemia)
Intrarenal azotemia is less commonly due to acute {{c1::glomerulonephritis}} or acute {{c2::interstitial nephritis}}
{{c1::Acute interstitial nephritis}} is a drug-induced {{c2::hypersensitivity}} reaction involving the interstitium and tubules of the kidney
Acute interstitial nephritis is characterized histologically by {{c1::inflammatory infiltrate}} in the connective tissue between renal tubules
Acute interstitial nephritis may present with {{c1::fever}} and {{c1::rash}}, days to weeks after starting a drug
Acute interstitial nephritis is associated with {{c2::hemat}}-uria and pyuria (classically {{c1::eosinophils}})

What physical exam finding may be associated with acute interstitial nephritis?

{{c1::CVA tenderness}}

Drugs that cause acute {{c6::interstitial nephritis}} may be remembered with the 5 "Ps"

{{c1::Pee (diuretics)}}
{{c2::Pain-free (NSAIDs)}}
{{c3::Penicillins (and cephalosporins)}}
{{c4::Proton pump inhibitors}}
{{c5::RifamPin}}

What is the treatment for drug-induced acute interstitial nephritis?

{{c1::Cessation of the drug}}
Acute interstitial nephritis is less commonly secondary to systemic {{c1::infections}} (e.g. mycoplasma)
Acute interstitial nephritis is less commonly secondary to {{c1::autoimmune}} diseases (e.g. Sjögrens syndrome, SLE, sarcoidosis)
Acute interstitial nephritis may progress to renal {{c1::papillary}} necrosis
{{c1::Renal papillary necrosis}} is characterized by sloughing of necrotic renal papillae
Renal papillary necrosis presents with gross {{c1::hemat}}-uria and colicky {{c2::flank}} pain
In addition to hematuria, renal papillary necrosis may also present with {{c1::protein}}-uria
Renal papillary necrosis may be caused by chronic {{c1::analgesic}} abuse
Renal papillary necrosis may be caused by {{c1::sickle cell}} disease or trait
Renal papillary necrosis may be caused by severe acute {{c1::pyelonephritis}}

What endocrine pathology may cause renal papillary necrosis?

{{c1::Diabetes mellitus}}
{{c3::Nephrotic}} syndrome is a group of glomerular disorders characterized by {{c2::protein}}-uria {{c1::> 3.5}} g/day
Nephrotic syndrome results in {{c1::hypoalbuminemia}}, which manifests as {{c2::pitting edema}} and {{c3::secondary}} hyperaldosteronism
Nephrotic syndrome results in {{c1::hypogammaglobulinemia}}, which increases risk of {{c2::infection}}
Nephrotic syndrome causes a(n) {{c1::hyper}}-coagulable state due to loss of {{c2::antithrombin III}}
Nephrotic syndrome is associated with {{c1::hyper}}-lipidemia and {{c1::hyper}}-cholesterolemia
{{c2::Nephrotic}} syndrome is associated with frothy urine with {{c1::fatty}} casts
{{c1::Minimal change disease (lipoid nephrosis)}} is the most common cause of {{c3::nephrotic}} syndrome in {{c2::children}}
The cause of minimal change disease is often {{c1::idiopathic}} and may be triggered by recent URI, immunization, or immune stimulus (ex. insect bite)
Minimal change disease (lipoid nephrosis) is rarely secondary to {{c1::Hodgkin lymphoma}}
Minimal change disease is characterized by {{c1::cytokine}}-mediated damage of {{c2::foot processes}} and loss of {{c3::glomerular basement}} anions
Minimal change disease is characterized by {{c1::normal}} glomeruli on light microscopy
In minimal change disease (lipoid nephrosis), {{c1::lipids}} may be seen in {{c2::proximal tubule}} cells of the nephron (light microscopy)
Minimal change disease is characterized by {{c1::effacement}} of {{c2::foot processes}} on electron microscopy

What immunofluorescence findings are associated with minimal change disease?

{{c1::None (no immune complex deposits)}}
Minimal change disease is characterized by loss of {{c1::albumin}}, but not {{c2::immunoglobulin}} in the urine (selective proteinuria)
Minimal change disease has a(n) {{c2::excellent}} response to {{c1::corticosteroids}}
{{c1::Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)}} is the most common cause of {{c3::nephrotic}} syndrome in {{c2::Hispanics::ethnicity}} and {{c2::African Americans::ethnicity}}

The cause of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is usually idiopathic, but may be secondary to:

- massive {{c1::obesity}}
- {{c2::interferon}} treatment
- congenital {{c3::kidney malformations}} that cause chronic kidney disease

What hematologic pathology is associated with increased risk for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis?

{{c1::Sickle cell disease}}

What infectious disease is associated with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis?

{{c1::HIV}}
{{c2::Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis}} is a type of nephrotic syndrome associated with {{c1::heroin}} abuse
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by focal and segmental {{c1::sclerosis}} and {{c2::hyalinosis}} on light microscopy
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by {{c1::effacement}} of {{c2::foot processes}} on electron microscopy

What immunofluorescence findings are usually associated with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis?

{{c1::None (no immune complex deposits)}}
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis has a(n) {{c1::poor}} response to corticosteroids
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis ultimately progresses to {{c1::chronic renal failure}}
{{c1::Membranous nephropathy}} is the most common cause of {{c3::nephrotic}} syndrome in {{c2::Caucasian adults}}
Primary {{c2::membranous nephropathy}} is associated with autoantibodies against the transmembrane {{c1::phospholipase A2}} receptor found in high concentrations in glomerular podocytes

What type of nephrotic syndrome is a patient with SLE most likely to get?

{{c1::Membranous nephropathy}}

What infectious diseases is membranous nephropathy associated with?

{{c1::HBV, HCV::2}}
Membranous nephropathy may occur secondary to drugs, such as {{c1::NSAIDs}} and {{c2::penicillamine}}

Which type of nephrotic syndrome is commonly seen secondary to solid tumors?

{{c1::Membranous nephropathy}}
Membranous nephropathy is characterized by diffuse capillary and {{c1::GBM}} {{c2::thickening}} on light microscopy

What immunofluorescence findings are associated with membranous nephropathy?

{{c1::Granular deposits (immune complex deposition)}}
{{c3::Membranous}} nephropathy is characterized by {{c2::subepithelial}} deposits with a {{c1::spike and dome}} appearance on electron microscopy
Membranous nephropathy has a(n) {{c1::poor}} response to corticosteroids
Membranous nephropathy ultimately progresses to {{c1::chronic renal failure}}

Is membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) a nephritic or nephrotic syndrome?

{{c1::Can be either or both}}
The tram-track appearance associated with MPGN is due to basement membrane splitting caused by {{c1::mesangial}} cell ingrowth
MPGN type {{c2::I}} is associated with {{c1::subendothelial}} immune complex deposits
MPGN type {{c2::II}} is associated with {{c1::intramembranous}} immune complex deposits

Which type of MPGN is more often associated with a tram track appearance on H&E stain?

{{c1::Type I}}

What infectious diseases are associated with type I MPGN?

{{c1::HBV, HCV::2}}
Type II MPGN is also known as {{c1::dense deposit}} disease
Type {{c3::II}} MPGN is associated with {{c1::C3 nephritic factor}}, an autoantibody that stabilizes {{c2::C3 convertase}}
Type II MPGN is associated with {{c1::low}} circulating levels of C3
In diabetes mellitus, high serum glucose leads to {{c1::non-enzymatic glycosylation}} of the GBM in the kidney
Non-enzymatic glycosylation of the GBM results in {{c1::hyaline}} arteriolosclerosis

Which renal arteriole is initially affected by non-enzymatic glycation?

{{c1::Efferent arteriole}}

How does non-enzymatic glycation of the efferent renal arteriole affect GFR?

{{c1::Increased GFR (hyperfiltration)}}

Initially, NEG of the glomerular basement membrane (diabetes mellitus) causes hyperfiltration injury which leads to the development of {{c1::microalbumin}}-uria by promoting production of {{c2::heparanase}}

Does untreated diabetes nephropathy stay at a nephrotic syndrome or can it progress to a nephritic syndrome?

{{c1::Can progress to nephritic syndrome}}
Diabetic glomerulonephropathy is associated with {{c1::mesangial}} proliferation on light microscopy
The hyperfiltration in diabetic glomerulonephropathy can lead to eosinophilic nodular glomerulosclerosis, known as {{c1::Kimmelstiel-Wilson}} nodules

What drug class is used to slow progression of hyperfiltration-induced damage in diabetic glomerulonephropathy?

{{c1::ACE inhibitors}}

What is the most common cause of end-stage renal disease in the U.S.?

{{c1::Diabetic glomerulonephropathy}}

What is the first change that occurs in the kidney in a diabetes mellitus patient?

{{c1::Non-enzymatic glycosylation of GBM}}
Nephrotic syndrome may be caused by systemic {{c1::amyloidosis}}
The most commonly involved organ in systemic amyloidosis is the {{c1::kidney}}

Where in the kidney does amyloid deposit, causing nephrotic syndrome?

{{c1::Mesangium}}
Amyloidosis is characterized by {{c1::apple-green birefringence}} under polarized light after staining with {{c2::Congo red}}
Nephrotic syndrome occurs due to {{c2::podocyte}} damage disrupting the glomerular filtration {{c1::charge}} barrier
Nephritic syndrome is a group of glomerular disorders characterized by glomerular {{c1::inflammation}} and {{c2::bleeding}}
Nephritic syndrome is characterized by limited {{c2::protein}}-uria {{c1::< 3.5}} g/day

How does nephritic syndrome affect urine output?

{{c1::Decreased (oliguria)}}
Nephritic syndrome is associated with {{c1::increased}} BUN and creatinine
Nephritic syndrome is associated with {{c3::salt}} retention with consequent {{c1::periorbital edema}} and {{c2::hypertension}}
Nephritic syndrome may lead to hematuria and {{c1::RBC}} casts in the urine
Biopsy of nephritic syndrome reveals {{c1::hyper}}-cellular, inflamed glomeruli
Nephritic syndrome is typically associated with immune-complex deposition, which activates {{c1::complement (e.g. C5a)}}

{{c1::Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)}} is a type of nephritic syndrome that arises after a(n) {{c2::group A β-hemolytic streptococcal}} infection of the {{c3::skin (impetigo)}} or {{c4::pharynx}}

PSGN occurs with nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococcus, which carry the {{c1::M protein}} virulence factor and is caused by glomerular deposition of nephritogenic antigens such as {{c2::SpeB}}
PSGN typically presents 2 to 4 {{c1::weeks}} after a group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infection

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?

{{c1::Type III (immune complex-mediated)}}
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis may present with {{c2::hemat}}-uria and {{c1::cola / tea}}-colored urine
PSGN may present with peripheral and periorbital {{c1::edema}}
PSGN may present with {{c1::hypertension::BP}}

What demographic is more commonly associated with PSGN?

{{c1::Children::age group}}
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is characterized by enlarged and {{c1::hyper}}-cellular glomeruli on light microscopy
{{c3::PSGN}} is characterized by a "{{c1::lumpy bumpy (granular)}}" immunofluorescence pattern due to {{c2::immune complex deposition}}
The "lumpy-bumpy" appearance of PSGN on immunofluorescence is due to deposits with immune complexes consisting of {{c1::IgG}} / {{c1::IgM}} and {{c2::C3}}
PSGN is characterized by {{c1::subepithelial}} immune complex "{{c2::humps}}" on electron microscopy

What is the treatment for post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?

{{c1::Supportive (resolves spontaneously)}}
Children with PSGN {{c1::rarely (1%)::frequency}} progress to renal failure
About 25% of adults with PSGN develop {{c1::rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis}}
Diagnosis of {{c1::post-streptococcal}} glomerulonephritis may be aided by positive strep titers/serologies
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is associated with {{c1::decreased}} levels of complement
{{c1::Rapidly progressive}} glomerulonephritis is a nephritic syndrome that progresses to renal failure in days to weeks

What is the prognosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis?

{{c1::Poor prognosis}}
{{c2::Rapidly progressive}} glomerulonephritis is characterized by {{c1::crescents}} in Bowmans space of the glomeruli (light microscopy)
The crescents seen in RPGN are composed of {{c1::fibrin}} and {{c2::macrophages}}
{{c2::Goodpasture syndrome}} is a form of RPGN that presents with a(n) {{c1::linear}} pattern on immunofluorescence

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is Goodpasture syndrome?

{{c1::Type II HSR}}
{{c3::Goodpasture}} syndrome occurs due to antibodies against the {{c1::glomerular}} and {{c1::alveolar}} {{c2::basement membranes}}
Goodpasture syndrome presents with {{c1::hematuria}} and {{c1::hemoptysis}}

What demographic is associated with Goodpasture syndrome?

{{c1::Young adult males}}

What is the treatment for Goodpasture syndrome?

{{c1::Emergent plasmapheresis}}
RPGN with a granular immunofluorescence pattern is more commonly due to {{c1::post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis}}
RPGN with a granular immunofluorescence pattern is less commonly due to {{c1::diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis}}

What type of nephritic syndrome is a patient with SLE most likely to get?

{{c1::Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis}}
Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is a common cause of death in patients with {{c1::SLE}}
{{c2::Diffuse proliferative}} glomerulonephritis is characterized by "{{c1::wire looping}}" of capillaries on light microscopy
Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is characterized by a(n) {{c1::granular}} pattern on immunofluorescence
DPGN is characterized by {{c1::subendothelial}} and sometimes {{c2::intramembranous}} immune complexes on electron microscopy
The immune complexes in DPGN are Ig{{c1::G}}-based and often have {{c2::C3}} deposition
If RPGN has no immunofluorescence pattern, it is termed {{c1::pauci-immune}} glomerulonephritis

Which cause of pauci-immune glomerulonephritis is associated with c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA)?

{{c1::Wegener granulomatosis}}

Which causes of pauci-immune glomerulonephritis are associated with p-ANCA (MPO-ANCA)?

{{c1::Microscopic polyangiitis, Churg-strauss syndrome::2}}

What is the most common nephropathy worldwide?

{{c1::IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)}}
{{c1::IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)}} is the renal pathology associated with Henoch-Schonlein purpura
IgA nephropathy typically presents during childhood with episodic gross or microscopic {{c1::hemat}}-uria or {{c2::RBC}} casts
IgA nephropathy typically follows a(n) {{c1::respiratory}} or {{c2::GI tract}} infection
IgA nephropathy is characterized by {{c1::mesangial}} proliferation on light microscopy
IgA nephropathy is characterized by {{c1::mesangial::location}} immune complex deposits on electron microscopy
Berger disease is characterized by Ig{{c1::A}}-based immune complex deposits in the {{c2::mesangium}} (seen with immunofluorescence)
IgA nephropathy (Berger disease) may slowly progress to {{c1::renal failure}}
{{c1::Alport}} syndrome is an inherited defect in type {{c2::IV}} collagen

What is the most common mode of inheritance of Alport syndrome?

{{c1::X-linked dominant}}
{{c3::Alport}} syndrome is characterized by {{c1::thinning}} and {{c2::splitting}} of the glomerular basement membrane
{{c4::Alport}} syndrome often presents with a triad of {{c3::ocular}} disturbances, isolated {{c1::hematuria}}, and sensory {{c2::hearing}} loss
Alport syndrome is associated with a "{{c1::basket-weave}}" appearance on electron microscopy
UTI most commonly arises due to {{c1::ascending::ascending or descending}} infection
{{c1::Females::gender}} have increased risk for UTI due to a relatively {{c2::short}} urethra

What endocrine pathology is associated with UTI?

{{c1::Diabetes mellitus}}
Impaired {{c1::bladder}} emptying increases risk for UTI
One risk factor for UTI is {{c1::sexual}} activity
One risk factor for UTI is indwelling {{c1::catheters}}
{{c2::Cystitis}} is an infection/inflammation of the {{c1::bladder}}
Cystitis typically presents with {{c1::dys}}-uria, urinary frequency, urgency, and {{c2::suprapubic}} pain

Does cystitis typically present with systemic signs (e.g. fever)?

{{c1::No}}
Cystitis is characterized by {{c1::cloudy}} urine with {{c2::> 10::#}} WBCs/hpf (urinalysis)
Cystitis is characterized by positive {{c1::leukocyte esterase}} due to {{c2::pyuria}}
Cystitis is characterized by positive {{c1::nitrites}}, which indicates gram {{c2::negative}} organisms
The gold standard for diagnosis of cystitis is culture showing > {{c1::100,000}} colony forming units

What infectious organism is the most common (80%) cause of cystitis?

{{c1::E. coli}}

What urease positive, pneumonia-causing bacteria is a common cause of UTI?

{{c1::Klebsiella pneumoniae}}
{{c1::Sterile}} pyuria is the presence of pyuria (> 10 WBCs/hpf and leukocyte esterase) with a negative urine culture
UTI with sterile pyuria suggests {{c1::urethritis}} due to {{c3::Chlamydia trachomatis}} or {{c2::Neisseria gonorrhoeae}}
{{c1::Pyelonephritis}} is an infection of the {{c2::kidney}}
One risk factor for pyelonephritis is {{c1::vesicoureteral}} reflux

What non-pathologic state is associated with increased risk for pyelonephritis?

{{c1::Pregnancy}}
One risk factor for pyelonephritis is urinary tract {{c1::obstruction::not infection}}

Does acute pyelonephritis typically present with systemic signs (e.g. fever, chills)?

{{c1::Yes}}
Acute pyelonephritis may present with {{c1::flank}} pain due to sensitization of the nerves of the kidney capsule
Acute pyelonephritis may present with {{c1::WBCs}} in the urine +/- {{c2::WBC}} casts
One complication of acute pyelonephritis is renal {{c1::papillary}} necrosis
{{c1::Chronic pyelonephritis}} is the result of recurrent episodes of acute pyelonephritis
Chronic {{c3::pyelonephritis}} is characterized by coarse, asymmetric {{c1::corticomedullary}} scarring and {{c2::blunted}} calyces in the kidney
Chronic {{c2::pyelonephritis}} is characterized histologically by renal tubules containing eosinophilic proteinaceous material resembling {{c1::thyroid follicles}}
{{c1::Nephrolithiasis}} is the precipitation of a urinary solute as a stone

Risk factors for nephrolithiasis include:

- high {{c1::solute}} concentration in the urinary filtrate
- low {{c2::urine}} volume
Nephrolithiasis may present as {{c1::colicky::character}} flank pain that radiates to the groin
An obstructed kidney stone may present with unilateral {{c1::flank}} tenderness that radiates to the {{c2::groin}}
Kidney stones may be treated and prevented by encouraging {{c1::fluid}} intake

What is the most common type of kidney stone?

{{c1::Calcium stone (80%)}}

Which type of calcium kidney stone (calcium-oxalate or calcium-phosphate) is more common?

{{c1::Calcium oxalate}}
{{c2::Calcium oxalate}} kidney stones often precipitate due to {{c1::hypocitrat}}-uria
Calcium {{c2::phosphate}} kidney stones precipitate with {{c1::increased}} urine pH
The most common kidney stone presentation is a(n) {{c2::calcium oxalate}} stone in a patient with {{c1::hyper}}-calciuria and {{c1::normo}}-calcemia

What GI pathology is associated with calcium oxalate kidney stones?

{{c1::Crohns disease}}
Crohn disease is associated with calcium oxalate kidney stones due to increased levels of {{c1::oxalate}}

What is the appearance calcium kidney stones on X-ray and CT?

{{c1::Radiopaque}}
{{c2::Calcium}} kidney stones may be treated with {{c1::thiazide}} diuretics
In addition to thiazides, calcium oxalate kidney stones may be treated with {{c1::citrate}} supplementation and a low-{{c2::sodium}} diet

What type of kidney stone may result from ethylene glycol (antifreeze) ingestion?

{{c1::Calcium oxalate}}
{{c2::Calcium oxalate}} kidney stones may result from vitamin {{c1::C}} abuse
The second most common type of kidney stone (15%) is a(n) {{c1::ammonium magnesium phosphate}} stone, also known as {{c2::struvite}}
Ammonium magnesium phosphate kidney stones precipitate with {{c1::high}} urine pH

What is the appearance of ammonium magnesium phosphate kidney stones on X-ray and CT?

{{c1::Radiopaque}}
Ammonium magnesium phosphate kidney stones are caused by {{c1::urease}} positive organisms
Urease positive organisms hydrolyze urea to {{c1::ammonia}}, causing urine alkalinization
Ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) kidney stones classically form {{c1::staghorn calculi}} in renal calyces
The staghorn calculi seen in struvite kidney stones may act as a nidus for {{c1::urinary tract}} infection

What type of kidney stone commonly requires surgical removal due to its size?

{{c1::Ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) stones}}
In addition to surgical removal, treatment of struvite stones involves eradication of underlying {{c1::infection}}
The third most common type of kidney stone (5%) is a(n) {{c1::uric acid}} stone
Uric acid kidney stones precipitate with {{c1::low}} urine pH

What is the appearance of uric acid kidney stones on X-ray?

{{c1::Radiolucent}}

What is the appearance of uric acid kidney stones on CT?

{{c1::Minimally visible}}

What imaging modality may be used to visualize uric acid kidney stones?

{{c1::Ultrasound}}
Risk factors for {{c3::uric acid}} kidney stones include {{c1::hot/arid}} climates and {{c2::low}} urine volume

What type of kidney stone is seen in patients with gout?

{{c1::Uric acid stone}}
{{c2::Uric acid}} kidney stones are often seen in diseases with increased {{c1::cell turnover}} (e.g. leukemia, myeloproliferative disorders)
Treatment of uric acid kidney stones involves {{c1::alkalinization}} of urine (e.g. potassium bicarbonate)
Treatment of uric acid kidney stones may include {{c1::allopurinol}}, especially in patients with gout
{{c1::Cystine}} stones are a rare form of nephrolithiasis, most commonly seen in {{c2::children::age group}}
Cystine kidney stones precipitate with {{c1::low}} urine pH

What is the appearance of cystine kidney stones on X-ray?

{{c1::Faintly radioopaque}}

What is the appearance of cystine kidney stones on CT?

{{c1::Moderately radioopaque (sometimes visible)}}
{{c2::Cystine}} kidney stones are characterized by urine crystals that are {{c1::hexagonal}} in shape

What inherited pathology are cystine kidney stones associated with?

{{c1::Cystinuria}}
Patients with {{c1::cystinuria}} have decreased reabsorption of cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine
Cystine kidney stones may form {{c1::staghorn}} calculi
A positive {{c2::sodium cyanide nitroprusside}} test may help in the diagnosis of {{c1::cystine}} kidney stones
Treatment of cystine kidney stones involves {{c1::alkalinization}} of urine and a low-{{c2::sodium}} diet
Chronic renal failure is most commonly caused by {{c1::diabetes mellitus}}, {{c2::hypertension}}, and {{c3::glomerular}} disease
Renal failure is associated with an inability to make {{c1::urine}} and excrete {{c2::nitrogenous}} wastes
One clinical feature of renal failure is {{c1::uremia}}, which is a symptomatic clinical syndrome marked by increased nitrogenous waste products in the blood (azotemia)

What cardiac pathology is a consequence of uremia (renal failure)?

{{c1::Pericarditis}}
Uremia, a consequence of renal failure, may cause {{c1::platelet}} dysfunction in the blood
Uremia, a consequence of renal failure, may cause {{c1::encephalopathy}} with {{c2::asterixis}}

What GI symptoms are associated with uremia (renal failure)?

{{c1::Nausea, anorexia::2}}
Uremia, a consequence of renal failure, may cause deposition of {{c1::urea}} crystals in the skin

What acid-base disorder is a consequence of renal failure?

{{c1::Metabolic acidosis}}

The consequences of {{c9::renal failure}} may be remembered using the mnemonic "MAD HUNGER":

M.A: {{c1::Metabolic Acidosis}}
D: {{c2::Dyslipidemia}} (especially increased {{c2::triglycerides}})
H: {{c3::Hyperkalemia}}
U: {{c4::Uremia}}
N: {{c5::Na+ / H2O retention}}
G: {{c6::Growth retardation and developmental delay}}
E: {{c7::Erythropoietin failure (anemia)}}
R: {{c8::Renal osteodystrophy}}

What potassium imbalance is a consequence of renal failure?

{{c1::Hyperkalemia}}
One consequence of renal failure is {{c1::Na+}} and {{c1::H2O}} retention with resulting hypertension, heart failure, and pulmonary edema
One consequence of renal failure is {{c1::anemia}} due to decreased {{c2::erythropoietin}} production
Erythropoietin is produced by renal {{c1::peritubular interstitial}} cells

What bone pathology is associated with chronic renal failure?

{{c1::Renal osteodystrophy}}
Chronic renal disease is characterized by {{c1::hypo}}-calcemia
Chronic renal disease is characterized by {{c2::hyper}}-phosphatemia
Hypocalcemia in chronic renal disease is caused, in part, by decreased {{c1::1-α-hydroxylation}} of vitamin D

How do levels of parathyroid hormone change in chronic renal disease?

{{c1::Increased (secondary hyperparathyroidism)}}
Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by {{c1::subperiosteal}} thinning of bones
Treatment of renal failure involves {{c1::dialysis}} or {{c2::renal transplant}}
{{c1::Angiomyolipoma}} is a renal hamartoma comprised of blood vessels, smooth muscle, and adipose tissues
There is an increased frequency of renal angiomyolipoma in patients with {{c1::tuberous sclerosis}}

What is the most common primary renal malignancy?

{{c1::Renal cell carcinoma}}
Renal cell carcinoma is associated with a classic triad of {{c1::hematuria}}, {{c2::palpable mass}}, and {{c3::flank}} pain
Renal cell carcinoma may present with systemic symptoms including {{c1::fever}} and {{c2::weight loss}}

Renal cell carcinoma is associated with "PEAR-aneoplastic" syndromes, producing:

- P{{c1::THrP}}
- E{{c2::PO}}
- A{{c3::CTH}}
- R{{c4::enin}}
Renal cell carcinoma may present with paraneoplastic syndromes, such as secondary {{c1::polycythemia::hematocrit levels}}
Renal cell carcinoma rarely may present with {{c2::left}}-sided {{c1::varicocele}} in males
The most common variant of renal cell carcinoma exhibits {{c1::clear cell}} cytoplasm
Renal cell carcinoma often originates from the {{c1::PCT}} cells of the nephron
Renal cell carcinoma is associated with loss of the {{c1::VHL}} tumor suppressor gene on chromosome {{c2::3p}}
