Loss of the VHL tumor suppressor gene (renal cell carcinoma) leads to increased {{c1::HIF}} transcription factor, which increases VEGF and PDGF
The {{c3::sporadic}} form of renal cell carcinoma classically arises in adult {{c1::males}} (average age is {{c2::60}})
The major risk factor for sporadic form of renal cell carcinoma is {{c1::cigarette smoke}}

In addition to smoking, what is another modifiable risk factor for renal cell carcinoma?

{{c1::Obesity}}
{{c3::Von Hippel-Lindau}} disease is an inherited disease associated with increased risk for {{c1::renal cell}} carcinoma and {{c2::hemangioblastoma}} of the cerebellum

What is the mode of inheritance of von Hippel Lindau disease?

{{c1::Autosomal dominant}}
The N of TNM staging for renal cell carcinoma represents spread to regional lymph nodes (i.e. {{c1::retroperitoneal}} nodes)
Renal cell carcinoma is referred to as a "{{c1::silent}}" cancer because it commonly presents as a metastatic neoplasm
Renal cell carcinoma may invade the renal vein, then IVC, before spreading {{c1::hematogenously}}

What are the top two places renal cell carcinoma typically metastasizes to?

1st - {{c1::Lung}}
2nd - {{c1::Bone}}
Treatment for localized renal cell carcinoma is {{c1::surgical resection}}

How does renal cell carcinoma respond to chemotherapy and radiation therapy?

{{c1::Poor response (resistant)}}

What is the most common renal malignancy of early childhood (ages 2-4)?

{{c1::Wilms tumor}}
{{c2::Wilms}} tumor is a malignant kidney tumor composed primarily of {{c1::blastema}} +/- primitive glomeruli, tubules, and stromal cells
Wilms tumor presents as a large, {{c1::uni}}-lateral {{c2::flank}} mass and/or {{c3::hematuria}}
Wilms tumor may present with {{c1::hypertension}} due to increased {{c2::renin}} secretion
Wilms tumor is caused by "loss of function" mutations of tumor suppression genes {{c1::WT1}} or {{c1::WT2}} on chromosome {{c2::11}}

WAGR syndrome is a combination of:

- W{{c1::ilms tumor}}
- A{{c2::niridia (absence of iris)}}
- G{{c3::enital abnormalities}}
- R{{c4::etardation (mental or motor)}}
{{c3::WAGR}} syndrome is associated with a(n) {{c1::WT1}} gene {{c2::deletion}}

{{c5::Beckwith-Wiedemann}} syndrome is a combination of:

1. {{c1::Wilms tumor}}
2. {{c2::Macroglossia}}
3. {{c3::Muscular hemihypertrophy (or hyperplasia)}}
4. {{c4::Organomegaly}}
{{c1::Transitional cell (urothelial)}} carcinoma is the most common tumor of the urinary tract system

Which part of the urinary tract does transitional cell carcinoma most commonly occur?

{{c1::Bladder}}
Transitional cell (urothelial) carcinoma classically presents with {{c2::painless}} {{c1::hematuria}}

What demographic is associated with transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder?

{{c1::Older adults::age group}}
The major risk factor for transitional cell carcinoma is {{c1::cigarette smoke}}

What drugs are risk factors for transitional cell carcinoma?

{{c1::Cyclophosphamide}}, {{c2::Phenacetin}}
{{c2::Transitional (urothelial) cell}} carcinoma is a urinary tract cancer associated with {{c1::aniline (azo)}} dyes
Transitional cell (urothelial) carcinoma tumors are often multifocal and recur due to a "{{c1::field}} defect"
Chronic irritation of the bladder can cause {{c1::squamous}} metaplasia, which may progress to {{c1::squamous}} cell carcinoma

Which part of the urinary tract does squamous cell carcinoma most commonly occur?

{{c1::Bladder}}
Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder arises in a background of {{c1::squamous}} metaplasia
Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder include {{c1::chronic cystitis}} (older women) and smoking
{{c1::Schistosoma haematobium}} infection is associated with {{c4::squamous cell}} carcinoma of the {{c3::bladder}} in {{c2::Middle eastern::ethnicity}} males
One risk factor for squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder is long-standing {{c1::nephrolithiasis::kidney}}

Which part of the urinary tract does adenocarcinoma most commonly occur?

{{c1::Bladder}}
{{c2::Adenocarcinoma}} is a cancer of the bladder that usually arises from a(n) {{c1::urachal}} remnant
Adenocarcinoma arising from a urachal remnant develops at the {{c1::dome}} of the bladder
Adenocarcinoma of the bladder may arise from {{c1::cystitis glandularis}}, which is a(n) {{c2::columnar}} metaplasia in response to chronic inflammation
Adenocarcinoma of the bladder may arise from {{c1::exstrophy}}, which is a congenital failure to form the caudal portion of the anterior abdominal and bladder walls

Where in the nephron do acetazolamide and mannitol primarily exert their effects?

{{c1::Proximal convoluted tubule}}
The Na+-K+ ATPase is located on the {{c1::basolateral}} membrane of the nephron
The Na+-H+ exchanger is located on the {{c1::apical (luminal)}} membrane in the PCT of the nephron
The H+ secreted into the lumen of the PCT combines with {{c1::HCO3-}} to form carbonic acid (H2CO3)

What enzyme catalyzes the conversion of H2CO3 into CO2 and H2O (and its reverse reaction)?

{{c1::Carbonic anhydrase}}
H2CO3 is converted into {{c1::H2O}} and {{c1::CO2}} by carbonic anhydrase
Inside the cells of the PCT, H2O and CO2 are converted back into {{c1::H2CO3}}
The H2CO3 formed inside the cells of the PCT dissociates into {{c1::H+}} and {{c1::HCO3-}}
H+ in the PCT cells, from H2CO3, is transported into the {{c1::lumen}} of the PCT
HCO3- in the PCT cells, from H2CO3, is transported into the {{c1::interstitium}} of the PCT
{{c2::Acetazolamide}} is a diuretic that inhibits the enzyme {{c1::carbonic anhydrase}}
Acetazolamide primarily prevents reabsorption of {{c1::HCO3-}}
Acetazolamide causes urine {{c1::alkalinization::pH}}
In addition to HCO3-, acetazolamide also prevents the reabsorption of {{c1::Na+}} and H2O
Acetazolamide causes {{c1::increased::increased or decreased}} excretion of HCO3-

Besides a type II RTA, what acid-base disorder may be caused by acetazolamide?

{{c1::Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis}}
Acetazolamide causes decreased production of {{c2::aqueous humor}}, which is useful in the management of {{c1::glaucoma}}
Acetazolamide causes decreased production of {{c2::CSF}}, which is useful in the management of {{c1::pseudotumor cerebri}}
Acetazolamide is useful in the treatment and prevention of acute {{c1::altitude}} sickness
Urinary alkalinization (e.g. acetazolamide) can increase solubility of {{c1::cystine}} and {{c2::uric acid}} kidney stones

What effect may acetazolamide have on serum K+ levels?

{{c1::Decreased (hypokalemia)}}

What type of renal tubular acidosis may be caused by acetazolamide?

{{c1::Type 2 (Proximal)}}

Which diuretic can cause type 2 renal tubular acidosis as an adverse effect?

{{c1::Acetazolamide}}
Acetazolamide may promote the formation of calcium {{c1::phosphate}} kidney stones OR {{c2::struvite stones}}
Acetazolamide is a(n) {{c1::sulfa}} drug and thus may cause adverse reactions in allergic patients
One adverse effect associated with acetazolamide is {{c1::NH3::compound}} toxicity

What neurological adverse effect may be caused by acetazolamide?

{{c1::Paresthesias}}

What acid-base disorder may be treated with acetazolamide?

{{c1::Metabolic alkalosis}}
{{c2::Mannitol}} is a(n) {{c1::osmotic}} diuretic that acts at the {{c3::proximal tubule}} and {{c3::descending limb (of Henle)::location}}
Mannitol may be used to decrease {{c1::intracranial}} and {{c2::intraocular}} pressure

What effect does mannitol have on urine flow?

{{c1::Increased urine flow (diuretic)}}
Mannitol may be used clinically for drug {{c1::overdose}}
Mannitol may be used to treat {{c1::elevated}} intracranial and/or intraocular pressure
Mannitol-induced expanded ECF volume can cause pulmonary {{c1::edema}}
Mannitol-induced expanded ECF volume can exacerbate heart {{c1::failure}}

Is mannitol associated with hypernatremia or hyponatremia as a possible adverse effect?

{{c1::Both :)}}
Mannitol is contraindicated in patients with {{c2::anuria}} and/or heart failure

Which osmotic diuretic may cause dehydration as a possible adverse effect?

{{c1::Mannitol}}
The {{c1::fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)}} is the ratio of the Na+ excreted/ Na+ filtered

What equation may be used to calculate the fractional excretion of sodium given the patients GFR?

FENa = {{c1::(V * UNa) / (GFR * PNa)}}

What equation may be used to calculate the fractional excretion of sodium using creatinine as an estimate of GFR?

FENa = {{c1::(PCr * UNa) / (UCr * PNa)}}

Where in the nephron is reabsorption isotonic?

{{c1::PCT}}
{{c1::Fanconi}} syndrome is a renal tubular defect characterized by a generalized reabsorptive defect in the {{c2::PCT::location}} of the nephron

Which renal tubular defect is associated with increased excretion of nearly all amino acids, glucose, HCO3-, and PO43- and all substances reabsorbed by the PCT

{{c1::Fanconi syndrome}}

What acid-base disorder may be seen with Fanconi syndrome?

{{c1::Metabolic acidosis}}

Which type of renal tubular acidosis may be caused by Fanconi syndrome?

{{c1::Type 2 (proximal renal tubular acidosis)}}

Which renal tubular defect may be caused by metabolism disorders (e.g. glycogen storage disease, tyrosinemia, cystinosis)?

{{c1::Fanconi syndrome}}

What renal tubular defect may be caused by ischemia, multiple myeloma, or lead poisoning?

{{c1::Fanconi syndrome}}

What renal tubular defect may be caused by nephrotoxins/drugs (e.g. ifosfamide, cisplatin, tenofovir, expired tetracyclines)?

{{c1::Fanconi syndrome}}
{{c1::Bartter}} syndrome is a renal tubular defect that affects the {{c2::Na+/K+/2Cl-}} cotransporter

Which renal tubular defect presents similarly to chronic loop diuretic use?

{{c1::Bartter syndrome}}

How do serum K+ levels change in Bartter syndrome?

{{c1::Decreased (hypokalemia)}}

What acid-base disorder may be seen with Bartter syndrome?

{{c1::Metabolic alkalosis}}

How does urinary excretion of Ca2+ change in Bartter syndrome?

{{c1::Increased (hypercalciuria)}}

How do levels of plasma renin and aldosterone change in Bartter syndrome?

{{c1::Increased (due to decreased Na+ reabsorption)}}
{{c1::Gitelman}} syndrome is a renal tubular defect that affects the {{c2::Na+-Cl-}} cotransporter

Which renal tubular defect presents similarly to lifelong thiazide diuretic use?

{{c1::Gitelman syndrome}}

How do serum K+ levels change in Gitelman syndrome?

{{c1::Decreased (hypokalemia)}}

What acid-base disorder may be seen with Gitelman syndrome?

{{c1::Metabolic alkalosis}}

How does urinary excretion of Ca2+ change in Gitelman syndrome?

{{c1::Decreased (hypocalciuria)}}

How do levels of plasma renin and aldosterone change in Gitelman syndrome?

{{c1::Increased (due to decreased Na+ reabsorption)}}
{{c1::Liddle}} syndrome is a renal tubular defect that increases activity of the {{c2::epithelial Na+}} channel

How do serum Na+ levels change in Liddle syndrome?

{{c1::Increased (hypernatremia)}}

How do serum K+ levels change in Liddle syndrome?

{{c1::Decreased (hypokalemia)}}

How does blood pressure change in Liddle syndrome?

{{c1::Increased (hypertension)}}

What acid-base disorder may be seen with Liddle syndrome?

{{c1::Metabolic alkalosis}}

How do serum aldosterone levels change in Liddle syndrome?

{{c1::Decreased}}

How do levels of plasma renin change in Liddle syndrome?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What is the treatment for Liddle syndrome?

{{c1::Amiloride}}

{{c1::Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess}} is a renal tubular defect characterized by a(n) {{c3::autosomal recessive}} inherited deficiency of the enzyme {{c2::11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase}}
In cells containing mineralocorticoid receptors, {{c1::cortisol}} may be converted to {{c2::cortisone}} by the enzyme {{c3::11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase}}

Can cortisol activate mineralocorticoid receptors?

{{c1::Yes}}

Can cortisone activate mineralocorticoid receptors?

{{c1::No}}
In syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess, excess {{c1::cortisol}} causes increased mineralocorticoid receptor activity

How do serum K+ levels change in syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess?

{{c1::Decreased (hypokalemia)}}

How does blood pressure change in syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess?

{{c1::Increased (hypertension)}}

What acid-base disorder may be seen with syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess?

{{c1::Metabolic alkalosis}}

How do serum aldosterone levels change in syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess?

{{c1::Decreased}}
{{c1::Glycyrrhetinic acid}} is a substance present in {{c2::licorice}} that may block activity of the enzyme {{c3::11β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase}}

Which renal tubular defect may be caused by ingestion of licorice?

{{c1::Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess}}

Which cell type in the nephron secretes renin?

{{c1::Juxtaglomerular cells}}
{{c2::Juxtaglomerular (JG)}} cells are modified {{c1::smooth muscle}} cells of the afferent arteriole

Which cells of the kidney detect changes in blood pressure?

{{c1::Juxtaglomerular cells}}

Which cells of the kidney detect changes in Na+ delivery?

{{c1::Macula densa cells}}
In response to {{c1::decreased}} blood pressure, the JG cells of the kidney cause increased renin release
In response to {{c1::decreased}} Na+ delivery, the macula densa cells of the kidney cause increased renin release
In response to {{c1::increased}} sympathetic tone, there is increased renin release
Increased sympathetic tone increases renin release via stimulation of the {{c1::β1}} adrenergic receptors of the JGA
β-blockers may decrease BP by inhibiting β1 receptors of the JGA, thus decreasing {{c1::renin}} release
Angiotensin II causes vaso-{{c1::constriction}} of vascular smooth muscle
Angiotensin II acts on the posterior pituitary to increase release of {{c1::ADH}}
Angiotensin II affects baroreceptor function, limiting reflex {{c1::bradycardia}} that would normally accompany its pressor effects

Which hormones are released in response to increased volume, and thus act as a "check" on the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system?

{{c1::ANP, BNP::2}}
{{c1::ADH::aldosterone or ADH}} primarily regulates osmolarity; may also respond to low volume states
{{c1::Aldosterone::aldosterone or ADH}} primarily regulates ECF volume and Na+ content
The juxtaglomerular apparatus consists of {{c1::JG}} cells, {{c2::macula densa}}, extraglomerular {{c3::mesangial}} cells
In response to increased Na+ delivery (e.g. increased GFR/RPF), the macula densa releases {{c1::ATP (adenosine)}}, which constricts the {{c2::afferent}} arterioles
In response to decreased Na+ delivery, the macula densa releases {{c1::PGE2}}, which relaxes the {{c2::afferent}} arterioles
In response to decreased Na+ delivery, the macula densa causes increased renin release, which ultimately constricts the {{c1::efferent}} arterioles
In response to increased Na+ delivery, the macula densa causes decreased renin release, which ultimately relaxes the {{c1::efferent}} arterioles
Erythropoietin is often supplemented in chronic {{c1::kidney::organ}} disease
25-OH vitamin D3 is converted to 1,25 (OH)2 vitamin D3 in cells of the {{c1::PCT}} of the nephron
Parathyroid hormone is secreted in response to increased plasma {{c1::PO43-}}
Prostaglandins act via a(n) {{c1::paracrine}} mechanism to vaso-{{c2::dilate}} the afferent arterioles
{{c1::Dopamine}} is a neurotransmitter that may be secreted by cells of the {{c2::PCT}} of the nephron

What effect do low doses of dopamine have on renal afferent and efferent arterioles?

{{c1::Dilation::dilation or constriction}}

What effect do low doses of dopamine have on RBF?

{{c1::Increased}}

What effect do low doses of dopamine have on GFR?

{{c1::Little or no change}}
At higher doses, dopamine acts as a vaso-{{c1::constrictor}} of renal arterioles

Which electrolyte disturbance causes nausea, malaise, stupor, coma, and seizures?

{{c1::Low Na+ (hyponatremia)}}

Which electrolyte disturbance causes irritability, stupor, coma?

{{c1::High Na+ (hypernatremia)}}

Which electrolyte disturbance causes U waves and flattened T waves on ECG?

{{c1::Low K+ (hypokalemia)}}

Which electrolyte disturbances cause arrhythmias, muscle cramps, spasm, and weakness?

{{c1::Low and high K+::2}}

Which electrolyte disturbance causes wide QRS and peaked T waves on ECG?

{{c1::High K+ (hyperkalemia)}}

Which electrolyte disturbance causes tetany, seizures, QT prolongation, twitching, and spasm?

{{c1::Low Ca2+ (hypocalcemia)}}

Which electrolyte disturbance causes stones, bones, groans, and psychiatric overtones?

{{c1::High Ca2+ (hypercalcemia)}}

Which electrolyte disturbance causes tetany, torsades de pointes, and hypokalemia?

{{c1::Low Mg2+ (hypomagnesemia)}}

Which electrolyte disturbance causes decreased DTRs, cardiac arrest, bradycardia, hypotension, and hypocalcemia?

{{c1::High Mg2+ (hypermagnesemia)}}

Which electrolyte disturbance causes bone loss, osteomalacia (adults), and rickets (children)?

{{c1::Low PO43-}}

Which electrolyte disturbance causes renal stones, metastatic calcifications, and hypocalcemia?

{{c1::High PO43-}}

The causes of {{c9::high}} anion gap metabolic acidosis may be remembered with the mnemonic MUDPILES:

M: {{c1::methanol (formic acid)}}
U: {{c2::uremia}}
D: {{c3::diabetic ketoacidosis}}
P: {{c4::propylene glycol}}
I: {{c5::iron tablets}} or {{c5::isoniazid}}
L: {{c6::lactic acidosis}}
E: {{c7::ethylene glycol (-> oxalic acid)}}
S: {{c8::salicylates (late)}}

The causes of {{c8::normal}} anion gap metabolic acidosis may be remembered with the mnemonic HARDASS:

H: {{c1::hyperalimentation (artificial supply of nutrition)}}
A: {{c2::Addison disease}}
R: {{c3::renal tubular acidosis}}
D: {{c4::diarrhea}}
A: {{c5::acetazolamide}}
S: {{c6::spironolactone}}
S: {{c7::saline infusion}}

What acid-base disorder may be caused by vomiting?

{{c1::Metabolic alkalosis}}
{{c1::Renal tubular acidosis}} is a group of disorders of the renal tubules that lead to normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis
{{c2::Distal}} renal tubular acidosis is also known as type {{c1::1}} RTA
{{c2::Distal}} renal tubular acidosis is characterized by a urine pH {{c1::>}} 5.5
{{c2::Distal}} renal tubular acidosis is due to a defect in the ability of α-intercalated cells to secrete {{c1::H+}}
Inability to secrete H+ by the α-intercalated cells (distal RTA) results in no new {{c1::HCO3-}} generation
Distal renal tubular acidosis is associated with {{c1::hypo}}-kalemia
{{c1::Distal}} renal tubular acidosis is associated with increased risk for calcium {{c2::phosphate}} kidney stones

Which renal tubular acidosis may be caused by amphotericin B toxicity?

{{c1::Distal RTA (type 1)}}

Which renal tubular acidosis may be caused by analgesic nephropathy?

{{c1::Distal RTA (type 1)}}

Which renal tubular acidosis is highly associated with autoimmune diseases?

{{c1::Distal RTA (type 1)}}
{{c2::Proximal}} renal tubular acidosis is also known as type {{c1::2}} RTA
Proximal renal tubular acidosis is characterized by a urine pH {{c1::<}} 5.5
{{c2::Proximal}} renal tubular acidosis is due to a defect in the ability of PCT cells to reabsorb {{c1::HCO3-}}

Which renal tubular acidosis is associated with increased urinary excretion of HCO3-?

{{c1::Proximal RTA (type 2)}}
Proximal renal tubular acidosis is associated with {{c1::hypo}}-kalemia
There is an increased risk for {{c2::hypophosphatemic}} rickets with {{c1::proximal}} renal tubular acidosis due to Fanconi Syndrome
{{c1::Fanconi}} Syndrome and Multiple {{c2::Myeloma}} can both cause proximal (type 2) renal tubular acidosis
{{c2::Proximal}} renal tubular acidosis may be caused by {{c1::carbonic anhydrase}} inhibitors, {{c3::aminoglycosides::antimicrobial}}, and {{c4::lead::metal}}
{{c2::Hyperkalemic}} renal tubular acidosis is also known as type {{c1::4}} RTA
Hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis may be characterized by a urine pH {{c1::<}} 5.5
In hyperkalemic RTA, {{c1::hypoaldosteronism}} causes hyperkalemia
In hyperkalemic RTA, hyperkalemia causes {{c1::decreased}} NH3 synthesis in the PCT
In hyperkalemic RTA, decreased NH3 synthesis in the PCT causes decreased {{c1::NH4+}} excretion

Which renal tubular acidosis may be caused by decreased aldosterone production?

{{c1::Hyperkalemic (type 4) RTA}}

Which renal tubular acidosis may be caused by aldosterone resistance?

{{c1::Hyperkalemic (type 4) RTA}}

What pathologies are characterized by hematuria with no casts?

{{c1::Bladder cancer, Kidney stones::2}}
{{c2::Fatty}} casts ("oval fat bodies") are often associated with the "{{c1::Maltese cross}}" sign

What type of cast may be seen in end-stage renal disease and chronic renal failure?

{{c1::Waxy casts}}
A "{{c1::focal}}" glomerular disorder involves < 50% of glomeruli

Is diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (DPGN) a nephritic or nephrotic syndrome?

{{c1::Can be either or both}}

Which two pathologies may present as nephritic and/or nephrotic syndrome?

{{c1::DPGN, MPGN}}
Hydronephrosis is usually caused by urinary tract {{c1::obstruction}}

Is serum creatinine usually elevated in unilateral hydronephrosis?

{{c1::No}}
{{c1::Diffuse cortical necrosis}} is an acute generalized cortical infarction of both kidneys
Diffuse cortical necrosis is likely due to a combination of {{c1::vasospasm}} and {{c1::DIC}}
{{c2::Diffuse cortical}} necrosis is a renal pathology associated with {{c1::obstetric}} catastrophes and septic shock
{{c3::Urgency}} incontinence may be treated with {{c1::M3}} antagonists or {{c2::β3}} agonists
{{c1::Buerger}} disease may also be referred to as thromboangiitis obliterans
{{c1::Kawasaki}} disease may also be referred to as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis used to be referred to as {{c1::Wegeners granulomatosis}}
Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis may present with paranasal sinus abnormalities and skin nodules / palpable {{c1::purpura}}
{{c1::Secondary}} hyperaldosteronism is seen in patients with renovascular hypertension due to independent activation of the RAAS
One clinical feature of Addison disease is {{c1::metabolic acidosis::H+ levels}}
One clinical feature of Addison disease is {{c1::hypotension::BP}}, due to lack of cortisol
{{c1::Loop}} diuretics exert their effects on the {{c2::thick ascending limb of Henle::location}} of the nephron
The Na+-K+ ATPase is located on the {{c1::basolateral}} membrane of the thick ascending limb (loop of Henle)
The {{c1::Na+-K+-2Cl-}} cotransporter is present on the luminal membrane of the thick ascending limb (of Henle)
The thick ascending limb (of Henle) is {{c1::impermeable}} to water (permeability)

What drug class do furosemide, bumetanide, and torsemide belong to?

{{c1::Loop diuretics}}
{{c2::Loop}} diuretics block the {{c1::Na+-K+-2Cl-}} cotransporter on the luminal membrane of the thick ascending limb

What class of diuretics are the most effective?

{{c1::Loop diuretics}}

What drug class does ethacrynic acid belong to?

{{c1::Loop diuretics}}
{{c3::Loop}} diuretics decrease the lumen positive potential, thus promoting the {{c2::excretion}} of {{c1::Ca2+}} and {{c1::Mg2+}}
Loop diuretics may cause {{c1::hypo}}-magnesemia as an adverse effect
Loop diuretics may cause {{c1::hypo}}-calcemia as an adverse effect
{{c3::Loop}} diuretics induce expression of {{c1::COX-2}}, which leads to synthesis of {{c2::prostaglandins (e.g. PGE)}}
Increased prostaglandin (e.g. loop diuretics) causes vaso-{{c1::dilation}} of the {{c2::afferent}} arteriole

What class of drugs may inhibit the renal-protective aspect of loop diuretics?

{{c1::NSAIDs (decreased prostaglandin synthesis)}}
{{c1::Loop}} diuretics are the 1st line treatment for the symptomatic treatment of acute decompensated heart failure with fluid overload
Loop diuretics may be used to treat the symptoms of pulmonary {{c1::edema}} in an acute heart failure exacerbation

Do loop diuretics prolong life in heart failure?

{{c1::No}}
Loop diuretics may be used to treat {{c1::ascites}} in liver failure (e.g. cirrhosis)
Loop diuretics can be useful in the treatment of {{c1::hypertension}}, especially if other comorbidities are present (e.g. heart failure with edema)
Loop diuretics may be used in the treatment of {{c1::hyper}}-calcemia

What class of renal disorders may be treated with loop diuretics?

{{c1::Nephrotic syndrome}}

What effect may loop diuretics have on serum K+ levels?

{{c1::Decreased (hypokalemia)}}
{{c2::Loop}} diuretics may cause {{c1::oto}}-toxicity as an adverse effect

Which loop diuretic is more ototoxic, furosemide or ethacrynic acid?

{{c1::Ethacrynic acid}}
Most loop diuretics are {{c1::sulfa}} drugs and thus may cause adverse reactions in allergic patients
{{c1::Ethacrynic acid}} is a non-sulfonamide loop diuretic

What renal pathology may be caused by loop diuretics?

{{c1::Interstitial nephritis}}
{{c3::Loop}} and {{c4::thiazide}} diuretics can cause {{c1::hyperuricemia}}, which may lead to precipitation of {{c2::gout}}

What acid-base disorder may be caused by loop diuretics?

{{c1::Metabolic alkalosis}}
The potent diuretic effects of loop diuretics may lead to significant volume loss and thus {{c1::dehydration}}
Ethacrynic acid is used for diuresis in patients allergic to {{c1::sulfa}} drugs, who thus cannot tolerate other loop diuretics
Loop diuretics cause {{c1::decreased::increased or decreased}} hypertonicity of the renal medulla
Decreased medullary hypertonicity (e.g. due to loop diuretics) results in an inability to {{c1::concentrate}} urine
{{c1::Thiazide}} diuretics exert their effects on the {{c2::DCT::location}} of the nephron
The {{c1::Na+-Cl-}} cotransporter is present on the luminal membrane of the DCT
In the {{c1::DCT}} of the nephron, Ca2+ is reabsorbed by an apical Ca2+ channel and a basolateral Na+-Ca2+ exchanger
The early distal convoluted tubule is {{c1::impermeable}} to water (permeability)
Thiazide diuretics {{c1::decrease}} the diluting capacity of the nephron

What drug class does hydrochlorothiazide belong to?

{{c1::Thiazide diuretics}}

What drug class do chlorthalidone, metolazone and indapamide belong to?

{{c1::Thiazide diuretics}}
{{c2::Thiazide}} diuretics block the {{c1::Na+-Cl-}} cotransporter on the luminal membrane of the DCT
Thiazide diuretics increase Ca2+ {{c1::reabsorption}} (excretion or reabsorption)
{{c1::Thiazide}} diuretics are a 1st line agent for treatment of mild or moderate {{c2::hypertension}}
Thiazide diuretics can be useful in the symptomatic treatment of heart {{c1::failure}} (loop diuretics are first line)
{{c2::Thiazide}} diuretics may be useful in the treatment of {{c1::nephrogenic}} diabetes insipidus
{{c2::Thiazide}} diuretics can be used to prevent {{c1::calcium}} kidney stones
{{c1::Thiazide}} diuretics may be useful for attenuating bone loss in patients with osteoporosis
Thiazide diuretics may be useful in the treatment of idiopathic {{c1::hypercalciuria}}
Thiazide diuretics may cause {{c1::hyper}}-calcemia as an adverse effect

What effect may thiazide diuretics have on serum glucose levels?

{{c1::Increased (hyperglycemia)}}

What effect may thiazide diuretics have on serum lipid levels (e.g. cholesterol, triglycerides)?

{{c1::Increased (hyperlipidemia)}}
{{c2::Thiazide}} diuretics may decrease renal excretion of {{c1::lithium}}, which is commonly used as an anti-psychotic drug

What effect may thiazide diuretics have on serum K+ levels?

{{c1::Decreased (hypokalemia)}}
{{c2::Thiazide}} diuretics may cause {{c1::hypo}}-natremia as an adverse effect
Thiazide diuretics are {{c1::sulfa}} drugs and thus may rarely cause allergic reactions

What acid-base disorder may be caused by thiazide diuretics?

{{c1::Metabolic alkalosis}}
K+ sparing diuretics exert their effects on the {{c2::cortical collecting tubules::location}} of the nephron

Which part of the nephron do mineralocorticoids exert their effects?

{{c1::Collecting duct}}
The {{c1::principal}} cells of the collecting duct are the major site of Na+, K+, and H2O transport
Na+ is reabsorbed on the luminal membrane of the collecting duct through {{c1::epithelial Na+}} channels
K+ channels on the luminal membrane of the principal cells of the collecting duct {{c1::secrete::absorb/secrete}} K+
Reabsorption of Na+ in the collecting duct creates a(n) {{c2::negative}} luminal potential that facilitates {{c1::K+}} excretion
The {{c1::α-intercalated}} cells of collecting duct are the major site of H+ secretion
H+ is secreted by {{c1::H+-ATPase}} on the luminal membrane of the α-intercalated cells of the collecting duct

Is the mineralocorticoid receptor an intracellular or membrane receptor?

{{c1::Intracellular}}
Aldosterone upregulates {{c1::K+}} channels on the apical membranes of the principal cells, increasing K+ excretion
Aldosterone upregulates {{c1::ENaCs}} on the apical membrane of the principal cells, increasing Na+ reabsorption
Aldosterone upregulates the {{c1::Na+-K+ ATPase}} pump on the basolateral membrane of the principal cells
Aldosterone upregulates the {{c1::H+ ATPase}} pump on the apical membrane of the α-intercalated cells, increasing H+ excretion
{{c1::Triamterene}} and {{c1::amiloride}} are {{c3::K+ sparing}} diuretics that act by blocking Na+ reabsorption through {{c2::ENaCs}}
{{c1::Eplerenone}} and {{c1::spironolactone}} are {{c3::K+ sparing}} diuretics that act by competitively antagonizing the {{c2::mineralocorticoid}} receptor
{{c2::K+ sparing}} diuretics are useful in the treatment of primary and secondary {{c1::hyper}}-aldosteronism
K+ sparing diuretics (e.g. spironolactone, eplerenone) are useful in the treatment of heart {{c1::failure}}, especially in combination with loop diuretics
{{c2::Mineralocorticoid}} receptor antagonists prevent myocardial {{c1::remodeling}} induced by high levels of aldosterone

Do mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (e.g. spironolactone, eplerenone) prolong life in heart failure?

{{c1::Yes}}
{{c1::Amiloride}}, a K+ sparing diuretic, is useful in the treatment of {{c2::Li+}}-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
{{c2::Amiloride}} and {{c2::triamterene}} are K+ sparing diuretics that may be used to treat {{c1::Liddles}} syndrome, which is characterized by overactive ENaCs

Which ion depletion may be treated with K+ sparing diuretics?

{{c1::K+ depletion (hypokalemia)}}
{{c2::Spironolactone}}, a K+ sparing diuretic, may be used in the treatment of hepatic {{c1::ascites}}
One adverse effect of K+ sparing diuretics is {{c1::hyperkalemia}}, which increases risk for {{c2::arrhythmia}}

What acid-base disorder may be caused by K+-sparing diuretics?

{{c1::Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis}}

What type of renal tubular acidosis may be caused by K+ sparing diuretics?

{{c1::Type 4 RTA}}

{{c1::Spironolactone}}, a K+ sparing diuretic, may be used to treat symptoms of androgen excess in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)

What adverse anti-androgenic effect may be caused by spironolactone use in males?

{{c1::Gynecomastia}}
Spironolactone may cause impotence and decreased {{c1::libido}} as adverse effects

Which diuretics cause an increase in urine NaCl?

{{c1::All diuretics :)}}

What classes of diuretics are characterized by increased urine K+?

{{c1::Loop and thiazide diuretics::2}}

What classes of diuretics are characterized by decreased blood pH (acidemia)?

{{c1::Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, K+ sparing diuretics::2}}

What classes of diuretics cause increased blood pH (alkalemia)?

{{c1::Loop and thiazide diuretics::2}}
In a low K+ state, {{c1::H+}} is exchanged for Na+ in the basolateral membrane of cortical collecting tubule, causing alkalosis and "paradoxical aciduria"

What class of diuretics is characterized by increased urine Ca2+?

{{c1::Loop diuretics}}

What class of diuretics is characterized by decreased urine Ca2+?

{{c1::Thiazide diuretics}}

Which type of nephrotic syndrome is most commonly seen in HIV patients?

{{c1::Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis}}

Which type of kidney stone is associated with staghorn calculi in children?

{{c1::Cystine kidney stones}}
Incremental reductions in {{c1::GFR}} define the stages of chronic kidney disease
Aortic {{c1::dissection}} may present with markedly unequal blood pressure in the arms

What is the male remnant of the müllerian (paramesonephric) duct?

{{c1::Appendix testis}}

+bonus

Which type of lung carcinoma may present with cavitations on CXR?

{{c1::Squamous cell carcinoma}}

Which vitamins are fat-soluble?

{{c1::A, D, E, K::4}}

Is toxicity more common for water-soluble or fat-soluble vitamins?

{{c1::Fat-soluble (vitamins can accumulate in fat)}}
Fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies may occur with {{c1::mineral oil}} intake, which can be used to treat constipation
Fat-soluble deficiencies may occur with syndromes that cause {{c1::steatorrhea}} (e.g. cystic fibrosis and sprue)
Absorption of fat-soluble vitamins is dependent on the {{c1::gut}} and {{c2::pancreas}}
Vitamin {{c1::A}} is also known as {{c2::retinol}}
The {{c1::retinal}} form of vitamin A is a constituent of {{c2::visual}} pigments
Vitamin {{c2::A}} is a co-factor for the synthesis of the visual pigment {{c1::rhodopsin}}

Vitamin {{c2::A}} prevents {{c1::squamous}} metaplasia
Vitamin {{c3::A}} may be used to treat {{c1::measles}} and {{c2::acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML)}}
Vitamin A is found in {{c1::liver}} and {{c2::leafy vegetables}}
Oral {{c2::isotretinoin}} (vitamin A) is used to treat severe cystic {{c1::acne}}

What vitamin is used topically for wrinkles and acne?

{{c1::Vitamin A}}
{{c2::All-trans-retinoic acid}} (vitamin A) is used to treat {{c1::acute promyelocytic leukemia}}
One sign of vitamin {{c2::A}} deficiency is night {{c1::blindness (nyctalopia)}}
One sign of vitamin {{c2::A}} deficiency is dry, scaly {{c1::skin (xerosis cutis)}}
One sign of vitamin {{c2::A}} deficiency is corneal degeneration, known as {{c1::keratomalacia}}

What effect does vitamin A deficiency have on the immune system?

{{c1::Immunosuppression}}

Chronic vitamin {{c2::A}} toxicity may cause {{c1::pseudotumor cerebri::CNS complication}}
Chronic vitamin {{c2::A}} toxicity may cause {{c1::arthralgias::joint complication}}

{{c1::Vitamin A (isotretinoin)}}

Vitamin {{c1::B1}} is also known as {{c2::thiamine}}

What is the coenzyme (active) form of vitamin B1?

{{c1::Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)}}

Thiamine pyrophosphate (B1) is a cofactor for the enzyme {{c1::α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase}} (TCA cycle)
Thiamine pyrophosphate (B1) is a cofactor for the enzyme {{c1::transketolase}} (HMP shunt)
Thiamine pyrophosphate (B1) is a cofactor for the enzyme {{c1::branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase}} (amino acid metabolism)

Vitamin {{c1::B2}} is also known as {{c2::riboflavin}}

Vitamin {{c2::B2}} deficiency may be associated with a(n) {{c1::magenta}}-colored tongue
Vitamin {{c1::B3}} is also known as {{c2::niacin}}

Vitamin B3 (niacin) is involved in many {{c1::redox}} reactions

What vitamin is derived from the amino acid tryptophan?

{{c1::Vitamin B3 (niacin)}}

Mild deficiencies of vitamin B3 cause {{c1::glossitis}}

What is the mode of inheritance of Hartnup disease?

{{c1::Autosomal recessive}}
{{c2::Hartnup}} disease is due to a deficiency of neutral amino acid transporters (especially {{c1::tryptophan}}) in the proximal renal tubular cells and enterocytes

What change in bowel movement is associated with pellagra (B3 deficiency)?

{{c1::Diarrhea}}

What CNS complication is associated with pellagra (B3 deficiency)?

{{c1::Dementia (also hallucinations)}}
{{c3::Pellagra}} is a vitamin deficiency complication associated with {{c1::dermatitis}} in a(n) {{c2::C3/C4}} dermatome distribution

Vitamin {{c3::B3 (niacin)}} excess is characterized by {{c1::facial flushing}}; can be avoided by taking {{c2::NSAIDs}} if given 30-60 minutes before administration
The facial flushing seen with vitamin B3 excess is mediated by {{c1::prostaglandins}}
Vitamin {{c3::B3 (niacin)}} excess is associated with hyper-{{c1::glycemia}} and hyper-{{c2::uricemia}}
Vitamin {{c1::B5}} is also known as {{c2::pantothenic acid}}

Vitamin {{c1::B6}} is also known as {{c2::pyridoxine}}

What is the coenzyme (active) form of vitamin B6?

{{c1::Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP)}}

What vitamin is used as a cofactor for transamination, decarboxylation reactions, and glycogen phosphorylase?

{{c1::B6 (pyridoxal phosphate)}}

What vitamin is used as a cofactor for synthesis of cystathionine, heme, histamine, and neurotransmitters?

{{c1::B6 (pyridoxal phosphate)}}
Vitamin B6 deficiency may occur with {{c1::isoniazid}} and {{c2::oral contraceptive}} use
Vitamin {{c2::B6}} deficiency is characterized by {{c1::sideroblastic}} anemia and {{c3::peripheral neuropathy}}
Vitamin {{c1::B7}} is also known as {{c2::biotin}}

Vitamin B7 (biotin) is a cofactor for the enzyme {{c1::pyruvate carboxylase}} (gluconeogenesis)

Vitamin B7 (biotin) is a cofactor for the enzyme {{c1::propionyl-CoA carboxylase}} (propionyl CoA metabolism)

Which vitamin is important for synthesis of nitrogenous bases in DNA and RNA?

{{c1::B9 (folate)}}
Vitamin B9 (folate) is absorbed in the {{c1::jejunum}} of the small intestine

{{c1::Macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia}}

Vitamin {{c1::B12}} is also known as {{c2::cobalamin}}

{{c1::Diphyllobothrium latum}}

What type of anemia is seen with vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency?

{{c1::Macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia}}

Vitamin {{c1::C}} is also known as {{c2::ascorbic acid}}

What effect does vitamin C deficiency have on the immune system?

{{c1::Weakened immune response}}

What is the storage form of vitamin D?

{{c1::25-OH D3}}

What is the active form of vitamin D?

{{c1::1,25-(OH)2 D3}}

Vitamin {{c2::D}} deficiency is associated with hypocalcemic {{c1::tetany}}

What vitamin should be orally supplemented in breastfed infants?

{{c1::Vitamin D}}

Vitamin E deficiency may cause muscle {{c1::weakness}}

What vitamin deficiency has similar neurologic presentation to B12 deficiency but lacks megaloblastic anemia?

{{c1::Vitamin E deficiency}}
Vitamin {{c1::K}} is also referred to as phytomenadione, phylloquinone, and phytonadione

Does breast milk contain vitamin K?

{{c1::No}}

Vitamin K deficiency is characterized by a(n) {{c1::increased}} PT and {{c1::increased}} PTT
Vitamin K deficiency can occur after prolonged use of broad-spectrum {{c1::antibiotics}}

What vitamins function as antioxidants?

{{c1::Vitamins A, C, and E::3}}

{{c2::Zinc}} deficiency is a trace mineral deficiency that is associated with {{c1::hypo}}-gonadism

{{c1::Taste (dysgeusia)}} and {{c2::smell (anosmia)}}

What mineral deficiency is associated with acrodermatitis enteropathica?

{{c1::Zinc deficiency}}
Zinc deficiency may predispose to alcoholic {{c1::cirrhosis}}
{{c1::Kwashiorkor}} is a malnutrition disorder that results from a(n) {{c2::protein}}-deficient diet

The symptoms of {{c1::Kwashiorkor}} may be remembered with the mnemonic "MEALS":

M: Malnutrition
E: {{c2::Edema}}
A: {{c3::Anemia}}
L: {{c4::Liver (fatty)}}
S: {{c5::Skin lesions (dyspigmentation, hyperkeratosis, etc)}}
Kwashiorkor may present with edema (due to decreased plasma {{c1::oncotic}} pressure) and skin lesions

What malnutrition disorder presents as a small child with a swollen abdomen?

{{c1::Kwashiorkor}}
{{c1::Marasmus}} is a malnutrition disorder that results from a(n) {{c2::calorie}}-deficient diet
{{c1::Marasmus}} is a malnutrition disorder characterized by emaciation with tissue and muscle wasting and loss of subcutaneous fat +/- edema
The neurologic symptoms seen in vitamin B12 deficiency are due to abnormal {{c1::myelin}}
Vitamin B12 deficiency presents with {{c1::paresthesias}} and {{c2::subacute combined degeneration}} (neurologic symptoms)
Subacute combined degeneration in vitamin B12 deficiency affects the {{c1::dorsal columns}}, {{c2::corticospinal tracts}}, and {{c3::spinocerebellar tracts}}
Vitamin E deficiency may cause {{c1::Posterior (Dorsal) Column}} and {{c2::Spinocerebellar tract}} demyelination
Ferrous (Fe2+) iron within the duodenal cell is transported into the blood by the {{c1::ferroportin}} transporter
The Fe3+ iron in the plasma is bound to {{c1::transferrin}} for transport in the blood
{{c1::Hepcidin}} binds to the {{c2::ferroportin}} transporter on intestinal mucosal cells and macrophages, thus {{c3::inhibiting}} iron absorption
Some of the iron absorbed in the duodenum is taken up by {{c1::hepatocytes}} for storage as {{c2::ferritin}}
Some of the iron absorbed in the duodenum is taken up by erythroid precursors in bone marrow to make {{c1::hemoglobin}} for RBCs

In the first step of heme synthesis, {{c1::glycine}} and {{c2::succinyl-CoA}} are combined to form {{c3::δ-aminolevulinic acid}} via the enzyme {{c4::δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase}} (with {{c5::vitamin B6}} as a cofactor)

What is the rate-limiting enzyme of heme synthesis?

{{c1::δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase (ALAS)}}
δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase is regulated via negative feedback by {{c1::glucose}} and {{c2::heme}}

Does heme synthesis occur in the cytoplasm or mitochondria?

{{c1::Both :)}}
δ-aminolevulinic acid is converted to {{c1::porphobilinogen}} via the enzyme {{c2::δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase}} (heme synthesis)
Porphobilinogen is converted to {{c1::hydroxymethylbilane}} via the enzyme {{c2::porphobilinogen deaminase}} (heme synthesis)
Hydroxymethylbilane is converted to {{c1::uroporphyrinogen III}} via the enzyme uroporphyrinogen III synthase (heme synthesis)
Uroporphyrinogen III is converted to {{c1::coproporphyrinogen III}} via the enzyme {{c2::uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase}} (heme synthesis)
Coproporphyrinogen III is converted to {{c1::protoporphyrin}} (heme synthesis)
{{c1::Protoporphyrin}} and {{c2::Fe2+}} combine to form {{c3::heme}} via the enzyme {{c4::ferrochelatase}}
Lead (Pb) poisoning leads to inhibition of the enzymes {{c1::δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase}} and {{c2::ferrochelatase}} (heme synthesis)
In splenic macrophages, heme is metabolized to {{c1::biliverdin}} by the enzyme {{c2::heme oxygenase}}
In splenic macrophages, biliverdin is reduced to {{c1::(unconjugated) bilirubin}}

What type of bilirubin (conjugated or unconjugated) is formed in the splenic macrophages?

{{c1::Unconjugated/indirect bilirubin}}
Unconjugated bilirubin travels in the blood bound to {{c1::albumin}}
Unconjugated bilirubin is removed from the blood by the {{c1::liver::organ}}
In the liver, unconjugated bilirubin is converted to {{c1::conjugated bilirubin}} via the enzyme {{c2::UDP-glucuronyl transferase}}
Conjugated (direct) bilirubin is excreted in bile and metabolized by bacterial flora, producing {{c1::urobilinogen}}
Most (80%) of urobilinogen is excreted in feces as {{c1::stercobilin}}, which gives stool its brown color
~ 18% of urobilinogen is returned to the liver via {{c1::enterohepatic}} circulation
~ 2% of urobilinogen is excreted in urine as {{c1::urobilin}}, which gives urine its yellow color

Is unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin water soluble?

{{c1::No (insoluble)}}

Is conjugated (direct) bilirubin water soluble?

{{c1::Yes}}
The "-ogen" suffix (e.g. urobilinogen) indicates a(n) {{c1::colorless::colored or colorless}} compound
The "-in" suffix (e.g. stercobilin) indicates a(n) {{c1::colored::colored or colorless}} compound

What chromosomal abnormality is commonly associated with endocardial cushion defects?

{{c1::Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome)}}

The effects of {{c10::cholinergic}} toxicity may be remembered with the mnemonic "DUMBBELSS":

D: {{c1::diarrhea}}
U: {{c2::urination}}
M: {{c3::miosis}}
B: {{c4::bronchospasm}}
B: {{c5::bradycardia/bradypnea}}
E: {{c6::excitation of skeletal muscle and CNS}}
L: {{c7::lacrimation}}
S: {{c8::salivation}}
S: {{c9::sweating}}

The cells in {{c2::hairy cell}} leukemia stain positive for {{c1::tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP)}}
Positive TRAP stain for diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia has been largely replaced with {{c1::flow cytometry}}
Patients with hairy cell leukemia typically present with massive {{c1::splenomegaly}} due to expansion of the {{c2::red}} pulp
{{c2::Hairy cell}} leukemia causes marrow fibrosis, which results in a  "{{c1::dry tap}}" on bone marrow aspiration

Does hairy cell leukemia typically present with lymphadenopathy?

{{c1::No}}
Hairy cell leukemia has an excellent response to {{c1::cladribine (2-CDA)}}, which is an adenosine deaminase inhibitor
In addition to cladribine (2-CDA), hairy cell leukemia may also be treated with {{c1::pentostatin}}

What demographic is associated with hairy cell leukemia?

{{c1::Adult males::age/gender}}
Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) is a neoplastic proliferation of mature {{c1::CD4+ T::specific}} cells
{{c2::Adult T-cell}} leukemia/lymphoma is caused by the {{c1::HTLV-1}} virus
The HTLV-1 virus (cause of ATLL) is associated with {{c1::IV drug}} users

What regions are most commonly affected by adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma?

{{c1::Japan}}, {{c2::West Africa}}, and the {{c3::Caribbean}}
Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma may present with {{c1::cutaneous lesions (rash)}} due to skin infiltration
{{c3::Adult T-cell}} leukemia/lymphoma may present with {{c1::lytic (punched-out)}} {{c2::bone}} lesions and hypercalcemia

How can adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma be distinguished from multiple myeloma?

{{c1::ATLL causes a rash}}
Mycosis fungoides is a neoplastic proliferation of mature {{c1::CD4+ T::name and type}} cells
Mycosis fungoides typically presents in adults with {{c1::skin}} patches/plaques
The aggregates of neoplastic cells in the epidermis seen with mycosis fungoides are called {{c1::Pautrier microabscesses}}
Mycosis fungoides may spread to involve the blood, producing {{c1::Sézary}} syndrome (T-cell leukemia)
{{c2::Sézary}} syndrome is characterized by atypical CD4+ cells with {{c1::cerebriform}} nuclei seen on blood smear
{{c1::Myeloproliferative}} disorders are neoplastic proliferations of mature cells of myeloid lineage
Myeloproliferative disorders most commonly present in {{c1::late adulthood (50 - 60 years old)::age group}}
Myeloproliferative disorders may cause {{c1::hyperuricemia}} and {{c2::gout}} due to high turnover of cells
Myeloproliferative disorders may progress to marrow {{c1::fibrosis}} or transform to acute leukemia
Chronic myeloproliferative disorders (except CML) are associated with {{c1::V617F JAK2}} mutations
{{c1::Chronic myeloid}} leukemia is a neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially {{c2::granulocytes}} and their precursors (basophil, neutrophil, eosinophils)
{{c2::Chronic myeloid}} leukemia is defined by the t({{c1::9}};{{c1::22}}) translocation
Chronic myeloid leukemia* responds well to tyrosine kinase inhibitors, such as {{c1::imatinib}}
Chronic myeloid leukemia commonly results in {{c1::spleno}}-megaly
An enlarging {{c1::spleen}} in CML suggests progression to accelerated disease ("blast crisis")
CML may transform to acute {{c1::myeloid}} leukemia (2/3rd of cases)
CML may transform to acute {{c1::lymphoid}} leukemia (1/3rd of transformations)
CML is distinguished from a leukemoid reaction (benign neutrophilia) by presence of increased {{c1::basophils}}
CML is distinguished from a leukemoid reaction (benign neutrophilia) by a(n) {{c2::negative}} {{c1::leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP)}} stain
{{c1::Polycythemia vera}} is a neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially {{c2::red blood}} cells
Polycythemia vera is a form of {{c1::primary::primary or secondary}} polycythemia
Polycythemia vera may present with symptoms of {{c1::hyperviscosity}} of the blood (e.g. blurry vision, headache)
Polycythemia vera increases risk of venous and arterial {{c1::thrombosis}}
Polycythemia vera rarely may cause {{c1::erythromelalgia}}, which is characterized by severe, burning pain and red-blood discoloration
{{c2::Polycythemia vera}} classically presents with intense {{c1::itching}}, especially after a hot shower
The 1st line treatment for polycythemia vera is {{c1::phlebotomy}}; second-line therapy is {{c2::hydroxyurea}}
Patients with polycythemia vera may take low-dose {{c1::aspirin}} to decrease risk of thrombosis
Polycythemia vera is characterized by {{c1::increased}} plasma volume
Polycythemia vera is characterized by {{c1::significantly increased}} RBC mass
Polycythemia vera is characterized by {{c1::decreased}} EPO
Relative polycythemia is characterized by {{c1::decreased}} plasma volume
Relative polycythemia is characterized by {{c1::normal}} RBC mass
Relative polycythemia is characterized by {{c1::normal}} EPO

Which form of polycythemia is associated with dehydration and burns?

{{c1::Relative polycythemia (relative erythrocytosis / hemoconcentration)}}
Appropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by {{c1::increased}} RBC mass
Appropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by {{c1::increased}} EPO
{{c2::Appropriate}} absolute polycythemia is characterized by {{c1::decreased}} O2 saturation

Which form of polycythemia is associated with lung disease (ex. COPD / obstructive sleep apnea), congenital heart disease, high altitude, or low birth weight?

{{c1::Appropriate absolute polycythemia (appropriate secondary erythrocytosis)}}
Inappropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by {{c1::increased}} RBC mass
Inappropriate absolute polycythemia is characterized by {{c1::increased}} EPO
{{c2::Inappropriate}} absolute polycythemia is characterized by {{c1::normal}} O2 saturation

Which form of polycythemia is associated with ectopic EPO production (e.g. malignancy, hydronephrosis & renal cysts) or exogenous EPO?

{{c1::Inappropriate absolute polycythemia (innapropriate secondary erythrocytosis)}}
{{c1::Essential thrombocythemia (ET)}} is a neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially {{c2::platelets}}
Blood smear of essential {{c1::thrombocythemia}} shows markedly increased number of platelets, which may be large or abnormally formed
Symptoms of essential thrombocythemia are related to an increased risk of {{c1::bleeding}} and/or {{c2::thrombosis}}

Are patients with essential thrombocythemia (ET) at risk for marrow fibrosis and/or acute leukemia?

{{c1::No (rare)}}

Does essential thrombocythemia (ET) present with significant risk for hyperuricemia and gout?

{{c1::No}}
{{c1::Myelofibrosis}} is a neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially {{c2::megakaryocytes}}
In myelofibrosis, megakaryocytes produce excess {{c1::platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)}} and {{c1::TGF-b}}, causing marrow fibrosis
Myelofibrosis is often associated with massive {{c1::splenomegaly}} due to extramedullary hematopoiesis

Myelofibrosis is characterized by a(n) {{c1::leukoerythroblastic}} smear (increased nucleated RBCs and immature granulocytes)

Why?
Myelofibrosis causes increased risk of infection, thrombosis, and bleeding due to {{c1::pancytopenia}}

What pathologic RBC is associated with myelofibrosis?

{{c1::"Tear drop" cells (dacrocyte)}}
Polycythemia vera is characterized by {{c1::increased}} WBCs
Polycythemia vera is characterized by {{c1::increased}} platelets

Is polycythemia vera associated with JAK2 mutations?

{{c1::Yes}}

Is essential thrombocythemia associated with JAK2 mutations?

{{c1::Yes (30-50%)}}

Is myelofibrosis associated with JAK2 mutations?

{{c1::Yes (30-50%)}}

Is chronic myeloid leukemia associated with JAK2 mutations?

{{c1::No (associated with Philadelphia chromosome)}}
{{c1::Lymphomas::leukemias or lymphomas}} are neoplastic proliferations of lymphoid cells that form a mass
{{c1::Follicular}} lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of small B cells (CD20+) that form follicle-like nodules
Follicular lymphoma typically presents in {{c1::late adulthood::age group}}
{{c2::Follicular}} lymphoma is characterized by painless "{{c1::waxing and waning}}" lymphadenopathy
{{c2::Follicular}} lymphoma is driven by a t({{c1::14}};{{c1::18}}) translocation

What chromosome is BCL2 located on?

{{c1::Chromosome 18}}
The t({{c3::14}};{{c3::18}}) translocation results in overexpression of {{c1::Bcl2}}, resulting in inhibition of {{c2::apoptosis}}
Treatment of follicular lymphoma is reserved for symptomatic patients and involves low-dose chemotherapy or {{c1::rituximab}} (anti-CD20 antibody)
Follicular lymphoma is distinguished from reactive follicular hyperplasia by expression of {{c1::Bcl2}} in follicles
Follicular lymphoma is distinguished from reactive follicular hyperplasia by {{c1::mono}}-clonality

Is follicular lymphoma typically aggressive or indolent?

{{c1::Indolent}}
{{c1::Mantle cell}} lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of small B cells (CD20+ & CD{{c2::5}}+) that expands into the mantle zone

What demographic is associated with mantle cell lymphoma?

{{c1::Adult males}}
{{c2::Mantle cell}} lymphoma is driven by a t({{c1::11}};{{c1::14}}) translocation
The t({{c3::11}};{{c3::14}}) translocation results in overexpression of {{c1::Cyclin D1}}, which promotes the {{c2::G1/S}} transition in the cell cycle, facilitating neoplastic proliferation
{{c1::Marginal zone}} lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of small B cells (CD20+) that expands into the marginal zone
{{c1::Marginal zone}} lymphoma is associated with chronic inflammatory states (e.g. Hashimoto thyroiditis, Sjögrens syndrome, H. pylori gastritis)
{{c1::MALToma}} is a form of marginal zone lymphoma in mucosal sites
Gastric MALTomas may regress with treatment of {{c1::H. pylori}}
{{c1::Burkitt}} lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of intermediate-sized B cells (CD20+)
Endemic Burkitt lymphoma is associated with {{c1::EBV}} infection
Burkitt lymphoma classically presents as an extranodal mass in a(n) {{c1::child}} or {{c1::young adult::age group}}
{{c2::Burkitt}} lymphoma is driven by a t({{c1::8}};{{c1::14}}) translocation
The t({{c2::8}},{{c2::14}}) translocation results in overexpression of {{c1::c-myc}}, which promotes growth
{{c2::Burkitt}} lymphoma is characterized by a high {{c3::mitotic index}} and "{{c1::starry-sky}}" appearance on microscopy
{{c1::Diffuse large B-cell}} lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of large B cells (CD20+) that grow diffusely in sheets

What is the most common form of non-Hodgkins lymphoma?

{{c1::Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL)}}
While diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is usually seen in older adults, {{c1::20}}% of cases occur in children
{{c2::Hodgkin}} lymphoma is a neoplastic proliferation of {{c1::Reed-Sternberg}} cells
{{c2::Reed-Sternberg}} cells are large {{c1::B}} cells with multilobed nuclei and prominent nucleoli ("owl eye" appearance)
Reed-Sternberg cells are classically positive for CD-{{c1::15}} and CD-{{c1::30}}
Reed-Sternberg cells secrete {{c1::cytokines}}, which attract other inflammatory cells
Reed-Sternberg cells occasionally result in "{{c1::B}}" symptoms (fever, chills, weight loss, night sweats)

What is the most common subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma (70%)?

{{c1::Nodular sclerosis}}

What demographic is classically associated with the nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma?

{{c1::Young adult females::age and gender}}
The {{c1::nodular sclerosis}} subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma typically presents as an enlarging cervical or {{c2::mediastinal}} lymph node in a female

Which subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma has the best prognosis?

{{c1::Lymphocyte-rich}}

Which subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma is often associated with abundant eosinophils?

{{c1::Mixed-cellularity}}

Which subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma is the most aggressive?

{{c1::Lymphocyte-depleted}}

Which type of lymphoma is associated with masses composed of lymphoid cells?

{{c1::Non-Hodgkin lymphoma::Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin}}

Which type of lymphoma is characterized by contiguous spread?

{{c1::Hodgkin lymphoma::Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin}}

Which type of lymphoma is characterized by non-contiguous spread?

{{c1::Non-Hodgkin lymphoma::Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin}}

Which type of lymphoma is associated with extranodal involvement?

{{c1::Non-Hodgkin lymphoma::Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin}}
{{c2::Staging}} is important and the strongest predictor of prognosis for {{c1::Hodgkin::Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin}} lymphoma
{{c1::Radiation}} is the mainstay of treatment for Hodgkin lymphoma
Hodgkin lymphoma has a bimodal distribution: common in {{c1::young adulthood}} and {{c2::adults > 55 years}}
{{c2::Multiple myeloma}} is a malignant proliferation of {{c3::mono}}-clonal {{c1::plasma}} cells in the bone marrow
Multiple myeloma is associated with high serum IL-{{c1::6}}, which stimulates plasma cell growth and immunoglobulin production
Multiple myeloma presents with {{c1::lytic (punched-out)}} {{c2::bone}} lesions and hypercalcemia
The bone lesions seen with multiple myeloma are most common in the {{c1::vertebrae}} and {{c2::skull}}
Multiple myeloma is associated with {{c1::M spike}} on serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP)
The M spike seen in {{c3::multiple myeloma}} is most commonly due to monoclonal {{c1::IgG}} (55%) or {{c2::IgA}} (25%)
Multiple myeloma is associated with increased risk of {{c1::infection}} due to lack of {{c2::antigenic}} diversity of monoclonal antibodies

What is the most common cause of death in multiple myeloma?

{{c1::Infection}}
Multiple myeloma is associated with {{c1::Rouleaux formation}} of RBCs on blood smear
Multiple myeloma may deposit in tissue, causing {{c1::primary (AL)}} amyloidosis
{{c3::Multiple myeloma}} is associated with free {{c1::light chain}} excretion in the urine, known as {{c2::Bence Jones}} proteinuria
In multiple myeloma, free light chain (Bence Jones protein) may deposit in kidney tubules, leading to risk for {{c1::renal failure (myeloma kidney)}}

The signs/symptoms of {{c6::multiple myeloma}} may be remembered with the mnemonic "CRAB":

C: {{c1::hyperCalcemia}}
R: {{c2::Renal involvement, height Reduction}}
A: {{c3::Anemia*}}
B: {{c4::Bone lytic lesions}} / {{c5::Back pain}}
{{c1::Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)}} is an asymptomatic condition characterized by an M spike on SPEP without other features of multiple myeloma
1-2% of patients with monoclonal gammopathy of underdetermined significance (MGUS) develop {{c1::multiple myeloma}} per year
{{c1::Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia}} is a B-cell lymphoma with monoclonal IgM production

Does Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia present with lytic bone lesions?

{{c1::No}}
The M spike seen in {{c2::Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia}} is due to monoclonal Ig{{c1::M}}
Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia typically presents with {{c1::visual}} and {{c2::neurologic}} deficits without CRAB symptoms of multiple myeloma
Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is associated with symptoms of {{c1::hyperviscosity}} (due to large size of IgM pentamer)
Acute complications of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia are treated with {{c1::plasmapheresis}}, which removes IgM from the serum

Which Langerhans cell histiocytosis presents as scalp rash, lytic skull lesions, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos?

{{c1::Hand-Schüller-Christian disease}}
{{c1::Acute lymphoblastic}} leukemia is associated with the t(12;21) translocation
The t(9;22) translocation (BCR-ABL) is also known as the {{c1::Philadelphia}} chromosome
The innermost layer of the gut wall is the {{c1::mucosa}}
The mucosa of the gut wall consists of three layers: a(n) {{c1::epithelium}}, {{c2::lamina propria}}, and {{c3::muscularis mucosa}}
External to the mucosal layer of the gut wall is the {{c1::submucosa}}
External to the submucosal layer of the gut wall is the {{c1::muscularis externa}}
The muscularis externa of the gut wall consists of an inner {{c1::circular}} and an outer {{c1::longitudinal}} muscle layer
The {{c1::myenteric (Auerbach)}} nerve plexus lies between the circular and longitudinal muscles layers of the gut wall
The {{c1::submucosal (Meissner)}} nerve plexus lies between the submucosa and inner circular muscle layer of the gut wall
The outermost layer of the gut wall is the {{c1::serosa}} (when intraperitoneal)
The outermost layer of the gut wall is the {{c1::adventitia}} (when retroperitoneal)

Which gut wall layer contains Meissners plexus?

{{c1::Submucosa}}

Which gut wall layer contains Auerbachs plexus?

{{c1::Muscularis externa}}
Post-ganglionic sympathetic and Pre-ganglionic parasympathetic neurons supplying the GI tract synapse in the {{c1::myenteric}} or {{c1::submucosal plexuses}}
The {{c1::enteric}} nervous system can direct all functions of the GI tract, even in the absence of extrinsic innervation (e.g. PNS/SNS)
The {{c1::submucosal (Meissners)}} plexus of the gut wall primarily controls secretion and blood flow
The {{c1::myenteric (Auerbach)}} plexus of the gut wall primarily controls motility
{{c4::Gastrin}} is secreted from {{c1::G}} cells in the {{c2::antrum}} of the stomach and the {{c3::duodenum}}
One function of gastrin is to {{c1::increase}} gastric H+ secretion
One function of gastrin is to increase growth of {{c1::gastric mucosa}} and {{c2::parietal cells}}
One function of gastrin is to {{c1::increase}} gastric motility
Gastrin secretion is most stimulated by stomach {{c1::distention}}
Gastrin secretion is {{c2::stimulated}} by {{c1::high}} pH of gastric contents
Gastrin secretion is stimulated by vagal stimulation via the neuropeptide {{c1::gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP, bombesin)}}

Is the vagal stimulation of G cells (gastrin secretion) inhibited by atropine?

{{c1::No}}

Which nutrient stimulates gastrin secretion?

{{c1::Protein (amino acids)::glucose, fat, protein}}
Of the amino acids, {{c1::phenylalanine}} and {{c2::tryptophan}} are the most potent stimuli for gastrin secretion
Gastrin secretion is {{c2::inhibited}} by {{c1::low}} pH of gastric contents
Gastrin secretion is {{c1::inhibited}} by somatostatin
The minimum fragment necessary for biologic activity of gastrin is the {{c1::C-terminal tetrapeptide}}

How does gastrin secretion change with chronic PPI use?

{{c1::Increased}}

How does gastrin secretion change with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome?

{{c1::Very increased}}
{{c2::Zollinger-Ellison}} syndrome is caused by a(n) {{c1::gastrinoma}} of the pancreas (non-β cells) or duodenum
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is characterized by acid hypersecretion, causing recurrent {{c1::ulcers}} in the {{c2::duodenum}} and {{c3::jejunum}}
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome may present with {{c1::abdominal}} pain, due to peptic ulcer disease and distal ulcers
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome may present with {{c1::steatorrhea}} due to inactivation of pancreatic lipases
{{c2::Zollinger-Ellison}} syndrome is diagnosed with a positive {{c1::secretin stimulation}} test
A secretin stimulation test is positive if gastrin levels {{c1::increase}} after administration of secretin

What endocrine disorder may be associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome?

{{c1::MEN 1}}
{{c4::Cholecystokinin (CCK)}} is secreted from {{c1::I}} cells in the {{c2::duodenum}} and the {{c3::jejunum}}
One function of cholecystokinin is to increase secretion of {{c1::pancreatic}} enzymes
One function of cholecystokinin is to increase {{c1::contraction}} of the gallbladder
One function of cholecystokinin is to increase {{c1::relaxation}} of the sphincter of Oddi
One function of cholecystokinin is to {{c1::decrease}} gastric emptying
Cholecystokinin secretion is stimulated by {{c1::fatty acids}} and {{c2::amino acids}}

Which cholecystokinin receptor is equally sensitive to gastrin and CCK?

{{c1::CCKB}}
{{c3::Secretin}} is secreted from {{c1::S}} cells in the {{c2::duodenum}}
One function of secretin is to increase secretion of pancreatic {{c1::HCO3-}}
One function of secretin is to {{c1::increase}} bile secretion
One function of secretin is to {{c1::decrease}} gastric acid secretion and {{c1::increase}} pyloric sphincter contraction
Secretin is secreted in response to {{c1::H+}} and {{c2::fatty acids}} in the lumen of the duodenum
{{c4::Glucose-insulinotropic peptide (GIP)}} is secreted from {{c1::K}} cells in the {{c2::duodenum}} and {{c3::jejunum}}
The {{c1::oral::oral or IV?}} form of glucose administration leads to greater insulin release due to stimulation of {{c2::GIP}} and {{c2::GLP-1}} secretion
Motilin is secreted from the small intestine during {{c1::fasting::fed or fasting}} states
{{c2::Motilin}} is a hormone that initiates {{c1::migrating motor complexes (MMCs)}} at 90-minute intervals between meals
Motilin receptor agonists, such as {{c1::erythromycin}}, are used to stimulate intestinal peristalsis
{{c2::Somatostatin}} is secreted from {{c1::D}} cells in the GI mucosa
Somatostatin secretion is stimulated by {{c1::low::high or low}} pH in the GI mucosa
Somatostatin secretion is {{c1::decreased}} in response to vagal stimulation

What effect does somatostatin have on gastric acid secretion?

{{c1::Decreased secretion}}

What effect does somatostatin have on pancreatic/small intestinal fluid secretion?

{{c1::Decreased secretion}}

What effect does somatostatin have on gallbladder contraction?

{{c1::Decreased contraction}}

What effect does somatostatin have on insulin and glucagon secretion?

{{c1::Decreased secretion}}
Leptin is secreted by fat cells and acts to {{c1::decrease}} appetite
Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) is secreted from {{c1::parasympathetic}} neurons in the gallbladder, small intestine, and sphincters
Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) causes {{c1::relaxation}} of GI smooth muscle and sphincters (including LES)
Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) causes {{c1::increased}} intestinal H2O and electrolyte secretion
{{c1::VIPoma}} is a non-α, non-β, non-δ islet cell pancreatic tumor that secretes VIP (also known as WDHA syndrome)
{{c4::VIPoma}} is characterized by a triad of {{c1::watery diarrhea}}, {{c2::hypokalemia}}, and {{c3::achlorhydria}}
{{c1::Slow waves}} are oscillating membrane potentials inherent to the smooth muscle cells of some parts of the GI tract
The frequency of slow waves in the stomach is {{c1::3}} waves/minute
The frequency of slow waves in the duodenum is {{c1::12}} waves/minute
The frequency of slow waves in the ileum is {{c1::8 - 9}} waves/minute

Which portion of the GI tract has the lowest rate of slow waves?

{{c1::Stomach (3 waves/min)}}

Which portion of the GI tract has the highest rate of slow waves?

{{c1::Duodenum (12 waves/min)}}
Slow waves originate in the {{c1::interstitial cells of Cajal}}, which serve as the pacemaker for GI smooth muscle
Slow waves of the GI tract are produced via cyclic opening of {{c1::Ca2+}} channels (depolarization), followed by opening of {{c2::K+}} channels (repolarization)
The {{c1::upper}} esophageal sphincter prevents air from entering the esophagus
The {{c1::lower}} esophageal sphincter prevents gastric contents from entering the esophagus
The {{c1::orad}} region of the stomach is thin-walled and includes the fundus and proximal body
The {{c1::caudad}} region of the stomach is thick-walled and includes the distal body and antrum

Which region of the stomach (orad or caudad) is responsible for the strong contractions that mix food with gastric secretions?

{{c1::Caudad}}
Saliva is formed by three major glands: {{c1::parotid}}, {{c2::submandibular}}, and {{c3::sublingual}}
The {{c2::acinar}} cells of salivary glands secrete the initial saliva, which is {{c1::iso}}-tonic and in similar composition to plasma
The {{c2::ductal}} cells modify the initial saliva via {{c1::absorption}} of Na+ and Cl-
The ductal cells modify the initial saliva via {{c1::secretion}} of K+ and HCO3-
Saliva is characterized by {{c1::high}} K+ and HCO3- concentration relative to plasma
Saliva is characterized by {{c1::low}} Na+ and Cl- concentration relative to plasma
Saliva is {{c1::hypo}}-tonic relative to plasma

What salivary enzyme begins the initial digestion of carbohydrates?

{{c1::α-amylase}}

What salivary enzyme begins the initial digestion of fats?

{{c1::Lingual lipase}}

What salivary enzyme cleaves kininogen into bradykinin, a potent vasodilator?

{{c1::Kallikrein}}
At the {{c1::highest}} flow rates, saliva is most similar to plasma (high Na+ and Cl-, low K+)
At the {{c1::lowest}} flow rates, saliva is most dissimilar to plasma (high K+, low Na+ and Cl-)
The levels of salivary HCO3- increase with {{c1::increased}} flow rate

What is the effect of parasympathetic innervation on salivary secretion?

{{c1::Increased secretion}}

What is the effect of sympathetic innervation on salivary secretion?

{{c1::Increased secretion}}
{{c4::Parietal}} cells are located in the {{c3::body}} of the stomach and secrete {{c1::HCl}} and {{c2::intrinsic factor}}

{{c3::Chief}} cells are located in the {{c2::body}} of the stomach and secrete {{c1::pepsinogen}}

*bonus: also secretes...
Pepsinogen (inactive) is converted into {{c1::pepsin}} (active) in the presence of {{c2::H+}}
In the first step of gastric acid secretion, CO2 and H2O combine to form H2CO3 via the enzyme {{c1::carbonic anhydrase}}
The H+ from H2CO3 is secreted from the parietal cell via the {{c1::H+-K+ ATPase}} pump
Cl- in the parietal cell follows H+ into the lumen by diffusing through {{c1::Cl-}} channels
The HCO3- from H2CO3 is absorbed from the parietal cell into the blood via the {{c1::Cl--HCO3-}} exchanger
The increased {{c2::blood}} pH following gastric acid secretion is referred to as the "{{c1::alkaline tide}}" (e.g. after meals, vomiting)
{{c2::Histamine}} is released from {{c1::enterochromaffin-like (ECL)}} cells in the gastric mucosa
Histamine binds to {{c1::H2}} receptors on parietal cells, causing {{c2::increased}} H+ secretion
Vagal stimulation increases H+ secretion directly via binding of {{c2::acetylcholine}} to {{c1::M3}} receptors on parietal cells
{{c2::Vagal}} stimulation increases H+ secretion indirectly via binding of {{c1::GRP}} to G cells
Gastrin increases H+ secretion directly via binding to {{c1::CCKB}} receptors on parietal cells
{{c1::Gastrin}} increases H+ secretion indirectly by causing histamine release from ECL cells
Gastrin increases acid secretion primarily through its effects on {{c1::ECL::parietal or ECL}} cells

What type of signaling mechanism does gastrin use to reach parietal cells?

{{c1::Endocrine (enters systemic circulation)::endocrine or paracrine}}

What type of signaling mechanism does histamine use to reach parietal cells?

{{c1::Paracrine (locally diffuses)::endocrine or paracrine}}

Which second messenger is released upon binding of gastrin to CCKB receptors?

{{c1::IP3/Ca2+}}

Which second messenger is increased upon binding of histamine to H2 receptors?

{{c1::cAMP}}
The {{c1::cephalic}} phase of gastric HCl secretion accounts for 30% of total HCl secreted
Gastric HCl secretion during the {{c2::cephalic}} phase is mediated by {{c1::vagal stimulation}} only
The {{c1::gastric}} phase of gastric HCl secretion accounts for 60% of total HCl secreted
Gastric HCl secretion during the {{c1::gastric}} phase is mediated by both vagal stimulation and direct gastrin release

What effect does alcohol and caffeine have on gastric HCl secretion?

{{c1::Increased secretion}}
Somatostatin decreases gastric acid secretion by decreasing levels of {{c1::cAMP::second messenger}}

What effect do prostaglandins have on gastric acid secretion?

{{c1::Decreased secretion}}
Prostaglandins decrease gastric acid secretion by decreasing levels of {{c1::cAMP}} (second messenger)
Pepsinogen is secreted in response to {{c1::vagal stimulation}} and {{c2::local H+}}
Mucus is secreted into the GI tract via {{c1::Brunner}} glands in the duodenum

Are the concentrations of Na+ and K+ in pancreatic secretions similar or dissimilar to plasma?

{{c1::Similar}}
Pancreatic secretions are {{c1::iso}}-tonic relative to plasma, regardless of flow rate
At {{c2::low}} flow rates, the pancreatic secretions have high {{c1::Cl-}} concentration
At {{c2::high}} flow rates, the pancreatic secretions have high {{c1::HCO3-}} concentration
The {{c1::enzymatic}} component of pancreatic secretion is secreted by acinar cells
The {{c1::aqueous}} component of pancreatic secretion is secreted by ductal and centroacinar cells
The ductal cells modify the initial pancreatic secretion via {{c1::absorption}} of Cl-
The ductal cells modify the initial pancreatic secretion via {{c1::secretion}} of HCO3-
Release of the aqueous (HCO3-) component of pancreatic secretion is primarily stimulated by {{c1::secretin}}

Which second messenger is released upon binding of cholecystokinin to CCKA receptors?

{{c1::IP3/Ca2+}}
{{c1::Bile}} is composed of bile salts, phospholipids, cholesterol, bilirubin, water, and ions
One component of bile is {{c1::bilirubin}}, which is the major bile pigment
In the liver, bile acids are conjugated to the amino acids {{c1::glycine}} or {{c2::taurine}} to form {{c3::bile salts}}

What is the purpose of conjugating bile acids in the liver?

{{c1::Increase water solubility}}
The bile salts and phospholipids in bile are {{c1::amphipathic}} molecules, which allows for the emulsification and solubilization of lipids in an aqueous environment

Which organ is responsible for synthesis of bile?

{{c1::Liver}}

Which organ is responsible for the storage and concentration of bile?

{{c1::Gallbladder}}

Which hormone provides the major stimulus for bile ejection?

{{c1::Cholecystokinin (CCK)}}
Most of the secreted bile salts are recirculated to the liver via {{c1::enterohepatic circulation}}

Which portion of the small intestine is responsible for absorption of bile salts?

{{c1::Terminal ileum}}

What is the rate-limiting enzyme for bile acid synthesis?

{{c1::7α-hydroxylase}}
7α-hydroxylase is regulated via negative feedback by {{c1::bile salts}}
One function of bile is to aid in the digestion and absorption of {{c1::lipids}}
One function of bile is excretion of {{c1::cholesterol}}
One function of bile is {{c1::anti-microbial}} activity via membrane disruption

What is the only type of carbohydrate that can be absorbed by enterocytes?

{{c1::Monosaccharides}}
Pancreatic and salivary {{c1::α-amylases}} hydrolyze 1,4-glycosidic bonds in {{c2::starch}}
Lactose is a disaccharide that is digested into {{c1::glucose}} and {{c1::galactose}} by lactase
Sucrose is a disaccharide that is digested into {{c1::glucose}} and {{c1::fructose}} by sucrase

Is pancreatic α-amylase secreted in an active or inactive form?

{{c1::Active}}
Glucose and galactose are transported from the intestinal lumen into the cells by {{c1::Na+-dependent cotransport (SGLT1)}}

Which monosaccharide(s) are absorbed from the intestine by Na+-dependent cotransport (SGLT1)?

{{c1::Glucose and galactose}}
Glucose, galactose and fructose are extruded from the intestinal cell into the blood by {{c1::GLUT-2 (facilitated diffusion)}}

Which monosaccharide(s) are absorbed from the intestine by GLUT-5?

{{c1::Fructose}}
Fructose is extruded from the intestinal cell into the blood by {{c1::GLUT-2 (facilitated diffusion)}}

Which monosaccharide(s) are extruded from the intestinal cell into the blood by GLUT-2?

{{c1::Glucose, galactose, and fructose}}
The {{c1::D-xylose absorption}} test helps distinguish GI mucosal damage from other causes of malabsorption (e.g. lactose intolerance)
{{c1::Decreased}} excretion of urinary D-xylose is indicative of GI mucosal damage or bacterial overgrowth (D-xylose absorption test)
Digestion of protein begins in the stomach with the action of {{c1::pepsin}}
The first step in intestinal protein digestion involves activation of {{c1::trypsinogen}} (inactive) to {{c1::trypsin}} (active)
Trypsinogen is converted to trypsin via {{c1::enteropeptidase (enterokinase)}}, a brush-border enzyme on duodenal and jejunal mucosa

Are pancreatic proteases secreted in an active or inactive form?

{{c1::Inactive (proenzymes/zymogens)}}

Which pancreatic protease cleaves all pancreatic proenzymes to their active forms?

{{c1::Trypsin}}
{{c1::Chymotripsinogen}} (inactive) is activated to chymotrypsin (active) via trypsin
{{c1::Proelastase}} (inactive) is activated to elastase (active) via trypsin
{{c1::Procarboxypeptidase}} (inactive) is activated to carboxypeptidase (active) via trypsin
Trypsin results in {{c1::increased::increased or decreased}} cleavage of trypsinogen to trypsin
Pancreatic {{c1::lipases}} are responsible for fat digestion in the small intestine
Pancreatic lipase is inactivated by {{c1::low::high or low}} duodenal pH
The hydrophobic products of {{c1::lipid}} digestion are solubilized in micelles by bile acids
The chylomicrons in intestinal epithelial cells enter lymphatic capillaries known as {{c1::lacteals}}
The chylomicrons in the lymphatic capillaries enter the bloodstream via the {{c1::thoracic duct}}

What virus is associated with bilateral inflammation of the parotid glands?

{{c1::Mumps virus}}
In addition to parotitis, mumps may also present with {{c1::orchitis}}, pancreatitis, and aseptic meningitis

What enzyme is elevated in mumps patients due to involvement of the pancreatic or salivary glands?

{{c1::α-amylase}}
Orchitis due to mumps infection carries risk of {{c1::sterility}}, especially in teenagers
{{c1::Sialadenitis}} is inflammation of a salivary gland
Sialadenitis most commonly occurs due to {{c1::sialolithiasis}}, which often leads to {{c2::Staphylococcus aureus}} mediated sialadenitis / parotitis

Is Warthin tumor typically unilateral or bilateral?

{{c1::Unilateral}}
Salivary gland tumors are most commonly {{c1::benign::benign or malignant}}
Salivary gland tumors most commonly arise in the {{c1::parotid}} gland
If a salivary gland tumor involves a non-parotid gland it is more likely to be {{c1::malignant::benign or malignant}}
Salivary gland tumors typically present as a mobile, {{c1::painless::painful or painless}} mass/swelling at the angle of the jaw

What is the most common salivary gland tumor?

{{c1::Pleomorphic adenoma}}
{{c3::Pleomorphic adenoma}} is a salivary gland tumor composed of {{c1::chondromyxoid stroma}} and {{c2::epithelium}}

Is pleomorphic adenoma a benign or malignant salivary gland tumor?

{{c1::Benign}}
Pleomorphic adenoma is associated with a high rate of recurrence due to {{c1::incomplete resection}} or {{c2::intraoperative rupture}}

Which salivary gland tumor is associated with a high rate of recurrence following resection?

{{c1::Pleomorphic adenoma}}
{{c2::Warthin tumor}} is a cystic salivary gland tumor with abundant lymphocytes and {{c1::germinal centers}}

Is Warthin tumor typically a benign or malignant salivary gland tumor?

{{c1::Benign}}
{{c3::Mucoepidermoid carcinoma}} is a malignant salivary gland tumor composed of {{c1::mucinous}} and {{c2::squamous}} cells

What is the most common malignant salivary gland tumor?

{{c1::Mucoepidermoid carcinoma}}
Malignant salivary gland tumors present with signs of {{c1::facial}} nerve damage
{{c1::Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF)}} is a congenital defect resulting in a connection between the esophagus and trachea
The most common tracheoesophageal anomaly (85%) is proximal {{c1::esophageal atresia}} with distal {{c1::tracheoesophageal fistula}}
Esophageal atresia with distal TEF presents with {{c1::polyhydramnios}} in utero
Esophageal atresia with distal TEF presents as drooling, choking, and {{c1::vomiting}} with the first feeding
Esophageal atresia with distal TEF may present with abdominal distention due to {{c1::air}} in the stomach (visible on CXR)
Esophageal atresia with distal TEF may present with {{c1::cyanosis}}, secondary to {{c2::laryngospasm}} to avoid aspiration
Esophageal atresia with distal TEF is characterized by failure to pass a(n) {{c1::nasogastric}} tube into the stomach

Which tracheoesophageal anomaly resembles the letter H?

{{c1::Pure TEF ("H-type")}}

Which tracheoesophageal anomaly is associated with a gasless abdomen on CXR?

{{c1::Pure esophageal atresia}}
{{c1::Esophageal web}} is a thin protrusion of esophageal mucosa, most often in the upper esophagus
Esophageal web presents with dysphagia for {{c1::poorly chewed}} food
{{c1::Plummer-Vinson}} syndrome is characterized by a triad of iron deficiency anemia, esophageal web, and a beefy-red tongue (atrophic glossitis)
{{c1::Zenker}} diverticulum is an outpouching of pharyngeal mucosa through an acquired defect in the muscular wall (false diverticulum) caused by {{c2::cricopharyngeal motor}} dysfunction
