Is Zenker diverticulum a true or false diverticulum?

{{c1::False (only involves mucosa and submucosa)}}
{{c4::Zenker}} diverticulum classically arises at {{c1::Killians triangle}}, between the {{c2::thyropharyngeal}} and {{c3::cricopharyngeal}} parts of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor
Zenker diverticulum often presents with oropharyngeal dysphagia, obstruction, and {{c1::halitosis (bad breath)}}

What demographic is most commonly affected by Zenker diverticulum?

{{c1::Elderly males}}
{{c2::Mallory-Weiss}} syndrome is a linear {{c1::mucosal}} laceration at the gastroesophageal (GE) junction
The tears in Mallory-Weiss syndrome are caused by a rapid increase in {{c1::intraabdominal}} pressure (ex. retching, vomiting)
Mallory-Weiss syndrome is usually seen in {{c1::alcoholics}} and {{c2::bulimics}}
Mallory-Weiss syndrome presents with {{c1::hematemesis}} that can be painful

Is the hematemesis seen with Mallory-Weiss syndrome typically painful or painless?

{{c1::Painful}}
{{c2::Boerhaave}} syndrome is a(n) {{c1::transmural}} laceration of the distal esophagus
Boerhaave syndrome presents as esophageal rupture with {{c1::pneumomediastinum (air in the mediastinum)}} and subcutaneous emphysema
Boerhaave syndrome is usually due to violent {{c1::retching}}
{{c1::Esophageal varices}} are dilated submucosal veins in the lower 1/3rd of the esophagus
Esophageal varices arise secondary to {{c1::portal hypertension}}
In portal hypertension, the {{c1::left gastric}} vein backs up into the esophageal vein, resulting in varices
Esophageal varices may rupture, which presents with painless {{c1::hematemesis}}

Is the hematemesis seen with esophageal varices typically painful or painless?

{{c1::Painless}}
Esophageal {{c2::varices}} are a common cause of death in patients with {{c1::cirrhosis}}
{{c2::Achalasia}} is characterized by disordered esophageal motility due to inability to relax the {{c1::lower}} esophageal sphincter
Primary achalasia is due to an autoimmune destruction of ganglion cells in the {{c1::myenteric (Auerbach)}} plexus
Achalasia may be idiopathic or secondary to a known insult, such as {{c1::Chagas}} disease and extraesophageal malignancies

Does achalasia present with dysphagia for solids or liquids?

{{c1::Both solids and liquids :)}}
Achalasia is characterized by {{c1::high}} LES pressure on esophageal manometry
Achalasia is characterized by uncoordinated or absent {{c1::peristalsis}} in the esophagus
{{c2::Achalasia}} is characterized by the "{{c1::Birds beak}}" sign on barium swallow
{{c1::Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)}} is caused by reflux of acid from the stomach due to transiently decreased {{c2::LES}} tone

What type of hernia increases risk of developing GERD?

{{c1::Sliding hiatal hernia}}
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) often presents with {{c1::heartburn}}, which can mimic cardiac chest pain
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) may present with chronic cough and adult-onset {{c1::asthma}}
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) may damage the {{c1::enamel}} of teeth

Late complications of GERD include:
- {{c2::Barrett}} esophagus
- ulcerations followed by esophageal {{c1::strictures}}
Esophageal strictures are associated with {{c1::caustic ingestion}} and {{c2::GERD}}
{{c1::Barretts esophagus}} is characterized by specialized intestinal metaplasia of the lower esophageal mucosa
In Barretts esophagus, {{c1::non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium}} is replaced with {{c2::non-ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells}} (metaplasia)
Barretts esophagus is seen in 10% of patients with {{c1::GERD}}

Which type of esophageal cancer is associated with obesity, GERD and Barretts esophagus?

{{c1::Adenocarcinoma::SCC or adenocarcinoma}}
Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus most commonly arises from pre-existing {{c1::Barrett esophagus}}

Which type of esophageal cancer (SCC or adenocarcinoma) is associated with esophageal web (e.g. Plummer-Vinson syndrome)?

{{c1::Squamous cell carcinoma}}

Which type of esophageal cancer (SCC or adenocarcinoma) is associated with achalasia?

{{c1::Both :)}}

Which type of esophageal cancer (SCC or adenocarcinoma) is associated with very hot tea?

{{c1::Squamous cell carcinoma}}

Which type of esophageal cancer (SCC or adenocarcinoma) is associated with esophageal injury (e.g. lye/caustic ingestion)?

{{c1::Squamous cell carcinoma}}
Barrett esophagus is characterized by extension of the {{c1::squamocolumnar}} junction (Z-line) into the esophageal mucosa
{{c1::Eosinophilic esophagitis}} is characterized by eosinophilic infiltration of the esophagus, often in {{c2::atopic}} patients
{{c2::Eosinophilic esophagitis}} presents with esophageal {{c1::rings}} and linear furrows, often seen on endoscopy
Eosinophilic esophagitis classically presents with dysphagia and food impaction in response to {{c1::food allergens}}

Does eosinophilic esophagitis respond to GERD therapy (e.g. PPIs)?

{{c1::No}}

What infectious cause of esophagitis presents as punched-out ulcers?

{{c1::HSV-1}}

What infectious cause of esophagitis presents as linear ulcers?

{{c1::CMV}}

What infectious cause of esophagitis presents as white pseudomembranes?

{{c1::Candida}}
Infectious esophagitis is typically seen in {{c1::immunocompromised}} patients
Sclerodermal esophageal dysmotility is characterized by {{c1::low}} LES pressure on esophageal manometry
{{c1::Gastroschisis}} is a congenital malformation characterized by extrusion of abdominal contents through the anterior abdominal wall

Which congenital abdominal wall defect IS NOT covered by peritoneum?

{{c1::Gastroschisis}}
Omphalocele is a persistent {{c2::herniation}} of bowel into umbilical cord
{{c1::Omphalocele}} is caused by failure of the herniated intestines to return to the body cavity during embryologic development

Which congenital abdominal wall defect IS covered by peritoneum?

{{c1::Omphalocele}}
{{c2::Gastroschisis}} and {{c2::omphalocele}} occur due to failure of {{c1::lateral}} fold closure of the anterior abdominal wall
{{c2::Bladder exstrophy}} occurs due to failure of {{c1::caudal}} fold closure of the anterior abdominal wall
{{c1::Pyloric stenosis}} is a congenital hypertrophy of the pyloric smooth muscle

What is the most common cause of gastric outlet obstruction in infants?

{{c1::Pyloric stenosis (1:600)}}

What demographic is associated with pyloric stenosis?

{{c1::First-born males}}

How soon after birth does pyloric stenosis typically present?

{{c1::~ 2 - 6 weeks}}
Pyloric stenosis typically presents with {{c1::nonbilious::bilious or nonbilious}}, projectile vomiting
{{c2::Pyloric stenosis}} often presents with a palpable "{{c1::olive}}-like" mass in the epigastric region of the abdomen
Pyloric stenosis may present with visible {{c1::peristalsis}}

What drug class is associated with pyloric stenosis?

{{c1::Macrolides (antibiotics)}}

What acid-base disturbance is associated with pyloric stenosis?

{{c1::Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis}}

What is the treatment for pyloric stenosis?

{{c1::Surgical excision (pyloromyotomy)}}
{{c1::Acute}} gastritis occurs due to acidic damage to the stomach mucosa
{{c1::Acute}} gastritis arises due to imbalance between mucosal defenses and acidic environment
Mucosal defenses include secretion of {{c1::mucus}}, {{c2::HCO3-}}, prostaglandins, and {{c3::normal blood supply}}
Mucosal defenses include normal {{c1::blood supply}}, which provides nutrients and picks up leaked acids
Acute gastritis may arise with severe {{c1::burns}} due to hypovolemia, which causes mucosal {{c2::ischemia}}

What type of gastric ulcer is caused by severe burns?

{{c1::Curling ulcer}}
Acute gastritis may arise with {{c1::NSAID}} use due to decreased {{c2::PGE2}}
Acute gastritis may arise with increased {{c1::ICP}}, which to increases {{c2::vagal stimulation}}, which increases H+ production

What type of gastric ulcer is caused by increased intracranial pressure?

{{c1::Cushing ulcer}}
Acute gastritis may arise with {{c1::shock}}, which presents as multiple stress ulcers secondary to ischemia
{{c2::Acute}} gastritis is especially common among {{c1::alcoholics}} and patients taking daily NSAIDs (e.g. rheumatoid arthritis patients)
Gastric {{c1::erosions::erosions or ulcers}} involves loss of the {{c2::mucosal}} layer only
Gastric {{c1::ulcers::erosions or ulcers}} may extend into and beyond the {{c2::submucosa}}
{{c1::Chronic}} gastritis occurs due to chronic inflammation of the stomach mucosa
Chronic gastritis is associated with {{c1::atrophy::hypertrophy or atrophy}} of the gastric mucosa
Chronic gastritis is associated with {{c1::intestinal}} metaplasia

What is the effect of chronic gastritis on gastric HCl secretion?

{{c1::Decreased (achlorhydria or hypochlorhydria)}}

What is the effect of chronic gastritis on gastrin secretion?

{{c1::Increased (hypergastrinemia)}}
{{c3::Chronic}} gastritis is divided into two types based on etiology: {{c1::autoimmune}} and {{c2::H. pylori}} gastritis
Chronic autoimmune gastritis is also referred to as type {{c1::A}} gastritis
Chronic H. pylori gastritis is also referred to as type {{c1::B}} gastritis
Chronic autoimmune gastritis is due to autoimmune destruction of {{c1::parietal}} cells

Which areas of the stomach are affected in chronic autoimmune gastritis?

{{c1::body and fundus}}
Chronic autoimmune gastritis is associated with antibodies against {{c1::parietal cells}} and/or {{c2::intrinsic factor}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is chronic autoimmune gastritis?

{{c1::Type IV (T-cell mediated)}}
{{c2::Chronic autoimmune}} gastritis is associated with increased risk for {{c1::pernicious}} anemia

What is the most common (90%) form of chronic gastritis?

{{c1::Chronic H. pylori gastritis}}

Which area of the stomach is initially affected by chronic H. pylori gastritis?

{{c1::Antrum}}
Chronic H. pylori gastritis causes increased risk for {{c1::peptic ulcer}} disease
Chronic {{c2::H. pylori}} gastritis causes increased risk for {{c1::MALT}} lymphoma

What cytotoxin released by H. pylori breaks down the protective mucus barrier?

{{c1::CagA toxin}}
H. pylori produces {{c1::urease}}, which alkalinizes the local environment, enabling bacterial survival
H. pylori infection may be diagnosed using the {{c1::urea}} breath test

Is the intestinal metaplasia seen with H. pylori gastritis reversible?

{{c1::Yes (resolves with treatment of infection)}}
Duodenal ulcers are almost always due to {{c1::H. pylori}} (~ 90%)
Duodenal ulcers rarely may be due to {{c1::Zollinger-Ellison}} syndrome
{{c2::Duodenal}} ulcers present with epigastric pain that {{c1::improves}} with meals
{{c2::Duodenal}} ulcers are diagnosed via endoscopic biopsy, which shows an ulcer with hypertrophy of {{c1::Brunner glands}}
Duodenal ulcers usually arise in the {{c1::anterior::anterior or posterior}} duodenum
Duodenal ulcers located in the {{c1::posterior}} duodenum may rupture, leading to bleeding from the {{c2::gastroduodenal}} artery
Gastric ulcers are usually due to {{c1::H. pylori}} (~ 70%)
Less common causes of gastric ulcers include {{c1::NSAIDs}} and bile reflux
{{c2::Gastric}} ulcers present with epigastric pain that {{c1::worsens}} with meals

What is the most common location for a gastric ulcer?

{{c1::Lesser curvature of stomach}}
Gastric ulcers on the lesser curvature of the stomach may rupture, leading to bleeding from the {{c1::left gastric}} artery

Which type of ulcer (gastric or duodenal) is more likely to be malignant?

{{c1::Gastric}}
{{c1::Benign::Benign or Malignant}} gastric ulcers are usually small (< 3 cm), sharply demarcated ("punched-out"), and surrounded by radiating folds of mucosa
{{c1::Gastric::gastric or duodenal}} ulcers should be biopsied at the margins to rule out malignancy

What is the most common ulcer complication (both gastric and duodenal)?

{{c1::Hemorrhage}}

Which type of duodenal ulcer is more commonly associated with perforation?

{{c1::Anterior::anterior or posterior}}
{{c1::Perforation}} of an anterior duodenal ulcer is characterized by free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum)
Perforation of an anterior duodenal ulcer may present with referred pain to the {{c1::shoulder}} via the phrenic nerve

What is the most common classification of gastric carcinoma (e.g. SCC, lymphoma, adenocarcinoma, etc.)?

{{c1::Adenocarcinoma}}
Gastric carcinoma is subclassified into {{c1::intestinal}} and {{c2::diffuse}} types

Which type of gastric carcinoma (intestinal or diffuse) is more common?

{{c1::Intestinal}}
The intestinal type of gastric carcinoma most commonly arises on the {{c1::lesser curvature of the antrum}}

Which type of gastric carcinoma (intestinal or diffuse) is associated with H. pylori infection?

{{c1::Intestinal}}

Which type of gastric carcinoma (diffuse or intestinal) is associated with chronic gastritis?

{{c1::Intestinal}}
The {{c2::intestinal}} type of gastric carcinoma is associated with {{c1::nitrosamines}}, which are found in smoked foods (common in Japan)
The {{c2::intestinal}} type of gastric carcinoma is associated with blood type {{c1::A}}
The {{c2::diffuse}} type of gastric carcinoma is characterized by {{c1::signet ring}} cells that infiltrate the gastric wall
The {{c2::diffuse}} type of gastric carcinoma may cause {{c1::linitis plastica}}, which is a grossly thickened and leathery stomach wall
Gastric carcinoma typically presents {{c1::late::timing}} with weight loss, early satiety, abdominal pain, and anemia
Gastric {{c2::adenocarcinoma}} rarely may present with {{c1::acanthosis nigricans}}, which is hyperpigmented velvety plaques in the axilla and neck
{{c2::Gastric}} adenocarcinoma rarely may present with the {{c1::Leser-Trélat}} sign, which is sudden onset of multiple {{c3::seborrheic keratoses}}
Gastric carcinoma may spread and involve the {{c1::left supraclavicular}} node, also known as {{c2::Virchows node}}
Distant metastasis of gastric adenocarcinoma most commonly involves the {{c1::liver}}
Gastric carcinoma may spread and involve the {{c1::periumbilical}} region, also known as a(n) {{c2::Sister Mary Joseph nodule}}

Which type of gastric carcinoma (diffuse or intestinal) is associated with a Sister Mary Joseph nodule?

{{c1::Intestinal}}
Gastric carcinoma may spread and involve the {{c1::bilateral ovaries}}, also known as a(n) {{c2::Krukenberg tumor}}
Ménétrier disease is characterized by {{c1::hyperplasia}} of the gastric mucosa and {{c1::atrophy}} of the parietal / chief cells
{{c1::Ménétrier}} disease is characterized by hypertrophied gastric rugae that resemble brain gyri
Ménétrier disease is characterized by excess mucus production with resultant {{c1::protein}} loss, leading to edema
Ménétrier disease is characterized by {{c1::parietal}} cell atrophy with decreased acid production

Does ménétrier disease increase risk for gastric cancer?

{{c1::Yes (pre-cancerous lesion)}}
Intestinal atresia presents with abdominal distention and {{c1::bilious::bilious or nonbilious}} vomiting

How soon after birth does intestinal atresia typically present?

{{c1::~ 1 - 2 days}}
Duodenal {{c1::atresia}} is a congenital failure of the duodenum to canalize
{{c2::Duodenal}} atresia is associated with {{c1::Down}} syndrome
Duodenal atresia presents with {{c1::polyhydramnios}} in utero
{{c2::Duodenal atresia}} is characterized by dilation of the stomach and proximal duodenum with a "{{c1::double bubble}}" sign on X-ray
Jejunal and ileal atresia occur due to disruption of {{c1::mesenteric}} vessels during development, which causes ischemic necrosis and segmental resorption
Jejunal and ileal atresia are associated with an "{{c1::apple peel}}" appearance of the bowel
{{c1::Meckel}} diverticulum is an outpouching of all three layers of the bowel wall (true diverticulum)

Is Meckel diverticulum a true or false diverticulum?

{{c1::True (outpouching of all layers)}}
Meckel diverticulum arises due to persistence of the {{c1::vitelline (omphalomesenteric) duct}}

What is the most common congenital anomaly of the GI tract?

{{c1::Meckel diverticulum}}
Meckel diverticulum is associated with the "rule of {{c1::2s}}"
Meckel diverticulum is two times more likely to occur in {{c1::males::gender}}
Meckel diverticulum is typically two {{c1::inches}} long
Meckel diverticulum is typically located in the small bowel, two {{c1::feet}} from the ileocecal valve
Meckel diverticulum typically presents during the first two {{c1::years}} of life
Meckel diverticulum may contain ectopic acid-secreting {{c1::gastric mucosa}} and/or {{c2::pancreatic}} tissue
{{c2::Meckel}} diverticulum is diagnosed using a(n) {{c1::99mTc-pertechnetate}} study for uptake by heterotopic gastric mucosa
Meckel diverticulum is typically {{c1::asymptomatic}} but may present with volvulus, intussusception, melena/hematochezia, RLQ pain, or obstruction
The {{c2::vitelline}} duct connects the yolk sac to the {{c1::midgut}} lumen

What week does the vitelline duct normally obliterate?

{{c1::Week 7}}

What congenital anomaly is caused by complete failure of the vitelline duct to close?

{{c1::Vitelline fistula}}

What congenital anomaly is caused by only partial closure of the vitelline duct?

{{c1::Meckel diverticulum}}

What congenital anomaly is caused by cystic dilation of the vitelline duct?

{{c1::Vitelline cyst (enterocyst)}}
{{c1::Volvulus}} is caused by twisting of a portion of bowel around its mesentery
Volvulus can lead to {{c1::obstruction}} and {{c2::infarction}} of the affected bowel region
Volvulus of the {{c1::sigmoid colon}} is more commonly seen in {{c2::the elderly::age group}}
{{c1::Intussusception}} is telescoping of a(n) {{c2::proximal::proximal or distal}} bowel segment into a(n) {{c2::distal::proximal or distal}} segment
In children, the most common cause of intussusception is {{c1::lymphoid hyperplasia}} (e.g. due to rotavirus or adenovirus)

What is the most common pathologic lead point for intussusception in children over 2?

{{c1::Meckel diverticulum}}

What is the most common lead point for intussusception in adults?

{{c1::Intraluminal mass or tumor}}

Where in the GI tract does intussusception most commonly occur?

{{c1::Ileocecal junction}}
Intussusception results in compromised blood supply, which causes {{c2::intermittent::frequency}} abdominal pain with "{{c1::currant jelly}}" stool
{{c2::Acute}} mesenteric ischemia may occur due to a thrombotic or embolic occlusion of the {{c1::superior mesenteric}} artery
{{c2::Acute}} mesenteric ischemia may occur due to a thrombosis of the {{c1::mesenteric}} vein
Acute mesenteric ischemia is associated with transmural infarction and perforation, which may cause {{c1::septic shock}}
{{c1::Acute mesenteric ischemia}} is associated with small bowel necrosis and abdominal pain out of proportion to physical findings
Acute mesenteric ischemia may present with "{{c1::currant jelly}}" stool
{{c2::Chronic}} mesenteric ischemia may occur due to severe hypotension or {{c1::atherosclerosis}} of the celiac artery, SMA, or IMA
Chronic mesenteric ischemia is associated with {{c1::mucosal::mucosal or transmural}} infarction
{{c1::Chronic}} mesenteric ischemia is typically caused by intestinal hypoperfusion as a result of narrowed vasculature
Chronic mesenteric ischemia presents with epigastric pain that occurs {{c1::after::before or after}} eating

What risk factor is associated with Warthin tumors?

{{c1::Smoking}}
Boerhaave syndrome may present with subcutaneous {{c1::emphysema}}, which is characterized by crepitus felt in the neck region or chest wall
Esophagitis may occur with medications such as {{c1::bisphosphonates}}, tetracyclines, NSAIDs, iron, and potassium chloride

Loss of which hormones/neurotransmitters are implicated in the pathogenesis of achalasia?

{{c1::NO and VIP::2}}

What GI pathology is associated with the rotavirus vaccine?

{{c1::Intussusception}}
Lactose intolerance is caused by decreased function of the {{c1::lactase}} enzyme found in brush border enterocytes
{{c1::Lactose}} intolerance presents with abdominal distention and diarrhea upon consumption of milk products
Lactose intolerance is typically characterized by {{c1::normal}}-appearing villi
Lactose intolerance is characterized by a(n){{c1::decreased}} stool pH
Lactose intolerance may be diagnosed using the {{c1::lactose hydrogen}} breath test
{{c2::Celiac}} disease is immune-mediated damage of small bowel villi due to {{c1::gluten}} exposure
Celiac disease is associated with HLA-{{c1::DQ2}} and HLA-{{c1::DQ8}}

What malabsorption disorder is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8?

{{c1::Celiac disease}}

What is the most pathogenic component of gluten (celiac disease)?

{{c1::Gliadin}}
In Celiac disease, {{c1::deamidated gliadin}} is presented by APCs via MHC class II

Which immune cell mediates the tissue damage in Celiac disease?

{{c1::Helper T cells}}
Celiac disease in {{c1::children::age group}} classically presents as abdominal distention, steatorrhea, and failure to thrive
Celiac disease in {{c1::adults::age group}} classically presents with chronic steatorrhea and bloating
Celiac disease is classically seen in people of {{c1::northern European}} descent
{{c2::Celiac}} disease is associated with {{c1::dermatitis herpetiformis}}, which are small, herpes-like vesicles on the skin
The dermatitis herpetiformis that arises with celiac disease is due to {{c1::IgA}} deposition at the tips of the dermal papillae
{{c4::Celiac}} disease is classically associated with Ig{{c5::A}} antibodies against {{c1::endomysium}}, {{c2::tissue transglutaminase (tTG)}}, and/or {{c3::deamidated gliadin}}
Celiac disease is characterized histologically by {{c1::flattening}} of {{c2::villi}}
Celiac disease is characterized histologically by {{c1::hyperplasia}} of {{c2::crypts}}
Celiac disease is characterized histologically by increased intraepithelial {{c1::lymphocytes}}
Celiac disease primarily affects the distal {{c1::duodenum}} or proximal {{c1::jejunum}}

Which type of sprue (celiac or tropical) primarily affects the proximal small bowel?

{{c1::Celiac sprue}}
Celiac disease is associated with increased risk for small bowel carcinoma and {{c1::T-cell}} lymphoma

What is the treatment for celiac disease?

{{c1::Gluten-free diet}}
{{c1::Tropical}} sprue is characterized by damage to small bowel villi due to an unknown organism, resulting in malabsorption

Which malabsorption disorder is more common in tropical regions?

{{c1::Tropical sprue}}
Tropical sprue classically arises after infectious {{c1::diarrhea}}

Which type of sprue (celiac or tropical) can affect any part of the small bowel?

{{c1::Tropical sprue}}
{{c1::Tropical sprue}} presents similarly to celiac disease but responds to {{c2::antibiotics}}
Tropical sprue may be associated with {{c1::megaloblastic}} anemia

Is tropical sprue associated with normal or decreased urinary excretion of D-xylose (D-xylose test)?

{{c1::Decreased}}
{{c2::Whipple}} disease is characterized by systemic tissue damage with macrophages loaded with {{c1::Tropheryma whipplei}} organisms
Tropheryma whipplei is an intracellular, gram {{c1::positive}} organism
The granules in macrophages in Whipple disease stain positive for {{c1::PAS}} and are {{c2::diastase}} resistant

Which malabsorption syndrome is associated with PAS positive, foamy macrophages?

{{c1::Whipple disease}}
Whipple disease classically involves the {{c1::lamina propria::mucosal layer}} of the small bowel
Whipple disease may present with fat malabsorption and {{c2::steatorrhea}} due to compression of {{c1::lacteals}} by macrophages

What lymph nodes are commonly affected in Whipple disease?

{{c1::Mesenteric nodes}}

The symptoms of Whipple disease may be remembered with the mnemonic "Foamy Whipped cream in a CAN":

C: {{c1::cardiac symptoms}}
A: {{c2::arthralgias}}
N: {{c3::neurologic symptoms}}

What demographic is most commonly affected by Whipple disease?

{{c1::Older men}}
Pancreatic insufficiency causes malabsorption of fat, fat-soluble vitamins, and vitamin {{c1::B12}}
Pancreatic insufficiency is associated with {{c1::decreased}} excretion of fecal elastase
Pancreatic insufficiency is associated with {{c1::decreased}} duodenal pH

Is pancreatic insufficiency associated with normal or decreased urinary excretion of D-xylose (D-xylose test)?

{{c1::Normal}}

What stain is used to screen for fecal fat?

{{c1::Sudan stain}}
{{c2::Abetalipoproteinemia}} is characterized by a deficiency of apolipoprotein {{c1::B-48}} and {{c1::B-100}}
Abetalipoproteinemia is a(n) {{c1::autosomal recessive}} inherited malabsorption disorder that is caused by a mutation in the {{c2::microsomal triglyceride transfer}} protein
Abetalipoproteinemia is associated with malabsorption due to defective {{c1::chylomicron}} formation, which requires apoB-48
{{c1::Abetalipoproteinemia}} is associated with absent plasma VLDL and LDL, which require apoB-100
Carcinoid tumor is a malignant proliferation of {{c1::neuroendocrine}} cells; low-grade malignancy

What is the most common malignancy in the small intestine?

{{c1::Carcinoid tumor (neuroendocrine cells)}}

What neurotransmitter is often secreted by carcinoid tumors?

{{c1::Serotonin}}
The serotonin released from carcinoid tumors in the small bowel is metabolized in the {{c1::liver}} by {{c2::monoamine oxidase (MAO)}}, producing {{c3::5-HIAA}}
Carcinoid tumors are characterized by increased excretion of {{c1::5-HIAA}} in the urine
Metastasis of carcinoid tumor to the liver allows serotonin to bypass {{c1::first-pass}} metabolism and enter systemic circulation

The symptoms of {{c5::carcinoid}} syndrome may be remembered with the mnemonic "Be FDR":

Be: {{c1::bronchospasm}}
F: {{c2::flushing}}
D: {{c3::diarrhea}}
R: {{c4::right-sided heart disease}}
Carcinoid syndrome may cause right-sided valvular heart lesions such as {{c1::tricuspid regurgitation}} and {{c2::pulmonic stenosis}}

Why are left-sided heart valve lesions NOT seen with Carcinoid syndrome?

{{c1::Lung contains MAO, which metabolizes serotonin}}

Does carcinoid syndrome occur with carcinoid tumors that are limited to the GI tract?

{{c1::No}}

What vitamin deficiency may be caused by malignant carcinoid syndrome?

{{c1::Niacin (B3) deficiency}}
Carcinoid syndrome may be treated with surgical resection or with a(n) {{c1::somatostatin}} analog
Carcinoid syndrome is associated with the "rule of {{c1::1/3s}}"
{{c1::Appendicitis}} is defined as acute inflammation of the appendix
Appendicitis is related to obstruction of the appendix by {{c1::lymphoid hyperplasia}} (children)
Appendicitis in adults is typically related to obstruction of the appendix by a(n) {{c1::fecalith}}
{{c2::Appendicitis}} presents with diffuse periumbilical pain that eventually localizes to {{c1::McBurneys point}}
Appendicitis may lead to rupture, resulting in peritonitis with guarding and {{c1::rebound tenderness}} on physical exam

What other pathologies should be on a differential when considering appendicitis?

{{c1::Diverticulitis}} (elderly) and {{c2::ectopic pregnancy}}
Inflammatory bowel disease classically presents in young {{c1::women::gender}} with recurrent bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain
Inflammatory bowel disease is more prevalent in the West, particularly in {{c1::caucasians}} and {{c2::Eastern European Jews}}
Inflammatory bowel disease is subclassified as {{c1::ulcerative colitis}} or {{c2::Crohn disease}}

Which form of IBD involves only mucosal and submucosal ulcers?

{{c1::Ulcerative colitis}}

Which form of IBD involves transmural inflammation with "knife-like" fissures?

{{c1::Crohn disease}}
{{c1::Ulcerative colitis}} (IBD) is characterized by continuous colonic lesions that always involve the rectum
Ulcerative colitis always involves the {{c1::rectum}} and can extend proximally up to the {{c2::cecum}}
{{c2::Crohn disease}} (IBD) is characterized by {{c1::skip}} lesions, which can occur anywhere from the mouth to the anus
Crohn disease most commonly involves the {{c1::terminal ileum}}

Which form of inflammatory bowel disease typically spares the rectum?

{{c1::Crohn disease}}

Which form of IBD always causes bloody diarrhea?

{{c1::Ulcerative colitis}}

Which form of IBD may cause bloody or non-bloody diarrhea?

{{c1::Crohn disease}}
Ulcerative colitis is typically characterized by {{c1::left::left or right}} lower quadrant pain
Crohn disease is typically characterized by {{c1::right::left or right}} lower quadrant pain
{{c2::Ulcerative colitis::IBD}} is characterized histologically by {{c1::crypt abscesses}} with neutrophils, ulcers, and bleeding
{{c2::Crohn disease}} (IBD) is characterized histologically by lymphoid aggregates with {{c1::noncaseating granulomas}}
{{c2::Ulcerative colitis::IBD}} is Th{{c1::2}} mediated
{{c2::Crohn disease}} (IBD) is Th{{c1::1}} mediated
{{c2::Crohn disease}} (IBD) appears grossly with {{c1::cobblestone}} mucosa
Crohn disease (IBD) appears grossly with "creeping" {{c1::fat}}
Crohn disease appears grossly with {{c1::strictures}} (lumen size) and bowel wall thickening
{{c2::Crohn disease}} (IBD) is associated with the "{{c1::string}}" sign on imaging, secondary to strictures
{{c2::Ulcerative colitis::IBD}} appears grossly with friable mucosal {{c1::pseudopolyps}}
{{c3::Ulcerative colitis::IBD}} is associated with the "{{c1::lead pipe}}" sign on imaging, secondary to loss of {{c2::haustra}}
Complications of both ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease include malabsorption and {{c1::colorectal}} cancer
Complications of ulcerative colitis include {{c1::toxic megacolon}}, which may perforate, and fulminant colitis
Complications associated with {{c2::Crohn disease}} (IBD) include gallstones and {{c1::calcium oxalate}} nephrolithiasis

Which form of IBD is associated with fistula formation?

{{c1::Crohn disease}}
One complication of Crohn disease is a(n) {{c1::enterovesical}} fistula, which can cause UTI and pneumaturia

Which form of IBD is associated with perianal disease, phlegmon/abscess formation, and strictures?

{{c1::Crohn disease}}
Extraintestinal manifestations of IBD include {{c1::rash}}, such as erythema nodosum and pyoderma gangrenosum
{{c1::Ulcerative colitis::IBD}} is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis

What biliary tract disease is associated with ulcerative colitis?

{{c1::Primary sclerosing cholangitis}}
{{c2::Ulcerative colitis::IBD}} may be associated with positive serum {{c1::p-ANCA}}
{{c2::Crohn disease}} (IBD) may be associated with positive serum {{c1::anti-Saccharomyces cervisiae antibodies (ASCA)}}
Treatment for acute exacerbation of Crohn disease often involves {{c1::corticosteroids}}

What 5-aminosalicylic preparations are useful in the management of ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease?

{{c1::Mesalamine and sulfasalazine::2}}
Treatment of IBD (Crohns, UC) may involve TNF-α inhibitors, such as {{c1::infliximab}} and {{c2::adalimumab}}
Treatment of IBD (Crohns, UC) may involve immunosuppressors, such as {{c1::azathioprine}} and {{c2::6-mercaptopurine}}

What treatment is curative for ulcerative colitis?

{{c1::Colectomy}}
Smoking is protective against {{c1::ulcerative colitis::IBD}}
Smoking increases risk for {{c1::Crohn disease::IBD}}
{{c1::Hirschsprung}} disease is characterized by defective relaxation and peristalsis of the rectum and distal sigmoid colon
{{c2::Hirschsprung}} disease is a congenital megacolon associated with {{c1::Down}} syndrome
{{c2::Hirschsprung}} disease occurs due to a congenital failure of {{c1::ganglion}} cells to descend into the myenteric and submucosal plexus
The ganglion cells that fail to descend in Hirschsprung disease are derived from {{c1::neural crest}}
Hirschsprung disease is characterized by failure to {{c1::pass meconium}} within 48 hours and chronic constipation
Hirschsprung disease may present with abdominal distention and {{c1::bilious::bilious or nonbilious}} vomiting
Hirschsprung disease is characterized by massive dilation of the bowel {{c1::proximal::proximal or distal}} to the aganglionic segment, resulting in a "transition zone"
{{c2::Hirschsprung}} disease is diagnosed by absence of ganglionic cells on {{c1::rectal suction}} biopsy
Treatment of Hirschsprung disease involves {{c1::resection}} of the involved bowel
Colonic {{c1::diverticula}} are "blind pouches" that communicate with the lumen of the gut

Which gut wall layers are involved in a false diverticulum (pseudodiverticulum)?

{{c1::Mucosa and submucosa}}

Which gut wall layers are involved in a true diverticulum?

{{c1::All three (mucosa, submucosa, muscularis externa)}}
GI tract diverticula classically arise where the {{c1::vasa recta}} perforates the {{c2::muscularis externa}} (weak point in colonic wall)
{{c1::Diverticulosis}} is characterized by many false diverticula in the colon

What is the most common location for diverticulosis?

{{c1::Sigmoid colon}}
Diverticulosis is related to wall {{c1::stress (pulsion diverticulosis)}} (e.g. constipation, straining, low fiber diet) and {{c2::obesity}}
Diverticulosis is associated with low {{c1::fiber}} diets

What demographic is commonly associated with diverticulosis?

{{c1::Older adults (risk increases with age)::age group}}
Diverticulosis is usually {{c1::asymptomatic}} or associated with vague discomfort
{{c1::Diverticulitis}} is a complication of diverticulosis due to inflammation of diverticula
Diverticulitis classically presents with a triad of {{c1::LLQ}} pain, fever, and {{c2::leukocytosis}}

What GI tract pathology presents with appendicitis-like symptoms in the LLQ?

{{c1::Diverticulitis}}
Diverticulitis may lead to a(n) {{c1::colovesical fistula}}, which presents with pneumaturia (e.g. air or stool in the urine)
Complications of diverticulitis include {{c1::abscess}}, perforation, and obstruction (inflammatory stenosis)

What is the general treatment for diverticulitis?

{{c1::Antibiotics}}
Angiodysplasia usually arises in the cecum and {{c1::right::right or left}} colon due to high wall tension
Angiodysplasia classically presents as {{c1::hematochezia}} in an older adult
Angiodysplasia is confirmed by {{c1::angiography}}
{{c2::Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia}} is a(n) {{c1::autosomal dominant::inheritance}} disorder resulting in thin-walled blood vessels, especially in the mouth and GI tract
{{c1::Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia}} is also known as Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome
{{c1::Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia}} presents with blanching skin lesions, AV malformations, recurrent epistaxis, skin discoloration, GI bleeding, and hematuria
{{c1::Ischemic colitis}} is caused by ischemic damage to the colon
Ischemic colitis usually occurs at the {{c1::splenic}} flexure (griffiths point), which is the watershed area of the {{c2::SMA}} and the {{c2::IMA}}
Ischemic colitis is most commonly due to {{c1::atherosclerosis}} of the SMA
Ischemic colitis presents with {{c1::post}}-prandial abdominal pain followed by {{c2::hematochezia}}
Ischemic colitis may present with the "{{c1::thumbprint}}" sign on imaging due to mucosal edema/hemorrhage

{{c1::Irritable bowel}} syndrome is recurrent abdominal pain with > 2 of the following:
- Pain {{c2::related}} to defecation
- Change in stool {{c3::frequency}}
- Change in stool {{c4::consistency}}

What demographic is most commonly associated with irritable bowel syndrome?

{{c1::Middle-aged women}}
The chronic symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome may be {{c1::diarrhea}}-predominant, {{c2::constipation}}-predominant, or mixed

Is irritable bowel syndrome related to structural abnormalities?

{{c1::No}}
Colonic {{c1::polyps}} are raised protrusions of colonic mucosa
Colonic polyps are grossly characterized as flat, {{c1::sessile}}, or {{c2::pedunculated (on a stalk)}}
{{c1::Hyperplastic}} colonic polyps are due to hyperplasia of glands
Hyperplastic colonic polyps classically show a "{{c1::serrated}}" appearance on microscopy

What is the most common type of colonic polyp?

{{c1::Hyperplastic polyp}}
Hyperplastic colonic polyps are usually {{c2::small::size}} and located in the {{c1::rectosigmoid}} region
Hyperplastic colonic polyps are benign with {{c1::no}} malignant potential

What type of colonic polyp is small (< 5 mm) and resembles normal mucosa?

{{c1::Mucosal polyps (clinically insignificant)}}
{{c1::Adenomatous}} colonic polyps are due to a neoplastic proliferation of glands
Adenomatous colonic polyps are benign with {{c1::some}} malignant potential
Adenomatous colonic polyps may progress to adenocarcinoma via the {{c1::adenoma-carcinoma}} sequence
The adenoma-carcinoma sequence begins with {{c1::APC}} gene mutations

Which adenoma-carcinoma sequence mutation results in increased risk for polyp formation?

{{c1::APC mutation}}
Following APC mutation (adenoma-carcinoma sequence), {{c1::KRAS}} mutations lead to {{c2::polyp formation (adenoma)}}
Progression of colonic adenoma to carcinoma occurs with mutations in the {{c1::p53}} or loss of heterozygosity in the region that encodes for {{c2::SMAD}} 2 / 4
Progression of colonic adenoma to carcinoma is associated with overexpression of {{c1::COX-2}}
{{c1::Sessile serrated}} colonic polyps have a "saw-tooth" pattern similar to hyperplastic polyps, but extend to the crypts and involve lateral crypt growth
Serrated colonic polyps are benign with {{c1::some}} malignant potential
Serrated colonic polyps may develop into CRC via {{c1::CpG}} hypermethylation with microsatellite instability and mutations in {{c2::BRAF}}
Screening for colorectal polyps/carcinoma is performed by {{c1::colonoscopy}} and testing for {{c2::fecal occult blood (stool guaiac test)}}

Can an adenomatous polyp be distinguished from a hyperplastic polyp on gross examination (e.g. colonoscopy)?

{{c1::No (thus remove all polyps)}}

Which type of polyp has greater malignant potential, sessile or pedunculated?

{{c1::Sessile}}
Colonic polyps have a greater risk of progression to carcinoma if they are {{c1::> 2}} cm in size
Adenomatous polyps with a(n) {{c1::tubular}} histology have {{c2::less}} malignant potential than {{c1::villous}} histology (tubular or villous)
{{c2::Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)}} is a(n) {{c1::autosomal dominant::inheritance}} disorder characterized by 100s to 1000s of adenomatous colonic polyps
{{c3::Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)}} is due to an inherited mutation in the {{c1::APC}} gene on chromosome {{c2::5q::arm}}
Colorectal cancer arises in patients with familial adenomatous polyposis via the "{{c1::2-hit}} hypothesis"
Familial adenomatous polyposis is pancolonic and always involves the {{c1::rectum}}
Familial adenomatous polyposis is treated with {{c1::prophylactic colectomy}}, or else 100% of patients progress to CRC
{{c4::Gardner}} syndrome is a combination of {{c1::familial adenomatous polyposis}} with {{c2::osteomas}} and {{c3::fibromatosis}}
{{c3::Turcot}} syndrome is a combination of {{c1::familial adenomatous polyposis}} with {{c2::malignant CNS tumors (e.g. medulloblastoma, glioma)}}
{{c1::Juvenile}} polyps usually present in childhood as a solitary rectal polyp that prolapses and bleeds
{{c2::Juvenile polyposis}} syndrome is characterized by numerous {{c1::hamartomatous}} polyps WITHOUT hyperpigmentation

What demographic is associated with juvenile polyposis syndrome?

{{c1::Children < 5 years old::age group- specific}}
{{c1::Juvenile polyposis}} syndrome is characterized by many juvenile polyps in the stomach, colon, and small bowel
Juvenile polyposis syndrome is associated with increased risk for {{c1::colorectal}} carcinoma
{{c2::Peutz-Jeghers}} syndrome is characterized by numerous {{c1::harmartomatous}} polyps WITH hyperpigmentation of the lips, mouth, hands, and genital skin
Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with increased risk of {{c1::breast}}, {{c2::GI}}, and gynecologic cancers
FAP and most sporadic colorectal carcinomas arise via the {{c1::chromosomal}} instability pathway
Lynch syndrome and some sporadic colorectal carcinomas arise via the {{c1::microsatellite}} instability pathway
Microsatellites are repeating sequences of {{c1::non-coding::coding/non-coding}} DNA
The {{c2::microsatellite}} instability pathway of colorectal cancer is characterized by mutations or methylation of {{c1::mismatch repair}} genes
{{c1::Lynch}} syndrome is due to an inherited defect in {{c2::DNA mismatch repair}} enzymes, resulting in microsatellite instability
Lynch syndrome was previously known as {{c1::hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)}}

What is the mode of inheritance of Lynch syndrome (HNPCC)?

{{c1::Autosomal dominant}}
Lynch syndrome progresses to {{c1::colorectal}} cancer in ~ 80% of patients
Lynch syndrome is usually right-sided and always involves the {{c1::proximal::proximal or distal}} colon
Lynch syndrome is associated with increased risk for {{c1::colorectal}}, {{c2::endometrial}}, {{c3::ovarian}}, and skin cancers
Risk factors for colorectal carcinoma include {{c1::adenomatous}} and {{c2::serrated}} polyps
{{c1::Left}}-sided colorectal carcinoma usually arises as a result of the adenoma-carcinoma sequence
{{c1::Right}}-sided colorectal carcinoma usually arises as a result of the microsatellite instability pathway
{{c2::Iron deficiency}} anemia in males (especially > 50) and postmenopausal females raises suspicion of {{c1::colorectal}} carcinoma
{{c1::Adhesions}} are fibrous bands of scar tissue that commonly form after GI {{c2::surgery}}

What is the most common cause of small bowel obstruction?

{{c1::Adhesion}}
{{c1::Ileus}} is an intestinal hypomotility without obstruction that results in constipation and decreased flatus
Ileus is associated with a distended/tympanic abdomen and {{c1::decreased}} bowel sounds
{{c1::Meconium ileus}} is characterized by a meconium plug that obstructs the intestine, preventing stool passage at birth
{{c2::Necrotizing enterocolitis}} is a GI pathology seen in premature, {{c1::formula}}-fed infants with immature immune systems

{{c2::Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC)}} is characterized by necrosis of intestinal mucosa with possible perforation, which can lead to:

- free air in the bowel wall ({{c1::pneumatosis intestinalis}})
- free air in the abdomen ({{c2::pneumoperitoneum}})
- portal venous gas on imaging
{{c2::Malrotation}} is a congenital anomaly of {{c1::midgut}} rotation during fetal development
Malrotation results in improper positioning of the bowel with improper formation of fibrous, "{{c1::Ladds}} bands"
Malrotation can lead to {{c1::volvulus}} and duodenal obstruction

Which embryological structure develops into the pancreas?

{{c1::Foregut}}

Which embryological pancreatic bud(s) contribute to the main pancreatic duct?

{{c1::Ventral pancreatic buds}}

Which embryological pancreatic bud(s) contribute to the uncinate process?

{{c1::Ventral pancreatic buds}}

Which embryological pancreatic bud(s) contribute to the body, tail, and isthmus of the pancreas?

{{c1::Dorsal pancreatic buds}}

Which embryological pancreatic bud(s) contribute to the accessory pancreatic duct?

{{c1::Dorsal pancreatic buds}}

Which embryological pancreatic bud(s) contribute to the head of the pancreas?

{{c1::Both ventral AND dorsal pancreatic buds :)}}
{{c1::Annular}} pancreas is a congenital malformation in which the {{c3::ventral}} pancreatic bud forms a ring around the {{c2::2nd}} part of the duodenum
Annular pancreas may cause {{c1::duodenal}} obstruction and {{c2::bilious::bilious/non-bilious}} vomiting
Pancreas {{c1::divisum}} is a congenital malformation in which the ventral and dorsal parts fail to fuse at {{c2::8}} weeks
Pancreas divisum is mostly asymptomatic, but may cause chronic abdominal pain and/or {{c1::pancreatitis}}

Which embryological structure develops into the spleen?

{{c1::Mesoderm}}

What is the embryonic gut region of the blood supply to the spleen (e.g. foregut, midgut, hindgut)?

{{c1::Foregut (celiac trunk gives rise to the splenic artery)}}
{{c1::Acute pancreatitis}} is due to {{c2::autodigestion}} of pancreatic parenchyma by pancreatic enzymes
In acute pancreatitis, {{c1::trypsin}} is prematurely activated, which leads to activation of other pancreatic enzymes
Acute pancreatitis results in {{c1::liquefactive}} necrosis of the pancreas
Acute pancreatitis results in {{c1::fat}} necrosis of the peripancreatic fat
Acute pancreatitis is most commonly due to {{c1::alcohol}} or {{c2::gallstones}}

The causes of {{c14::acute pancreatitis}} may be remembered with the mnemonic "I GET PP SMASHED":

I: {{c1::Idiopathic}}

G: {{c2::Gallstones}}
E: {{c3::Ethanol}}
T: {{c4::Trauma (e.g. automobile accident in children - seatbelt injury)}}

P: {{c13::Posterior duodenal ulcer rupture}}
P: {{c15::Pancreas Divisum}}

S: {{c5::Steroids}}
M: {{c6::Mumps}}
A: {{c7::Autoimmune disease}}
S: {{c8::Scorpion sting}}
H: {{c9::HYPERcalcemia}} or {{c10::Hypertriglyceridemia/Hyperchylomicronemia}}
E: {{c11::ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography)}}
D: {{c12::Drugs (e.g. sulfa drugs, NRTIs, protease inhibitors)}}

Acute {{c1::pancreatitis}} is diagnosed by 2 of 3 criteria:

- Acute epigastric pain that radiates to the back
- Increased serum amylase or lipase to 3x upper limit of normal
- Characteristic imaging findings
One criteria for diagnosis of acute pancreatitis is acute {{c1::epigastric}} abdominal pain that radiates to the {{c2::back}}
One criteria for diagnosis of acute pancreatitis is increased serum {{c1::amylase}} or {{c2::lipase}}

Which pancreatic enzyme is more specific for acute pancreatitis?

{{c1::Lipase::amylase or lipase}}
Acute pancreatitis may present with {{c1::hypo}}-calcemia/magnesemia
Acute pancreatitis may progress to {{c1::shock}}, due to pancreatic hemorrhage and fluid sequestration
Acute pancreatitis may be complicated by {{c1::pancreatic pseudocysts}}, which are formed by fibrous tissue surrounding liquefactive necrosis and pancreatic enzymes
Pancreatic pseudocyst presents as an abdominal mass with persistently elevated serum {{c1::amylase}}
Pancreatic pseudocysts may {{c1::rupture}}, causing hemorrhage and release of enzymes into the abdominal cavity
Complications of acute pancreatitis include {{c1::DIC}} due to activation of coagulation factors
Complications of acute pancreatitis include {{c1::ARDS}} due to damage to the alveolar capillary interface
{{c1::Chronic}} pancreatitis is characterized by fibrosis of pancreatic parenchyma
Chronic pancreatitis is most often secondary to recurrent acute {{c1::pancreatitis}}

What are the major causes of chronic pancreatitis in adults?

{{c1::Alcohol}} and {{c2::genetic predisposition (ex. Cystic Fibrosis)}}

What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis in children?

{{c1::Cystic fibrosis}}
Pancreatitis (acute and chronic) may present with {{c1::epigastric}} abdominal pain that radiates to the {{c2::back}}
Chronic pancreatitis may present with {{c1::pancreatic insufficiency}}, which results in malabsorption with steatorrhea and fat-soluble vitamin deficiences
{{c2::Chronic}} pancreatitis is characterized by atrophy and dystrophic {{c1::calcification}} of pancreatic parenchyma on imaging
Chronic pancreatitis results in increased risk for {{c1::pancreatic}} carcinoma

What type of cancer (e.g. SCC, adenocarcinoma, etc.) is pancreatic carcinoma?

{{c1::Adenocarcinoma}}

The major risk factors for pancreatic adenocarcinoma are
- {{c2::smoking}}
- {{c1::chronic pancreatitis (especially > 20 years)}}
{{c3::Pancreatic adenocarcinoma}} often presents as obstructive {{c1::jaundice}} with a(n) {{c2::painless}}, palpable gallbladder
A painless, palpable gallbladder in pancreatic adenocarcinoma is also known as the {{c1::Courvoisier}} sign
Pancreatic adenocarcinoma most commonly arises in the {{c1::head}} of the pancreas
Pancreatic adenocarcinoma in the body or tail may present with secondary {{c1::diabetes mellitus}}
Pancreatic adenocarcinoma may present with {{c1::migratory thrombophlebitis}}, which is redness and tenderness in the extremities
Migratory thrombophlebitis in pancreatic adenocarcinoma is also known as the {{c1::Trousseau}} syndrome
{{c3::Pancreatic}} adenocarcinoma is associated with the serum tumor markers {{c1::CA 19-9}} and {{c2::CEA}} (less specific)

What is the prognosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma?

{{c1::Very poor (1-year survival < 10%)}}
Biliary {{c1::atresia}} is a failure to form or early destruction of the extrahepatic biliary tree
Biliary atresia typically leads to biliary obstruction within the first 2 {{c1::months}} of life
Biliary atresia presents with {{c1::jaundice (CB)}} and progresses to cirrhosis
{{c1::Cholelithiasis (gallstones)}} are solid, round stones in the gallbladder
There are two types of gallstones: {{c1::cholesterol}} and {{c2::pigmented}}

Are cholesterol gallstones typically radiolucent or radiopaque?

{{c1::Radiolucent}}

Risk factors for {{c5::cholesterol}} gallstones may be remembered with the "4 Fs":

1. {{c1::Fat}}
2. {{c2::Female (estrogen increases activity of HMG-CoA reductase)}}
3. {{c3::Fertile (pregnant)}}
4. {{c4::Forty}}

What classes of lipid lowering drugs are associated with cholesterol gallstone formation?

{{c1::Fibrates and bile acid resins::2}}
{{c2::Cholesterol}} gallstones are more common in people of {{c1::Native American}} descent

Which form of IBD has increased risk for gallstones (both cholesterol and pigment)?

{{c1::Crohn disease}}

Which type of gallstone is associated with extravascular hemolysis?

{{c1::Bilirubin (pigment) stones}}

Which type of gallstone is associated with total parenteral nutrition (TPN)?

{{c1::Cholesterol stones}}

{{c1::Cholecystitis}} is an acute or chronic inflammation of the gallbladder with gallbladder wall thickening

{{c1::Calculous}}

{{c1::Ascending cholangitis}} is a bacterial infection of the {{c2::bile ducts}}

{{c1::Gallstone}} ileus typically involves obstruction of the {{c2::ileocecal}} valve by a gallstone

{{c1::Adenocarcinoma}}

What is the prognosis of gallbladder carcinoma?

{{c1::Poor}}

{{c2::Delirium tremens}}, secondary to alcohol withdrawal, typically occurs after {{c1::48}} - {{c1::96}} hours

Which type of generalized seizure is acutely treated with benzodiazepines?

What drug class do phenobarbital, pentobarbital, and secobarbital belong to?

{{c1::Barbiturates}}

What drug class do halothane, enflurane, methoxyflurane belong to?

{{c1::Inhaled anesthetics}}

Inhaled anesthetics with {{c1::lower}} solubility in blood have a(n) {{c2::faster}} onset of action

{{c1::Low (quickly saturated, e.g. N2O)}}

{{c1::Partial and tonic-clonic}}

{{c1::Carbamazepine}}

{{c1::Yes}}

What dermatologic complication is associated with phenytoin use?

Phenytoin is a(n) {{c2::inducer}} of {{c1::cytochrome P450}} and thus may have many drug interactions

What type(s) of seizures (partial, tonic-clonic, or absence) may be treated with gabapentin?

{{c1::Partial}}

Which anti-epileptic may be used to treat peripheral neuropathy and fibromyalgia (chronic pain)?

{{c1::Gabapentin}}

H: {{c3::Headache}}

What drug class do haloperidol and pimozide belong to?

What drug class do trifluoperazine, fluphenazine, thioridazine, and chlorpromazine belong to?

{{c1::Typical antipsychotics (1st generation)}}

{{c1::Positive}}

Are anti-cholinergic effects more common with high or low potency typical antipsychotics?

{{c1::Low potency}}

Are anti-histamine effects more common with high or low potency typical antipsychotics?

{{c1::Low potency}}

Are anti-α1 effects more common with high or low potency typical antipsychotics?

{{c1::Low potency}}

Are extrapyramidal symptoms more common with high or low potency typical antipsychotics?

{{c1::High potency}}

Which extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g. due to antipsychotic use) occur within minutes to days?

{{c1::Acute dystonia}}

Which extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g. due to antipsychotic use) occur within days to months?

{{c1::Akathisia (restlessness) and parkinsonism}}

Which extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g. due to antipsychotic use) occur within months to years?

{{c1::Tardive dyskinesia}}

What is the most serious adverse effect associated with antipsychotics?

{{c1::Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS)}}

The symptoms of {{c7::neuroleptic malignant}} syndrome may be remembered with the mnemonic "Malignant FEVER":

M: {{c1::Myoglobinuria}}
F: {{c2::Fever}}
E: {{c3::Encephalopathy (altered mental status)}}
V: {{c4::unstable Vitals (autonomic instability)}}
E: {{c5::increased Enzymes (e.g. CK)}}
R: {{c6::muscle Rigidity}}

{{c1::QT interval prolongation}}

What drug class do asenapine, clozapine, olanzapine, and quetiapine belong to?

{{c1::Atypical antipsychotics (2nd generation)}}

What drug class do iloperidone, paliperidone, and risperidone belong to?

{{c1::Atypical antipsychotics (2nd generation)}}

What drug class do lurasidone and ziprasidone belong to?

{{c1::Atypical antipsychotics (2nd generation)}}

What drug class does aripiprazole belong to?

{{c1::Atypical antipsychotics (2nd generation)}}

Which atypical antipsychotic is a D2 partial agonist?

Which serotonin receptor is antagonized by many atypical antipsychotics?

Are atypical antipsychotics effective at treating the positive or negative symptoms of schizophrenia?

What is the treatment of choice for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder?

Which atypical antipsychotic is used for suicidality in schizophrenia?

{{c1::Clozapine}}
Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics cause {{c1::less::more/less}} anti-cholinergic side effects
Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics cause {{c1::less::more/less}} anti-histamine side effects
Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics cause {{c1::less::more/less}} anti-α1 side effects
Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics are {{c1::more::more/less}} likely to cause metabolic syndrome

Which atypical antipsychotics are most associated with metabolic syndrome?

{{c1::"-pines" (esp. clozapine and olanzapine)}}
{{c2::Clozapine}} is an atypical antipsychotic that may cause {{c1::agranulocytosis::hematologic complication}}

{{c2::Clozapine}} is an atypical antipsychotic associated with a dose dependent risk for {{c1::seizures::neurologic complication}}
{{c2::Risperidone}} is an atypical antipsychotic that often causes {{c1::hyperprolactinemia::endocrine complication}}
Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics are {{c1::less::more/less}} likely to cause extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS)
Compared to typical antipsychotics, atypical antipsychotics are {{c1::less::more/less}} likely to cause neuroleptic malignant syndrome
{{c1::Levodopa (L-DOPA)}} is a precursor of dopamine that does cross the blood-brain-barrier

{{c1::Carbidopa}} is a peripheral {{c2::DOPA decarboxylase}} inhibitor used to increase the bioavailability of levodopa
Carbidopa {{c1::decreases}} the peripheral side effects of levodopa
Carbidopa {{c1::exacerbates}} the neuropsychiatric side effects of levodopa

{{c2::Entacapone}} is a peripheral {{c1::COMT}} inhibitor used to increase the bioavailability of levodopa

{{c2::Ropinirole}} is a non-ergot {{c1::D2}} receptor agonist that is used in initial treatment of Parkinson disease
{{c2::Pramipexole}} is a non-ergot {{c1::D3}} receptor agonist that is used in initial treatment of Parkinson disease

What is the first line treatment for restless leg syndrome?

Which anti-influenza agent is useful in the management of Parkinson disease?

Trihexyphenidyl and benztropine are useful for treating the {{c1::tremor}} and {{c1::rigidity}} of Parkinson disease

{{c1::Both :)}}

{{c1::No, only effective at muscarinic receptors}}

What is a lethal complication of cholinesterase inhibitor poisoning if untreated?

{{c1::Respiratory failure}}

What drug class do galantamine and tacrine belong to?

{{c1::Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors}}

What drug class does rivastigmine belong to?

{{c1::Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor}}

What drug class does donepezil belong to?

{{c1::Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor}}

{{c1::Alzheimers disease}}

What treatment for headaches is associated with serotonin syndrome?

What drug is used for chronic pain in tension headaches?

{{c1::Amitriptyline}}
{{c1::Jaundice}} is a yellow discoloration of the skin and/or sclera

What is the earliest sign of jaundice?

{{c1::Scleral icterus}}

Does hemolysis result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?

{{c1::Unconjugated}}

Does physiological neonatal jaundice result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?

{{c1::Unconjugated}}

What is the treatment for physiologic neonatal jaundice?

{{c1::Non-UV phototherapy}}

How does phototherapy treat neonatal jaundice?

{{c1::Isomerize UCB to water-soluble form}}

What is the mode of inheritance of hereditary hyperbilirubinemias (e.g. Gilbert, Crigler-Najjar, Dubin-Johnson)?

{{c1::Autosomal recessive}}

Does Gilbert syndrome result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?

{{c1::Unconjugated}}
{{c1::Crigler-Najjar}} syndrome is due to {{c2::absent}} UDP-glucuronyl transferase activity

Does Crigler-Najjar syndrome result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?

{{c1::Unconjugated}}

Which form of Crigler-Najjar syndrome is more severe?

{{c1::Type I}}

What are the treatments for Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I?

{{c1::Plasmapheresis and phototherapy::2}}
Crigler-Najjar syndrome type {{c1::II}} is less severe and responds to {{c2::phenobarbital}}, which increases liver enzyme synthesis

Does Dubin-Johnson syndrome result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?

{{c1::Conjugated}}

Does Rotor syndrome result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?

{{c1::Conjugated}}

What type of jaundice is associated with gallstones, parasites, and liver fluke?

Does biliary tract obstruction (obstructive jaundice) result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?

{{c1::Conjugated}}

Obstructive jaundice is associated with {{c1::decreased}} urine urobilinogen
Obstructive jaundice is associated with {{c1::pale}} stools

Viral hepatitis is characterized by elevated liver enzymes with ALT {{c1::>}} AST

{{c1::Chronic}} hepatitis is associated with inflammation that primarily involves the {{c2::portal tracts}}

{{c1::Both :)}}

What is the most common cause of portal hypertension in Western countries?

{{c1::Cirrhosis}}

{{c1::Lactulose}}

How do levels of estrogen change in cirrhosis?

{{c1::Increased}}

Increased estrogen in cirrhosis may lead to {{c1::gynecomastia}}, testicular atrophy, and amenorrhea (reproductive symptoms)
Cirrhosis may present with peripheral edema, secondary to {{c1::hypoalbuminemia}}
Cirrhosis may present with {{c1::coagulopathies}} due to decreased synthesis of clotting factors

What is the most common cause of liver disease in the West?

{{c1::Alcohol consumption}}

Which alcoholic liver disease is characterized by macrovesicular fatty change with a heavy, greasy liver?

{{c1::Hepatic steatosis}}

Alcoholic {{c2::hepatitis}} is characterized by {{c1::swelling}} of hepatocytes with necrosis and neutrophilic infiltration

{{c2::Alcoholic}} hepatitis is characterized by elevated liver enzymes with ALT {{c1::<}} AST
{{c1::Non-alcoholic fatty}} liver disease is associated with obesity and metabolic syndrome
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is characterized by elevated liver enzymes with ALT {{c1::>}} AST
{{c1::Hemochromatosis}} is characterized by organ damage, secondary to excess iron

Hemochromatosis may be primary; due to {{c1::autosomal recessive::inheritance pattern}} mutations in iron absorption

What is a common cause of death in hemochromatosis?

Hemochromatosis is characterized by {{c1::increased}} ferritin
Hemochromatosis is characterized by {{c1::decreased}} TIBC
Hemochromatosis is characterized by {{c1::increased}} serum iron

Which part of the cell does lipofuscin accumulate?

What GI disorder may be treated with deferasirox, deferoxamine, and oral deferiprone?

{{c1::Hemochromatosis}}

{{c3::Wilson disease}} is due to mutations in the {{c1::ATP7B}} gene on chromosome {{c2::13}}
Wilson disease results in lack of copper transport into {{c1::bile}} and lack of incorporation into {{c2::ceruloplasmin}}
Wilson disease is also known as {{c1::hepatolenticular degeneration}}
Wilson disease is characterized by accumulation of copper, especially in the {{c1::liver}}, brain, cornea, and kidneys
Wilson disease often presents with {{c1::cirrhosis}}, due to copper accumulation in the liver
{{c2::Wilson}} disease often presents with neuropsychiatric manifestations, due to copper deposition and resultant cystic degeneration in the {{c1::putamen}} and other adjacent structures
{{c3::Wilson}} disease presents with {{c1::Kayser-Fleischer rings}} due to copper deposits in {{c2::Descemets membrane}} of the cornea
Wilson disease is characterized by {{c1::decreased}} serum ceruloplasmin
Wilson disease is characterized by {{c1::increased}} urinary {{c2::copper}}
{{c2::Wilson}} disease may be treated with oral {{c1::zinc}} or chelating agents (e.g. penicillamine, trientine)
Biliary tract diseases (e.g. PSC, PBC) present with features of {{c1::obstructive}} jaundice

Does biliary tract disease (e.g. PBC, PSC) result in unconjugated or conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?

{{c1::Conjugated}}
{{c3::Primary biliary cholangitis}} is a(n) {{c1::autoimmune}} granulomatous destruction of {{c2::intra}}-hepatic bile ducts
Primary biliary cholangitis is associated with other {{c1::autoimmune}} diseases

Which biliary tract disease is caused by extrahepatic biliary obstruction?

{{c1::Secondary biliary cholangitis}}
Secondary biliary cholangitis may be complicated by ascending {{c1::cholangitis}}
{{c1::Primary sclerosing}} cholangitis is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of both intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts

Does primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) affect intra- or extrahepatic bile ducts?

{{c1::Both :)}}
{{c2::Primary sclerosing}} cholangitis causes periductal fibrosis with an "{{c1::onion-skin}}" appearance histologically
Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by a "{{c1::beading}}" appearance of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts on ERCP and MRCP

What demographic is classically affected by primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)?

{{c1::Middle-aged men (classically with IBD)}}
{{c2::Primary sclerosing}} cholangitis is associated with {{c1::p-ANCA}} antibody
Primary sclerosing cholangitis and primary biliary cholangitis are associated with increased serum Ig{{c1::M}}
Primary sclerosing cholangitis is associated with increased risk for {{c1::cholangiocarcinoma}} and gallbladder cancer

What is a late complication associated with biliary tract disease (e.g. PBC, PSC)?

{{c1::Cirrhosis}}
{{c2::Reye}} syndrome is fulminant liver failure and encephalopathy in children with viral illness who take {{c1::aspirin}}
Reye syndrome may occur due to decreased {{c1::β-oxidation}} secondary to reversible inhibition of {{c2::mitochondrial}} enzymes in hepatocytes by aspirin metabolites
Reye syndrome presents with {{c1::micro}}-vesicular fatty change in the liver, hypoglycemia, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and eventually coma/death

What viruses classically cause Reye syndrome when treated with aspirin?

{{c1::Influenza B}} and {{c2::VZV}}
Hepatic {{c2::adenomas}} are rare, benign tumors associated with {{c1::OCP}} and {{c1::anabolic steroid}} use; regress upon cessation of drug
Hepatic adenomas may rupture, causing intraperitoneal bleeding, especially during {{c1::pregnancy}}
Hepatic adenomas are subcapsular tumors and grow with exposure to {{c1::estrogen}}
Hepatic {{c1::angiosarcoma}} is a malignant tumor associated with exposure to arsenic and vinyl chloride
{{c1::Cavernous hemangiomas}} are common, benign tumors involving the deeper tissues of the body (ex. liver, brain) that typically occur from age 30 - 50 years
Cavernous hemangiomas should NOT be {{c1::biopsied}} due to risk of fatal hemorrhage
{{c1::Hepatocellular carcinoma (hepatoma)}} is the most common primary malignant liver tumor in adults
Risk factors for {{c1::hepatocellular}} carcinoma include chronic hepatitis (e.g. HBV, HCV)
Risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma include causes of {{c1::cirrhosis}} (e.g. alcohol, NAFLD, hemochromatosis, Wilson disease, A1AT deficiency)
{{c1::Hepatocellular}} carcinoma increases risk for Budd-Chiari syndrome
In addition to HCC, Budd-Chiari syndrome may also be seen with hypercoagulable and post-{{c1::partum}} states

What myeloproliferative disorder is associated with Budd-Chiari syndrome?

{{c1::Polycythemia vera}}
{{c1::Budd-Chiari}} syndrome is liver infarction secondary to {{c2::hepatic vein}} obstruction
Budd-Chiari syndrome presents with {{c1::painful::painful or painless}} hepatomegaly, ascites, varices, and liver failure
Budd-Chiari syndrome results in congestion and necrosis of the {{c1::centrilobular}} zone of the liver

Does Budd-Chiari syndrome present with jugular venous distention (JVD)?

{{c1::No}}
{{c2::Budd-Chiari}} syndrome is associated with a characteristic "{{c1::nutmeg}}" appearance of the liver

How does hepatocellular carcinoma spread?

{{c1::Hematogenously}}

What is the serum tumor marker for hepatocellular carcinoma?

{{c1::Alpha-fetoprotein}}
{{c1::Spontaneous (primary) bacterial peritonitis}} is a common, potentially fatal bacterial infection in patients with cirrhosis and ascites
Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is commonly caused by aerobic, gram negative organisms, especially {{c1::E. coli}} and {{c1::Klebsiella}}
{{c2::Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis}} is diagnosed by paracentesis with ascitic fluid absolute neutrophil count > {{c1::250}} cells/mm3
AST {{c1::>}} ALT in nonalcoholic liver disease suggests progression to advanced fibrosis or cirrhosis

Which liver enzyme is increased in cholestasis (e.g. biliary obstruction), infiltrative disorders, and bone disease?

{{c1::Alkaline phosphatase}}

Which liver enzyme is increased in various liver/biliary diseases, but NOT in bone disease?

{{c1::γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)}}
γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) is associated with {{c1::alcohol}} use

How does prothrombin time (PT) change with advanced liver disease?

{{c1::Increased}}

Which embryological structure develops into the GI tract from the lower esophagus to the proximal duodenum?

{{c1::Foregut}}

Which embryological structure develops into the GI tract from the distal duodenum to the proximal 2/3 of the transverse colon?

{{c1::Midgut}}

Which embryological structure develops into the GI tract from the distal 1/3 of the transverse colon to the anal canal above the pectinate line?

{{c1::Hindgut}}

Which embryological structure develops into the liver and gallbladder?

{{c1::Foregut}}

During the {{c2::10th}} week of gestation, the midgut returns to the abdominal cavity and rotates {{c3::270}}° counterclockwise around the {{c1::superior mesenteric}} artery

The main pancreatic duct drains into the {{c1::major}} duodenal papilla
The accessory pancreatic duct drains into the {{c1::minor}} duodenal papilla

S: {{c1::Suprarenal (adrenal) glands}}
AI: {{c2::Aorta and IVC}}
D: {{c3::Duodenum (2nd through 4th part)}}

P: {{c4::Pancreas (except tail)::except...}}
U: {{c5::Ureters}}
C: {{c6::Colon (ascending and descending) *surgeons consider these intraperitoneal}}
K: {{c7::Kidney}}
E: {{c8::Esophagus (thoracic portion)}}
R: {{c9::Rectum (partially)}}

{{c1::Gastrosplenic ligament}}

What structures are contained within the gastrosplenic ligament?

{{c1::Short gastric arteries}} and {{c2::left gastroepiploic vessels}}
The {{c2::gastrosplenic}} ligament separates the greater and lesser sacs on the {{c1::left::left or right}}
The greater omentum is formed by the {{c1::gastrocolic}} and {{c2::gastrosplenic}} ligaments

Which GI ligament connects the spleen to the posterior abdominal wall?

{{c1::Splenorenal ligament}}

What structures are contained within the splenorenal ligament?

{{c1::Splenic artery/vein}} and the {{c2::tail of the pancreas}}

What type of epithelium lines the esophagus?

{{c1::Non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium}}
The surface of the stomach is marked histologically by closely spaced grooves called gastric {{c1::pits}}, into which several gastric glands secrete
The gastric {{c1::glands}} of the stomach contain the mucous cells, chief cells, and parietal cells
The {{c2::chief::chief or parietal}} cells of the stomach stain {{c1::baso}}-philic
The {{c2::parietal::chief or parietal}} cells of the stomach stain {{c1::eosino}}-philic

{{c1::Simple columnar epithelium}}
All three parts of the small intestine contain {{c1::villi}} and {{c1::microvilli}}, which increase absorptive surface area

{{c1::Crypts of Lieberkühn::specific name}}

{{c1::Brunner glands (in submucosa)}}

What histologic feature distinguishes the jejunum from other parts of the small intestine?

{{c1::Plicae circulares}}

What histologic feature distinguishes the ileum from other parts of the small intestine?

{{c1::Peyer patches}}

Which part of the small intestine contains the largest number of goblet cells?

{{c1::Ileum}}

Does the large intestine contain crypts of Lieberkühn?

{{c1::Yes}}

Does the large intestine contain villi?

{{c1::No}}

What vertebral level does the superior mesenteric artery branch off the aorta?

{{c1::L1}}

What vertebral level does the inferior mesenteric artery branch off the aorta?

{{c1::L3}}

{{c1::Celiac trunk}}

Which artery supplies the regions of the midgut?

{{c1::Superior mesenteric artery}}

Which artery supplies the regions of the hindgut?

{{c1::Inferior mesenteric artery}}

{{c1::L1/L2}}

{{c1::Vagus nerve}}

Which sympathetics innervate the regions of the foregut and midgut?

{{c1::Greater and lesser splanchnics (T5 - T12)::2}}

The midgut develops into structures from the {{c1::distal duodenum}} to the {{c2::proximal 2/3 of the transverse colon}}

The {{c1::left gastric}} artery gives off esophageal branches

The {{c1::proper hepatic}} artery gives rise to the {{c2::right}} gastric artery
The {{c1::gastroduodenal}} artery gives rise to the {{c2::right}} gastroepiploic artery

The {{c3::splenic}} artery gives rise to the {{c1::left gastroepiploic}} and {{c2::short gastric}} arteries
ID Artery: {{c1::Left gastroepiploic}}
ID Artery: {{c1::Splenic}}
ID Artery: {{c1::Right gastroepiploic}}
ID Artery: {{c1::Left gastric}}
ID Artery: {{c1::Right gastric}}
ID Artery: {{c1::Common hepatic}}
ID Artery: {{c1::Gastroduodenal}}
ID Artery: {{c1::Short gastric arteries}}
The fundus and upper portion of the greater curvature of the stomach are supplied by the {{c1::short gastric}} arteries

{{c2::Caput medusae}} results from portosystemic shunting between the {{c1::paraumbilical}} veins (portal) and small {{c1::epigastric}} veins of the abdominal wall (systemic)

Which type of hemorrhoid is NOT painful?

{{c1::Internal hemorrhoids}}

{{c1::Portal}}

Which type of hemorrhoids are found below the pectinate line?

{{c1::External hemorrhoids}}

Which type of carcinoma forms below the pectinate line?

{{c1::Squamous cell carcinoma}}

Which artery supplies the rectum below the pectinate line?

Which type of hemorrhoid IS painful?

{{c1::External hemorrhoids}}

{{c1::Zone I (periportal)}}

{{c1::Zone II (intermediate)}}

{{c1::Zone III (centrilobular)}}

{{c1::Zone III (centrilobular)}}

{{c1::Femoral nerve, artery, and vein}}

{{c1::Femoral artery, vein, and canal (deep inguinal lymph nodes)}}

{{c1::Inguinal ligament}}

{{c1::Adductor longus muscle}}

{{c1::IgM and IgD}}

{{c1::Bone marrow}}
