{{c1::Celiac}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the upper duodenum?

{{c1::Celiac}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the lower duodenum?

{{c1::Superior mesenteric}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the jejunum and ileum?

{{c1::Superior mesenteric}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the proximal colon up to the splenic flexure?

{{c1::Superior mesenteric}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the colon from splenic flexure to upper rectum?

{{c1::Inferior mesenteric}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the bladder?

{{c1::Internal iliac}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the prostate?

{{c1::Internal iliac}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the cervix?

{{c1::Internal iliac}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the testes and ovaries?

{{c1::Para-aortic}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the kidney?

{{c1::Para-aortic}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the uterus?

{{c1::Para-aortic}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the scrotum and vulva?

{{c1::Superficial inguinal}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the skin below the umbilicus?

{{c1::Superficial inguinal}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the dorsolateral foot?

{{c1::Popliteal}}

Which lymph node cluster drains the posterior calf?

{{c1::Popliteal}}
The {{c1::right lymphatic}} duct drains lymph from the right side of the body above the diaphragm
The {{c2::thoracic}} duct drains most lymph into the junction of the {{c1::left subclavian}} and {{c1::left internal jugular veins}}
The spleen is located in the LUQ of the abdomen, behind the {{c1::9th}} - {{c1::11th}} ribs
Within the spleen, central arterioles are surrounded by {{c1::periarterial lymphatic sheaths (PALS)}}
The PALS and lymphoid follicles of the spleen constitute the {{c1::white}} pulp

Where in the spleen are T-cells found?

{{c1::Periarterial lymphatic sheath (white pulp)}}

Where in the spleen are B-cells found?

{{c1::Follicles (white pulp)}}
Splenic sinusoids are long, vascular channels with fenestrated basement membranes that constitute the {{c1::red}} pulp
In between the red and white pulp of the spleen is the {{c1::marginal zone}}, which contains macrophages and specialized B cells

Where in the spleen do Splenic Macrophages capture blood-borne antigens for recognition by lymphocytes?

{{c1::Marginal zone}}

How do platelet levels change post-splenectomy?

{{c1::Increased (thrombocytosis)}}

How do lymphocyte levels change post-splenectomy?

{{c1::Increased (lymphocytosis)}}

What RBC abnormalities are seen on blood smear post-splenectomy?

{{c1::Howell-Jolly bodies and target cells::2}}
Patients undergoing splenectomy should be vaccinated against {{c1::encapsulated}} organisms

Which immunoglobulin is decreased with splenic dysfunction?

{{c1::IgM}}
The {{c1::thymus}} is an encapsulated lymphoid organ located in the anterosuperior mediastinum

What branchial pouch develops into the thymus?

{{c1::Third branchial pouch (ventral wing)}}

What is the embryonic origin of lymphocytes in the thymus?

{{c1::Mesenchymal origin}}
The {{c1::cortex}} of the thymus is dense and comprised of {{c2::immature}} T cells
The {{c1::medulla}} of the thymus is pale and comprised of {{c2::mature}} T cells and Hassall corpuscles
{{c1::Hassalls corpuscles}} are eosinophilic areas in the thymus composed of epithelial reticular cells
Thymoma is a benign neoplasm of thymus associated with {{c1::myasthenia gravis::immune}}, {{c2::SVC syndrome::lung/vascular}}, {{c3::pure red cell}} aplasia and Good syndrome
The {{c1::progenitor}} B cell lacks cytoplasmic μ and surface IgM/IgD
The {{c1::precursor}} B cell is characterized by cytoplasmic μ
The {{c1::immature}} B cell is characterized by surface IgM, but no surface IgD
{{c1::Plasma}} cells are mature, differentiated B cells characterized by cytoplasmic Ig
{{c1::Memory B}} cells are mature, differentiated B cells characterized by surface IgG, IgA, or IgE
B-cells with self-reactivity in the bone marrow are destroyed by clonal {{c1::deletion}}
T-cells that are self-reactive in the periphery are inactivated by clonal {{c1::anergy}}
{{c1::Major histocompatibility complexes (MHCs)}} present antigen fragments to T cells and bind T-cell receptors (TCRs)
Major histocompatibility complexes (MHCs) are encoded by {{c1::HLA}} genes

Which MHC class is associated with the gene products of HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C?

{{c1::MHC I}}

Which MHC class is expressed on all nucleated cells and platelets?

{{c1::MHC I}}
MHC {{c2::I}} binds to the T-cell receptor (TCR) and CD-{{c1::8}}

Which MHC class is formed by 1 long chain and 1 short chain?

{{c1::MHC I}}

Which MHC class has a smaller peptide binding groove (8 - 10 AA)?

{{c1::MHC I}}

What protein is associated with MHC I?

{{c1::β2-microglobulin}}

Which MHC class is associated with the gene products of HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR?

{{c1::MHC II}}

Which MHC class is expressed on antigen presenting cells (APCs), only?

{{c1::MHC II}}
MHC {{c2::II}} binds to the T-cell receptor (TCR) and CD-{{c1::4}}

Which MHC class is formed by 2 equal length chains?

{{c1::MHC II}}

Which MHC class has a larger peptide binding groove (13 - 17 AA)?

{{c1::MHC II}}

What protein is associated with MHC II?

{{c1::Invariant chain}}

How many classes of MHC I are expressed on a single cell?

{{c1::Six}}

Which CD markers (CD4, CD8) does the T-cell precursor express in the bone marrow?

{{c1::None :)}}

Which CD marker(s) (CD4, CD8) does the T-cell express in the thymic cortex?

{{c1::Both CD4 and CD8}}

Which CD marker(s) (CD4, CD8) does the T-cell express in the thymic medulla?

{{c1::Either CD4 or CD8}}
In the {{c1::thymic medulla}}, the T cell differentiates into a CD4+ or CD8+ T cell

Which type of selection allows survival of T cells expressing TCRs capable of binding self-MHC on cortical epithelial cells?

{{c1::Positive selection}}

Where does positive selection of T cells occur?

{{c1::Thymic cortex}}

Which type of selection causes T cells expressing TCRs with high affinity for self antigens on cortical epithelial cells to either undergo apoptosis or become regulatory T cells

{{c1::Negative selection}}
The tissue-restricted self-antigens expressed in the thymus for negative selection are due to the action of {{c1::autoimmune regulator (AIRE)}}
Deficiency of {{c2::autoimmune regulator (AIRE)}} protein causes {{c1::autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome-1}}

Where does negative selection of T cells occur?

{{c1::Thymic medulla}}

What non-nucleated cell expresses MHC class I?

{{c1::Platelets}}
MHC {{c2::I}} presents {{c1::endogenously}} synthesized antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells

Antigen loading onto MHC I occurs in the RER after breakdown of endogenous antigen by the {{c1::proteasome}} in the cytosol, and delivery to the RER via {{c2::TAP (transporter associated with antigen processing)}}
MHC {{c2::II}} presents {{c1::exogenously}} synthesized antigens to CD4+ helper T cells
Antigen loading onto MHC II occurs following release of the {{c2::invariant chain}} in a(n) {{c1::acidified endosome}}
The first signal for T-cell activation is binding between the {{c1::TCR}} and {{c1::MHC/peptide complex}}
The second signal for T-cell activation is a costimulatory signal via interaction between {{c1::B7}} (APC) and {{c1::CD28}} (T cell)
Differentiation of helper T cells to {{c2::Th2}} is induced by {{c1::IL-2}} and {{c1::IL-4}}
Differentiation of helper T cells to {{c2::Th2}} is inhibited by {{c1::IFN-γ}}

What class of helper T cell secretes IL-4, -5, -6, -10, and -13?

{{c1::Th2}}

What class of helper T cell recruits eosinophils for parasite defense?

{{c1::Th2}}

What class of helper T cell promotes IgE production by B cells?

{{c1::Th2}}

What class of helper T cell promotes humoral immunity?

{{c1::Th2}}
Differentiation of helper T cells to {{c2::Th1}} is induced by {{c1::IFN-γ}} and {{c1::IL-12}}
Differentiation of helper T cells to {{c2::Th1}} is inhibited by {{c1::IL-4}} and {{c1::IL-10}} (from Th2 cells)

What class of helper T cell secretes IFN-γ and IL-2?

{{c1::Th1}}
Th1 cells secrete {{c1::IFN-γ}} and {{c2::IL-2}}

What class of helper T cell activates macrophages and cytotoxic T cells?

{{c1::Th1}}

What class of helper T cell promotes cell-mediated immunity?

{{c1::Th1}}
Differentiation of helper T cells to {{c2::Treg}} is induced by {{c1::TGF-β}} and {{c1::IL-2}}; inhibited by {{c2::IL-6}}

What class of helper T cell helps maintain specific immune tolerance by suppressing CD4 and CD8 T-cell effector functions?

{{c1::Regulatory T (TReg) cells}}
{{c3::Regulatory T}} cells are identified by expression of CD3, CD4, {{c1::CD25}}, and {{c2::FOXP3}}
Activated regulatory T cells produce {{c1::IL-10}} and {{c2::TGF-β}} (anti-inflammatory cytokines)
Differentiation of helper T cells to {{c2::Th17}} is induced by {{c2::IL-1}}, {{c1::IL-6}} and {{c1::TGF-β}}

What class of helper T cell are believed to play a role in tissue damage associated with autoimmune disease?

{{c1::Th17 cells}}

Which type of immunity responds to antigens with antibodies from plasma cells?

{{c1::Humoral immunity::humoral or cell-mediated}}
Humoral immunity is used to defend against {{c1::extra}}-cellular agents

Is humoral immunity primarily mediated by B-cells or T-cells?

{{c1::B-cells}}
B-cell activation begins with presentation of foreign antigen on {{c1::MHC II}}, which is recognized by a T-cell receptor
B-cell activation requires a costimulatory signal from binding between the {{c1::CD40 receptor}} (B cell) and {{c1::CD40 ligand}} (Th2 cell)
Antigens that lack a(n) {{c1::peptide}} component are not recognizable by T cells and thus stimulate B cells directly

Do thymus-independent antigens result in immunologic memory?

{{c1::No}}

What is the only immunoglobulin that can be secreted in response to thymus-independent antigens?

{{c1::IgM}}
One example of a thymus-independent antigen is {{c1::lipopolysaccharides (LPS)}} from gram negative bacteria

Do thymus-dependent antigens result in immunologic memory?

{{c1::Yes}}

Which type of antibody digestion results in 2 monovalent Fab regions and 1 Fc region?

{{c1::Papain cleavage}}

Which type of antibody digestion results in 1 bivalent Fab region and 1 Fc region?

{{c1::Pepsin cleavage}}

Which immunoglobulin isotypes can exist as a monomer?

{{c1::All Ig types}}
IgM exists as a(n) {{c1::monomer}} on the surface of B cells
Ig{{c2::M}} exists as a(n) {{c1::pentamer}} held by a J chain when secreted

How many identical antigens can a single IgM molecule bind?

{{c1::10}}

Does IgM fix complement?

{{c1::Yes}}

Does IgM cross the placenta?

{{c1::No}}

Which immunoglobulin is produced first in response to an infection?

{{c1::IgM}}

Which immunoglobulin is the main antibody produced during the primary response to antigen?

{{c1::IgM}}
The {{c1::valence}} of an antibody refers to the number of sites available to bind epitopes
The {{c1::affinity}} of an antibody refers to the binding strength for an epitope

Which immunoglobulin has the highest avidity?

{{c1::IgM}}

Which immunoglobulin has the highest affinity?

{{c1::IgG}}
Generation of antibody specificity occurs via {{c1::somatic hypermutation}} with {{c2::affinity maturation}}

Where does class switching of IgM take place?

{{c1::Germinal centers of lymph nodes}}
Class switching of IgM is mediated by CD40L and cytokines from {{c1::Th2::specific}} cells
Class switching to Ig{{c2::A}} is promoted by {{c1::IL-5}} and TGF-β
Class switching to Ig{{c2::E}} is promoted by {{c1::IL-4}} and {{c1::IL-13}}

Which immunoglobulin is the main antibody produced during the secondary response to antigen?

{{c1::IgG}}

What is the most abundant immunoglobulin isotype in serum?

{{c1::IgG}}

Does IgG fix complement?

{{c1::Yes}}

Does IgG cross the placenta?

{{c1::Yes}}

Which immunoglobulin(s) fix complement?

{{c1::IgM and IgG}}

Which immunoglobulin(s) cross the placenta?

{{c1::IgG}}

Which immunoglobulin opsonizes bacteria?

{{c1::IgG}}

Which immunoglobulin is the most produced antibody overall?

{{c1::IgA}}
IgA exists as a(n) {{c1::monomer}} in circulation
Ig{{c2::A}} exists as a(n) {{c1::dimer}} held by a J chain when secreted
IgA crosses epithelial cells by {{c1::transcytosis}}

Which immunoglobulin is produced in the GI tract and protects against gut infections?

{{c1::IgA}}

Which immunoglobulin is released into breast milk (colostrum)?

{{c1::IgA}}

Which immunoglobulin is released into secretions (tears, saliva, mucus)?

{{c1::IgA}}

Does IgA fix complement?

{{c1::No}}

Does IgA cross the placenta?

{{c1::No}}
IgA is transported through the mucosa via binding between the {{c1::J chain}} of IgA and the {{c2::polymeric Ig}} receptor on epithelial cells
When IgA is released into the mucosa, the poly Ig receptor becomes the {{c1::secretory component}}, which protects IgA from luminal proteases

Which immunoglobulin binds directly to mast cells and basophils?

{{c1::IgE}}
IgE cross-links when exposed to allergen, mediating type {{c1::I}} hypersensitivity reactions

Which immunoglobulin contributes to immunity to worms by activating eosinophils?

{{c1::IgE}}

What is the least abundant immunoglobulin isotype in serum?

{{c1::IgE}}

Which immunoglobulin(s) can be secreted by plasma cells?

{{c1::IgA, IgG, or IgE (one type per plasma cell)}}

Which type of immunity responds to antigens with activated cytotoxic T-cells?

{{c1::Cell-mediated immunity::humoral or cell-mediated}}
Cell-mediated immunity is used to defend against {{c1::intra}}-cellular agents

Is cell-mediated immunity primarily mediated by B-cells or T-cells?

{{c1::T-cells}}
Cytotoxic (CD8+) T-cells kill virus infected, neoplastic, and donor graft cells by inducing {{c1::apoptosis}}
Cytotoxic T cells may induce apoptosis of target cells via release of {{c1::perforins}} and {{c1::granzymes}}, which leads to activation of caspases
Cytotoxic T cells may induce apoptosis of target cells via binding of {{c1::Fas ligand}} to {{c1::Fas}}, which causes release of TNF

Which immune cell is a lymphocyte member of the innate immune system?

{{c1::Natural killer (NK) cells}}
Natural killer cells may induce apoptosis of virally infected cells and tumors cells via release of {{c1::perforins}} and {{c1::granzymes}}

Which interferons enhance activity of natural killer cells?

{{c1::Interferon-α and Interferon-β}}

Which interleukins enhance activity of natural killer cells?

{{c1::IL-2 and IL-12}}
{{c2::Natural killer}} cells are induced to kill cells that have an absence of {{c1::MHC I}} on their cell surface
Natural killer cells may kill cells via binding between {{c1::CD16}} (NK cells) and the {{c2::Fc}} region of IgG-bound antigen

Which immunoglobulin typically mediates antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)?

{{c1::IgG*}}
{{c1::Superantigens}} are antigens that {{c2::cross-link}} the β region of T-cell receptors to MHC II on APCs outside the normal peptide-binding groove
{{c1::Superantigens}} can activate any CD4+ T-cell, resulting in massive release of cytokines
{{c1::Anergy}} refers to a state in which an immune cell cannot become activated by exposure to its antigen
T-cells and B-cells become {{c1::anergic}} when exposed to their antigen without a costimulatory signal

Which type of immunization is acquired by receiving preformed antibodies?

{{c1::Passive immunization}}

Which type of immunization has a rapid onset?

{{c1::Passive immunization}}

Which type of immunization has a short span of duration?

{{c1::Passive immunization}}
Consumption of IgA in breast milk is an example of {{c1::passive}} immunization
Maternal IgG crossing the placenta is an example of {{c1::passive}} immunization
Administration of antitoxin or monoclonal antibody is an example of {{c1::passive}} immunization
One risk of passive immunotherapy is IgE production and anaphylaxis, especially in patients with selective {{c1::IgA}} deficiency

Toxins that require passive immunity in exposed, unvaccinated patients may be remembered with the mnemonic "To Be Healed Very Rapidly":

T: {{c1::Tetanus toxin}}
B: {{c2::Botulinum toxin}}
H: {{c3::HBV}}
V: {{c4::Varicella}}
R: {{c5::Rabies virus}}

Which type of immunization is acquired by exposure to foreign antigens?

{{c1::Active immunization}}

Which type of immunization has a slow onset?

{{c1::Active immunization}}

Which type of immunization has a long-lasting protection (memory)?

{{c1::Active immunization}}
Natural infection is an example of {{c1::active}} immunization
Administration of toxoid is an example of {{c1::active}} immunization
Administration of vaccines is an example of {{c1::active}} immunization

Which type of vaccine induces a strong, often lifelong immunity?

{{c1::Live, attenuated vaccines}}

Which type of vaccine has the potential to revert to a virulent form?

{{c1::Live, attenuated vaccines}}
Live attenuated vaccines are often contraindicated in {{c1::pregnancy}} and {{c2::immunodeficiency}}
{{c2::MMR}} and {{c3::varicella}} are live vaccines that can be given to HIV patients with CD4 counts > {{c1::200}}/mm3

Do live attenuated vaccines induce cellular or humoral responses?

{{c1::Both cellular and humoral :)}}

What type of vaccine is the MMR vaccine?

{{c1::Live attenuated}}

What type of vaccine is the rotavirus vaccine?

{{c1::Live attenuated}}

What type of vaccine is the yellow fever vaccine?

{{c1::Live attenuated}}

What type of vaccine is the varicella vaccine?

{{c1::Live attenuated}}

What type of vaccine is the BCG vaccine?

{{c1::Live attenuated}}

What type of vaccine is the intranasal influenza vaccine?

{{c1::Live attenuated}}

Which polio vaccine is a live attenuated (oral) vaccine?

{{c1::Sabin}}

Which type of vaccine is a pathogen that has been inactivated by heat or chemicals?

{{c1::Inactivated/killed vaccine}}

What is an advantage of inactivated vaccines compared to live attenuated?

{{c1::Inactivated vaccines are safer}}

Which types of vaccine induce a relatively weak immune response?

{{c1::Inactivated/killed vaccines and Subunit vaccine::2}}

Do killed/inactivated vaccines induce cellular or humoral responses?

{{c1::Humoral}}

What part of an antigen should be preserved to elicit an immune response when given as an inactivated/killed vaccine?

{{c1::Epitope}}

What type of vaccine is the rabies vaccine?

{{c1::Inactivated/killed}}

What type of vaccine is the injected influenza vaccine?

{{c1::Inactivated/killed}}

Which polio vaccine is an inactivated/killed vaccine?

{{c1::Salk}}

What type of vaccine is the hepatitis A vaccine?

{{c1::Inactivated/killed}}

What is the first type of immunoglobulin produced in a neonate?

{{c1::IgM}}
By age 1, the total antibody level is approximately {{c1::60}}% of adult levels
By age 1, the total IgA level is approximately {{c1::20}}% of adult levels

What is the only useful immunoglobulin for diagnosing neonatal infections?

{{c1::IgM}}
Some killed vaccines are conjugated to a(n) {{c1::protein}} to elicit a stronger immune response (e.g. immunologic memory)
Type I HSR occurs due to cross-linking of Ig{{c1::E}} on presensitized {{c3::mast cells}} and {{c3::basophils}} by antigen
The immediate response of mast cell and basophil activation is release of preformed {{c1::histamine}} granules and {{c2::tryptase::marker of activation}}
The delayed response of mast cell and basophil activation involves production of {{c2::chemokines}} (ex. to attract eosinophils) and cytokines (particularly {{c1::leukotrienes}})

Which type of hypersensitivity mediates anaphylaxis (e.g. food, drug, or bee sting allergies)?

{{c1::Type I}}

Which type of hypersensitivity mediates atopic reactions (e.g. asthma, allergic rhinitis)?

{{c1::Type I}}
{{c1::Skin Pinprick}} tests or {{c2::Blood (ELISA)}} tests for allergen-specific IgE are typically used to diagnose type I hypersensivity reactions

Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by binding of antibodies to cell-surface antigens?

{{c1::Type II HSR}}
Type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing {{c1::cellular destruction}} by opsonizing the target with antibodies
Type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing {{c1::cellular dysfunction}}, causing abnormal blockade or activation/inactivation of downstream cellular processes
Type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing {{c1::inflammation}} by antibodies depositing on cell surfaces, which in turn activates complement

Which immunoglobulins mediate type II hypersensivity reactions?

{{c1::IgM and IgG}}

What test is used to diagnose type II hypersensitivity reactions against RBCs?

{{c1::Coombs test}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction are immune thrombocytopenic purpura and autoimmune-hemolytic anemia?

{{c1::Type II HSR (cellular destruction)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction are hemolytic disease of the newborn and transfusion reactions?

{{c1::Type II HSR (cellular destruction)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is Goodpasture syndrome?

{{c1::Type II HSR (inflammation)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is rheumatic fever?

{{c1::Type II HSR (inflammation)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is hyperacute transplant rejection?

{{c1::Type II HSR (inflammation)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is Graves disease and Myasthenia Gravis?

{{c1::Type II HSR (cellular dysfunction)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is Pemphigus Vulgaris?

{{c1::Type II HSR (cellular dysfunction)}}

Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is characterized by circulating immune complexes?

{{c1::Type III HSR}}
In type III HSRs, antigen-antibody complexes activate {{c1::complement}}, which attracts {{c2::neutrophils}}
{{c1::Serum sickness}} is an immune complex disease in which antibodies to foreign serum proteins are produced
Serum sickness-like reactions are associated with some drugs acting as {{c1::haptens (ex. penicillin)}} and {{c2::infections (ex. HBV)}}
A(n) {{c1::hapten}} is a small antigen that may conjugate with larger proteins to elicit an immune response
Serum sickness presents with fever, urticaria, arthralgia, proteinuria, and lymphadenopathy {{c1::1}} - {{c1::2}} weeks after antigen exposure

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is serum sickness?

{{c1::Type III HSR}}
{{c1::Arthus reaction}} is a local subacute antibody-mediated HSR to antigen in intradermal injection
Arthus reaction leads to immune complex formation in the {{c1::skin}}; characterized by edema, necrosis, and activation of complement

What type of hypersensivitity reaction is the Arthus reaction?

{{c1::Type III HSR}}

Which is more common, serum sickness or arthus reaction?

{{c1::Serum sickness}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is polyarteritis nodosa?

{{c1::Type III}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)?

{{c1::Type III}}

Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is T-cell mediated?

{{c1::Type IV}}
Type {{c2::IV}} HSRs may occur via direct cell cytotoxicity, which involves CD8+ T cells
Type {{c2::IV}} HSRs may occur via delayed-type hypersensitivity, which involves CD4+ T-cells

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is type I diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::Type IV HSR (direct cell cytotoxicity)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is contact dermatitis (e.g. poison ivy, nickel allergy)?

{{c1::Type IV HSR (CD4 & CD8 Mediated)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is graft-versus-host-disease?

{{c1::Type IV HSR (delayed-type hypersensitivity)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is tuberculin skin test (PPD)?

{{c1::Type IV HSR (Th1 Mediated*)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is patch test?

{{c1::Type IV HSR (CD4 Mediated)}}

Which type(s) of hypersensitivity reactions are antibody-mediated?

{{c1::I, II, and III}}

What type of graft is from self?

{{c1::Autograft}}

What type of graft is from an identical twin or clone?

{{c1::Syngeneic graft (isograft)}}

What type of graft is from a non-identical individual of the same species?

{{c1::Allograft}}

What type of graft is from a different species?

{{c1::Xenograft}}
Chronic kidney transplant rejection typically presents as {{c1::chronic allograft nephropathy}}

What skin appearance is classically seen in carbon monoxide poisoning?

{{c1::Cherry-red appearance}}

Which cellular change is characterized by an increased number of cells?

{{c1::Hyperplasia}}

Which cellular change is characterized by an increased size of cells?

{{c1::Hypertrophy}}
{{c1::Hypertrophy::(hypertrophy or hyperplasia)}} involves gene activation, protein synthesis, and production of organelles
{{c1::Hyperplasia::(hypertrophy or hyperplasia)}} involves the controlled proliferation of stem cells and differentiated cells

Do permanent tissues (e.g. cardiac muscle, skeletal muscle, nerve) undergo hypertrophy and/or hyperplasia?

{{c1::Hypertrophy, only}}

Which cellular change is characterized by a decrease in tissue mass due to decrease in size or number of cells?

{{c1::Atrophy}}
Atrophy via decrease in cell number occurs via {{c1::apoptosis}}
Atrophy via decrease in cell size may occur via {{c1::ubiquitin-proteasome}} degradation of cytoskeleton
Atrophy via decrease in cell size may occur via {{c1::autophagy}} of cellular components

Which cellular change is characterized by replacement of one cell type by another?

{{c1::Metaplasia}}

Which cellular change typically occurs after chronic exposure to an irritant, such as gastric acid or smoke?

{{c1::Metaplasia}}
Metaplasia occurs via reprogramming of {{c1::stem}} cells, which then produce the new cell type

Is metaplasia reversible or irreversible?

{{c1::Reversible}}
Under persistent stress, metaplasia can progress to dysplasia and eventually {{c1::cancer}}

Which metaplasia carries no increased risk for malignancy?

{{c1::Apocrine metaplasia of breast}}
Vitamin {{c1::A}} deficiency can result in metaplasia

What musculoskeletal disorder is characterized by metaplasia of skeletal muscle to bone?

{{c1::Myositis ossificans}}

Which cellular change is characterized by disordered, non-neoplastic cellular growth?

{{c1::Dysplasia}}

Which mitochondrial membrane contains the electron transport chain?

{{c1::Inner mitochondrial membrane}}
Cellular injury is characterized by {{c1::decreased}} activity of the Na+-K+ and Ca2+ pumps

What is the hallmark of reversible cellular injury?

{{c1::Swelling}}
{{c2::Reversible}} cellular injury is characterized ultrastructurally by membrane {{c1::blebbing}} and loss of microvilli
{{c2::Reversible}} cellular injury is characterized ultrastructurally by {{c1::ribosomal}} detachment and {{c3::polysomal}} detachment, leading to decreased protein synthesis

What is the hallmark of irreversible cellular injury?

{{c1::Membrane damage}}
Plasma membrane damage in irreversible cellular injury results in entry of {{c1::Ca2+}} ions into the cell
Mitochondrial {{c1::vacuolization}} signifies irreversible cellular injury
{{c1::Lysosome}} membrane damage in irreversible cell injury results in hydrolytic enzymes leaking into the cytosol

What is the end result of irreversible cell injury?

{{c1::Cell death}}
The morphologic hallmark of cell death is loss of the {{c1::nucleus}}

Which feature of cell death is characterized by nuclear condensation?

{{c1::Pyknosis}}

Which feature of cell death is characterized by nuclear fragmentation?

{{c1::Karyorrhexis}}

Which feature of cell death is characterized by nuclear dissolution?

{{c1::Karyolysis}}
The two MAIN mechanisms of cell death are {{c1::necrosis}} and {{c2::apoptosis}}

Which mechanism of cell death is never physiologic*?

{{c1::Necrosis}}

Which mechanism of cell death is an inflammatory process?

{{c1::Necrosis}}

Which mechanism of cell death involves death of a large group of cells?

{{c1::Necrosis}}

Which type of necrosis is characterized by preserved cell shape and organ structure?

{{c1::Coagulative necrosis}}
Coagulative necrosis is characterized by preserved cell architecture (cell {{c2::outlines}} are seen) but the {{c1::nucleus}} disappears
{{c1::Coagulative}} necrosis is characteristic of {{c2::ischemic infarction}} of any organ except the {{c3::brain}}
In coagulative necrosis, injury denatures {{c1::proteolytic enzymes}}

Which type of necrosis is characterized by enzymatic lysis of cells and protein?

{{c1::Liquefactive necrosis}}
In the late phase of liquefactive necrosis of the {{c1::brain}}, cystic spaces and cavitation may be seen

What type of necrosis is seen with brain infarcts and abscess?

{{c1::Liquefactive necrosis}}

Which cells release proteolytic enzymes in response to brain infarction, causing liquefactive necrosis?

{{c1::Microglial cells}}

Which cells release proteolytic enzymes in response to brain abscess, causing liquefactive necrosis?

{{c1::Neutrophils}}

In addition to the brain, what other organ may undergo liquefactive necrosis?

{{c1::Pancreas}}

Which type of necrosis resembles mummified tissue?

{{c1::Gangrenous (dry)}}
{{c1::Gangrenous}} necrosis is characteristic of chronic ischemia of the {{c2::lower limb}} and {{c3::GI tract}}
Gangrenous necrosis is a form of {{c1::coagulative}} necrosis

What type of necrosis may be seen with gangrenous necrosis if superinfection occurs?

{{c1::Liquefactive necrosis ("wet gangrene")}}

Which type of necrosis is characterized by soft, friable necrotic tissue with a "cottage cheese-like" appearance?

{{c1::Caseous necrosis}}
Caseous necrosis is a combination of {{c1::coagulative}} and {{c1::liquefactive}} necrosis

Which type of necrosis is characteristic of tuberculous and fungal infections?

{{c1::Caseous necrosis}}

Which type of necrosis is characterized by fragmented cells/debris surrounded by lymphocytes and macrophages?

{{c1::Caseous necrosis}}

Which type of necrosis is characterized by a chalky-white appearance due to deposition of Ca2+?

{{c1::Fat necrosis}}
Fat necrosis is characteristically due to {{c2::acute pancreatitis}} or {{c1::trauma (e.g. breast)}}
In fat necrosis, fatty acids bind to Ca2+ via a process called {{c1::saponification}}
Saponification of fat appears {{c1::dark blue::color}} on H&E stain

Which type of calcification occurs in abnormal, necrotic tissues?

{{c1::Dystrophic::dystrophic or metastatic}}

Which type of calcification occurs secondary to injury or necrosis?

{{c1::Dystrophic::dystrophic or metastatic}}

Which type of calcification tends to be localized?

{{c1::Dystrophic::dystrophic or metastatic}}

Are patients with dystrophic calcifications usually normocalcemic?

{{c1::Yes}}

Which type of calcification occurs in normal, non-necrotic tissues?

{{c1::Metastatic::dystrophic or metastatic}}

Which type of calcification occurs secondary to hypercalcemia or hyperphosphatemia?

{{c1::Metastatic::dystrophic or metastatic}}

Which type of calcification tends to be widespread?

{{c1::Metastatic::dystrophic or metastatic}}
Metastatic calcification predominantly occurs in the {{c1::kidney}}, {{c2::lung}}, and gastric mucosa

Which type of necrosis is characterized by necrotic damage to blood vessel walls?

{{c1::Fibrinoid necrosis}}
Fibrinoid necrosis is characteristic of {{c1::malignant}} hypertension, {{c2::vasculitis (e.g. PAN)}}, and {{c3::preeclampsia}}
Fibrinoid necrosis is characterized histologically by thick, {{c1::bright pink::color}} staining of vessel walls

Which mechanism of cell death is an ATP-dependent programmed cell death?

{{c1::Apoptosis}}

Which mechanism of cell death is NOT followed by inflammation?

{{c1::Apoptosis}}

Which mechanism of cell death involves death of single cells or small groups of cells?

{{c1::Apoptosis}}
Apoptosis is characterized morphologically by cell {{c1::shrinkage::size}}, chromatin condensation, and membrane blebbing
The nucleus of apoptotic cells stains deeply {{c1::baso}}-philic
Apoptosis results in the formation of apoptotic bodies, which are subsequently phagocytosed by {{c1::macrophages}}
Apoptosis is mediated by {{c1::caspases}}, which activate proteases and endonucleases

What class of enzymes breaks down DNA in apoptosis?

{{c1::Endonucleases}}

What class of enzymes breaks down the cytoskeleton in apoptosis?

{{c1::Proteases}}
The mitochondrial (intrinsic) pathway of apoptosis occurs via inactivation of {{c1::Bcl2}}
Bcl-2 normally keeps the mitochondrial outer membrane impermeable, thus preventing {{c1::cytochrome c}} release from the intermembrane space

Are the Bcl-2 related proteins BAX and BAK pro- or anti-apoptotic?

{{c1::Pro-apoptotic}}
The extrinsic (death receptor) pathway of apoptosis can occur via receptor binding between {{c1::Fas-L}}-(receptor: CD{{c3::95}}) or {{c2::TNF-α}} and their respective receptors
The extrinsic pathway of apoptosis can occur via a CD-{{c1::8}}+ T-cell pathway
Defective {{c2::Fas-FasL}} interactions can cause {{c1::autoimmune lymphoproliferative}} syndrome
DNA laddering in multiples of 180 BP is a sensitive indicator of {{c1::apoptosis}}
{{c1::Free radicals}} are chemical species with an unpaired electron in their outer orbit
If O2 accepts one electron, it forms {{c1::superoxide (O2-)}}
If O2 accepts two electrons, it forms {{c1::hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)}}
If O2 accepts three electrons, it forms {{c1::hydroxyl anion (OH-)}}
Pathologic generation of free radicals arises with ionizing radiation, which hydrolyzes H2O to {{c1::OH-}}

Which oxygen-derived free radical is the most damaging?

{{c1::OH-}}
Pathologic generation of free radicals arises with metals (e.g. copper and iron) via the {{c1::Fenton}} reaction
Free radicals cause cellular injury via {{c1::peroxidation}} of lipids and {{c2::oxidation}} of DNA and proteins
Free radicals may be eliminated via {{c1::antioxidants}} (e.g. reduced glutathione and vitamins A, C, and E)

What mitochondrial enzyme reduces superoxide (O2-) to H2O2?

{{c1::Superoxide dismutase}}

What enzymes reduce hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to O2 and H2O?

{{c1::Catalase}} and {{c1::glutathione peroxidase}}
Free radicals may be eliminated via metal carrier proteins, such as {{c1::transferrin (Fe2+)}} and {{c2::ceruloplasmin (Cu2+)}}

What organic solvent used in the dry cleaning industry is converted to free radicals in the liver?

{{c1::Carbon tetrachloride (CCl4)}}
CCl3 free radical damage in the liver results in decreased apolipoprotein synthesis with resultant {{c1::fatty}} change and {{c2::centrilobular::location}} necrosis

What cause of free radical injury occurs following thrombolytic therapy?

{{c1::Reperfusion injury}}

Which layer of the heart wall is most vulnerable to hypoxia/ischemia?

{{c1::Subendocardium (LV)}}

Which regions of the colon are most vulnerable to hypoxia/ischemia?

{{c1::Splenic flexure}} and {{c2::rectosigmoid junction}}
{{c1::Amyloid}} is a misfolded protein that deposits in the extracellular space, resulting in cellular damage and apoptosis

What is the shared structural feature of amyloid?

{{c1::β-pleated sheet}}
Amyloid may be visualized using {{c1::Congo red}} staining
Amyloid may be visualized as {{c1::apple-green birefringence}} under polarized light
{{c3::Primary}} amyloidosis is characterized by systemic deposition of {{c1::AL amyloid}}, which is derived from {{c2::Ig light chain}}
{{c3::Secondary}} amyloidosis is characterized by systemic deposition of {{c1::AA amyloid}}, which is derived from {{c2::serum amyloid-associated protein (SAA)}}
Serum amyloid-associated protein (SAA) is an acute phase reactant that is increased in chronic inflammatory states, malignancy, and {{c1::Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF)}}
Familial Mediterranean Fever is due to dysfunction of {{c1::neutrophils::cell type}}
Familial Mediterranean fever is characterized by {{c1::AA amyloid}} deposits in tissues during attacks

What organ is most commonly affected by systemic amyloidosis?

{{c1::Kidney}}
Diagnosis of amyloidosis requires {{c1::tissue biopsy}}; the abdominal fat pad and rectum are easily accessible targets
{{c2::Senile cardiac}} amyloidosis is characterized by deposition of non-mutated {{c1::transthyretin (TTR)}} protein
{{c2::Familial amyloid}} cardiomyopathy / polyneuropathies are characterized by deposition of mutated {{c1::transthyretin (TTR)}} protein in the heart and nerves

What type of cardiomyopathy is caused by mutated transthyretin deposits (familial amyloid cardiomyopathy)?

{{c1::Restrictive cardiomyopathy}}
Type {{c2::II}} diabetes mellitus is associated with deposition of {{c1::amylin (islet amyloid polypeptide)}} in the islets of the pancreas
Alzheimer disease is characterized by deposition of {{c1::Aβ-amyloid}} in the brain, which forms amyloid plaques
{{c2::Dialysis}}-associated amyloidosis is characterized by deposition of {{c1::β2-microglobulin}} in {{c3::joints}}

Which amyloidosis may present as carpal tunnel syndrome?

{{c1::Any amyloidosis*}}
Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is characterized by deposition of {{c1::calcitonin}} within the tumor

What HLA subtype is associated with hemochromatosis?

{{c1::A3}}

What HLA subtypes are associated with Addison disease?

{{c1::B8}}, {{c2::DR3}}, and {{c3::DR4}}

What HLA subtypes are associated with Graves disease?

{{c1::B8}} and {{c2::DR3}}

What HLA subtype is associated with seronegative arthropathies?

{{c1::B27}}

What HLA subtype is associated with multiple sclerosis?

{{c1::DR2}}

What HLA subtype is associated with hay fever?

{{c1::DR2}}

What HLA subtypes are associated with SLE?

{{c1::DR2}} and {{c1::DR3}}

What HLA subtype is associated with Goodpasture syndrome?

{{c1::DR2}}

What HLA subtypes are associated with type I diabetes mellitus?

{{c1::DR3}} and {{c1::DR4}}

What HLA subtype is associated with Rheumatoid arthritis?

{{c1::DR4}}

What HLA subtypes are associated with Hashimoto thyroiditis?

{{c1::DR3}} and {{c1::DR5}}

What HLA subtype is associated with pernicious anemia?

{{c1::DR5}}

What is another name for the p-ANCA antibody?

{{c1::Myeloperoxidase (MPO)-ANCA}}

What is another name for the c-ANCA antibody?

{{c1::Proteinase 3 (PR3)-ANCA}}
{{c2::Anti-smooth muscle}} autoantibodies are associated with {{c1::autoimmune hepatitis type 1}}

What is the penetrance of achondroplasia?

{{c1::100%}}
Achondroplasia is characterized by {{c2::short (rhizomelic)}} extremities with a relatively {{c1::large}} head
{{c2::Osteopetrosis}} is caused by an inherited defect in bone {{c1::resorption}}
Osteopetrosis is due to poor osteo-{{c1::clast}} function, impairing the ability to {{c2::remodel}} bone

What MSK pathology is characterized by thick, heavy bone that fractures easily due to failure of bone resorption?

{{c1::Osteopetrosis}}
Osteopetrosis is characterized by diffuse, symmetric skeletal {{c1::sclerosis}} on X-ray
{{c2::Osteopetrosis}} may occur due to mutations in {{c1::carbonic anhydrase II}}, which leads to loss of the acidic environment necessary for bone resorption
Osteopetrosis is associated with {{c1::pancytopenia}} and extramedullary hematopoiesis due to bony replacement of the marrow (myelophthisic process)
Osteopetrosis may present with vision and hearing impairment due to {{c1::cranial nerve}} impingement
Osteopetrosis may present with hydrocephalus due to narrowing of the {{c1::foramen magnum}}

What is the treatment for osteopetrosis?

{{c1::Bone marrow transplant (osteoclasts are derived from monocytes)}}
{{c2::Osteomalacia (Rickets)}} is due to defective mineralization of {{c1::osteoid}}

What is the most common cause of osteomalacia/rickets?

{{c1::Vitamin D deficiency}}

What MSK pathology is caused by low vitamin D in children?

{{c1::Rickets}}
Rickets may present with {{c1::rachitic rosary}} due to osteoid deposition at the costochondral junction
Rickets may present with frontal bossing and {{c1::craniotabes}} (soft skull)
Rickets may present with pathologic {{c1::bow}} legs (genu varum)

What MSK pathology is associated with metaphyseal cupping/fraying?

{{c1::Rickets}}

What MSK pathology is caused by low vitamin D in adults?

{{c1::Osteomalacia}}

What MSK pathology is associated with "Looser zones" (pseudofractures) on X-ray?

{{c1::Osteomalacia}}
Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by {{c1::decreased}} serum Ca2+
Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by {{c1::decreased}} serum PO43-
Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by {{c1::increased}} serum PTH
Osteomalacia/rickets is characterized by {{c1::increased}} serum alkaline phosphatase

What MSK pathology is characterized by a reduction in trabecular and cortical bone mass and interconnections?

{{c1::Osteoporosis}}
Peak bone mass is achieved by {{c1::30}} years of age
Osteoporosis is most commonly due to decreased {{c1::estrogen}} levels or increased {{c2::age}}
Osteoporosis may be secondary to {{c1::hyper}}-thyroidism
Osteoporosis may be secondary to {{c1::hyper}}-parathyroidism
Osteoporosis is diagnosed by DXA scan with a T-score of < {{c1::- 2.5}} or a fragility fracture of the hip or vertebrae
Prophylaxis for osteoporosis includes regular {{c1::weight-bearing}} exercise and adequate Ca2+ / vitamin D intake throughout adulthood

What ethnicity is associated with decreased risk for osteoporosis?

{{c1::African Americans}}
Osteoporosis can lead to {{c1::vertebral}} compression fractures, which result in loss of height and kyphosis
Osteoporosis may present with fracture of the femoral neck or distal {{c1::radius}} (Colles fracture)

What is test used to measure bone density?

{{c1::DEXA scan}}
Osteoporosis is characterized by {{c1::normal}} serum Ca2+
Osteoporosis is characterized by {{c1::normal}} serum PO43-
Osteoporosis is characterized by {{c1::normal}} serum PTH
Osteoporosis is characterized by {{c1::normal}} serum alkaline phosphatase

What MSK pathology is characterized by thick, heavy bone that fractures easily due to imbalance of osteoblast and osteoclast function?

{{c1::Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)}}

Is Paget disease of bone a localized or diffuse process?

{{c1::Localized}}

What demographic is associated with Paget disease of bone?

{{c1::Late adulthood (age > 60)::age group}}

What is the first stage of Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)?

{{c1::Osteoclastic (lytic)}}

What is the second stage of Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)?

{{c1::Mixed osteoblastic-osteoclastic}}

What is the third stage of Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)?

{{c1::Osteoblastic (sclerotic)}}

What is the fourth stage of Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)?

{{c1::Quiescent (minimal osteoclast/osteoblast activity)}}

What MSK pathology is characterized histologically by a mosaic pattern of woven and lamellar bone?

{{c1::Paget disease of bone}}

What MSK pathology is associated with an increasing hat size due to skull thickening?

{{c1::Paget disease of bone}}
Paget disease of bone often presents with {{c1::hearing}} loss due to CN impingement from foramen narrowing
Paget disease of bone is characterized by {{c1::normal}} serum Ca2+
Paget disease of bone is characterized by {{c1::normal}} serum PO43-
Paget disease of bone is characterized by {{c1::normal}} serum PTH
Paget disease of bone is characterized by {{c1::elevated}} serum alkaline phosphatase
Treatment for Paget disease of bone includes {{c1::calcitonin}} and {{c2::bisphosphonates}}
One complication of {{c3::Paget disease of bone}} is {{c1::high-output heart failure}} due to formation of {{c2::AV shunts}} in bone

What malignancy is associated with Paget disease of bone (osteitis deformans)?

{{c1::Osteosarcoma}}

What cause of osteomyelitis is more common in dog and cat bites?

{{c1::Pasteurella multocida}}

What is the most common site for osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis)?

{{c1::Femoral head}}
{{c1::Teriparatide}} is a recombinant form of {{c2::PTH}} used to treat osteoporosis
Osteoma is a benign tumor of {{c1::bone::what overall type of structure?}} that is seen in {{c2::middle}} age
Osteomas most commonly arise on the surface of {{c1::facial}} bones

What GI pathology is associated with osteomas?

{{c1::Gardner syndrome}}
Osteoid osteoma is a benign tumor of {{c1::osteoblasts (which make osteoid)}}, surrounded by a rim of reactive bone

What demographic is associated with osteoid osteoma?

{{c1::Males < 25 years old::age, gender}}
Osteoid osteoma typically arises in the {{c1::cortex}} of the {{c2::diaphysis}} of long bones (e.g. femur)

Imaging of osteoid osteoma reveals a bony mass, {{c1::<}} 2 cm, with a radiolucent core (osteoid)
Osteoblastoma is benign tumor of osteoblasts, typically {{c1::>}} 2 cm
Osteoblastoma presents with bone pain, especially at night, that {{c1::DOES NOT}} resolve with aspirin
Osteoblastoma typically arises in {{c1::vertebrae::body location}}
{{c1::Osteochondroma}} is a benign bone tumor with an overlying cartilage cap

What is the most common benign tumor of bone?

{{c1::Osteochondroma}}
Osteochondroma arises as a lateral projection of the {{c1::growth plate (metaphysis)}}
The overlying cartilage in osteochondroma rarely transforms to {{c1::chondrosarcoma}}

What demographic is associated with osteochondroma?

{{c1::Males < 25 years old::age, gender}}
Osteosarcoma is a malignant proliferation of {{c1::osteoblasts}}
The peak incidence for primary osteosarcoma is in {{c1::teenagers (10-20 years old)::specific}}
The peak incidence for secondary osteosarcoma is in {{c1::the elderly (>65 years old)}}

What MSK pathology predisposes to osteosarcoma?

{{c1::Paget disease of bone}}
Osteosarcoma is associated with {{c1::radiation}} exposure

What inherited cancers are associated with osteosarcoma?

{{c1::Li-Fraumeni syndrome and familial retinoblastoma::2}}
Osteosarcoma arises in the {{c1::metaphysis}} of long bones, often around the {{c2::knee::body location}}
Osteosarcoma typically presents as a pathologic {{c1::fracture}} or bone pain with swelling
Imaging of osteosarcoma may reveal a(n) "{{c1::sunburst}}" pattern on X-ray
Imaging of osteosarcoma may reveal elevation of periosteum, which is known as {{c1::Codman triangle}}

What bone tumor is characterized by a "sunburst" pattern and Codman triangle on X-ray?

{{c1::Osteosarcoma}}
Biopsy of osteosarcoma reveals pleomorphic cells that produce {{c1::osteoid}}

What is the treatment for osteosarcoma?

{{c1::En bloc resection}} and {{c1::chemotherapy}}
Giant cell tumor is a bone tumor comprised of multinucleated giant cells and stromal cells that express {{c1::RANKL}}

What demographic is associated with giant cell tumor of bone?

{{c1::Young adults (20 - 40 years old)::age group}}
Giant cell tumor arises in the {{c1::epiphysis}} of long bones, often in the knee region

Which bone tumor arises in the epiphysis of long bones?

{{c1::Giant cell tumor}}
Giant cell tumor usually arises at the distal {{c1::femur}} or proximal {{c2::tibia}}
Giant cell tumor is associated with a(n) "{{c1::soap bubble}}" appearance on X-ray

Which bone tumor is associated with a "soap-bubble" appearance on X-ray?

{{c1::Giant cell tumor}}
Giant cell tumor is a locally aggressive {{c1::benign::benign or malignant}} tumor
Ewing sarcoma is a malignant proliferation of poorly-differentiated cells derived from {{c1::neuroectoderm}}
Ewing sarcoma arises in the {{c1::diaphysis}} of long bones (particularly the femur); other locations include pelvic {{c2::flat bones}}, scapula, and ribs

What demographic is associated with Ewing sarcoma?

{{c1::Boys < 15 years old::age, gender}}
Ewing sarcoma is associated with a(n) "{{c1::onion-skin}}" appearance on X-ray

Which bone tumor is characterized by small, round blue cells that resemble lymphocytes?

{{c1::Ewing sarcoma}}
{{c2::Ewing sarcoma}} is a bone tumor that is associated with t({{c1::11}};{{c1::22}}) translocation

What is the treatment for Ewing sarcoma?

{{c1::Chemotherapy}}
{{c1::Chondroma}} is a benign tumor of cartilage

Which cartilage tumor arises in the medulla of the small bones in the hands and feet?

{{c1::Chondroma (benign)}}
{{c1::Chondrosarcoma}} is a malignant cartilage-forming tumor

Which cartilage tumor arises in the medulla of the pelvis or central skeleton?

{{c1::Chondrosarcoma (malignant)}}

Which is more common, primary bone tumors or metastasis to the bone?

{{c1::Metastasis}}

Prostatic carcinoma with bone metastasis classically produces {{c1::osteoblastic}} lesions
Pain management for osteoarthritis includes acetaminophen, {{c1::NSAIDs}}, {{c3::Celecoxib}} and/or intra-articular {{c2::glucocorticoids}}

Which arthritis is characterized by joint space narrowing, erosions, and periarticular osteopenia on imaging?

{{c1::Rheumatoid arthritis}}
Reactive arthritis is characterized by a triad of {{c1::conjunctivitis}}, {{c2::urethritis}}, and {{c3::arthritis}}, with patients often also having {{c4::diarrhea::GI}}
{{c1::Dermato}}-myositis in an inflammatory disorder of the skin and skeletal muscle
{{c2::Dermato}}-myositis is characterized by {{c1::peri}}-mysial inflammation with perifascicular atrophy on biopsy
Inflammation in {{c2::dermato}}-myositis is mediated by CD-{{c1::4}}+ T cells
{{c2::Dermatomyositis}} may present with a "{{c1::heliotrope}}" rash, which is an erythematous periorbital rash
{{c2::Dermatomyositis}} may present with a(n) {{c1::malar}} rash that is similar to SLE
{{c1::Dermatomyositis}} may present with a "shawl and face" rash

What enzyme is elevated in both dermatomyositis and polymyositis?

{{c1::Creatine kinase (CK)}}

What is the treatment for dermatomyositis and polymyositis?

{{c1::Corticosteroids, followed by immunosuppressant therapy}}

What demographic is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica?

{{c1::Women > 50 years old::age, gender}}

What vasculitis is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica?

{{c1::Giant cell (temporal) arteritis}}
Polymyalgia rheumatica is associated with a(n) {{c1::normal}} serum creatine kinase (CK)
Polymyalgia rheumatica is associated with a(n) {{c1::elevated}} serum CRP and ESR

What is the treatment for polymyalgia rheumatica?

{{c1::Low-dose corticosteroids}}
{{c1::Fibromyalgia}} presents with chronic, widespread musculoskeletal pain associated with "tender points"

Fibromyalgia is associated with a(n) {{c1::normal}} serum CRP and ESR

What classes of antidepressant are useful for treating fibromyalgia?

{{c1::TCAs and SNRIs::2}}
X-linked muscular dystrophy is characterized by muscle wasting and replacement of skeletal muscle by {{c1::adipose}} tissue

What gene is defective in X-linked muscular dystrophy (e.g. Duchenne, Becker)?

{{c1::Dystrophin (DMD) gene}}

Why is the dystrophin (DMD) gene prone to spontaneous mutations?

{{c1::Largest protein-coding human gene}}

What is the mode of inheritance of Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophy?

{{c1::X-linked}}
{{c1::Duchenne}} muscular dystrophy is typically due to frameshift or non-sense mutations, resulting in a truncated or absent dystrophin protein
{{c1::Becker}} muscular dystrophy is typically due to a non-frameshift deletion, resulting in a partially functional dystrophin protein

{{c1::Duchenne}}

What is a common cause of death in Duchenne muscular dystrophy?

{{c1::Dilated cardiomyopathy}}

Duchenne muscular dystrophy classically presents with the {{c1::Gower}} sign, in which a patient uses their upper extremities to help stand up

What is the mode of inheritance of myotonic dystrophy?

{{c1::Autosomal dominant}}

C: {{c1::Cataracts}}
T: {{c2::Toupee (early balding in men)}}
G: {{c3::Gonadal atrophy}}

What gender is more commonly affected by myasthenia gravis?

{{c1::Females}}

{{c1::Yes}}

What malignancy is associated with myasthenia gravis?

{{c1::Thymoma (also may have thymic hyperplasia)}}

What malignancy is associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome?

{{c1::Small cell lung cancer}}

Is the tensilon test (administration of edrophonium) very useful in diagnosis of Lambert-Eaton?

{{c1::No}}

Which is more common, myasthenia gravis or Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome?

{{c1::Myasthenia gravis}}
{{c1::Liposarcoma}} is a malignant tumor of adipose tissue
{{c1::Rhabdomyoma}} is a benign tumor of striated muscle
{{c1::Rhabdomyosarcoma}} is a malignant tumor of skeletal muscle

What cell type is characteristic of a rhabdomyosarcoma?

{{c1::Rhabdomyoblast}}

What vascular tumor is associated with HHV-8 and HIV?

{{c1::Kaposi sarcoma}}
Vitamin {{c1::K}} is a cofactor for the enzymatic activation of clotting factors

Vitamin K promotes γ-carboxylation at {{c1::glutamic acid::amino acid}} residues

What enzyme activates vitamin K?

{{c1::Epoxide reductase}}

What is the mechanism of action of warfarin?

{{c1::Epoxide reductase inhibitor}}

What is the first clotting factor to be reduced when starting warfarin therapy?

{{c1::Factor VII}}
Warfarins onset of action is {{c1::8}} - {{c1::12}} hours (slow)

What is the route of administration of warfarin?

{{c1::Oral}}
Warfarin has a(n) {{c1::long}} half-life

What laboratory assay is used to follow the effects of warfarin?

{{c1::PT/INR}}
The goal INR for warfarin therapy is typically between {{c1::2}} - {{c1::3}}

Which anticoagulant, warfarin or heparin, is used for chronic anticoagulation?

{{c1::Warfarin}}

Does warfarin cross the placenta?

{{c1::Yes (lipid soluble)}}

Because the bone marrow is a rapidly proliferating population, use of 6-mercaptopurine (and thus azathioprine) is associated with {{c1::Myelosuppression}}
Adalimumab is a monoclonal antibody against {{c1::TNF-α}}
Certolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against {{c1::TNF-α}}

Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody against {{c1::TNF-α}}

Ranibizumab and Bevacizumab are monoclonal antibodies against {{c1::Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF)}} which prevents the growth of blood vessel

{{c1::Degmacyte ("bite cell")::2 names}}

{{c1::Autosomal dominant}}

1. {{c1::Painful abdomen}}
2. {{c2::Port wine-colored urine}}
3. {{c3::Polyneuropathy}}

{{c1::No}}
Treatment for acute intermittent porphyria include {{c1::heme}} and {{c1::glucose}}, which inhibit ALA synthesis

What is the most common porphyria?

Iron poisoning causes cell death due to {{c1::peroxidation}} of membrane lipids

Which blood transfusion therapy is used to increase Hb and O2 carrying capacity?

{{c1::Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) or prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC)::2}}

{{c1::Cryoprecipitate}}

What pharmokinetic term describes the theoretical volume occupied by total amount of drug in the body relative to its plasma concentration?

{{c1::Volume of distribution (Vd)}}

What formula is used to estimate volume of distribution (Vd)?

{{c1::}}

What is the relative volume of distribution (Vd) of a large/charged molecule?

{{c1::Low}}

What is the relative volume of distribution (Vd) of a plasma protein-bound molecule?

{{c1::Low}}

What is the relative volume of distribution (Vd) of a small hydrophilic molecule?

{{c1::Medium}}

What is the relative volume of distribution (Vd) of a small lipophilic molecule, especially if it can bind to tissue protein?

What compartment is the majority of a drug with medium Vd found in?

{{c1::Extracellular fluid}}

What compartment is the majority of a drug with high Vd found in?

{{c1::All tissues including fat}}

What formula is used to calculate clearance?

{{c1::}}

What formula is used to calculate half-life in first-order elimination kinetics?

{{c1::}}

What formula is used to calculate loading dose?

{{c1::}}

What formula is used to calculate maintenance dose?

{{c1::}}

How should loading dose be adjusted in patients with renal or liver disease?

{{c1::Unchanged}}

How should maintenance dose be adjusted in patients with renal or liver disease?

{{c1::Decreased}}

What type of drug interaction is the effect of substance A and B together is equal to the sum of their individual products?

{{c1::Additive (e.g. aspirin and acetaminophen)}}

What type of drug interaction is the presence of A is required for the full effects of substance B?

{{c1::Permissive (e.g. cortisol on catecholamine responsiveness)}}

What type of drug interaction is the effect of substance A and B together being greater than the sum of their individual products?

{{c1::Synergistic (e.g. clopidogrel with aspirin)}}

{{c1::Tachyphylactic (e.g. nitrates, niacin, phenylephrine, LSD, MDMA)}}

What drug elimination is characterized by a linear curve?

{{c1::Zero-order elimination}}

What drug elimination is characterized by an exponential curve?

{{c1::First-order elimination}}

Which type of drug, ionized or uncharged, is cleared more quickly?

{{c1::Ionized (trapped in urine)}}

{{c1::Bicarbonate (alkalinize urine)}}

What is the treatment for overdose of drugs that act as weak bases (e.g. amphetamines, TCAs)?

{{c1::Ammonium chloride (acidify urine)}}

{{c1::Phase I}}

What phase of drug metabolism includes methylation, glucuronidation, acetylation, and sulfation (i.e. conjugation)?

{{c1::Phase II}}
Phase {{c1::II}} drug metabolism usually yields very polar, water-soluble metabolites (inactive)

Which phase of drug metabolism is lost first in geriatric patients?

{{c1::Phase I}}
{{c1::Efficacy}} is the maximal effect a drug can produce
Vmax of a drug is indicative of {{c1::efficacy::potency or efficacy}}
Compared to full agonists, partial agonists have {{c1::less}} efficacy
{{c1::Potency}} is the amount of drug needed for a given effect
EC50 of a drug is indicative of {{c1::potency::potency or efficacy}}

What effect does a competitive antagonist have on potency?

{{c1::Decrease (curve shifts right)}}

What effect does a competitive antagonist have on efficacy?

{{c1::No change}}

What effect does a non-competitive antagonist have on potency?

{{c1::No change}}

What effect does a non-competitive antagonist have on efficacy?

{{c1::Decrease (curve shifts down)}}

What effect does a partial agonist have on efficacy?

{{c1::Decrease (curve shifts down)}}
The therapeutic index is calculated by {{c1::TD50}}/{{c1::ED50}}
Safer drugs have a(n) {{c1::higher}} therapeutic index value

W: {{c1::Warfarin}}
T: {{c2::Theophylline}}
D: {{c3::Digoxin}}
L: {{c4::Lithium}}

What toxin is found in pufferfish?

{{c1::Tetrodotoxin}}

Does tetrodotoxin cause or prevent depolarization?

{{c1::Prevent}}

-Azoles (antifungals) are {{c1::inhibitors}} of CYP-450
