Phenytoin is a(n) {{c1::inducer}} of CYP-450
Phenobarbital is a(n) {{c1::inducer}} of CYP-450
Carbamazepine is a(n) {{c1::inducer}} of CYP-450
{{c1::DiGeorge Syndrome}} is a 22q11 deletion syndrome that presents with {{c2::thymic}} aplasia, {{c2::parathyroid}} aplasia and {{c2::cardiac}} defects
{{c1::Patau Syndrome (Trisomy 13)}} is an autosomal trisomy that is associated with {{c2::cleft lip::face}} and {{c2::cleft palate::face}}
{{c1::Patau Syndrome (Trisomy 13)}} is an autosomal trisomy that is associated with rocker-bottom feet and {{c2::microphthalmia}}

SVC syndrome is commonly caused by malignancy, such as:
- #1 {{c1::mediastinal mass}}
- #2 {{c2::superior sulcus tumor}}
The TSH receptor on the thyroid follicular cells may be stimulated by {{c1::TSI (thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin)}} in Graves Disease
TRH acts on which signalling cascade? {{c1::IP3}}
Thyroid Peroxidase is involved in the first part of T4 synthesis, specifically by catalyzing the addition of {{c2::iodine}} to tyrosine residues on {{c1::thyroglobulin}}
Thyroid hormones (T3/T4) play a role in development of the {{c1::CNS}}
Thyroid hormone increases <u>basal metabolic rate (BMR)</u> via increased activity of {{c1::Na/K-ATPase}}

How does Thyroxine-Binding Globulin (TBG) change with hepatic failure and steroids?

{{c1::Decrease}}

How does Thyroxine-Binding Globulin change in pregnancy and with OCPs?

{{c1::Increase}}
{{c1::Reverse T3 (rT3)}} is an isomer of T3 that mirrors T4 levels

TSH increases which 2nd messenger?

{{c1::cAMP}}
{{c1::Hashimotos Thyroiditis}} is an autoimmune disorder that initially causes a hyperthyroidism that then becomes a hypothyroidism
{{c1::Cretinism}} is a form of congenital hypothyroidism that presents with developmental delay, protruding umbilicus, pot belly, and protruding tongue

Levothyroxine = {{c1::synthetic T4}}
Triiodothyronine = {{c2::synthetic T3}}
Levothyroxine and Triiodothyronine are {{c1::thyroid replacement}} medications that are used to treat hypothyroidism and myxedema
{{c1::Propylthiouracil}} is a thioamide that works by inhibiting Thyroid peroxidase AND 5-Deiodinase
{{c1::Propylthiouracil}} and {{c2::methimazole}} are thionamides used to treat {{c3::hyperthyroidism}}

What kind of hair texture is associated with hypothyroidism?

{{c1::Dry, brittle hair}}
{{c1::Levothyroxine}} is a synthetic T4 hormone replacement that can cause hyperthyroidism

Which thioamide is contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy?

{{c1::Methimazole, so need to use PTU}}

Which thyroid medications can cause agranulocytosis?

{{c1::PTU and Methimazole}}

Which thyroid medications are associated with drug-induced lupus?

{{c1::Propylthiouracil (PTU), methimazole}}
{{c1::Propylthiouracil (PTU)}} is a thioamide associated with severe hepatotoxicity
Propylthiouracil (PTU) and Methimazole are associated with a(n) {{c1::maculopapular skin}} rash
The {{c2::Wolff-Chaikoff}} effect is the inhibition of thyroperoxidase by excess {{c1::iodine}}
Lugols iodine is a large dose of {{c1::Potassium Iodide}} given to evoke the Wolff-Chaikoff effect
The {{c1::Jod-Basedow}} phenomenon is a condition where a patient develops thyrotoxicosis after a period of being administered Iodine
{{c1::Jod-Basedow phenomenon}} occurs when a patient being given high dose potassium iodide (Lugols solution) develops thyrotoxicosis as an adverse effect
Radioactive (I131) Iodine is a last resort treatment of Hyperthyroidism / Graves disease that works by {{c1::ablating}} the Thyroid
Patients who undergo radioactive iodine (I<sup>131</sup>)  treatment can develop {{c1::hypothyroidism}}
β-Blockers are used to treat {{c1::Thyrotoxicosis (thyroid storm)}} by blocking the hyperadrenergic symptoms
β-blockers (ex propranolol) can block peripheral conversion of T4 into T3 by inhibiting {{c1::5-deiodinase}}
Glucocorticoids are anti-inflammatory agents that can be used to inhibit peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting {{c1::5-deiodinase}}
<u>Graves ophthalmopathy</u> can be treated with {{c1::Glucocorticoids}}
{{c1::Amiodarone}} is a class III anti-arrhythmic that can produce hyper or hypothyroidism
{{c1::Lithium}} is a mood stabilizer associated with development of hypothyroidism
Low serum Ca2+ levels will {{c1::increase}} PTH levels in the blood stream
The parathyroid glands have <u>{{c1::Ca2+ sensing </u><u>(CaSR)</u>}} receptors that {{c2::negatively}} regulate secretion of PTH
Chronic PTH exposure stimulates osteoblasts to express as well as secrete {{c1::RANKL}}
RANKL binds to {{c1::RANK}} on Osteoclast precursors / Osteoclast surfaces causing {{c2::activation}} of these cells
Intermittent PTH stimulates maturation of osteoblasts, thus {{c1::increasing}} bone formation
PTH increases Ca2+ {{c1::reabsorption}} by the kidney
PTH increases phosphate {{c1::excretion}} by the kidney
Teriparatide is a(n) {{c1::PTH analog}} used to treat {{c2::osteoporosis}}, wherein the goal is to increase bone density and formation

Does Teriparatide have the exact same activity as endogenous PTH?

{{c1::Yes}}
{{c1::1-alpha-hydroxylase}} converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol) into {{c2::1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (aka calcitriol)}}
Calcitriol stimulates increased {{c1::reabsorption}} of Ca2+ and {{c2::reabsorption}} of phosphate by the kidney
Calcitriol increases {{c2::absorption}} of Ca2+ and {{c1::absorption}} of phosphate in the intestine
Calcitriol {{c1::increases}} Ca2+ and phosphate release into the bloodstream by {{c2::stimulating}} osteoblasts to {{c2::activate}} osteoclasts
Both Calcitriol and Vitamin D can be used to prophylactically treat and mitigate symptoms of {{c1::osteoporosis}}
Vitamin D deficiency can cause {{c1::rickets}} in children and {{c2::osteomalacia}} in adults
Patients with renal insufficiency can be given {{c1::Calcitriol}} to correct their hypocalcemia
Calcitriol is useful in the long term management of {{c1::hypocalcemia}} due to chronic disorders
Patients who have undergone {{c1::Thyroid}} surgery can sometimes manifest with symptoms of hypoparathyroidism and hypocalcemia
Hypocalcemia can lead to {{c1::tetany}} and in severe cases lead to {{c2::seizures}}
Teriparatide and Vitamin D therapy can cause {{c1::hypercalcemia::adverse effect}}
{{c2::Cinacalcet}} is an allosteric activator of the {{c1::Ca2+ sensing (CaSR)}} receptor on the Parathyroid Gland
Cinacalcet is used to treat hypercalcemia secondary to {{c1::hyperparathyroidism}}
{{c2::Sevelamer}} is a compound that binds free {{c1::phosphate}} in the gastrointestinal tract
Sevelamer is used to treat {{c1::hyperphosphatemia}} due to {{c2::chronic kidney}} disease
{{c1::Ubiquitin}}-ation of proteins recruits the {{c2::proteasome}} to degrade them
Adverse effects of sirolimus (rapamycin) include {{c1::pancytopenia}} and {{c2::insulin}} resistance
Sirolimus is primarily used to treat {{c2::transplant rejection}} prophylaxis in patients who have received a(n) {{c1::kidney}} transplant
Sirolimus works by binding {{c1::FKBP}}, which inhibits the {{c2::mTOR::specific signal}} signalling complex involved in cell growth
mTOR is a(n) {{c1::protooncogene::protooncogene or tumorsuppressor?}}
Denosumab prevents {{c1::osteoclast}} activation by binding {{c2::RANKL}} expressed on osteoblasts
Because denosumab impairs osteoclast activity (like bisphosphonates), these drugs can cause {{c1::osteonecrosis of the jaw}}
All biologics (ex monoclonal antibodies) carry the risk of eliciting a(n) {{c1::infusion reaction}} within the first hour of administration

Is the heart failure associated with Trastuzumab reversible with treatment discontinuation?

{{c1::Yes}}
Trastuzumab is contraindicated with {{c1::anthracycline}} usage
Trastuzumab is indicated for {{c1::Her2}}-positive cancers, the most important example being {{c2::breast}} cancer
Busulfans use as an antineoplastic comes from its ability to be a(n) {{c1::alkylating}} agent
Busulfan mediated alkylation of DNA leads to {{c1::cross-linking}} of strands, which DNA repair mechanisms cannot fix
"Busulfan Lung" is the term for the {{c1::fibrotic}} pattern of lung damage which can be caused by Busulfan
Busulfan chemotherapy is associated with a(n) {{c1::hyperpigmentation::skin}} reaction
Busulfan is used to treat {{c1::Chronic Myelogenous}} Leukemia
Prior to a bone marrow transplant, Busulfan can be used as a(n) {{c1::conditioning}} agent
Nitrosureas are chemotherapeutics which can be recognized by the suffixes {{c1::-mustine}} and {{c2::-zotocin}}
Nitrosureas work by {{c1::crosslinking}} DNA
Nitrosureas requires bioactivation by {{c1::cytochrome p450}} enzymes to be effective
Nitrosureas are able to penetrate the {{c1::Blood Brain Barrier}}, making them especially useful for tumors of the {{c2::Central Nervous System}}
-Phosphamide chemotherapeutics are {{c1::alkylating}} agents that work by {{c2::crosslinking}} DNA strands
Cyclophosphamide must be bioactivated by the {{c1::liver}} in order to function
Cyclophosphamide is selective for cells that express low / no levels of {{c1::Aldehyde Dehydrogenase}}
In the process of bioactivating -phosphamides, a highly cytotoxic side product known as {{c1::Acrolein}} is released which can cause {{c2::Hemorrhagic Cystititis}}
To treat the Hemorrhagic Cystitis induced by cyclophosphamide, the compound {{c1::MESNA}} can be administered
Cyclophosphamide and Ifosfamide are especially suited for neoplasias of {{c2::immune}} cells as well as {{c1::solid}} malignancies
Cyclophosphamide can be used as an immunosuppressant for the treatment of {{c1::lupus}} nephritis, as well as for systemic {{c2::vasculitides}}

Cyclophosphamide can cause a congenital syndrome (remember with the mnemonic conGEAL) - congenital:

- G{{c1::rowth Restriction}}
- E{{c2::ar and facial abnormalities}}
- A{{c3::bsence of digits}}
- L{{c4::imb hypoplasia}}
Cyclophosphamide can stimulate {{c1::ADH}} secretion, resulting in a euvolemic hyponatremia
As a result of Cyclophosphamide metabolites accumulating in the {{c2::bladder}}, it is associated with {{c1::transitional cell}} carcinoma
Ifosfamide can cause a generalized reabsorptive defect in the {{c1::proximal convoluted}} tubule
Imatinib is the gold standard for patients with {{c1::Chronic Myelogenous}} Leukemia that have a(n) {{c2::Bcr-Abl}} fusion receptor tyrosine kinase
Imatinib can inhibit the receptor tyrosine kinase {{c1::c-Kit}}, making it useful for GI {{c2::Stromal Tumors (GIST)}}
Patients being treated with Imatinib can experience side effects of {{c1::fluid}} retention

Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors work by targeting downstream signaling pathways involved in growth - the most important being:

- {{c1::PI3K/Akt}} leads to increased {{c2::Bcl-2}} expression (anti-apoptosis)
- {{c2::JAK/STAT}} which wouldve led to increased cell {{c5::proliferation}}
- {{c3::Ras/MAPK}} which wouldve led to increased cell {{c6::growth}}
- {{c4::Src/FAK}} which wouldve led to increased cell {{c7::motility (invasion)}} and decreased cell {{c8::adhesion (migration)}}
{{c3::Hydroxyurea}} is an antimetabolite that inhibits pyrimidine synthesis by inhibiting {{c1::Ribonucleotide Reductase}}, thus blocking {{c2::Thymidine}} synthesis
In patients with Sickle Cell Anemia, Hydroxyurea is used prophylactically to reduce {{c1::veno-occlusive crises}}
Patients taking hydroxyurea can develop a(n) {{c1::megaloblastic}} anemia
Hydroxyurea is used in the treatment of hematological malignancies, particularly {{c1::myeloproliferative}} disorders
Irinotecan, a(n) {{c2::Topoisomerase I}} inhibitor, is used to treat {{c1::Colon}} Cancer

Platinum based antineoplastics can cause side effects which might make ya say NOPE

- N{{c1::ephrotoxicity}}
- O{{c2::totoxicity}}
- P{{c3::eripheral Neuropathy}}
- E{{c4::mesis}}
To prevent cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity, you can administer Amifostine or IV {{c2::Saline}} diuresis
Vinca Alkaloids are antineoplastics that prevent cell cycle progression at the {{c2::M}} phase
Vinca Alkaloids bind {{c2::B-Tubulin}}, inhibiting the assembly of microtubules

As two classes of antineoplastic agents that modulate microtubule structure, the distinction lies in that vinca-alkaloids prevent microtubule {{c1::assembly}} whereas taxanes prevent microtubule {{c1::disassembly}}
Vincristine can cause a(n) {{c1::peripheral sensory}} neuropathy
Taxanes (-taxel) are antineoplastics that prevent cell cycle progression at the {{c1::M}}-Phase
Taxanes work by preventing the {{c1::disassembly}} of microtubules
Taxanes can cause a peripheral sensory neuropathy as well as induce {{c2::hypersensitivity}} reactions
Taxanes are used to treat for {{c1::breast}} and {{c1::ovarian}} carcinomas
Patients taking Erlotinib can get a(n) {{c1::papulopustular acneiform}} rash
The abbreviation RTK stands for {{c1::Receptor Tyrosine Kinase}}
A common side effect of all alkylating agents is {{c1::myelosuppression}}
A general rule of chemotherapeutic side effects is that they will affect all {{c1::rapidly}} dividing cells
Cyclophosphamide can target germ cells, resulting in {{c1::infertility}} and premature menopause
Because Her2/Neu is expressed on the {{c1::Heart}}, Trastuzumab can cause {{c1::Heart}} failure
The {{c1::anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)}} extends from the {{c2::lateral femoral condyle}} to the {{c3::anterior tibia}}
The {{c1::posterior cruciate ligament (PCL)}} extends from the {{c2::medial femoral condyle}} to the {{c3::posterior tibia}}
A knee exam should be performed with the patient in the {{c1::supine}} position
The {{c1::anterior drawer test}} and {{c1::lachman}} test are used to test for {{c2::ACL injury}}
The {{c2::anterior drawer}} test is performed with the knee at a(n) {{c1::90}} degree angle to test for ACL injury
A positive anterior drawer sign demonstrates increased {{c1::anterior gliding}} of the {{c1::tibia}}
The {{c2::Lachman}} test is similar to the anterior drawer test, but the knee is at a(n) {{c1::30}} degree angle
The {{c3::posterior drawer}} test is performed with the knee at a(n) {{c1::90}} degree angle to test for {{c2::PCL injury}}
A positive posterior drawer sign shows increased {{c1::posterior gliding}} of the {{c1::tibia}}
The {{c1::Valgus}} test is <u>most commonly</u> used to identify {{c2::MCL}} injury
The {{c1::Valgus}} test is performed with the knee at a(n) {{c2::30}} degree angle while a(n) {{c3::lateral}} {{c1::(valgus)}} force is applied
An abnormal {{c1::Valgus}} test shows increased {{c2::medial space widening}} of the tibia
The {{c1::Varus}} test is used to identify {{c2::LCL}} injury
The {{c1::Varus}} test is performed with the knee at a(n) {{c2::30}} degree angle while a(n) {{c3::medial}} {{c1::(varus)}} force is applied
An abnormal {{c1::Varus}} test shows increased {{c2::lateral space widening}} of the tibia
The {{c1::McMurray}} test is used to identify injury to the {{c2::meniscus (of the knee)}}

The {{c1::McMurray}} test is performed by

1) {{c2::full flexion}} of the knee
2) followed by {{c2::extension}} of the knee with {{c3::rotation of the tibia}} and pressure on the {{c3::opposite}} side of the knee you want to test
In a positive McMurray test, pain and "popping" on {{c1::external}} rotation indicates a(n) {{c2::medial}} meniscus tear
In a positive McMurray test, pain and "popping" on {{c1::internal}} rotation indicates a(n) {{c2::lateral}} meniscal tear
A positive McMurray test is characterized by {{c1::pain and "popping"}} on extension (with rotation and side of the knee pressure)
A(n) {{c1::greenstick}} fracture is a(n) {{c2::incomplete}} fracture through the width of the bone following {{c3::bending stress}}
{{c2::Greenstick}} fractures and {{c3::torus}} fractures are both common fractures in {{c1::pediatric}} populations
A(n) {{c1::torus}} fracture occurs when {{c2::axial}} force is applied to immature bone, leading to a(n) {{c3::simple buckle}} fracture of the {{c4::cortex}}
Actinomycin D (aka Dactinomycin) is an antineoplastic antibiotic that works by preventing {{c1::transcription}} through the process of DNA {{c2::intercalation}}
Dactinomycin is used to treat for numerous malignancies that affect the {{c1::pediatric}} age group
Anthracycline associated Dilated Cardiomyopathy can be prevented with {{c1::dexrazoxane}}, a(n) {{c1::iron}} chelating agent
Bleomycin is an antineoplastic antibiotic indicated for {{c1::lymphoma}} as well as cancers of the {{c2::reproductive}} system
Bleomycin can have severe effects at the lung, which over time can cause {{c2::pulmonary fibrosis}}
In the setting of lung cancer / mesothelioma, Bleomycin can be used to prevent recurrent {{c1::pleural effusions}}
Patients taking Bleomycin can experience {{c1::hyperpigmentation}} of the skin
Cytarabine and Gemcitabine are examples of {{c1::pyrimidine}} nucleoside analogs that block cell cycle progression at {{c2::S}} phase
Pyrimidine nucleoside analogs (ex Cytarabine and Gemcitabine) work by inhibiting {{c1::DNA polymerase A/B}}
Because Cytarabine targets lymphocytes, it is indicated for {{c1::leukemias}} as well as {{c2::non-Hodgkins}} Lymphoma
All antineoplastic nucleoside analogs (including cladribine, cytarabine, gemcitabine) can cause {{c1::myelo}}suppression
The {{c1::"unhappy triad"}} is a common {{c2::knee}} injury in {{c3::contact}} sports due to {{c4::lateral}} force applied to a(n) {{c5::planted}} leg
The {{c1::"unhappy triad"}} classically consists of damage to the {{c2::ACL}}, {{c3::MCL}}, and {{c4::medial meniscus* (attached to MCL)}}
Although the classic presentation for the "unhappy triad" involves {{c1::medial meniscus}} injury, the {{c1::lateral meniscus}} is more commonly injured
The "unhappy triad" presents with acute {{c1::knee pain}} and {{c2::signs of joint injury/instability}}
{{c1::Prepatellar}} bursitis is an inflammation of the {{c1::prepatellar}} bursa in front of the kneecap
Prepatellar bursitis can be caused by {{c1::repeated trauma}} or pressure from {{c2::excessive kneeling}}
{{c1::Prepatellar bursitis}} is also known as {{c2::"housemaids knee"}}
A(n) {{c1::Baker cyst}} is a collection of {{c2::synovial fluid}} in the {{c3::popliteal fossa}} in the {{c4::gastrocnemius-semimembranosus}} bursa
Baker cyst forms in the setting of {{c1::chronic degenerative or inflammatory joint}} disease
A(n) {{c3::Baker cyst}} presents with {{c1::posterior knee pain/stiffness}} and detection of a swelling/mass in the {{c2::popliteal fossa}}
The rotator cuff muscles are innervated primarily by {{c1::C5-C6::(nerve roots)}}

The rotator cuff muscles are:
1. {{c1::supraspinatus}}
2. {{c2::infraspinatus}}
3. {{c3::teres minor}}
4. {{c4::subscapularis}}
The {{c1::supraspinatus}} and {{c1::infraspinatus}} (rotator cuff muscles) are innervated by the {{c2::suprascapular (C5-C6)::roots}} nerve
The {{c1::teres minor}} (rotator cuff muscle) is innervated by the {{c2::axillary}} nerve
The {{c1::subscapularis::rotator cuff muscle}} is innervated by the {{c2::upper and lower}} {{c3::subscapular (C5-C6)}} nerves
The {{c1::supraspinatus}} {{c3::aBducts}} the arm initially (from {{c2::0 to 15}}°)
The {{c1::supraspinatus}} is the most commonly injured rotator cuff muscle, due to {{c2::trauma}} or {{c3::degeneration and impingement}} which leads to {{c4::tendinopathy or tear}}
Function of the {{c1::supraspinatus}} muscle may be assessed using the {{c2::"empty/full can"}} test
The {{c1::infraspinatus::rotator cuff muscle}} and {{c1::teres minor::rotator cuff muscle}} {{c2::laterally (external) rotate::action}} the arm
Injury to the {{c1::infraspinatus}} (rotator cuff muscle) is classically seen in {{c2::baseball pitchers}}

The {{c1::teres minor}} (rotator cuff muscle) does the following actions
- {{c2::aDducts}} the arm
- {{c2::laterally (externally) rotates}} the arm
The {{c1::subscapularis}} (rotator cuff muscle) {{c2::aDducts and medially (internally) rotates}} the arm (action)
The {{c1::supraspinatus}} abducts the arm from {{c2::0 to 15}}° and is innervated by the {{c1::suprascapular}} nerve
The {{c1::deltoid}} abducts the arm from {{c2::15}} to {{c2::100}}° and is innervated by the {{c3::axillary}} nerve
The {{c1::trapezius}} abducts the arm {{c2::>90}}° and is innervated by the {{c3::Spinal Accessory (CNXI)}} nerve
The {{c1::serratus anterior}} abducts the arm {{c2::>100}}° and is innervated by the {{c3::long thoracic}} nerve

Medial epicondylitis (aka golfers elbow) is an elbow injury that may be due to repetitive {{c2::flexion}} ({{c2::forehand}} shots) that causes tendinosis of the {{c1::pronator teres}} and {{c1::flexor carpi radialis}}

Lateral epicondylitis (aka tennis elbow) is an elbow injury that may be due to repetitive {{c1::extension}} ({{c1::backhand}} shots) that causes microtrauma of the {{c2::extensor carpi radialis brevis}} tendon at its origin

The bones of the wrist can be remembered by the mnemonic "So Long To Pinky, Here Comes The Thumb":

So: {{c1::scaphoid}}
Long: {{c2::lunate}}
To: {{c3::triquetrum}}
Pinky: {{c4::pisiform}}
Here: {{c5::hamate}}
Comes: {{c6::capitate}}
The: {{c7::trapezoid}}
Thumb: {{c7::trapezium}}
The {{c1::scaphoid}} (bone) (palpable in the {{c2::anatomic snuff box}}) is the most commonly fractured carpal bone
The {{c1::scaphoid}} (bone) is typically injured due to {{c2::a fall on an outstretched hand}}
Complications of {{c1::proximal}} scaphoid fractures include {{c2::avascular necrosis}} and {{c3::nonunion}} due to {{c4::retrograde blood supply}}
Dislocation of the {{c1::lunate}} (bone) may cause acute {{c2::carpal tunnel}} syndrome
Carpal tunnel syndrome is due to entrapment of the {{c2::median}} nerve between the {{c1::transverse carpal}} ligament and the {{c1::carpal}} bones
Nerve compression in carpal tunnel syndrome presents as {{c1::paresthesia}}, {{c2::pain}}, and {{c3::numbness}} in the distribution of the {{c4::median}} nerve
{{c1::Carpal tunnel}} syndrome leads to atrophy of the {{c2::thenar eminence}}, but spares {{c3::sensation}} because the {{c4::palmar cutaneous branch}} enters the hand external to the carpal tunnel

Carpal tunnel syndrome is associated with
- {{c1::pregnancy::reproductive circumstance}} (due to edema)
- {{c2::rheumatoid arthritis::inflammatory disorder}}
- {{c3::hypothyroidism::thyroid disorder}}
- {{c4::diabetes mellitus::endocrine disorder}}
- {{c5::acromegaly::pituitary disorder}}
- {{c6::dialysis-related amyloidosis::inflammatory disorder}}

It may also be associated with {{c7::repetitive use}}
A positive {{c1::Tinel}} sign and {{c2::Phalen}} maneuver are suggestive of {{c3::carpal tunnel}} syndrome
A positive {{c1::Tinel}} sign is when {{c2::percussion of the wrist causes tingling}}
A positive {{c1::Phalen}} maneuver is when {{c2::90 degree flexion of the wrist causes tingling}}
{{c1::Guyon canal}} syndrome is due to compression of the {{c2::ulnar}} nerve at the {{c3::wrist}} or {{c3::hand}}
Guyon canal syndrome is classically seen in {{c1::cyclists}} due to {{c1::pressure from handlebars}}

Treating an organophosphate poisoning is two fold; {{c1::Atropine}} which inhibits all subtypes of {{c1::muscarinic receptors}}, and {{c2::Pralidoxime}}, which if given early - regenerates {{c2::AChE}}

Injury to the {{c1::axillary}} nerve ({{c2::C5-C6::(nerve roots)}}) is commonly due to:

- fracture at {{c3::the surgical neck of the humerus}}
- {{c4::anterior dislocation}} of the humerus

Injury to the {{c1::axillary (C5-C6)::roots}} nerve presents as:
1. {{c2::flattened deltoid}} (appearance)
2. loss of {{c3::arm abduction at shoulder (>15°)}} (action) 
3. loss of {{c4::sensation over the deltoid muscle and lateral arm}} (sensation)
Injury to the {{c1::musculocutaneous}} nerve ({{c2::C5-C7}} (nerve roots)) is commonly due to {{c3::upper trunk compression}}

Injury to the {{c1::musculocutaneous (C5-7)::roots}} nerve presents as:
1. loss of {{c2::forearm flexion}} and {{c2::forearm supination}} (action)
2. loss of {{c3::sensation over the lateral forearm}} (sensation)

Injury to the {{c1::radial}} nerve ({{c2::C5-T1::(nerve roots)}}) can be caused by
- {{c3::midshaft}} fracture of the humerus
- compression of the {{c4::axilla}}
- "{{c5::nursemaids}} elbow"
- "{{c6::finger}}" drop
Compression of the axilla (resulting in radial nerve injury) can occur due to improper use of {{c1::crutches}} or {{c2::sleeping with an arm over a chair (aka Saturday night palsy)}}

{{c1::Radial}} nerve injury presents with:
1. {{c2::wrist drop, including loss of elbow, wrist, and finger extension}} (action)
2. {{c3::decreased grip strength (due to loss of wrist extension)}} (strength)
3. {{c4::loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand}} (sensation)

{{c2::Median}} nerve ({{c1::C5-T1::nerve roots}}) injury is commonly due to:

- {{c6::anteromedial}} {{c3::supracondylar}} fracture of the humerus ({{c3::proximal::proximal or distal?}} lesion)
- {{c4::carpal tunnel}} syndrome ({{c4::distal::proximal or distal?}} lesion)
- {{c5::wrist}} laceration ({{c5::distal::proximal or distal?}} lesion)
Special findings in a(n) {{c1::median}} nerve injury include "{{c1::Median}} Claw" ({{c3::distal lesion}}) and "{{c2::Popes blessing}}" ({{c3::proximal lesion}})

Loss of muscle action in a(n) {{c5::median}} nerve injury includes loss of:
1. {{c1::wrist flexion (weakened-ulnar nerve contributes)}}
2. {{c2::flexion of lateral fingers (2nd and 3rd digits)}}
3. {{c3::thumb opposition and thumb flexion}}
4. {{c4::lateral 2 lumbricals (2nd and 3rd digits)}}

In a(n) {{c1::median}} nerve injury, sensation is lost over the:
1. {{c2::thenar eminence}}
2. {{c3::dorsal aspects of lateral 3 1/2 fingers (with proximal lesion)}}
3. {{c4::palmar aspects of lateral 3 1/2 fingers (with proximal lesion)}}

Injury to the {{c1::ulnar}} nerve ({{c2::C8-T1}} (nerve roots)) commonly occurs due to:

- {{c3::fracture of the medial epicondyle of humerus}} {{c5::"funny bone"}} ({{c6::proximal}} lesion)

- {{c4::fractured hook of hamate}} ({{c7::distal}} lesion) (from fall on outstretched hand - "FOOSH")
A special finding in a(n) {{c1::distal ulnar}} nerve injury is "{{c2::ulnar claw}}" on {{c3::digit extension}}
The wrist will deviate {{c1::radially}} upon {{c2::flexion}} in a(n) {{c3::proximal}} {{c4::ulnar}} nerve lesion

Loss of muscle action in a(n) {{c1::ulnar}} nerve injury includes loss of:
1. {{c2::wrist flexion}}
2. {{c3::flexion of medial fingers (4th and 5th digits)}}
3. {{c4::abduction AND adduction of fingers (interossei)}}
4. {{c5::medial 2 lumbricals (4th and 5th digits)}}
In a(n) {{c1::ulnar}} nerve injury, sensation is lost over the {{c2::medial 1 1/2 fingers}}, including the {{c3::hypothenar eminence}}
Injury to the {{c1::recurrent branch of the median}} nerve ({{c2::C5-T1::nerve roots}}) is commonly due to {{c3::superficial laceration of the palm}}

Injury to the {{c4::recurrent branch of the median}} nerve results in:
1. "{{c1::ape hand / median claw}}" (appearance)
2. {{c2::loss of thenar muscles}} (action)
3. {{c3::no loss of sensation}} (sensation)
A lesion to #{{c2::1 (upper trunk injury)}} would result in {{c1:: Erb palsy ("waiters tip")}}
A lesion to #{{c2::2}} would result in {{c1::Klumpke palsy (total claw hand)}}
A lesion to the #{{c1::3 - posterior}} cord would result in {{c2::wrist drop}}, paralysis of the {{c3::deltoid}}, and impairment of {{c4::internal}} rotation of the humerus
A lesion to #{{c1::4 (long thoracic nerve injury)}} ({{c3::C5-C7::root}}) would result in {{c2::winged scapula}}
A lesion to #{{c1::5 (axillary nerve injury)}} would result in {{c2::deltoid paralysis}}
A lesion to #{{c1::6 (radial nerve injury)}} would result in "Saturday night palsy" ({{c2::wrist drop}})
A lesion to #{{c1::7 (musculocutaneous nerve injury)}} would result in {{c2::difficulty flexing elbow::muscular deficit}} and {{c2::variable loss of sensation::sensory deficit}}
A proximal lesion to #{{c1::8 (proximal median nerve injury)}} presents with {{c2::"Popes blessing"}} and a loss of sensation in the {{c1::median}} nerve distribution
A(n) {{c1::distal::Proximal or Distal?}} lesion to #{{c1::9 (distal ulnar nerve lesion)}} would result in {{c2::loss of intrinsic muscles of the hand and ulnar claw hand}}
{{c1::Erb palsy::condition}} is due to traction or tear of {{c2::the upper trunk}} ({{c2::C5-C6}} roots)

Erb palsy is commonly caused by:

- {{c1::lateral traction}} on neck during {{c1::delivery}} (in infants)
- {{c2::trauma}} (in adults)

Muscles lost in Erb palsy include:
1. {{c1::deltoid}}
2. {{c1::supraspinatus}}
3. {{c2::infraspinatus}}
4. {{c2::biceps brachii}}
Loss of the {{c1::deltoid}} and {{c1::supraspinatus}} in Erb palsy result in {{c2::aDduction}} of the arm
Loss of the {{c1::infraspinatus}} (muscle) in Erb palsy results in {{c2::medial rotation}} of the arm
Loss of the {{c1::biceps brachii}} in Erb palsy results in {{c2::extension and pronation}} of the forearm
{{c1::Klumpke palsy::condition}} is due to traction or tear of {{c2::the lower trunk}} ({{c3::C8-T1}} roots)
Klumpke palsy is commonly caused by {{c1::upward force}} on the arm during {{c1::delivery}} (in infants) or {{c2::trauma}}, such as {{c2::grabbing}} a tree branch while {{c2::falling (in adults)}}

Muscles lost in Klumpke palsy include the {{c1::intrinsic hand muscles}}:
1. {{c2::lumbricals}}
2. {{c3::interossei}}
3. {{c3::hypothenar}}
4. {{c4::thenar}}
Loss of the {{c1::lumbricals::specific muscle group}} in {{c2::Klumpke palsy}} results in {{c3::total claw hand}}
{{c1::Thoracic outlet syndrome::condition}} is due to compression of the {{c2::lower trunk}} (roots {{c2::C8-T1}}) and {{c3::subclavian}} vessels

{{c1::Thoracic outlet syndrome}} (condition) is commonly caused by:
- presence of a(n) {{c2::cervical}} rib
- {{c3::Pancoast}} tumor
- {{c4::scalene}} muscular abnormalities / hypertrophy / trauma (ex repetitive overhead arm movements)

Muscles lost in thoracic outlet syndrome include the {{c1::intrinsic hand muscles}}:
1. {{c2::lumbricals}}
2. {{c3::interossei}}
3. {{c4::thenar}}
4. {{c5::hypothenar}}

Thoracic outlet syndrome presents with:

- {{c2::atrophy of intrinsic hand muscles}} (due to loss of lower trunk nourishment)
- {{c3::ischemia and pain}} (due to artery compression)
- {{c4::edema}} (due to venous compression)
- and Klumpke Palsy (due to lower trunk compression)
{{c1::Winged scapula}} (condition) is due to a lesion of the long thoracic nerve that supplies the {{c2::serratus anterior}}

Winged scapula is commonly caused by:
- {{c1::axillary node}} dissection after {{c1::mastectomy}}
- {{c2::stab wounds}}
Winged scapula is due to loss of action of the {{c1::serratus anterior}} muscle

A long thoracic nerve lesion presents with:
#1 - inability to abduct arm above {{c1::horizontal position}}
#2 - inability to anchor {{c2::scapula}} to thoracic cage
Clawing of the hand is best seen with {{c1::<u>distal</u>::proximal or distal}} lesions of the {{c2::median}} or {{c2::ulnar}} nerves

Clawing of the hand is characterized by {{c1::<u>extension</u>::flexion/extension}} at the {{c2::MCP}} joint, {{c1::<u>flexion</u>::flexion/extension}} at the {{c2::PIP}} joint, and {{c1::<u>flexion</u>::flexion/extension}} at the {{c2::DIP}} joint
Claw hand deficits are {{c2::less::(more/less)}} pronounced in {{c1::proximal::(proximal/distal)}}  lesions
{{c1::"Ulnar claw" hand}} (distortion of the hand) is most apparent when {{c2::extending fingers or at rest}}, and is due to a(n) {{c3::distal ulnar}} nerve lesion
{{c1::"Popes blessing" hand (aka hand of benediction)}} (distortion of the hand) is most apparent when {{c2::making a fist}}, and is due to a(n) {{c3::proximal median}} nerve lesion
{{c1::"Median claw" hand}} (distortion of the hand) is most apparent when {{c2::extending fingers or at rest}}, and is due to a(n) {{c3::distal median}} nerve lesion
{{c1::"OK gesture" hand}} is most apparent when {{c2::<u>making a fist</u>}}, and is due to a(n) {{c3::<u>proximal ulnar</u>}} nerve lesion
Atrophy of the {{c1::thenar}} eminence is seen in {{c2::median}} nerve lesions, while atrophy of the {{c1::hypothenar}} eminence is seen in {{c2::ulnar}} nerve lesions

Muscles of the thenar eminence:
1. {{c1::Opponens pollicis}}
2. {{c2::Abductor pollicis brevis}}
3. {{c3::Flexor pollicis brevis}}

Muscles of the hypothenar eminence:
1. {{c1::Opponens digiti minimi}}
2. {{c2::Abductor digiti minimi}}
3. {{c3::Flexor digiti minimi brevis}}
Muscles of the {{c1::thenar}} eminence are innervated by the {{c2::median}} nerve
Muscles of the {{c1::hypothenar}} eminence are innervated by the {{c2::ulnar}} nerve
The {{c1::dorsal}} interossei {{c2::aBduct}} the fingers; the {{c1::palmar}} interossei {{c2::aDduct}} the fingers
The lumbricals {{c1::flex}} at the {{c2::MCP}} joint and {{c1::extend}} at the {{c2::PIP and DIP::2}} joints

The {{c1::iliohypogastric}} nerve ({{c2::T12-L1::nerve roots}}) provides:

- sensory innervation to the {{c3::suprapubic region}}
- motor innervation to the {{c4::transversus abdominis}} and {{c4::internal oblique}}
The iliohypogastric nerve is commonly injured due to post abdominal surgery {{c1::sutures}}
Injury to the iliohypogastric nerve often presents as burning or tingling pain at the {{c1::surgical incision site}} radiating to the inguinal and suprapubic region

The {{c1::genitofemoral}} nerve ({{c2::L1-L2::(nerve roots)}}) provides:

- sensory innervation to the {{c3::scrotum/labia majora::genital area}} and {{c3::upper anterior thigh::femoral area}}
- motor innervation to the {{c4::cremaster}}
The genitofemoral nerve is commonly injured due to laparoscopic surgeries for {{c1::inguinal hernias}} or by {{c2::retractor blades}} used in abdominal surgery
Injury to the {{c1::genitofemoral}} nerve presents as decreased sensation of {{c2::upper anterior thigh}} and an absent {{c3::cremasteric reflex}}
The {{c1::lateral femoral cutaneous}} nerve ({{c2::L2-L3}} (nerve roots)) provides sensory innervation to the {{c3::anterior and lateral thigh}} and motor innervation to the {{c4::none}}
The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is commonly injured (meralgia paresthetica) due to {{c1::tight clothing}}, {{c1::obesity}} or {{c1::pregnancy}}
Injury to the {{c1::lateral femoral cutaneous}} nerve presents as {{c2::decreased anterior and lateral thigh sensation}}

The {{c1::Obturator}} nerve ({{c2::L2-L4}} (nerve roots)) provides:
- sensory innervation to the {{c3::distal medial thigh::very specific}}
- motor innervation to the thigh {{c4::adductor}} muscles
The obturator nerve is commonly injured due to surgery of the {{c1::posterior}} pelvis using a trocar
Injury to the {{c1::obturator}} nerve presents as {{c2::decreased medial thigh sensation and adduction}}

The {{c1::femoral}} nerve ({{c2::L2-L4}} (nerve roots)) provides:
- sensory innervation to the {{c3::anterior thigh and medial leg}}
- motor innervation to the {{c4::quadriceps}}, {{c4::iliopsoas}}, {{c5::pectineus}}, and {{c5::sartorius}}
The femoral nerve is commonly injured due to {{c1::pelvic fracture}}
Injury to the {{c1::femoral}} nerve presents as decreased thigh {{c2::flexion}} and leg {{c2::extension}}

The {{c1::sciatic}} nerve ({{c2::L4-S3}} (nerve roots)) provides:

- sensory innervation to the {{c3::none}}
- motor innervation to the {{c4::semitendinosus}}, {{c4::semimembranosus}}, {{c5::biceps femoris}}, and {{c5::hamstring portion of the adductor magnus}}

The sciatic nerve is commonly injured due to:
- {{c1::a herniated disc}}
- {{c2::posterior hip dislocation}}
- {{c3::piriformis syndrome}}
The {{c1::sciatic}} nerve splits into the {{c2::common peroneal/fibular}} nerve and the {{c2::tibial}} nerve

The {{c1::common peroneal}} nerve ({{c2::L4-S2}} (nerve roots)) provides:

- sensory innervation to the {{c3::dorsum of the foot}}
- motor innervation to the {{c4::short head of the biceps femoris::proximal}}, {{c4::tibialis anterior}}, and {{c5::extensor muscles of the digits}}

The {{c1::common peroneal}} nerve is commonly injured due to

- {{c2::trauma}}
- {{c3::compression of the lateral aspect of the leg (ex Cast)}}
- a(n) {{c4::fibular neck}} fracture
Injury to the {{c1::common peroneal}} nerve presents as loss of sensation on {{c2::the dorsum of the foot}} and {{c3::foot drop::motor}}
Foot drop is characterized by a foot that is {{c1::inverted}} and {{c1::plantarflexed}} at rest
Foot drop is characterized by loss of {{c1::eversion}} and {{c1::dorsiflexion}} (movements) of the foot
Foot drop results in a "{{c1::steppage}} gait"

The {{c1::tibial}} nerve ({{c2::L4-S3::nerve roots}}) provides:
- sensory innervation to the {{c3::sole of foot}}
- motor innervation to the {{c4::triceps surae (soleus)}}, {{c4::plantaris}}, {{c5::popliteus}}, {{c5::flexor muscles of the foot}}, and {{c6::tibialis posterior}}

The tibial nerve is commonly injured due to:
- {{c1::knee}} trauma
- {{c2::Baker cyst}} (proximal lesion)
- {{c3::tarsal tunnel syndrome}} (distal lesion)

Distal tibial nerve lesions present with:

- sensory loss over the {{c1::sole}} of the foot
- weakness of {{c2::intrinsic}} muscles of the foot

The {{c1::superior gluteal}} nerve ({{c2::L4-S1::(nerve roots)}}) provides:

- sensory innervation to the {{c3::none}}
- motor innervation to the {{c4::gluteus medius}}, {{c4::gluteus minimus}}, and {{c5::tensor fascia latae}}
The superior gluteal nerve is commonly injured due to {{c1::intramuscular}} injection to the {{c1::upper medial}} gluteal region (iatrogenic)
Injury to the superior gluteal nerve presents with {{c7::trendelenburg sign}} and a gluteus medius {{c8::lurch}}
Trendelenburg sign is characterized by {{c2::tilting of the pelvis}} {{c1::contralateral}} to the lesion
Intramuscular injections in the buttocks should be given in the {{c1::anterolateral}} quadrant (specifically the {{c2::von Hochstetter}} triangle) to avoid injury to the superior gluteal nerve

The {{c1::inferior gluteal}} nerve ({{c2::L5-S2::(nerve roots)}}) provides:

- sensory innervation to the {{c3::none}}
- motor innervation to the {{c4::gluteus maximus}}
The inferior gluteal nerve is commonly injured due to {{c1::posterior hip dislocation}}
Injury to the {{c1::inferior gluteal}} nerve presents as difficulty {{c2::climbing stairs}} and {{c2::rising from a seated position}} due to {{c3::loss of hip extension}}

The {{c1::pudendal}} nerve ({{c2::S2-S4}} (nerve roots)) provides:
- sensory innervation to the {{c3::perineum}}
- motor innervation to the {{c4::external urethral}} and {{c4::anal sphincters}}

The pudendal nerve can be injured due to:

In a cervical or lumbar disc herniation, the disc typically herniates into the {{c1::vertebral canal}}, affecting the {{c2::inferior}} nerve

{{c1::T-tubules}} are extensions of plasma membrane found in {{c2::striated}} muscle
T-tubules allow for {{c1::coordinated}} contraction of muscles
A(n) {{c1::triad}} is a structure found in {{c2::skeletal}} muscle which contains 1 {{c3::T-tubule}} with 2 {{c3::terminal cisternae}}
A(n) {{c1::dyad}} is a structure found in {{c2::cardiac}} muscle which contains 1 {{c3::T-tubule}} with 1 {{c3::terminal cisterna}}

The first step of muscle contraction occurs when the {{c1::somatic motor}} neuron depolarizes, opens {{c2::Ca2+}} channels and {{c3::ACh}} is released into the motor end plate
The second step of muscle contraction occurs after {{c1::ACh}} has been released by the motor neuron and binds to {{c2::nicotinic cholinergic}} receptors, depolarizing the {{c3::muscle}} cell
In muscle contraction, after the muscle cell is depolarized, the action potential travels down the {{c1::T-tubule}} and to the {{c2::dihydropyridine receptor::long name}}
Once a(n) {{c1::conformational}} change is induced in the {{c2::dihydropyridine receptor::long name}}, it opens the {{c3::ryanodine receptor}} which releases {{c4::Ca<sup>2+</sup>}}

After the {{c1::ryanodine}} receptor is opened, the Ca2+ that is released binds to {{c2::troponin C}}. This induces a conformational change that moves {{c3::tropomyosin}} out of the myosin-binding groove on {{c4::actin}} filaments, allowing {{c5::actin-myosin}} binding
In muscle contraction, the {{c1::power stroke}} occurs when myosin binds to actin after releasing P<sub>i</sub>

During muscle contraction:
- the {{c1::H}} and {{c1::I}} bands, and distance between Z bands, are shortened
- the {{c2::A}} band remains the same length
After the power stroke in muscle contraction, binding of a new {{c1::ATP}} molecule causes {{c2::detachment}} of the {{c3::myosin head}} from the actin filament

After myosin binds a new ATP molecule in muscle contraction, hydrolysis of the new ATP molecule to ADP allows the myosin head to adopt a(n) {{c1::high-energy, "cocked"}} position, ready for a new contraction cycle
Type {{c1::I}} muscle fibers are also known as <u>slow twitch</u> muscle fibers

Fast twitch muscle fibers are {{c1::white::color}} due to {{c2::decreased}} myoglobin concentration

Fast twitch muscle fibers perform less {{c1::oxidative phosphorylation}} due to decreased {{c2::mitochondria}}
Type {{c1::II}} muscle fibers are also known as <u>fast twitch</u> muscle fibers
Type {{c1::I}} muscle fibers are increased in proportion after endurance training
Type {{c1::II}} muscle fibers are increased in proportion after <u>weight/resistance training</u> and <u>sprinting</u>

Aztreonam, a β-lactam based monobactam, prevents cross-linking by binding to {{c1::Penicillin-binding protein 3}}

Does Aztreonam have any cross-allergenicity with penicillins?

{{c1::No}}

Which anti-microbial class is Aztreonam particularly synergistic with?

{{c1::Aminoglycosides}}
Aztreonam is used only for {{c1::Gram negative Rods::gram stain and shape}}
Carbapenems work by by binding bacterial {{c1::transpeptidases}}, inhibiting cell wall synthesis
Vancomycin is antibacterial that is indicated for multi-drug resistant Gram-{{c1::positive}} bugs only
Vancomycin inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding the {{c1::D-ala-D-ala}} portion of cell wall precursors, thus preventing {{c2::transpeptidation}}
Resistance to Vancomycin is encoded via modifying the bacterias D-Ala-D-Ala subunit to {{c1::D-ala-D-lac}}
Vancomycin is especially suitable for Clostridioides difficile infections when it is prescribed {{c1::orally::IV or Orally?}}
Vancomycin causes Red Man Syndrome due to stimulating release of {{c1::Histamine}}

The following drugs are what class of antimicrobial?

{{c1::β-Lactamase Inhibitors}}

Which group of modified Penicillins does NOT need to be prescribed with β-lactamase (penicillinase) inhibitors?

{{c1::Right::Left or Right?}}

Which group of modified penicillins is especially useful for Pseudomonas and Gram Negative Rods (ex. Bacteroides)?

{{c1::Piperacillin, Ticarcillin}}

Which group of modified penicillins is associated with Hypersensitivity reactions?

{{c1::All :)}}

Which group of modified penicillins is especially associated with Acute Interstitial Nephritis (AIN)?

{{c1::Dicloxacillin, Nafcillin, Oxacillin}}

Which group of modified penicillins is associated with the following rash?

{{c1::Amoxicillin, Ampicillin, Aminopenicillins}}

{{c1::Infectious Mononucleosis (EBV infection)}}

Which has greater oral bioavailability?

{{c1::Amoxicillin::Ampicillin OR Amoxicillin?}}

H{{c7::aemophilus influenzae}}
H{{c6::elicobacter pylori}}
E{{c5::scherchia coli}}
L{{c4::isteria monocytogenes}}
P{{c3::roteus mirabilis}}
S{{c2::almonella spp.}}
S{{c1::higella spp.}}
The benzathine forms of Pencillin V/G make them {{c1::long}}-acting
Penicillins and their derivatives are {{c2::D-ala-D-ala}} structural analogs which bind and inhibit {{c1::transpeptidases}}

Does inhibition of transpeptidases directly kill bacteria?

{{c1::No}}

Which Penicillinase-resistant penicillin is commonly used to treat Staph Aureus?

{{c1::Nafcillin}}
Penicillin V/G are mostly used for Gram-{{c1::Positive}} organisms
Besides Gram + organisms, Penicillin V/G are used to treat {{c1::Neisseria meningitidis::Gram Negative organism}} and {{c2::Treponema pallidum::Spirochete organism}}

{{c1::Streptococcus agalactiae}}

Patients who have been exposed to what STD should be given prophylactic Benzathine Penicillin G

{{c1::Rheumatic Fever}}

{{c1::Type I Hypersensitivity}}

If a patient taking penicillin manifests with mild fever, myalgia or arthralagias, and the following rash, they are demonstrating what side effect?

{{c1::Hypersensitivity Vasculitis (Cutaneous Small Vessel Vasculitis)}}
Patients taking Penicillin G/V can develop a(n) {{c1::hemolytic}} anemia

Is the hemolytic anemia caused by penicillin G/V coombs positive or negative?

{{c1::Coombs positive}}

Between patients taking Ampicillin and Amoxicillin, which group has a higher risk of developing a Pseudomembranous Colitis?

In patients receiving Triple Therapy for H Pylori that have an amoxicillin allergy, what drug should replace it?

{{c1::Metronidazole}}
In pregnant women and children who have been infected with Borrelia Burgdorferi, they should receive {{c1::amoxicillin}} and {{c1::cefuroxime}}

Are penicillins bactericidal or bacteriostatic?

{{c1::Bactericidal}}

In patients with streptococcal infections who are allergic to penicillin, they should be given what class of antibiotics instead?

{{c1::Macrolides}}
Patients who are high risk for endocarditis and are undergoing surgical or dental procedures should be given {{c1::Amoxicillin}} prophylaxis

{{c1::Yes}}

What gout drug can precipitate the side effects of penicillins?

{{c1::Probenecid}}

What structural feature of Penicillins give them their activity?

{{c1::B-lactam ring}}

Which generation of Cephalosporins are Cefazolin and Cephalexin?

{{c1::1st Generation}}

To prevent post-surgical wound infections by Staph aureus, what Cephalosporin is indicated?

{{c1::Cefazolin}}

Which generation of Cephalosporins are Cefaclor, Cefoxetin, Cefuroxime?

{{c1::2nd Generation}}
All generations of Cephalosporins can be used for Gram-{{c1::positive cocci::stain and shape}}

- H{{c1::aemophilus influenzae}}
- E{{c2::nterobacter aerogenes}}
- N{{c3::eisseria spp.}}
- S{{c4::erratia marscescens}}

Which generation of Cephalosporins is Cefepime?

{{c1::4th Generation}}
Cefepime is primarily used to treat multiple drug resistant {{c1::Pseudomonas aeruginosa}}

Which generation of Cephalosporins is Ceftaroline?

{{c1::5th Generation}}

Can Cephalosporins cause the same hypersensitivity reactions as Penicillin V/G?

{{c1::Yes}}
Cephalosporins are associated with a(n) {{c1::Disulfiram like}} reaction
Cephalosporins can cause a Vitamin {{c1::K}} deficiency

Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis does Chloramphenicol inhibit?

{{c1::[C]}}
Nitrofurantoin is used to treat patients who have UTIs and are currently {{c1::pregnant}}
Nitrofurantoin is contraindicated in patients with a deficiency of the enzyme {{c1::Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase}}
Metronidazole is used to treat anaerobic infections {{c1::below}} the diaphragm

The important coverage of Metronidazole can be remembered with the mnemonic: "GET GAP on the Metro with metronidazole"

- G{{c1::iardia lamblia}}
- E{{c2::ntamoeba histolytica}}
- T{{c3::richomonas vaginalis}}

- G{{c4::ardnerella vaginalis}}
- A{{c5::naerobes}}
- {{c6::Helicobacter}} P{{c6::ylori triple therapy replacement}}
Patients taking Metronidazole can report side effects of headache as well as a(n) {{c1::metallic}} taste

Which step ([A] - [F]) of Fungal homeostasis do Echinocandins impact?

{{c1::[A]}}

Which step ([A] - [E]) of the HIV life cycle does Maraviroc target?

{{c1::[A]}}

Which step ([A] - [D]) of the viral life cycle does Oseltamivir and Zanamivir target?

{{c1::[D]}}

Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis do Aminoglycosides inhibit?

{{c1::[B]}}

What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs?

{{c1::Aminoglycosides}}

Are aminoglycosides bactericidal or bacteriostatic?

{{c1::Bactericidal}}

Can aminoglycosides be used for both aerobic and anaerobic infections?

{{c1::No}}
Besides inhibiting the formation of the initiation complex, Aminoglycosides can damage protein synthesis by causing {{c1::misreading}} of mRNA
Aminoglycosides are primarily indicated for severe Gram-{{c1::Negative Rod::Stain and Shape?}} infections
<u>Paromomycin</u> is used as a luminal agent against {{c1::parasites}} of the GI tract
Aminoglycosides are synergistic with β-lactams and Vancomycin since they increase {{c1::cell wall permeability}}

Are aminoglycosides absorbed effectively from the alimentary / GI tract?

{{c1::No}}

<u>Aminoglycosides</u> can impact the neuromuscular junction, blocking {{c1::post::pre or post?}} synaptic {{c1:: Nm}} receptors

Patients are at much greater risk of developing ototoxicity while taking Aminoglycosides if they are used with a(n) {{c1::Loop Diuretic}}
Aminoglycosides act as a teratogen by causing congenital {{c1::deafness}}

Do bacterial ribosomal inhibitors affect the human ribosome (80S)?

{{c1::No}}

Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis do Tetracyclines inhibit?

{{c1::[E]}}

Are Tetracyclines indicated for patients who are experiencing symptoms of Meningitis?

{{c1::No}}
Doxycycline is safe to use in patients with renal failure as it is {{c1::fecally}} eliminated
Patients should not consume Milk, Antacids, or Iron-containing preparations with Tetracyclines as they prevent the drugs {{c1::absorption}}
If a patient presents to you with <u>Lyme disease</u>, your first line drug is {{c1::Doxycycline}}

Tetracyclines are used to treat what cause of atypical pneumonia?

{{c1::Mycoplasma pneumoniae}}

Doxycycline and Clindamycin can be used as a treatment for what infectious skin condition

{{c1::Acne vulgaris}}
Patients taking Tetracyclines can manifest symptoms of skin sensitivity to {{c1::light}} and {{c2::GI}} distress

Tetracyclines are contraindicated in pregnancy and in children due to their ability to:
1) discolor / deposit in {{c1::teeth}}
2) inhibit {{c2::bone}} growth

Resistance to Tetracyclines occurs in two primary ways

1) Decreasing {{c1::uptake}}
2) Increasing {{c2::efflux}}
Tigecycline is a(n) {{c1::tetracycline}} derivative that is resistant to bacterial {{c2::efflux pumps}}
Tigecycline is useful for infections that have {{c1::deep}} tissue penetration
Tigecycline is primarily used for bacteria that are {{c1::multiple-drug resistant}}
Chloramphenicol prevents peptidyl bond formation by inhibiting the enzyme {{c1::peptidyltransferase}}
Chloramphenicol is hepatically metabolized by {{c1::UDP-glucuronyltransferase}}
Chloramphenicol is primarily used to treat {{c2::meningitis}} and {{c1::rocky mountain spotted}} fever
Chloramphenicol causes a dose-{{c1::dependent}} anemia and a dose-{{c1::independent}} aplastic-anemia
Chloramphenicol is contraindicated in infants as they havent developed enough {{c1::UDP-glucuronyltransferase}}
If Chloramphenicol levels build up in infants before liver enzymes have developed, this manifests with {{c1::Gray-Baby Syndrome}}
Resistance to Chloramphenicol is encoded via a plasmid-encoded {{c1::acetyltransferase}} enzyme

Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis does Clindamycin inhibit?

{{c1::[D]}}
Clindamycin prevents translocation by binding the 50S ribosome and sterically hindering {{c1::peptidyl transfer}}

Clindamycin use can unintentionally cause an overgrowth of {{c1::Clostridioides difficile}}

Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis does Linezolid inhibit?

{{c1::[A]}}

Is Linezolid bacteriostatic or bactericidal?

{{c1::Both :)}}
Linezolid is a drug of last resort used primarily for {{c1::MRSA}} and {{c2::VRE}}
Linezolid can suppress the {{c1::bone marrow}}, often manifesting with thrombocytopenia
Linezolid can cause a(n) {{c1::peripheral}} and {{c2::optic}} neuropathy

Resistance to Linezolid is developed via a point mutation of {{c1::ribosomal RNA}}

Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis do Macrolides inhibit?

{{c1::[D]}}
Macrolides prevents translocation by binding the 50S ribosome and sterically hindering {{c1::peptidyl transfer}}

What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs?

{{c1::Macrolides}}
Tetracyclines are very effective against Rickettsia and Chlamydophila because these drugs {{c1::accumulate intracellularly}}

What macrolide is used for Chlamydia (and thus for Chlamydia-Gonorrhea empirical therapy)?

{{c1::Azithromycin}}

- Patients who are {{c1::pregnant}}
- Chlamydia Trachomatis serotypes {{c2::A-C (eye drop ointment)}}, {{c2::D-K (STI)}}

- M{{c1::otility issues of the GI tract}}
- A{{c2::rrhythmia due to prolonged QT}}
- C{{c3::holestatic Hepatitis}}
- R{{c4::ash}}
- {{c5::e}}O{{c5::sinophilia}}

Azithromycin can be used as an antiprotozoal in the treatment of {{c1::Babesiosis}}
Erythromycin eye ointment is indicated as prophylaxis for {{c1::gonococcal}} conjunctivitis in the newborn

Which of the following macrolides inhibit cytochrome p450 enzymes?

{{c1::Clarithromycin, Erythromycin}}
Erythromycin is used off-label for the treatment of gastro-{{c1::paresis}}

Which step ([A] - [E]) of Bacterial Protein Synthesis does the Quinupristin-Dalfopristin (Streptogramins) combination inhibit?

{{c1::[C]}}

Which Topoisomerases do Fluoroquinolones inhibit?

{{c1::II and IV}}

{{c1::Bactericidal}}
Fluoroquinolones are indicated for treatment of Otitis {{c1::Externa}}

- nursing mothers
- children < 18 years old

Fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in the following groups due to damage to {{c1::tendons}}

- people > 60 years old
- patients taking prednisone

{{c1::[A]}}

{{c1::[B]}}

When taken during early pregnancy, Trimethoprim can cause the baby to develop {{c1::neural tube defects}}

1 - {{c1::Neisseria Meningitidis}}
2 - {{c2::Haemophilus Influenzae B}}
If a patient on Isoniazid develops arthralgias and a rash, you should suspect the patient has developed {{c1::Drug Induced Lupus}}

Which step ([A] - [F]) of Bacterial Genetics does Dapsone impact?

{{c1::[A]}}

{{c1::Both :)}}

Clofazimine is used to treat Mycobacterium {{c1::leprae}}

Which form of Leprosy is Clofazimine used to treat? Lepromatous or Tuberculoid?

{{c1::Lepromatous)}}

Echinocandins are primarily indicated for {{c1::invasive}} infections of Aspergillosis and Candida
Echinocandins cause flushing and GI upset by stimulating {{c1::Histamine}} release

What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs?

{{c1::Echinocandins}}

Which step ([A] - [F]) of Fungal homeostasis does Flucytosine impact?

{{c1::[C]}}

{{c1::[B]}}

What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs?

{{c1::Polyenes}}

Polyenes disrupt cell membrane stability by binding {{c1::
}}

Amphotericin B causes a dose-dependent / slow-accumulated Type {{c1::1}} Renal Tubular Acidosis

{{c1::No}}

Which step ([A] - [F]) of Fungal homeostasis does Terbinafine impact?

{{c1::[E]}}

{{c1::[D]}}

{{c1::Yes}}

{{c1::Flucon}}azole is used for:

- chronic suppression of cryptococcal meningitis in AIDS patients
- candidal infections of all types
{{c1::Itracon}}azole is used for systemic infections with {{c2::dimorphic}} fungi

Amphotericin B can be used for certain protozoal infections, particularly {{c1::Leishmaniasis}} and {{c2::Naegleria Fowleri}}

{{c1::gp120}}

{{c1::[B]}}

{{c1::gp41}}

What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs?

{{c1::Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NRTI)}}

{{c1::[C]}}

{{c1::Yes}}

What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs?

{{c1::Non-Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NNRTI)}}

{{c1::No}}

{{c1::Efavirenz}}

Which NNRTIs are contraindicated in pregnancy?

{{c1::Delaviridine, Efavirenz}}

{{c1::Saquinavir}}

What class of antimicrobials are the following drugs?

{{c1::Integrase Inhibitors}}

Which step ([A] - [E]) of the HIV life cycle do drugs with the infix -tegra- target?

{{c1::[D]}}

{{c1::Rhabdomyolysis}}

{{c1::Chronic}}

{{c1::Pregnant patients}}

Which step ([A] - [D]) of the viral life cycle does Ribavirin target?

{{c1::[C]}}
